Adaptations.title: Farm-Dike Establishment
Adaptations.description: Building farm-dikes with flap-gates would be a cost efficient strategy to protect farmland from rising sea levels. It is thought that in South Kalimantan over 150,000 ha of re-claimed coastal swampland, which is currently being farmed for rice and other food crops, are at risk. Farm-dikes with flap-gates have been shown to be successful in draining off excess surface and groundwater, providing flood protection, preventing salt intrusion, and controlling water quality. Each farm-dike can be used for 50 years, after which it should be replaced with a new one while the lifespan of a gate is 15 years.
Adaptations.contact_person: Akhmad R Saidy & Yusuf Azis, Faculty of Agriculture Lambung Mangkurat University and Environmental Research Centre
Adaptations.contact_adress: Kampus Unlam Simpang Empat Jalan Ahmad Yani KM36, Banjarbaru 70714, Indonesia
Adaptations.source: Economy and Environment Program For Southeast Asia, http://www.idrc.ca/eepsea/
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret option. The dikes and gates can be used during the rainy season to protect the agricultural land.
Adaptations.comments: This research focused on adaptation strategies for a 1.0-m SLR. Based on the data that SLR in this area was 15 mm per year and assuming the rate to be constant, we estimated that a 1.0-m SLR would be reached in the 66th year. Therefore, the lifespan of the project was set at 66 years.

Adaptations.query: Vaovai Village, South Coast of Upolu Island, Samoa
Adaptations.title: Coastal Resources Adaptation Project
Adaptations.description: The Vaovai Village Community Based Adaptation Project aims to reduce the vulnerability to climate change risks including storm surges and flooding through the sustainable management of its natural resources. Another aim is to build community capacity to manage coastal resources by assisting village groups to design and develop alternative income generating initiatives that reduce climate change risks while protecting natural coastal defences such as mangroves, beaches, and coral reefs. Reduce erosion from farming practices and improve tidal flushing through the removal of maladaptive coastal Infrastructure to improve the resilience of climate-threatened coastal ecosystems by reducing climate-related sedimentation risks.
Adaptations.contact_person: Andrew Crane-Droesch, UNDP-GEF Community-Based Adaptation Project
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government
Adaptations.funding_source: UNDP (CBA), Australian Agency for International Development
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration due to mangroves plantation.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. The project is also associated with upgrading the well-beings of local community through alternative means of income generation.
Adaptations.comments: The project is designed to compliment activities already implemented under Samoa’s Cyclone Emergency Recovery Program which has focused mainly on rehabilitating the mangrove and inshore environments.

Adaptations.title: Coral gardening
Adaptations.description: Restoration of coral ecosystems will reduce coastal erosion and sand loss. Restoration includes “coral gardening”, which seeks to rescue temperature tolerant and slow-growing massive corals from situations of overgrowth, extreme shallows, and severe bleaching events. The first step has been to reduce pollution stress on the corals, the community engaged in planting mangroves and improving waste management. Next steps were to plant fast-growing corals and remove the coral-eating crown of thorn starfish. The community also engaged in constructing fish-houses, stone and cement structures that serve as shelter for coral and fish and also absorbing wave energy. A decisive element was to plant the corals in large colonies to promote resistance and survival.
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr. Austin Bowden-Kerby, Project Scientist, Coral Gardens Initiative Counterpart International/Foundation for the Peoples of the South Pacific
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 14447, Suva, Fiji Islands
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Database on local coping strategies
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Foundation for the Peoples of the South Pacific International
Adaptations.executing_agent: local community, a national NGO, and a holiday resort
Adaptations.success_factors: """Staghorn"" Acropora corals worked well in sites were reefs had been destructed into shifting rubble. Porites corals were best suited for silty areas or areas with periodic freshwater runoff. Inconsiderate use of different species may have negative implications to biodiversity. Test plantings are highly recommended."
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Improvements in fish catch and stimulation of local economy
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: It has clearly improved the state of coral ecosystems locally, and has also promoted the diversification of the local economy.

Adaptations.title: Conservancy Adaptation Project with integration of advanced mapping and engineering analysis
Adaptations.description: The project development objective of the Conservancy Adaptation Project (CAP) is to reduce the vulnerability of flooding in low-lying coastal areas currently threatened by sea level rise. The CAP aims at strengthening the government’s and donor understanding of the East Demerara Water Conservancy (EDWC) system and coastal drainage patterns through the integration of advanced mapping and engineering analysis. The project also aims at implementing infrastructure investments to improve drainage performance, to strengthen the institutional capacity for managing water and floodwater levels, and to guide interventions to reduce Guyana’s vulnerability to floods.
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Agriculture
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret option.

Adaptations.title: Enhancing Coping and Adaptation Capacity of the Community to Reduce Vulnerability to Climate Change
Adaptations.description: "This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc."
Adaptations.contact_person: Francis Atul Sarker, Development Director, Caritas Bangladesh
Adaptations.contact_adress: 2, Outer Circular Road Shantibagh, Dhaka-1217 G.P.O. Box : 994, Dhaka-1000, Bangladesh
Adaptations.executing_agent: Caritas Bangladesh
Adaptations.funding_source: Caritas Australia, Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies (BCAS)
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration due to mangrove plantation.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. Approximately 250 poor and marginal families of various occupational groups are direct beneficiaries based on the set criteria of their socio-economic and livelihood conditions additionally with the community people as a whole are indirect beneficiaries, because most of the community people will also be benefited from project intervention. The direct beneficiaries will share their knowledge, technologies, and experience with the neighboring families.

Adaptations.title: Coast Protection constructing coastal structures
Adaptations.description: Construction of 142 m long coastal structures to protect Coastal Roads and lands.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 4 th Floor, New Secretariat Building, Maligawatta, Colombo 10
Adaptations.executing_agent: Coast Conservation Department, Sri Lanka
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret option. The construction of coastal erosion controls coastal erosion.

Adaptations.title: Coast Protection constructing revetment
Adaptations.description: Construction of 476 m long revetment, to protect Matara Hmbantota Highway, dwelling units and coastal lands from coastal erosion.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 4 th Floor, New Secretariat Building, Maligawatta, Colombo 10
Adaptations.executing_agent: Coast Conservation Department, Sri Lanka
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret option. The construction for revetment present soil erosion and ensure safety of the highway.

Adaptations.title: Khazan technology
Adaptations.description: The Khazan technology is based on the traditional knowledge. Low-lying coastal land, which has been reclaimed from marshy mangroves by construction of dikes, bunds and sluice gates (which regulate water movement – both inflow and outflow – during high and low tides). It is based on the principle of a tidal clock and salinity regulation. The sluice gate is strategically located depending on the contours and relief of the land. The wooden shutters open and close with the pressure of the tidal flow and thereby protect the agriculture fields from tidal effects. There are three components which are independent and need to be conserved as one Khazan ecosystem: agricultural fields, fisheries, and sluice gates.
Adaptations.contact_adress: F-9, La Marvel Colony Dona Paula, Panaji - 403004 Goa, India
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Database on local coping strategies, http://maindb.unfccc.int/public/adaptation/adaptation_casestudy.pl?id_project=159
Adaptations.executing_agent: Local community, Government
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. Promotes symbiotic relationship between the rich and poor class people through employment generation and labor sharing
Adaptations.comments: The mentioned adaptation measure(s) is not an adaptation project but traditional measure used for agriculture and aquaculture in reclaimed coastal land to deal with coastal flooding and salinity.

Adaptations.title: Adaptation to Coastal Erosion - relocation
Adaptations.description: San Fernando Bay is a densely populated area and it is a place where coastal erosion is already prevalent. Coastal erosion scale and impact are both expected to become more widespread due to climate change and sea level rise. A relocation facility for poor coastal dwellers, called the Fisherman’s Village, was constructed by the city local government. The village has 87 housing units which can be availed by fishermen. The dwelling units in the village are not immediately habitable and would require an initial outlay from the occupants for the construction of the bathroom and kitchen, and for the installation of doors and windows.
Adaptations.contact_person: Jaimie Kim E. Bayani, Moises A. Dorado and Rowena A. Dorado Department of Economics College of Economics and Management University of the Philippines Los Banos
Adaptations.contact_adress: College, Laguna 4031, Philippines
Adaptations.source: Economy and Environment Program For Southeast Asia, http://www.idrc.ca/eepsea/
Adaptations.executing_agent: Worldbank, government
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Only 20 units are reported to be occupied as of March 2008. It was found that this low number was because most of the fishermen found the cost of relocating to the facility unaffordable. The dwelling units in the village are not immediately habitable and would require an estimated Php 140,000 initial outlay from the occupants. It will also cost them about Php 700 per month, amortized over 25 years, to pay for the whole value of the house.

Adaptations.title: Adaptation to Coastal Erosion - bulkheads and revetments
Adaptations.description: The planned adaptation strategy involves the building of bulkheads and revetments complemented by bio-engineering. Revetments and vegetation are desirable adaptation measures for portions of the coast where there is recreational or docking use for the beach and it will also allow easier access to the sea. The revetments should be constructed from boulders and concrete. Bulkheads, on the other hand, are upright structures that form a wall. These are recommended only in limited portions of the coast due to their negative impacts leading to undesirable changes in the beach and due to their prohibitive cost.
Adaptations.contact_person: Jaimie Kim E. Bayani, Moises A. Dorado and Rowena A. Dorado Department of Economics College of Economics and Management University of the Philippines Los Banos
Adaptations.contact_adress: College, Laguna 4031, Philippines
Adaptations.source: Economy and Environment Program For Southeast Asia, http://www.idrc.ca/eepsea/
Adaptations.executing_agent: government

Adaptations.title: Community-based Afforestation
Adaptations.description: The project based on four parts: Community-based adaptation interventions, Capacity building, Policy analysis and Learning. As first a climate-resilient and community-based coastal afforestation measure (6,700 ha and 1,000 km of coastal afforestation, 12,200 people trained) and a warning communications for Extreme Climate Events will be implemented. Climate Risk Reduction Measures incorporated into Coastal Area Management Frameworks, which includes training of National Planners and Policymakers on Climate -Resilient Coastal Development and District Officials in Facilitating Community-based Adaptation. Furthermore a Community Awareness Campaign and a coordination mechanism for Climate-Resilient Policy Development and Coastal Planning will be established. Last part is a knowledge-transfer with Other Regions and Countries Facing Climate-Induced Coastal Hazards.
Adaptations.contact_person: Gernot Laganda Regional Technical Advisor UNDP/GEF (through Bo Lim, Principal Technical Advisor, Climate Change Adaptation)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government, Local community
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration due to afforestation program.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. The project is also associated with livelihood resilience and integrated coastal management.

Adaptations.title: Implementing NAPA Priority Interventions to Build Resilience in Coastal Zones (Pilot measures part)
Adaptations.description: "The following measures are part of the ""Implementing NAPA priority interventions to build resilience in the most vulnerable coastal zones in Djibouti"". Environmental resilience restored in degraded watersheds to reduce floods from sea water intrusion and intense rains. This will be done through replanting of vegetation and identifying natural groundwater infiltration zones. Also planned is a Mangrove rehabilitation in the north to reduce coastal erosion/ floods from sea-level rise. To reduce pressure on mangrove harvesting put in place (cooking efficiency, enhanced community management of fuel wood, and ecotourism and fishing development around mangroves for incentivization). Furthermore small sand banks to control sea water intrusion in Damerjog will be implemented."
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government, Ministry of Natural Resources (MUHEAT)
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration due to restoration of Mangroves
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. Watershed management, ecotourism, fishing development and mangroves restoration helps uplifting socio-economic condition of local community.

Adaptations.title: Implementing NAPA Priority Interventions to Build Resilience in Coastal Zones (Planning, Policy & Prediction part)
Adaptations.description: "The following measures are part of the ""Implementing NAPA priority interventions to build resilience in the most vulnerable coastal zones in Djibouti"". Long-term vulnerability reduction plan for Khor Angar/ Damerjog approved at district level. It aims to generate a detailed synthesis of vulnerability of coastal water resources in context of climate change and to build up policy implications/ guidelines document, including revised standards or norms for sustainable coastal resource extraction, including water. Necessary institutional and legal reforms put in place. Furthermore Climate disaster prediction and prevention (Sea-level rise impact monitoring system) will be created for decision making and necessary training of communities/staff on climate change adaptation and ICZM will be established."
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. Study on capacity building, integrated coastal zone management and water management helps to provide basic policy framework for natural resource management to the government.

Adaptations.title: Enhancing Resilience of Vulnerable Coastal Areas to Climate Change Risks
Adaptations.description: "The following demonstration measures are part of the ""Enhancing Resilience to Climate Change Impacts in Coastal Liberia"". An environmentally-friendly and cost-effective breakwater system for Monrovia coastal area will be implemented. Furthermore soft systems to reduce beach erosion induced by SLR will be implemented in selected coastal areas and Mangroves systems and coastal natural ""buffer zones"" will be restored and maintained to withstand climate-induced pressures. The main Project also creates a Master Plan for urban coastal cities (Monrovia and Buchanan), zoning regulations and land-use plans. Also an early warning system for informing national planners and coastal communities on climate change-related coastal risks will be established."
Adaptations.contact_person: Tom Twining-Ward, Regional Technical Advisor, UNDP/GEF (through Bo Lim, Principal Technical Advisor, Climate Change Adaptation)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration due to restoration of Mangroves
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. Capacity building of local community and socio-economic sectors helps improving well-beings of local community.

Adaptations.title: Implementation of pilot adaptation measures in selected wetlands highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change
Adaptations.description: "As part of the ""Adaptation to Climate Change Impacts on the Coastal Wetlands in the Gulf of Mexico through Improved Water Resource Management Project"" several pilot adaptation measures in selected areas will be implemented. To address the impacts of an expected increase in the frequency of more intense hurricanes, the project would: (i) increasing the extension of the protected area status for wetlands, implementing wetlands conservation strategies; (ii) building protection barriers, strengthening river beds and the cleaning river mouths; (iii) improving existing health services anticipating CC impacts and conducting biological control of diseases; (iv) improving infrastructure (embankments); and (v) modification of building norms, application of land use plans. Furthermore buffer zones and of biological corridors between vulnerable wetlands an early warning systems based on hydro-meteorological models will be established. Expansion of civil protection system and restitution of vulnerable ecosystems through conservation, reforestation and restoration of wetlands are also planed. "
Adaptations.contact_person: Jocelyne Albert Sr. GEF Regional Coordinator Latin America and the Caribbean, World Bank
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration and emission reduction due to extension of the protected area status for wetlands and implementing wetlands conservation strategies.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option. Conservation of wetlands in combination of improving heath services and infrastructure helps in improving well-beings of the local people.

Adaptations.title: Increasing Resilience of Coastal areas and Community Settlements to Climate Change
Adaptations.description: The project will implement effective community based adaptation measures in coastal areas that reduce vulnerability and improve adaptive capacity to climate change and sea level rise. The project will use demonstration measures aligned with local conditions, which will encompass community-based systems for the management of protective ecosystems, sustainable use of climate-sensitive natural resources and diversification of vulnerable livelihoods. Envisaged demonstration projects will focus on opportunities for community-based afforestation, mangrove regeneration and plantation management, erosion prevention and participative protection of coastal sediment barriers, reduction of man-made stresses on coral reefs and protective ecosystems, diversification of crops and agricultural practices, optimization of freshwater and irrigation management, and improved information flows in climate information and early warning systems. The project will also enable a strategic revision of national and sub-national policies and programs to incorporate climate change risk considerations and adaptation strategies into financial decision processes.
Adaptations.contact_person: Gernot Laganda UNDP/GEF Regional Technical Advisor (through Bo Lim, Principal Technical Advisor)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government, Local community
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration due to afforestation, mangrove regeneration and plantation management.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option.Community based adaptation helps in capacity building of local community.

Adaptations.title: Mangrove planting
Adaptations.description:
"The mangroves planted by the Red Cross since 1994 protect 110 kilometers of the 3,000-kilometre sea dyke system that runs up and down Viet Nam’s coastline. They plant four different species, which reach a height of 1.5m after three years. The plants stabilized the dyke system and protect Viet Nam’s coastal inhabitants from the ravages of typhoons and storms and future sea level rise.
The planning and protection of 12,000 hectares of mangroves has cost around US$ 1.1 million, but has helped reduce the cost of dyke maintenance by US$ 7.3 million per year."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 82, Nguyen Du Street, Hanoï
Adaptations.source: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, http://www.ifrc.org/docs/news/02/061902/
Adaptations.executing_agent: Viet Nam Red Cross
Adaptations.funding_source: Viet Nam Red Cross, Japanese Red Cross, Danish Red Cross
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, through carbon sequestration by the mangroves.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: reduce the cost of dyke maintenance by US$ 7.3 million per year
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: In lives spared, one need only look to the dividend reaped during typhoon Wukong in October 2000. This typhoon pummeled three northern provinces, but left no damage to the dykes behind regenerated mangroves, and no deaths inland of the protected dykes. In the past, waves would breach the coastal dykes and flood the land of poor coastal families.

Adaptations.title: Technical advice to adapt SLR
Adaptations.description: "The Project improves local and decentralized-level capacity to assess and understand climate change related sea-levelrise (SLR) and to perform coastal vulnerability assessments, as well as information and analytical tools to undertake participatory adaptation planning. Furthermore the project will demonstrate innovative and integrated approaches to coastal zone and river basin management in order to achieve a reduction in vulnerability among coastal communities and ecoystems, as well as to inform future policy development. Pilots will address shifting of shallow wells affected by inundation of salt water; afforestation/reforestation of mangroves in Bagamoyo will also be undertaken as a means to restore key buffer areas, and rehabilitation of sea defence wall in Pangani Districts will also be foreseen as a tool for climate change adaptation. "
Adaptations.contact_person: Ermira Fida, Task Manager Climate Change, UNEP
Adaptations.executing_agent: UNEP, Vice Presidents Office, Environment Division
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes. Carbon sequestration due to mangroves plantation.
Adaptations.comments: These Measures are part of the GEF-project: Tanzania - Developing Core Capacity to Address Adaptation to Climate Change in Productive Coastal Zones

Adaptations.title: Incorporation of climate change risks into national level policies
Adaptations.description: The Project would take action at the national level to provide the essential capacities and strategies to advance national frameworks for incorporating climate change considerations into systems that govern land-use and coastal management practices that affect coastal ecosystems. The focus here would be on response systems that would enable stresses to be kept within the coping range of ecosystems under future climate change, thus increasing resilience and the conservation of key biodiversity. Existing policy systems regarding coastal areas would be adjusted over time to the changing conditions expected under different climate scenarios. Specific guidelines and measures would be included in these procedures to ensure that climate change scenarios are adequately addressed and that those responsible for their application and evaluation are fully trained to implement new approaches and standards. It will address as well specific activities to enhance regulations related to the National Protected Area System as a particular land planning policy with a high potential for coastal ecosystems protection from surrounding environmental stresses. For these purposes, the project will develop communication strategies aimed at reaching specific target groups whose decisions and behaviours affect coastal biodiversity and/or who are affected by climate change. Among them, policy and decision makers, natural resource managers, the media, and stakeholders from key economic sectors related to coastal resources (e.g. fisheries, tourism, and agriculture).
Adaptations.contact_person: Oliver Page, Regional Technical Advisor, UNDP
Adaptations.executing_agent: UNDP, Ministerio de Vivienda, Ordenameinto Territorial y Medio Ambiente (MVOTMA)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Yes, although risk management is primarily focused on the population, the benefits will affect biodiversity as well, as the coastal ecosystems would be protected by the national strategy of risk management emphasizing climate risk.

Adaptations.title: Training and Development of a seasonal weather forecast
Adaptations.description: This project integrates climate change risks into critical decision-processes for agriculture management at the local, sub-national, and national levels. In cooperation with Meteorological Service and Ministry of Agriculture a seasonal weather forecasts will be developed and applied to help farmers, agricultural sector planners and water managers. For this reason collaborative partnerships between Meteorological Service and end users and a training-program will be established. Furthermore the project will create an economic impact assessment of the adaptation value of using climate risk information to adapt agricultural planning, so future policy will reflecting long-term adaptation priorities.
Adaptations.contact_person: Jessica Troni, Regional Technical Advisor, UNDP
Adaptations.executing_agent: UNDP, Meteorological Service, Ministry of Agriculture
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Limited human resources, financial sustainability, farmers acceptability
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: It’s a No-regret Option. These measures improve food security and environmental sustainability through a better use of natural resources.
Adaptations.comments: Impacts: Food security These Measures are part of the GEF-project: Zambia - Adaptation to the effects of drought and climate change in Agro-ecological Zone 1 and 2 in Zambia

Adaptations.title: Development of a Risk Management Strategy against SLR
Adaptations.description: "This Study from the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) is a technical cooperation to support the management of sea-level rise (SLR) in Valparaiso. The activities planned in this study are (i) compile all relevant existing information in the Municipality; (ii) evaluate the institutional and operative capacity to respond to risks; (iii) carry out a study of vulnerability to natural risks--seismic, tsunami, coastal erosion; (iv) carry out a study of vulnerability to man-made risks--fires, buildings in risk areas; (v) identify interventions that could mitigate the effects of disasters both natural and man-made; (vi) prepare a strategy for risk management for the short and medium terms; (vii) make recommendations and prepare guidelines regarding these risks for the Patrimony Master Plan of Valparaíso; (viii) prepare specific measures that could be financed by the Program of Revitalization and Development of Valparaíso (CH-L1004); and (ix) draft terms of reference for a project which could be financed by this Program. With these TC products, plans can be developed for the growth of the City, current vulnerabilities can be reduced, and future occurrences can be mitigated."
Adaptations.executing_agent: Inter-American Development Bank (IADB),
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: It is a No-regret Option. These measures will protect for SLR, but also against earthquakes. The Project generates a better protection of urban infrastructure and of people at risk.

Adaptations.title: Kalpsar Seawall Project
Adaptations.description: The Government of Gujarat planning the construction of a 34-kilometer dam across the Gulf of Khambat. It is a long-term strategy to tide over the perennial water crisis, generate electricity from tidal waves, create road transport facilities and reclaimed land. It will be completed by the year 2020. The project, when completed, will have a vast fresh water reservoir with 2,000 sq km of water, a 35 m wide dam and a tidal wave power generation house with an installed capacity of 5,880 mw. The project seeks to ease a shortage of electricity in Gujarat, while supplying water for irrigation in drought-prone areas and developing the ports along its coastline.
Adaptations.contact_person: Narmada, Water Resources, Water Supply and Kalpsar Department, Gujarat
Adaptations.source: Narmada, Water Resources, Water Supply and Kalpsar Department, Gujarat, http://guj-nwrws.gujarat.gov.in/kalpsar/default_e.htm
Adaptations.executing_agent: The Government of Gujarat, Korea Responsible Care Council (KRCC)

Adaptations.title: Waru waru
Adaptations.description:
"Waru Waru is an agricultural technique developed in South America around 300 B.C.
The project has introduced an ancient cultivation, irrigation and drainage system that made poor land productive: land with high salinity levels and poor drainage located in an area with frequent droughts and frost. The project involves the restoration of earthworks about one meter high and 10 to 15 meters wide. These are surrounded by wide, shallow canals which, when filled with water, ensure a microclimate that acts as a buffer against night-time frosts and provides moisture during droughts and drainage during the rainy season. The canals also act as barriers to keep out crawling insect pests."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av General Santa Cruz 659 Lima 11, Peru
Adaptations.executing_agent: Care Peru, local communities
Adaptations.success_factors: The amount of labour initially required to restore a waru waru can be a discouraging factor. This is why the project, during the first year, offered farmers tools and seeds as an incentive.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The practice increases the value of unused, flood-prone lands, as well as helping to reduce the damage caused by drought and frost. Experience shows that the minimum night-time temperatures reached in waru waru areas are two to three degrees centigrade higher than those of the surrounding plains. The moisture provided by the canals lowers the impact of sporadic droughts during the cycle and, in the rainy season, prevents the subsoil from becoming waterlogged by ensuring adequate drainage. Crop yields, in particular yields of potatoes and other Andean tubers, are 50% to 100% higher than the yields obtained using traditional farming techniques.
Adaptations.comments: The results of the system could be improved if crops, including pastures, were rotated on a long-term basis.

Adaptations.title: Conserving grazing and fodder lands through reforestation
Adaptations.description: The project reviving the Sukuma peoples traditional practice of conservation called ngitili - a Sukuma word meaning enclosure. The traditional practice of ngitili was used by people in response to serious fodder shortages caused by the frequent droughts typical in semi-arid areas. It provides animal fodder for animals unable to follow other animals to grazing lands. Involving the conservation of grazing and fodder lands by encouraging vegetation regeneration and tree planting, ngitili has proven to help protect the environment and improve the livelihoods of communities in the region.
Adaptations.contact_person: Edmund Barrow, IUCN Eastern Africa Regional Office
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 68200, Nairobi, Kenya
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Database on local coping strategies, http://maindb.unfccc.int/public/adaptation/adaptation_casestudy.pl?id_project=117
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Natural Resources and Tourism
Adaptations.success_factors: •Site selection: Individual ngitilis are usually established on degraded croplands and rangelands but site selection is also determined by land availability, proximity to homesteads, production potentials and ease of protection. •Responsibility: For individual ngitilis, the responsibility lies with the family heads. For communal ngitilis the responsibility lies with the group of elders. •Conservation: Once selected, degraded areas are closed off to protect them from animals for a period of five years to allow regeneration. •Management: Mapping and demarcation of village grazing and cropping areas, together with issuing title deeds, ensures the protection and management of the ngitili. •Protection: Traditional village guards are used to protect the ngitilis, and the community assemblies to formulate sanctions, laws and punishments for misuse. •Order of usage: Farmers prefer to use the communal ngitili first and save private ones until communal feed sources are exhausted. Where an individual ngitili usually covers an area of less than 5 ha (12 acres), a communal ngitili can cover up to 50 ha (124 acres). •Seasonal variations: In the wet season areas are closed off to animals in order to allow vegetation to regenerate. During the dry season, once grazing areas are depleted, the ngitili is opened bit by bit to allow animals to feed.

Adaptations.title: Jessour to collect water runoff
Adaptations.description: Building earthen dikes to collect water runoff is a widely used technique. In the mountains regions of North Africa people used the jessour, an ancient system of collecting run-off from long slopes. Farmers build earthen dams (tabias) across the valley floors to trap the run-off water and silt. Small terraces are created for growing crops and fruit trees that would normally struggle to survive in this arid climate. The Institut des Régions Aride (IRA) together with local farmers developed technologies to improve the jessour and to avoid destruction of the spillways trough heavy rain. Other improvements include the ‘buried stone pocket’ for the localized, underground irrigation of fruit trees to increase the efficiency of water use.
Adaptations.contact_person: Chris Reij, International Cooperation Centre, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam
Adaptations.contact_adress: De Boelelaan 1105, 1081 HV Amsterdam
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Database on local coping strategies, http://maindb.unfccc.int/public/adaptation/adaptation_casestudy.pl?id_project=87
Adaptations.executing_agent: Institut des Régions Arides (IRA), local farmers

Adaptations.title: Improving Agricultural Productivity through Photovoltaic Water Pumping
Adaptations.description: This project seeks to improve agricultural productivity in this increasingly drought-prone region through the implementation of a more efficient system of irrigation which uses a photo-voltaic. The project consists of the installation of an electric water pump powered by solar photovoltaic energy and connected to a drip-irrigation system on a family farm. Furthermore the project aims: Capacity building of small farmers to improve agricultural productivity using water-efficient and affordable technologies that are easy to implement and to use renewable energy for irrigation and to use water efficiently, to actively engage the local community, especially women, in the use of this technology, through participatory processes and to develop a regional replication and dissemination strategy.
Adaptations.contact_person: Thais Corral, Director of Partnerships and Implementation Strategies, REDEH - Network for Human Development
Adaptations.contact_adress: Rua Álvaro Alvim, 21/16º andar, Centro - CEP 20031-010, Rio de Janeiro - RJ - Brasil
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO , local communities
Adaptations.success_factors: Such pilot solutions needed to be carefully analyzed and their weak points identified to be monitored for a period of time long enough to understand their overall performance. Such performance needed also to be described and monitored through accurate social, economical, technological and environmental factors and indicators.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Emission reduction through photo voltaic power generation.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win-option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Replication is a key aspect of the project as it was conceived as a model to understand those factors that allow self-replication of technological systems within the semi-arid region. Since the beginning, the project put at its core the sustainability of small-scale technological solutions carried out in communities that have a low degree of mechanization. The challenge was to have a consistent process to be able to promote mutual learnings and understand how best to share the information among the project partners. Depending on the type of irrigation system and water pump, the payback time for the system showed to be in the order of 1.5 to 6 years.
Adaptations.comments: The financing is based on a revolving fund, where each farmer that meet specific eligibility criteria is entitled to receive up to 4,000 Euros to buy technology equipments. The peculiarity of this revolving fund is that the farmer does not receive cash but technology through a direct commercialization channel with some technology providers in Brazil for irrigation equipments.

Adaptations.title: Land and Water Optimization Project
Adaptations.description: The project aim is to reduce land-based sources of pollution discharging in the Mediterranean Sea, to optimize the use of Tunisia’s water resources and contribute to the reduction of land degradation and climate vulnerability of key productive sectors in arid agricultural lands. One component is a study of wastewater reuse, for that technical, economical and environmental feasibility studies on water reuse investments, including estimation of investing and operating costs for different scenarios. Improve Soil and Water Conservation, Sustainable Management and Use, for example increase in volume of treated wastewater use. Better and more frequent use of drought resistant species/plants/crops
Adaptations.contact_person: Kanta Kumari Rigaud, Project Contact Person, Worldbank
Adaptations.executing_agent: IBRD - The World Bank, Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources (MARH), National Sewerage and Sanitation Agency (ONAS), General Directorate of Rural Engineering (DGGRE) and General Directorate of Environment and Quality of Life (DGEQV)
Adaptations.funding_source: Global Environment Facility (GEF) – GEF Trust Fund

Adaptations.title: Reducing Disaster Risks from Wildfire Hazards Associated with Climate Change
Adaptations.description: The project will counter the increased probability of fires from climate change. This will entail institutional strengthening, capacity building, and awareness raising, under a programmatic approach to climate change sensitive fire management. The adaptation strategy around integrated fire management will be implemented in selected pilot areas identified to be at particularly high risk due to climate change. The project will in particular address long term adaptation to climate change needs in the context of forecasting and early warning systems, and strengthening and establishing national and regional centers and information networks for rapid response to extreme weather related events. Improved fire management will have important adaptation benefits.
Adaptations.executing_agent: UNDP - United Nations Development Programme

Adaptations.title: Agroforestry
Adaptations.description: "The wide range of traditional agroforestry (planting crops among trees) practices in Sri Lanka offers a promising solution to the ever-declining per capita availability of agricultural land and protects the land from degradation. On most coconut estates a variety of different crops are cultivated including food crops, spices and condiments, and cash crops. On some plantations pasture grass is grown in between coconut trees to allow cattle to graze. Bananas, black pepper, coffee, ginger, turmeric, betel, vegetables and pineapple are the preferred species because they can grow in shade and provide a good income. The most common crop mixtures in mature coconut plantations are coffee and banana; coffee and pineapple; pineapple and papaya; and banana, coffee and cacao. When farmers intercrop, the coconut trees benefit from the manure and fertilizers, weeds are eliminated, and the land is more productive."
Adaptations.contact_person: Prof. R. Ulluwishewa, Sri Lanka Resource Centre for Indigenous Knowledge (SLARCIK)
Adaptations.contact_adress: University of Sri Jayewardenapura, Geography Unit, Nugegoda, Sri Lanka
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Database on local coping strategies, http://maindb.unfccc.int/public/adaptation/adaptation_casestudy.pl?id_project=29
Adaptations.executing_agent: Sri Lanka Resource Centre for Indigenous Knowledge (SLARCIK)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The development of agroforestry in Sri Lanka has a three-pronged effect: it increases the living standards of the rural poor, improves environmental conditions, and safeguards the ecosystems of the natural forest with their valuable genetic resources.

Adaptations.title: Small-scale Rooibos tea farmers
Adaptations.description: The direct beneficiaries of the project will be the farmers’ households in the Suid Bokkeveld community. By researching (using scientific studies that will include the participation of the small-scale farmers) the success of wild rooibos tea propagation (this strain of the rooibos species is more weather-hardy and resistant to adverse climatic conditions) as either a supplement or replacement of the current cultivated variety, in the context of changing climatic conditions, the farmers will enhance their adaptive capacity by having insight and informed knowledge bases in order to make further ‘adaptive’ livelihood decisions that will include improved natural resource management.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 138 Waterkant Street, Green Point, Cape Town, 8003 South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: Indigo DC, Environmental monitoring group
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The communities will benefit of the transfer of the technical knowledge of cultivating wild Rooibos as it will enhance their livelihoods and in turn enhance their adaptive capacity to deal with the negative impacts of climate change. It also has a strong focus on women

Adaptations.title: Maize initiative
Adaptations.description: Maize is an important staple in Southern Africa. Droughts and poor soil often result in bad harvests or total harvest failure. The Seed Initiative for Maize in Southern Africa conducts research into drought-resistant varieties of maize which can generate bigger harvests than conventional varieties, even in less fertile soil, thus contributing to food security. At the same time, the project cooperates with government and private-sector players in the maize sector so as to foster production and the seed trade (also for small-scale producers).
Adaptations.contact_adress: Freiburgstrasse 130, 3003 Berne
Adaptations.source: SDC - Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, http://www.sdc.admin.ch/en/Home/Projects/Maize_initiative
Adaptations.executing_agent: CIMMYT (Centro Internacional de Mejoramiento de Maíz y Trigo – International Maize and Wheat Improvement Centre, Mexico), SADC - Southern African Development Community
Adaptations.funding_source: SDC - Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation

Adaptations.title: Johads - Rainwater harvesting
Adaptations.description: To harvest the monsoon waters, people in Rajasthan construct small earthen check dams (johads) across seasonally flooded gullies (nalas) which also improve percolation and groundwater recharge. Starting 1984, the last sixteen years have seen the revival of some 3000 johads spread across more than 650 villages in Alwar district. This has resulted in a general rise of the groundwater level by almost 6 m and a 33% increase in the forest cover in the area. Five rivers that used to go dry immediately following the monsoon have now become perennial.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 34/46 Kiran Path Mansarover, Jaipur 302020 Rajasthan, India
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Database on local coping strategies, http://maindb.unfccc.int/public/adaptation/adaptation_casestudy.pl?id_project=41
Adaptations.executing_agent: Tarun Bharat Sangh
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The construction of these johads not only allow for the harvesting of rain water, but they also increase groundwater recharge and stabilize the runoff levels of rivers. Also human activities benefit from these structures as crop yields may increase and also the area covered by forests.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: For the last 16 years the construction of these small scale infrastructures has spread all over the region with very positive results.

Adaptations.title: National strategy for agriculture, ecosystems and water resources
Adaptations.description: "The final product of the project is a National Adaptation Strategy containing detailed proposals and criteria for the authorities on adaptation to climate change and the specific measures which must now be implemented. Some of the measures the Strategy recommends are appointment of an interministerial National Climate Council to improve the coordination of measures for adaptation to climate change; promotion of interdisciplinary climate research and development of appropriate training programmes; broader-based collection of climate and water resource data to improve the quality of forecasting; better enforcement of existing water and agricultural ordinances; introduction of insurance services for climate-related damage in agriculture, with a particular focus on small farmers; assistance with the restructuring of farms that are affected by climate change; and development of a climate label for agricultural products which are particularly resilient to the impacts of climate change."
Adaptations.contact_adress: B.P. 753 10 80 Tunis-CEDEX, Tunisie
Adaptations.executing_agent: GTZ, Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources, General Directorate of Agricultural Studies and Development

Adaptations.title: Sustainable management of soil and water on hillsides (Masal)
Adaptations.description: Sustainable valuation of natural resources in rural areas with focus on integrated Water Resources Management, related to rural development and adaptation to climate change. The approach is based on consultation and leadership of municipalities and social organizations, promoting local mobilization for technological and institutional innovation.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Oswaldo Baca - J 12. Urb. Magisterio 1era Etapa - Cusco, Perú
Adaptations.source: "Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions, http://www.cooperacion-suiza.admin.ch/peru/es/Pagina_principal/Proyectos/Proyecto_MASAL; http://www.masal.org.pe/"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Intercooperation and Ministry of Agriculture (MINAG)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"1,700 families have improved their income by innovating their production systems, through Peasants Competitions.
330 leaders and women leaders have been trained and now assume leadership roles in local organizations.
10 concerted projects have been funded (up to 30%) by rural municipalities to improve management of natural resources in poor areas of Cusco and Apurimac.
5 Associations (24 municipalities) have been created for the sustainable management of natural resources."
Adaptations.comments: The project is located in Apurímac and Cusco in Perú.

Adaptations.title: Camellones or Waru Waru Rehabilitation and Production
Adaptations.description: Reevaluate the technology of pre-hispanic camellones (agricultural infrastructure formed by embankments from 4 to 10 feet wide and from 10 to 120 long, and connected with alternating channels serving the same catchment, adduction and water drainages functions), with the aim of contributing to improve food security and the income of 6 400 poor families in 80 rural communities. Communities suffered food deficits for up to 6 months in a year because of crop losses by abrupt climate changes and the reduction of cultivated areas on slopes.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av General Santa Cruz 659. San Isidro - Lima, Perú
Adaptations.executing_agent: CARE Perú
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "Reduction of food deficits from six to two months in the year, in some cases it allowed to obtain a surplus for sell in the market, 1.350 ha / rehabilitated waru waru: improving agricultural production levels based on the revaluation of agrobiodiversity in Andean crops; participation of 102 rural communities, the same that have been established in eight second-level organizations (NSOs) to transcend self-management and linkage with the market. Applied and participatory research approach is strengthened: Participatory Development of Appropriate Technologies (DPTA). "

Adaptations.title: Capacity building of poor rural communities to reduce their vulnerability to drought and desertification problems
Adaptations.description: "Capacity building of poor rural producers and their organizations to address desertification and drought, through primary and secondary data collection for the development of an inventory of strategies and technologies; consultation processes on traditional technologies with local stakeholders; training of small rural producers to address desertification and drought; implementation of a Geographic Information System (GIS); and support the construction of a participatory processes for a Risk Management Regional Plan with emphasis on desertification and drought."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av Jorge Chávez 275 - Miraflores - Lima, Perú
Adaptations.source: Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions, http://www.lamolina.edu.pe/zonasaridas/za11/pdfs/ZA11%2000%20art12.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: Practical Solutions - ITDG, regional government of Apurimac, National Natural Resources Institute (Inrena) and Board of Irrigation Users

Adaptations.title: Modeling scenarios for water availability in the Chancay-Lambayeque River Basin
Adaptations.description: It models changes of water availability in the surface of the Chancay-Lambayeque River Basin, during the period 2009-2046. The objective is to assess the possible impacts that climate change provoke in the surface water supply from the basin. It takes as an input variable the regionalized scenarios of precipitation and temperature for the period 2013- 2045 of the Japanese model CCSR / NIES.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Jirón Cahuide 785, Lima - Lima, Perú
Adaptations.executing_agent: National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru (SENAMHI)

Adaptations.title: Determination of present and future water availability of Rímac, Santa and Mantaro Rivers Basins
Adaptations.description: Determine the current and future water availability in the basins of the rivers Santa, Rimac and Mantaro for energy purposes. Perform a water characterization of the basins and get to know the availability of surface water associated with the occurrence of future climate change scenarios developed by the National Center for Atmospheric Research (ENCAR).
Adaptations.contact_adress: Jirón Cahuide 785, Lima - Lima, Perú
Adaptations.executing_agent: National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru (SENAMHI)

Adaptations.title: Determination of water availability in watersheds with glaciers
Adaptations.description: Determine water availability and its relation to climate change in watersheds with glaciers. Recognition and field evaluation to know the contribution that is causing the retreat of glaciers in the Cordillera Blanca and of the mountains Salkantay and Coropuna. Hydrological characterization of present and future water availability for 2020 and 2030.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Jirón Cahuide 785, Lima - Lima, Perú
Adaptations.executing_agent: National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru (SENAMHI)

Adaptations.title: Hydrological impact of El Niño / La Niña - Topara, San Juan, Pisco, Ica and Grande Rivers Basin
Adaptations.description: Assess the spatial and temporal behavior of rainfall in the Topara, San Juan, Pisco, Ica and Grande Rivers Basins and its response to the occurrence of ENSO events and LNOS.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Jr. Cahuide 785, 3er piso - Jesús María, Lima, Perú
Adaptations.executing_agent: National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru (SENAMHI)

Adaptations.title: Adaptation to Climate Change through sustainable management in watersheds
Adaptations.description: The project aims to help farmers in selected villages to adapt to changed water availability by small scale watershed improvements (in order to increase the infiltration rate) and awareness raising.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ) GmbH, Postfach 5180, 65726 Eschborn, Germany
Adaptations.executing_agent: GTZ, UNFCCC Focal Point, ministry of environment Benin, national NAPA commission, municipalities
Adaptations.success_factors: Market development of cultivated crops
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Extended droughts
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: binding of carbon in sustainable agriculture (small scale)

Adaptations.title: Reconstruction and rehabilitation of social infrastructure with regard to desaster precaution in districts affected by natural desasters
Adaptations.description: reconstruction of social infrastructure (needed druing crisis management such as health and drinking water, bat also schools) and capacity development in catastrophy development
Adaptations.contact_adress: Rua Companhia de Moçambique, No. 2230, Prédio Megaza 2º. Andar direito, CP 1462, Beira , República de Moçambique
Adaptations.executing_agent: german technical cooperation, provincial administrations in health and in schools, national authority incivil protection
Adaptations.success_factors: Structures after implementation
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win

Adaptations.title: Small-scale wind power
Adaptations.description: Small-scale wind power reduces water resource stress and contributes to climate change adaptation in two ways: (1) by providing energy for water pumping and (2) by reducing fuel wood consumption in households whose livelihood opportunities have expanded with electrification. Maintenance is done by local staff and spare parts are supplied by the machine manufacturer. It is based on a design by the Intermediate Technology Development Group, ITDG. The machine is a 300 watt multi-blade unit with a six meter rotor diameter. It cuts in at wind speed as low as one meter per second and is usually coupled to a lift pump or a bucket pump. Water from the pump is stored in a reservoir. The project is located in Temaruru, Mashonaland East.
Adaptations.contact_person: Southern Centre for Energy and Environment, Norbert Nziramasanga
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 107, Harare, Zimbabwe
Adaptations.executing_agent: ZERO (regional environment organization)
Adaptations.success_factors: Define a wind map and develop test schemes at sites showing high potential is the fundamental of success. Furthermore the project should be integrated into the rural development program.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: No wind no power.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Emission reductions through windmills. In this study all windmills together generate about 600 kWh per month. A diesel genset would emit about 640 kg of CO2 in supplying 600 kWh of electricity.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: It is a win-win option. The project reduces emissions, generates incomes and improves living conditions of rural people.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project was not conceived as a climate change project, however, it has displaced the use of kerosene for lighting and refrigeration at the site. In it’s current form the project supplies energy to a few shops and a rural health center. There is potential to expand the project to include energy supply for income generation projects.
Adaptations.comments: The wind machine used in this project was developed as part of the project.Local and foreign experts used local technical skills to construct the machines. The technology works well and is now exported to the U.S.

Adaptations.title: Adaptation of Water Management
Adaptations.description: The initial objective of the effort was to evaluate current and future vulnerability of water resources to climate change. Three case study reports were produced that summarized current and future livelihood systems and hydrology in each of the 5 ecological zones. To assess future vulnerability, the researchers developed a scenario-driven dataset for a water balance model using the WEAP water planning model for each case study area. The second objective was to identify a comprehensive set of adaptation strategies that address water scarcity and build resiliency in vulnerable communities. Based on the outcome of these adaptation strategy scenarios, recommendations for national policies are being formulated for national adaptation to water stress.
Adaptations.contact_person: Mr. Anwar Noaman, Head of Climate Change Unit, Environment Protection Authority
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 19719, Sana’a, Yemen
Adaptations.executing_agent: Water and Environmental Center Sanaa University
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Nothing of both, but the Project creates further possible measures.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Nothing of both, but the Project creates further possible measures.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: A number of adaptation strategies were developed through stakeholder consultations. Six different adaptation strategies were modeled as scenarios in WEAP over the period 2008-2025. (Table 1. Results of Scenario analyses - http://www.nlcap.net/fileadmin/NCAP/Countries/Yemen/032135.0607xx.YEM.CON-01.Output_3.doc)

Adaptations.title: The Radio and Internet Project (RANET)
Adaptations.description: The Radio and Internet Project (RANET) enhanced collection and dissemination of early warning and climate information at the local level. Using a computer connected to the internet, the project provided timely information on climate and other development information for the people in the district. While the Internet is not an option in many parts of rural Africa, RANET uses wind-up or solar powered radios to deliver satellite radio broadcasts to remote areas. Not only does RANET provide access to weather and climate information, it also enables remote communities to share information with Africans in other regions. The information enabled the local population to prepare for potential droughts and to take the climate forecast into account when making decisions.
Adaptations.contact_person: Department of Meteorology Ministry of Water, Lands and Environment
Adaptations.contact_adress: 10th floor, Postel Building Clement Hill Rd P. O. Box 7025 Kampala, Uganda
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Meteorology, World Vision
Adaptations.funding_source: Meteo-France, the UK Met Office, the National Meteorological Service of Spain, the French Embassy of Niger, the United States Embassy of Niger, FAO, UNDP, SNV
Adaptations.success_factors: Needed equipment is Computer, World Space Modem, World Space Receiver and Antenna. Existing structures could be helpful to disseminate the information.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Specific local forecast are very difficult and requires local maximum temperatures and wind speeds. Meteorologists should take efforts to improve on the farmer’s knowledge to build their capacity to make local specific forecasts.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The practice succeeded in collecting and disseminating climate information to local farming communities in a timely manner. In the case of RANET project, the local communities in 17 parishes of Nakasongola district benefited from the practice. This was possible because of the easy access to weather information through the Internet, and the established local structures for interpretation and dissemination of the information. The timely dissemination of information enabled the local population to improve the state of drought preparedness and food security.
Adaptations.comments: RANET hopes to equip villagers with the technology and skills to send e-mails to its upload site, which will then be re-broadcast as text messages to mobile devices. Similar efforts are planned in South and Southeast Asia.

Adaptations.title: Rainfall collection works and water harvesting
Adaptations.description: The following measure is part of the “Mainstreaming Climate Change Adaptation in Irrigated Agriculture Project” by the World Bank. It is located in the Huang-Huai-Hai River Basin, concerned provinces are Hebai, Jiangsu, Anhui, Shandong, Henan and Ningxia. The project identifies specific climate change adaptation measures and techniques, which are demonstrate at selected project sites. The construction of field rainfall collection and water harvesting works to increase storage and retention of surface runoff and rainfall and mitigate rainfall deficits or insufficient irrigation water resources, especially in dry seasons. Furthermore it helps to compensate for increasingly unbalanced natural rainfall between seasons expected as a result of climate change.
Adaptations.contact_person: Ms. Qun Li, Agric. Off., Worldbank
Adaptations.contact_adress: The World Bank 1818 H Street, NW Washington, DC 20433 USA
Adaptations.executing_agent: State Office for Comprehensive Agricultural Development (China)
Adaptations.funding_source: Global Environment Facility (GEF)/The Special Climate Change Fund (SCCF)
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change.
Adaptations.comments: More information about the main project you can found here: http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/343

Adaptations.query: Yapacani, Ichilo province, Santa Cruz, Bolivia
Adaptations.title: Mitigating the effects of drought on farms for food security
Adaptations.description: Reduce the effects of drought and climate change by promoting the implementation and incorporation of micro-irrigation techniques in crop management, to ensure agricultural production, household food security, and eventually for marketing to local markets
Adaptations.contact_adress: Campo Colpa Street Nº 2781, Barrio Petrolero Sur, city of Santa Cruz - Bolivia
Adaptations.source: Project Report - National Climate Change Program 2007, www.mmaya.gob.bo
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Ministry of Development Planning - National Climate Change Program
Adaptations.executing_agent: Rural Agricultural Promotion Center NGO (CEPAC)
Adaptations.success_factors: Qualified families do not make efficient use of water, soil conservation and micro-irrigation.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: None
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Reducing the effects of drought by applying and incorporating techniques of irrigation in crops management in fields of 81 families.
Adaptations.comments: Agronomic evaluation and verification of crop yield increase with the techniques employed between 15-45% higher.

Adaptations.title: Alternative management and exploitation of natural resources to reduce the effects of climate change on farming systems
Adaptations.description: Improving production systems of rural families with the introduction of irrigation and agro-ecological technologies for adaptation to climate change, to strengthen food security and markets supply.
Adaptations.contact_adress: A street of Arenales Nº 0-101, City of Cochabamba - Bolivia
Adaptations.source: Project Report 2006/2007 Five-Year Plan, National Climate Change Program, www.mmaya.gob.bo/
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Ministry of Development Planning - National Climate Change Program
Adaptations.executing_agent: Services Center and Technical Support NGO (CESAT)
Adaptations.success_factors: Availability of rain water for operation of reservoirs and agricultural production with supplemental irrigation.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Low rainfall, limited capacity of farmer organizations to use and sustainable management of soils, irrigation systems and natural resources.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, carbon sequestration through forest plantations with 500 seedlings of radiata pine and 1500 eucalyptus seedlings.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Increased availability of water for household agricultural production.
Increased intensification and diversification of agricultural production in 13.5 hectares of irrigated plots."
Adaptations.comments: Strengthened capacities of farmer organizations in the use and sustainable management of soils and irrigation systems.

Adaptations.title: The weather is changing, something must be done to prevent disasters
Adaptations.description: "The project area is highly vulnerable, with permanent threats and risks to disasters, especially drought, frost and floods; conditioned to climate, salinity, low rainfall, overgrazing, poor food security and few practices for the conservation and preservation of water, affecting crops and livestock production."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Sucre street, ENAF avenue, west side of Bolivian School, city of Oruro - Bolivia
Adaptations.source: Irish Catholic Agency for Development - TROCAIRE, www.trocaire.org
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Financial institution: Irish Catholic Agency for Development - TROCAIRE
Adaptations.executing_agent: JARAÑA NGO
Adaptations.funding_source: Irish Catholic Agency for Development - TROCAIRE
Adaptations.success_factors: Lack of cooperation from beneficiary families and community members in supporting the construction of reservoirs (water).
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Scattered rainfall.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: There is full readiness of the beneficiary families to develop the activities included in the project.
Adaptations.comments: The construction of reservoirs and wells allows people, animals and crops to have access to water supplies in order to strengthen the capacity of local agricultural production.

Adaptations.title: Vulnerability evaluation and adaptation capacity to climate change in the municipality of Chipaya
Adaptations.description: The objectives of the project are to establish the conservation status of the ecosystem and to recommend appropriate measures to prevent further ecological damage.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Saavedra avenue Nº 1179 Miraflores, City of La Paz - Bolivia
Adaptations.source: Project Report 2006/2007 National Climate Change Program, www.mmaya.gob.bo
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Ministry of Development Planning - National Climate Change Program
Adaptations.executing_agent: "NGO ""Nature and Community"" Study Center"
Adaptations.success_factors: Strengthening of traditional organizations generating participatory solutions to climate change adaptation.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Non implementation of local adaptation plans affecting the improvement and strengthening of agricultural systems, agroforestry systems and the strengthening of social, cultural and economic structure.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "The evaluation of vulnerability to climate change by observing indicators of economic productive sectors, social and cultural structures, water resources, biodiversity and human health; are considered appropriate adaptation measures at local level."
Adaptations.comments: It was possible to develop local plans for the municipality of Chipayas involving four lines of action.

Adaptations.title: Validation of rain water micro capture and micro climate techniques for reforestation
Adaptations.description: The project involves local population in the process of afforestation and reforestation with native and introduced trees. Through the use of water micro capture and micro climate techniques, the project will ensure the soil conservation and an efficient use of water resources.
Adaptations.contact_adress: University City, Dehene avenue, Oruro-Pisiga road, Oruro - Bolivia
Adaptations.source: Project Report 2006/2007 National Climate Change Program, www.mmaya.gob.bo
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Ministry of Development Planning - National Climate Change Program
Adaptations.executing_agent: Faculty of Agricultural , Animal and Veterinary Sciences, Technical University of Oruro
Adaptations.funding_source: Government of the Netherlands and local actors
Adaptations.success_factors: Microcaptación techniques of rainwater must be accepted by the communities.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, occurs when woodlands are implemented in communal areas, by capturing CO2.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Measures which are implemented had increase water availability for familiar agricultural production. With the strengthening of peasant organizations capacities, a greater control and prevention of erosion is achieved.

Adaptations.title: Integrated Watershed Management
Adaptations.description: The project aims to be the national reference center in the integrated watershed management in the watersheds of the Tunari Mountain range and the Central Valley of Cochabamba. It involves as an initial stage the socioeconomic and biophysical diagnostic, in order to evaluate the areas of influence for appropriate planning. Furthermore a hydraulic control of riverbeds and ravines will be promoted through protection, retention, canalization, centralization and consolidation works for the sediment deposition, water resources preservation and flood risks attenuation. Soil conservation managing and community agricultural extension development through participative form of mechanical and agronomic techniques, cultivations handlings and systems of water use optimization, is also an important part of the project.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Atahuallpa fibal avenue - Parque Tunari. City of Cochabamba - Bolivia
Adaptations.executing_agent: Integrated Watershed Management Program - PROMIC
Adaptations.success_factors: Changes of municipal authorities that may affect the development of the project, preventing the objectives of the project.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Difficulty in biophysical diagnosis of watershed and socioeconomic characterization due to social circumstances. Integrated watershed management not articulated to rural productive development.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Outcomes of the project are, among other things, the reversion of the environmental degradation processes of the watersheds, attenuation of natural risks on the Vally and natural resources preservation.
Adaptations.comments: The implementation of the project requires continuity in the participation of instances like the Prefecture and the involved municipalities, besides the rural population of the watersheds to make possible that the results and benefits of the integrated watershed management be permanent.

Adaptations.title: Risk Management Training
Adaptations.description: Water Resource and Risk Management will be more important under changing climate. Climate Change analysis and assessment methodology of natural disasters is necessary to support local politician in risk management. The Project will establish emergency centers, which can provide scenarios, practices and strategies for local risk prevention and management. Scenarios were constructed using weather forecasters and risk maps. So risks of climate change in the municipalities will be identified and the communities will be trained on disaster prevention.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Atahuallpa avenue fibal - Tunari Park, city of Cochabamba - Bolivia.
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation - COSUDE
Adaptations.executing_agent: PROINPA Foundation
Adaptations.success_factors: The non-implementation of local policies in risk management Permanent municipal human resource changes will affect the communities in the implementation of disaster prevention measures. Continued support from local institutions with financial and human resources in coordination with communities to work maintenance is necessary.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Weather conditions affecting access to the localities.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Based on the Municipal Risk Maps and risk scenarios, communities are adapted and equipped to mitigate the risks that climate change causes. Additional construction of traditional irrigation channels, called Sukakollos, achieved the reduction of climate change risks in the municipalities and communities.
Adaptations.comments: There are similar projects implemented in Ingavi, La Paz and Tiquipaya, Cochabamba.

Adaptations.title: Risk Management Training
Adaptations.description: Water Resource and Risk Management
Adaptations.contact_adress: "Elias Meneces avenue; 4th Km. of El Paso, 10th km. of Blanco Galindo avenue - North, Cochabamba - Bolivia"
Adaptations.source: publication of COSUDE records - Bolivia, www.cooperacion-suiza.admin.ch/bolivia/
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation - COSUDE
Adaptations.executing_agent: Proinpa foundation
Adaptations.success_factors: Continued support from local institutions with financial and human resources in coordination with communities to work maintenance.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Weather conditions affecting access to the localities.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: With the construction of traditional irrigation channels, called Sukakollos is achieved the reduction of climate change risks in the municipalities and communities involved.
Adaptations.comments: For the prevention of risks, weather forecasters were developed.

Adaptations.title: Risk Management Training
Adaptations.description: Practices and strategies for local risk prevention and management.
Adaptations.contact_adress: "Elias Meneces avenue; 4th Km. of El Paso, 10th km. of Blanco Galindo avenue - North, cuty of Cochabamba - Bolivia"
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation - COSUDE
Adaptations.executing_agent: PROINPA Foundation
Adaptations.success_factors: Completion of the project, participating municipalities should allocate financial and human resources for care in identified areas with climate risks .
Adaptations.limiting_factors: None
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Identification of risk areas to work on the prevention and integral management of Risk in Agricultural Production in the municipalities.
Adaptations.comments: Scenarios were constructed using talking risk maps.

Adaptations.title: Strengthening of the adaptation capacity to climate variability and the CC of water resources in Bolivia
Adaptations.description: Strengthen of local capacities to identify and evaluate current and future vulnerability to climate change on water resources and possible adaptation measures and to integrate adaptation to climate change in the definition of policies management and use of water resources.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Fernando Guachalla street Nº 342, Victor Building, 9 Floor. City of La Paz - Bolivia
Adaptations.executing_agent: World Bank
Adaptations.funding_source: Donors Fund through the World Bank
Adaptations.success_factors: Political processes have an impact on state institutions by unforeseen changes of authorities, particularly in the water sector.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Absence and / or little interest in social participation of local communities.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Strengthen local capacity to identify and assess current and future vulnerability to climate change on water resources and possible adaptation measures and to integrate adaptation to climate change in the definition of management policies and use of water resources.
Adaptations.comments: Priority measures will be formulated based on adaptation technical inputs, economic and social solid in the field of water resources - soil.

Adaptations.title: Governance, equitable adjustment, coalitions and climate change
Adaptations.description: The project aims to build resilience to climate change in Bolivia by improving governance structures and institutional support for local adaptation while reducing exclusion in decision-making processes. It will establish community strengthening to climate change, by developing communities and marginalized groups to build coalitions for action in relation to the governance of climate change, specifically with regard to water resources.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Fernando Guachalla street Nº 342, Victor Building, 9th floor. City of La Paz - Bolivia
Adaptations.executing_agent: PNCC/UMSA/UMSS/U Tomas frias/CARE/EPSAS
Adaptations.funding_source: World Bank, the Andean Community of Nations (CAN)
Adaptations.success_factors: Improving governance and institutional issues related to large differences in the social impacts of climate change and differences in their organization at a local level.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The clear role between communities, state and market in the context of establishing capacities to adapt to climate change
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Marginalized groups and communities prepared to build coalitions for action in relation to the governance of climate change, specifically in relation to water resources.
Adaptations.comments: Local level responses will be established related to the management of water resources and adaptation to climate change

Adaptations.title: Institutional Capacity Strengthening of the Municipality of La Paz in the Framework of Adaptation to Climate Change and the Impact on Biodiversity
