Adaptations.title: Coastal Climate Change and Adaptation - A Sea-Level Rise Risk Assessment for Cape Town
Adaptations.description:
"This project assessmented sea- level rise risk for the City of Cape Town by identifying and priortising risk reduction options including institutional, biological, physical and infrastructure options. Both direct and indirect risks were considered, focusing on the storm damage and what happens as a result of storm damage. The last phase identified particularly vulnerable locations and distinguished between different aspects of sea- level rise including wave run up, wave set up and eustatic sea- level rise. The findings supported the implementation of a coastal buffer zone in the City of Cape Town that is currently being planned.
Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops and the project received extensive media coverage."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Environmental Policy and Strategy, City of Cape Town, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: City of Cape Town along with LaQuar and Econologic
Adaptations.funding_source: The City of Cape Town and the Urban Environmental Management Project (UEM)
Adaptations.success_factors: Co-operative governance and operational budget for implementing set-back line and for beach replenishment and sea walls.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: "Pre-existing development; political and socio-economic pressure"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Marine and estuarine biodiversity, tourist assets retained, burden on disaster management reduced
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Policy and practice has been informed by the research.

Adaptations.query: Suid Bokkeveld (Hantam District), Northern Cape Province, South Africa.
Adaptations.title: Increasing the resilience of small-scale tea farmers in responding to climate change
Adaptations.description: This project was designed to provide concrete recommendations and to develop strategies to build resilience to climate change amongst small-scale tea growers, and mainstreaming adaptation to projected increasing climate risk. The following measures were undertaken to improve the resilience of the small-scale farmers: Through quarterly climate preparedness workshops farmers together with scientists discussed climate change projections and trends in the Suid Bokkeveld region, including adaptation options and long term strategies. In the workshops farmers learned to integrate seasonal weather forecast into their decision making. Mentor farmers trained their fellow farmers in soil erosion control and the removal of alien species. As a result of the training farmers created wind breaks and retention buffers in their tea production areas. Through the learning process initiated by the project farmers changed to more sustainable agricultural practices e.g. mulching as a method to conserve moisture and increase plant nutrients. Finally, farmers learned to monitor the growth of wild and cultivated rooibos stands, and were able to enhance their management abilities according to findings. In the participatory research farmers discovered that wild rooibos has a greater resilience to severe climatic events than cultivated varieties. Two communities of small-scale rooibos farmers, currently organised as the Heiveld Co-operative and the Wupperthal Tea Association, have been harvesting wild and cultivated rooibos, and have become the de facto guardians of the wild rooibos genetic stock.
Adaptations.contact_person: Noel Oettlé, Rural Program Manager, Environmental Monitoring Group,
Adaptations.contact_adress: P. O. Box 350, Nieuwoudtville 8180, South Africa
Adaptations.initiating_agent: World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: Environmental Monitoring Group, Climate Systems Analysis Group (UCT)
Adaptations.success_factors: •Access to latest scientific findings which provide info about seasonal trends and the level of confidence •Excellent relations with farmers (which built upon previous work in the community) •Continuity
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Farmers are resource poor, implementation of technical measures is often too costly. Many actions require investments that most of these farmers to not have. Drought conditions persisted in the Suid Bokkeveld for most of the project period. This was both a constraint to the project (because of the limited resources of farmers to participate in learning processes) and an incentive (as farmers are stimulated to learn more about the situation and how best to respond to it). One significant gap in adaptation support is the lack of engagement by the Department of Agriculture in the area.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: At a small scale there are synergies to mitigation created through more sustainable land use and farming practices.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The project has significantly contributed to the empowerment of farmers through the promotion of sustainable farming practices and better decision making based on the farmers enhanced climate and crop knowledge. They also have now better access to market and other resources through marketing of their climate proofing activities. Wild rooibos, for example , is much in demand by European markets and attracts a high price. Through the project farmers were able to develop a successful harvesting and marketing strategy that gave them access to those markets (e.g. fair trade and organic markets).
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: In order to be successful all project activities needed to be linked to local institutions (e.g. working with a particular rooibos farming co-operative, the Heiveld Cooperative). Project has been successful because farmers are more resilient and were able to improve their livelihoods. Here are some of the findings from the project: • There is a real enthusiasm amongst farmers in isolated communities to gain more understanding of global climatic patterns, and how these affect their livelihoods and their lifestyles. • A learning process that supports the sharing of information and experiences at both global and local scales breaks people’s sense of isolation and helplessness, and creates new capacities for positive action to mitigate the effects of climate change. • Adaptations are most effective when based on existing knowledge. • The role of formal and informal institutions at a range of scales is critical for supporting adaptation. • The project has shown that positive synergies may be found between rural livelihoods, conservation of biodiversity and successful adaptation to climate change. Finally, the learning approach adopted in the project has enhanced local knowledge and broadened farmers’ capacities to respond in a proactive manner. The project used indigenous adaptive capacity as a starting point, combined with relevant external knowledge, rather than imposing adaptation plans in a top-down manner. This allowed the development of adaptation strategies to current and future climate change in a more realistic and participatory way.
Adaptations.comments: CONSIDERATION OF CLIMATE CHANGE INFORMATION OR CLIMATE SCIENCE IN THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT: *Project design and implementations was based on the findings from downscaling data provided by the Climate Systems Analysis Group (UCT). *Farmers have access to quarterly weather forecasts (which is provided by the South African Weather Bureau) and learned about relevant climate information through climate preparedness workshops.

Adaptations.title: Learning about Adaptation in Eco Schools
Adaptations.description: The aim of the Eco-School Climate Change project is to facilitate and empower schools as drivers of community action, learning and social change toward reducing and offsetting greenhouse gas emissions. This is being achieved by encouraging climate-friendly behaviour through lessons and action projects that link with the curriculum. In the process biodiversity conservation and healthy ecosystems are promoted as part of climate change mitigation and adaptation. The framework of the current WESSA/WWF Eco-Schools programme forms the basis through which this is achieved, as it has a well researched and peer reviewed process framework that fosters whole school learning and education for sustainable living. Although there is no requirement to expand on the number of schools in the six climate change nodes, the number of schools has increased in 2010 from 144 to 240 and this is growing in number in all nodes, in almost all cases. Specific measures include:39 lessons on the curicculum relating to climate change, development of a climate change cartoon and theme specific educational puzzle, vegetable gardens and wetland rehabilitation activities. The project is located in the following provinces of South Africa: Western Cape, Mpumalanga, Eastern Cape, Free State and KwaZulu-Natal.
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 394, Howick, 3290/ 1 Karkloof Road, Howick
Adaptations.source: "Jessica Thorn, (Cape Action Program) ; Caroline Conway-Physick, (Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa)"
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa (WESSA), WWF South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa (WESSA), WWF South Africa
Adaptations.funding_source: Wildlands Conservation Trust and the Climate Change Action Partnership
Adaptations.success_factors: •Training of educators, teaching of learners (Capacity development) •Supply of theme specific resource support learning materials to schools
Adaptations.limiting_factors: •Funding •Lack of Integration into the national curriculum through the National Department of Education •Limited support time through coordinators to school •Limited conceptual depth and capacity of educators
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: • Yes as it teaches students to conserve their environment and contribute towards sustainable development through developing attitudes, lifestyles and values that are harmonious with the environment (understanding of interrelationships of eco-system services and resources)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Although quantitative values cannot effectively record the effective of impact, there are many qualitative assessments that have given a positive indication of the progress and impact being had in schools.
Adaptations.comments: a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Through teaching and learning in the classroom and action projects identified by schools. This has been in response to global concerns and developments but has been integrated into curricular learning through a cross-cutting approach supporting learning in the classroom. The resource materials that have been designed around climate change and related issues has been broadranging to show the complexity and implications of this issue, and how it impacts on every sphere of existence today and the future.

Adaptations.title: Vulnerability, Coping and Adaptation within the context of climate change and HIV/ AIDS
Adaptations.description: "The Project looks at multiple stressors, specifically health and environment issues, and how these are impacted by changes in climatic conditions in order to identify and implement appropriate community-based adaptation practices through a social learning approach. The main objectives of the project are: - to increase the understanding of the complex inter-relationships between climate change, HIV/AIDS, vulnerability and food security, and adaptation responses within the Eastern Cape; - to support the identification and implementation of community-based adaptation practices though a social learning research process; - to develop partnerships and constituencies to help bring about relevant change to policy and practice; - to build capacity amongst multiple stakeholders, from students to municipal officials and community members, to understand the complex processes around vulnerability and the ability to cope and adapt with multiple livelihood stressors. Activities include: •Stakeholder workshops •Liaison with different stakeholders (NGOs, municipalities) •Integration of project strategies into IDPS •Research team is acting as facilitators that assist the communities in building their resilience The project is located in three communities near Queenstown, Eastern Cape, South Africa."
Adaptations.contact_person: Nick Hamer, Department of Environmental Science Rodes University South Africa)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Nick Hamer, Department of Environmental Science Rodes University South Africa)
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Department of Environmental Science Rodes University South Africa) in partnership with University of Alberta (Canada)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Environmental Science Rodes University South Africa) in partnership with University of Alberta (Canada)
Adaptations.success_factors: •Ability to engage the different stakeholder groups •Champions in the communities •Willingness of local government to engage with projects and communities •Ownership by communities and local government
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of political will
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Maybe, as the approach taken in the project is ‘mitigation for adaptation’ (e.g. promoting the use of bio gass by municipalities)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Measures contribute to improvment of economic development, health care, empowerment of rural communities and the strengthening of institutions.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Not yet possible as the project just started.
Adaptations.comments: a)How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? IPCC studies and other related literature review have been considered in the design of the project and in the identification of the communities. A main challenge is that very little downscaling data for the Eastern Cape currently exist.

Adaptations.query: Swartland Local Municipality, Western Cape, South Africa
Adaptations.title: Climate Change Adaptation in the Swartland
Adaptations.description: The project focused on increasing resilience of small scale farmers in the Swartland to climate change through offering a range of activities and climate change preparedness workshops to farmers. With the use of historical time-lines, small scale farmers related their experiences of changes in weather over the past few years and shared with members of other farming communities in the region how they were able to respond to these changes. Follow up workshops were continually evaluated and reformatted to respond to the needs expressed by the small-scale farmers. They generally included the sharing of scientific and local information, outings to see local examples of farming practice, and discussions on how farmers might plan their farming activities given the most up to date weather forecasts available on the South African Weather Service’s website. Seasonal weather forecasts were integrated into appropriate livelihood strategies including the choice of crop, timing of cropping and technological options. Farmers expressed a desire to record their own rainfall and temperature data, and were supplied by the project with the necessary and appropriate devices to do so. The information was recorded in climate diaries and discussed at the subsequent workshops.
Adaptations.contact_person: Bettina Koeller, director, Idigo development & change
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 350, Nieuwoudtville 8180, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: Indigo development & change and Environmental Monitoring Group
Adaptations.funding_source: CCAA (Climate Change Adaptation in Africa) supported by IDRC (International Development Research Centre) and DFID (UK Department for International Development)
Adaptations.success_factors: •Engaging local and scientific knowledge •Participatory action research process
Adaptations.limiting_factors: •Short time scale •Learning processes take a long time and require long term commitment
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Economic empowerment and improvement of livelihoods
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Farmers are very eager to learn and like to engage with scientific knowledge. Participants have expressed that the interactions with each other and with researchers around Climate Change issues and livelihoods were necessary and useful. Many of the farmers have expressed a desire to continue with the workshops and data collection activities. Unfortunately funding issues and time for facilitation were not sufficient for sustaining the process.
Adaptations.comments: a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? The Climate Systems Analysis Group (CSAG) at UCT produced a brief report outlining a preliminary analysis of climate data from weather stations in the Swartland region. Given the limited size of the geographic area, together with the use of incomplete historical data from only 5 weather stations, CSAG emphasized that the results are not conclusive, and require further investigation and research. However, the report concludes that an increase in maximum and minimum temperatures is likely, with warming particularly in autumn. Furthermore, an increase of up to 2.5 degrees Celcius is projected for the end of the 21st century, based on the SRESA2 (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Special Report on Emissions Scenario) emissions scenario. Precipitation, given the complex nature of its drivers, was less easy to predict. Generally, precipitation is likely to stay the same, or otherwise decrease slightly. It is predicted that rainfall events will be fewer, but more intense. The report concludes that agricultural activities and livelihoods are likely to be negatively impacted by the projected changes.

Adaptations.title: Pilot adaptation measures to climate change
Adaptations.description: Integrating adaptation to climate change in agricultural value chains, water management and in the processes of local and regional planning and public investment in the departments of Arequipa and also in Piura.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Los Incas 172, piso 6, El Olivar. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions. Vulnerability and Adaptation to Climate change activities and products (Augusto 2009), PDRS-GTZ
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment , PDRS, GORE Arequipa, GORE Piura, SENAMHI, Municipios
Adaptations.funding_source: German Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)and GTZ
Adaptations.success_factors: Common concept learning, prioritization of issues with counterparts who are responsible for it, limited number of measures, attendance, local accountability and monitoring (consultants).
Adaptations.limiting_factors: GTZ-PDRS does not have an office in Arequipa.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project has been successfully implemented. The partners apply the lessons learned.
Adaptations.comments: Systematization of the pilot measure will be published.

Adaptations.title: Adaptation for small farmers of coffee and tea
Adaptations.description:
"The main part of this project is Capacity Building and Implementation of Integrated Coffee Management Practices. Around 872 coffee producers from 4 districts (Canchaque, Montero, San Miguel del Faique, Yamango) were involved.
Those farmers not only contributed through their local and traditional knowledge to design the adaptation strategy, but were also sensitized to the needs and solutions to confront climate risks.
10 technical advisors were trained to train 50 environmental promoters and 200 promoter farmers in climate change adaptation on coffee plantations at community level.
To reduce the risk of landslides and prevent erosion on community land, the four districts were reforested. Hence, 4 communal nurseries with around 45,000 seedlings were installed in the four districts.
Following the good practices in Nicaragua and Chiapas, CEPICAFE started the installation of 10 solar driers in Montero to assure the coffee drying process under changing precipitation patterns. More often unforeseeable rainfalls interrupt the sun drying process during harvest season, thus negatively affecting the quality of the green coffee beans.
Furthermore CEPICAFE supported sustainable coffee practices, like soil conservation, irrigation, fertilization, pest control or shadow management."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Los Incas 172, piso 6, El Olivar. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions, http://www.adapcc.org/en/peru.htm
Adaptations.executing_agent: Cafédirect (United Kingdom), Cepicafe and German Technical Cooperation Agency (GTZ)
Adaptations.funding_source: Cafedirect, German Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) and GTZ
Adaptations.success_factors: Family empowerment. Environmental education at all levels. Sustaining income levels of families with activities that cushion the negative effects of climate change. Inter-agency partnerships to develop proposals.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The project was aimed directly by the headquarters and there was poor coordination with the PDRS.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Prolonged drought periods and water scarcity for communities and agriculture were identified as climate related risk threatening the coffee farmers.
During the process a comprehensive study on water management and measures to implement in order to improve water use and efficiency has been elaborated. As the identified measures require huge investments at the regional and public level, those measures could not be implemented during the AdapCC lifetime. CEPICAFE focused on trainings and advisory services for farmers to improve irrigation systems and water management at the community and farm level. It is recommended to further support improved water management techniques and involves the local and regional political institutions to access additional financing."
Adaptations.comments: Another part of this project is Reforestation and Carbon Sequestration: + Reforestation project on 285 ha community land is planned + Nursery with 50.000 seedlings of native trees and pines installed + After 25 years carbon sequestration of 560.5 tCO2/ha on 285 ha, corresponding to 159,742.5 t CO2 in reforested areas expected + pre-sell of 5,092 carbon credits for approximately €60,000 by 2015

Adaptations.title: Managing Escalating Wildfires
Adaptations.description: Working on Fire is the South African Fire Management Programme, which is running very successfully, but theres a gap in addressing the increasing escalating hazardous effects of Climate Change on Wildfires So this project is in place to develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate change-induced fire hazards.” The Project aims to play a catalytic role in bringing about a paradigm shift from conventional wildfire management approaches that are focused on reactive fire fighting, to a more proactive Integrated Fire Management (IFM) approach. This will serve to enhance the adaptive management capacity of the national/provincial/local government and local communities to cope with the increase wildfire risks associated with climate change. The geographical area for this project is the Western Cape, parts of the Southern Cape, including Baviaanskloof and Tsitsikamma, because wildfires in this region has been escalating with increased intensity over the last few years. This areas falls within the Cape Floristic Region, which has been declared a hotspots with key endemic species and natural resources that needs adaptive management for long-term sustainability.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Kirstenbosch Gardens, Rhodes Drive, Newlands, South Africa
Adaptations.source: "As project is still in planning, key information is with the Project Coordinator – Chandra Fick ""mailto: chandra.fick@wofire.co.za but for more information on Working on Fire the website is www.wofire.co.za"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Working on Fire
Adaptations.success_factors: It was importance that there were structures in place to take up the implementation of these new projects. This body was found in the Fire Protections Assosications spread over the implementation area.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: A limiting factor will be to find the right skill in local communities. But this will give the project the chance to build the capacity of local communities and leave them with specified skill that will benefit them forever.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: In order to adapt, mitigation is going to be important as it will help us assess our decreasing ecological footprint.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: It will contribute to training and educating communities and students on the importance of protecting our sensitive ecosystems.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The outcome should be a proactive approach to fighting Wildfires with skilled manpower in local areas who has access to key information necessary to manage their technologically enhanced stations. As this project is still in the planning phase we hope that it will have desired effects.
Adaptations.comments: "Some of the Resources used; Guy Midgeleys Climate Change Scientific Research Data; Key information from the Initial National Communication (INC) 2003; CSRI on Weather Patterns and Fire Danger Rating Systems ; Department of Water Affairs and Forestry 2000 report on - Review of the veld fires in the Western Cape 15-25 January 2000"

Adaptations.title: Second National Communication on Climate Change of Peru to the UNFCCC (SNC)
Adaptations.description:
"Second National Communication on Climate Change to the UNFCCC. 
The aim was to develop and improve national capabilities to facilitate the integration of climate change in the national development and poverty reduction processes, establishing an adaptation strategy for priority areas and sectors. Develop a national management system for GHG inventory, propose a mitigating GHG emissions strategy for energy, industry and transport sectors, describe the steps to integrate climate change and development. Analyze constraints, gaps and needs of a national climate observation system."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Javier Prado Oeste 1440. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions, http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/pernc2s.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of the Environment (MINAM)
Adaptations.success_factors: "Continue the articulated work between the public and the private sector, in benefit of local, regional and national institutions; involve regional authorities, local population, universities, the media, scientific and national institutions, to design and manage projects and investigations in benefit of the most vulnerable populations of Peru."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The sub-projects have been assigned to different consultants, without a pre-established methodology, which can go to the detriment of the Project’s results. Scattered, outdated and limited access to information. There is no territorial information. Data is not comparable at spatial scales and generalized.
Adaptations.comments: The agriculture sector is especially vulnerable to climate change. For this reason, all adaptation measures must consider that climate change will produce greater food insecurity. As a response, a number of development projects and programs are been implemented. These projects and programs constitute adaptation measures in pilot areas, but the efforts are scarce considering the effects in the diverse productive regions of the country.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: TEST

Adaptations.title: Integrated Local Assessment of the Santa River Basin - SNC
Adaptations.description: "Vulnerability and adaptation to climate change assessment to identify and evaluate natural hazards, and the vulnerability and risk of socioeconomic activities and local affected infrastructure; the results are incorporated into the land use planning process. It evaluates the territory of ecosystems and natural resources of the Santa River Basin related to hydrometeorological anomalies, natural and anthropogenic processes that enable to design and implement adaptation measures in a participatory manner. The Integrated Local Assessment allow to know the vulnerability and the adaptation processes to climate change of the different systems, at a micro level. "
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Javier Prado Oeste 1440. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions/ Local Assessment Integrated biophysical and current vulnerability of the Holy Basin, http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/pernc2s.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ancash Regional Government with the Ministry of the Environment and Senamhi
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutionalize climate change in the Regional Government of Ancash, to be considered in the execution of all type of sustainable development projects. Fortify the local institutional capacities for the implementation of the adaptation measures like a permanent process.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Scattered, outdated and limited access to information. There is no territorial information. Data is not comparable at spatial scales and generalized.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: From the Integrated Local Assessment of the Santa River Basin the intrinsic vulnerability, as well as the current and future vulnerabilities were obtained, which set the basis to determine the proposals for the adaptation measures considering the current and future climate scenarios developed by SENAMHI.
Adaptations.comments: This assessment is part of the Second National Communication (SNC) on Climate Change to the UNFCCC. The aim was to develop and improve national capabilities to facilitate the integration of climate change in the national development and poverty reduction processes, establishing an adaptation strategy for priority areas and sectors.

Adaptations.title: Integrated Local Assessment: Evaluation of the Deterioration of the Natural Resources due to CC - SNC
Adaptations.description:
"Identify impacts, vulnerabilities and measures to adapt to future climate change scenarios in the river basin, with focus on rice and coffee crops, ornamental species of orchids and the municipal conservation area (MCA).
The models of impacts and vulnerabilities were based on the contribution of the spatial information generated in the ZEE (macro level) as well as the Meso-Zonificacion of the Rio Alto Watershed of the Mayo River Basin. This set of spatial data was validated at the regional level. Additionally, from this data, other local and regional studies and processes were generated and derived."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Javier Prado Oeste 1440. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Assessment of natural resource degradation by climate change in the Mayo River Basin and Yuracyacu watershed, http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/pernc2s.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: San Martin Regional Government - GORESAM
Adaptations.success_factors: Insufficient spatial information (including geo-spatial standards), and the lack of an integrated system to generate, organize and manage knowledge on climate change in the river basin. Regarding adaptation measures, without an adequate information system, the possibilities of making decisions and implementing the measures would fall into greater uncertainty.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Vulnerability to climate change impacts of the study area (rated as high, medium or low) is reported, according to the different crops in the area (rice, coffee, orchids and ornamental municipal conservation area). The amounts of losses that could arise is also presented.
Adaptations.comments: This assessment is part of the Second National Communication (SNC) on Climate Change to the UNFCCC. The aim was to develop and improve national capabilities to facilitate the integration of climate change in the national development and poverty reduction processes, establishing an adaptation strategy for priority areas and sectors.

Adaptations.title: Integrated Local Assessment: Evaluation of Natural Hazards - SNC
Adaptations.description: Peruvian water conditions and its current and future vulnerability to climate change description. It seeks to achieve an integrated water resources management and meeting the users demands.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Javier Prado Oeste 1440. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Assessment of current and future vulnerability of water resources from climate hazards and / or extreme events - SCN, http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/pernc2s.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment (MINAM)
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Currently there is no efficient and effective river basins management. Moreover, there is lack of a “river basin concept” in the Peruvian political organization.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Legal and institutional adaptation measures are presented, as well as measures for water resource systems, ecosystems and for sectors such as housing, construction and sanitation, agriculture, energy and mining, and production.
Adaptations.comments: This assessment is part of the Second National Communication (SNC) on Climate Change to the UNFCCC. The aim was to develop and improve national capabilities to facilitate the integration of climate change in the national development and poverty reduction processes, establishing an adaptation strategy for priority areas and sectors.

Adaptations.title: Vulnerability and Adaptation Assessment in the electricity sector and proposals to adapt to CC impacts - SNC
Adaptations.description: The aim is to propose adaptation measures for climate change in the electricity sector, (considering policies, strategies, programs, technical standards, legal standards, technologies, early warning systems) to reduce its vulnerability with the inclusion of adaptation options as part of national policies, development planning, investment prioritization and budget allocation. Electricity production, as well as electricity generation and transportation infrastructure, is vulnerable to natural hazards and climate change. This level of vulnerability shows the need to establish policies and its respective adaptation measures. At the same time, these policies and measures must be part of a greater adaptation policy, applicable to all economic sectors.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Javier Prado Oeste 1440. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Vulnerability Assessment and Adaptation in the electricity sector and proposals to adapt to the impacts of climate change - Report 4 - Final, http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/pernc2s.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment (MINAM) y Ministry of Energy and Mines (MINEM)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Proposed adaptation policies and measures correspond to the formulation of an adaptation strategy for electricity sector.
Adaptations.comments: This assessment is part of the Second National Communication (SNC) on Climate Change to the UNFCCC. The aim was to develop and improve national capabilities to facilitate the integration of climate change in the national development and poverty reduction processes, establishing an adaptation strategy for priority areas and sectors.

Adaptations.title: Synthesize and integrate specific studies assessing the vulnerability of agriculture to climate change and formulate proposals for adaptation - SNC
Adaptations.description: This assessment analyzes the current and future vulnerability of the agricultural sector, its institutional analysis seeks to incorporate adaptation measures and establish an adaptation strategy.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Javier Prado Oeste 1440. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: Synthesize and integrate specific studies assessing the vulnerability of agriculture to climate change and formulating proposals for adaptation - Final Report
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Agriculture (MINAG)
Adaptations.success_factors: The agriculture sector is especially vulnerable to climate change. For this reason, all adaptation measures must consider that climate change will produce greater food insecurity. As a response, a number of development projects and programs are been implemented. These projects and programs constitute adaptation measures in pilot areas, but the efforts are scarce considering the effects in the diverse productive regions of the country.

Adaptations.query: Chinchipe River Basin, Province of San Ignacio, Cajamarca
Adaptations.title: "Guidelines for a local strategy of adaptation to CC as part of the project ""A Living Landscape"""
Adaptations.description: A technical guideline document was prepared, it contained an analysis of vulnerability to climate hazards in the province of San Ignacio, and presented a number of adaptation measures.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Calle Alfredo León 211 - Miraflores
Adaptations.source: Local Adaptation Strategy Chinchipe River Basin
Adaptations.executing_agent: WWF-Perú and Libélula
Adaptations.limiting_factors: "Information gaps: The information on malnutrition in the River Basin has not been updated since 1999. In the case of illiteracy rates, the ones found on the document haven´t been used; however, latest figures of the Ministry of Education have been used. The figures found in the various documents do not always coincide. There are many figures which do not specify the year of the sources or they tend to be unreliable. "
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: It has been identified human, agricultural and coffee production vulnerability in the districts of the Chinchipe River Basin. The document makes recommendations for the situation in those locations and for future studies.

Adaptations.title: Adaptation to Climate Change Program (PACC)
Adaptations.description: The project aims to contribute to knowledge, identifying and implementing adaptation measures from the population, public and private institutions and governments at the regions of Cusco and Apurimac, having an impact on policies at national and international level. The program has emphasis on water resources, reducing the risk of natural disasters and food security. A website will promote knowledge management around adaptation to climate change in Peru and work as a tool to inform and sensitize local, regional and national actors.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Salaverry 3242, San Isidro
Adaptations.source: "Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions; http://www.cooperacion-suiza.admin.ch/peru/; http://www.predes.org.pe/pacc.html; http://www.paccperu.org.pe/"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Predes, Intercooperation, Libélula, Ministry of Environment, Apurimac Regional Government and Cusco Regional Government , National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru (SENAMHI)
Adaptations.funding_source: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)
Adaptations.success_factors: "The direct impacts of climate change occur at the local level, affecting mainly the livelihood of the most vulnerable. PACC promotes that the adaptation measures at the watershed-level have a solid base of knowledge and also an effect on the reduction of the vulnerabilities at both ""community"" and ""family"" level, and therefore have a transforming dimension. Hence, adaptation, will also be constituted into a strategy that contributes to the improvement of the quality of life, and in the development of local communities."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: "(i) Lack of hydrological and meteorological data, which can provide a historic perspective to allow making a distinction between effects and impacts of climate change, from climate variability; (ii) lack of data concerning other climate variables (in addition to temperature and precipitation) such as wind, humidity and radiation; (iii) scarce interdisciplinary investigation tradition and experience, which demands special efforts to coordinate through various spaces (meetings, workshops, online platforms, etc)."
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The results achieved at the time are: diagnostics, monitoring and reporting (with the Regional Information System), application of adaptation measures and policies. Information are available via www.paccperu.org.pe
Adaptations.comments: The program will promote from its second year after the organization of local, pilot adaptation priority watersheds. These pilot projects will be agreed with the municipalities and social organizations of these watersheds, and prioritize adaptation measures around water management, food security and reducing risks, underpinned by knowledge and experiences related to these 3 axes.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: "This is very nice ;) But please add more information. chears."

Adaptations.title: Adaptation to the Impact of Expedited Glacial Retreat in the Tropical Andes Project (PRAA)
Adaptations.description: The project aims to strengthen the resilience of ecosystems and local economies to the impacts of glacial retreat in the Tropical Andes, through the implementation of pilot activities that show the costs and benefits of adaptation to climate change. It monitors glacier water system of the Huaytapallana and Salkantay Rivers Basin.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Jorge Basadre 460. San Isidro
Adaptations.source: "Technical Summary: Climate Change Scenarios in the Mantaro River Basin in 2100, SENAMHI – National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru, 2007.; http://www.careclimatechange.org/files/adaptation/CARE_PRAA_Summary.pdf"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of the Environment (MINAM), SENAMHI
Adaptations.success_factors:
"To ensure that national and local governments in
Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru, as well as community-based organizations and groups participating in the PRAA, incorporate into their policies and development plans strategies for progressively adapting to reduced availability of water for agriculture and human consumption, caused by the retreat of glaciers in the Andean region."
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project is still under implementation.
Adaptations.comments: "Cost calculation: ""US$ 33 millones (donation + counterparts) * Perú = US$2,700,000 donation aprox."""

Adaptations.title: Program for the Strengthening of National Capacities to Manage the Impact of Climate Change and Air Pollution (PROCLIM)
Adaptations.description: "It sought to create and reinforce the capacity for developing climate change scenarios and vulnerability assessments and develop proposals for adaptation and geographic areas prioritized. As a whole, PROCLIM allowed the strengthening of institutional capacities. PROCLIM not only strengthens a specific group of people and central institutions for the management of Climate Change, but also contributes to the development of capabilities to reach a larger group, working in a collaborative environment, where each one does what they have to and knows how to do it. PROCLIM has implemented processes, which can be applied to other issues of national importance; it developed a work-methodology which conception and design extrapolates to other National institutions. PROCLIM opened a path to generate climate information needed for decision making to face climate change."
Adaptations.contact_adress: """Calle Alfredo León 211- Miraflores"
Adaptations.source: "Program Memory of PROCLIM; Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions"
Adaptations.executing_agent: National Environmental Council (CONAM)
Adaptations.success_factors: "Lack of knowledge about climate change at the community and local government level; First project of this type in Peru; Lack of clarity between key actors at the River Basin level on the relation between the environment, climate change, vulnerability and adaptation, and sustainable development; "
Adaptations.limiting_factors: "Climate change is not yet institutionalized at the project’s scope; Public, private and family management fields are disarticulated and lack a shared vision; Little continuity of the priorities of the governmental management."
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, PROCLIM has generated and strengthened capacity to identify, analyze and estimate GHG emissions and other air pollutants at 5 institutions: Environmental Health Department (DIGESA), National Natural Resources Institute (INRENA), Ministry of Energy and Mines (MINEM), Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MTC) in 13 prioritized cities .
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: PROCLIM has generated and strengthened capacity for developing climate change scenarios and vulnerability assessments of 7 institutions: AACHCHP, CENTRO, CONCYTEC, IGP, INRENA, ITDG and SENAMHI. It also developed integrated local assessments and adaptation strategies at 2 prioritized River Basins (Piura and Mantaro). The information generated has been widespread, “closing the circle” with the inclusion of the climate variable in the planning process towards sustainable development. It generated the Integrated National Emissions Inventory for 2000, five local inventories and thirteen sectoral inventories as well as map of deforestation of the Peruvian Amazon.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: "Test: fÜR tOBI ;)"

Adaptations.title: Future Climate Scenarios and Water Resource Availability - PROCLIM
Adaptations.description: The main objective of this study is to determine the availability of water based on the generation of global and regional climate temperature scenarios at approximately 5000 m and its correlation with the glacial retreat.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Calle Alfredo León 211 - Miraflores
Adaptations.source: Future Climate Scenarios and Water Resource Availability in the Santa River Basin, CONAM, 2005. Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions
Adaptations.executing_agent: Regional natural resource management and environmental management of the Ancash Regional Government in colaboration with the National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru (SENAMHI) and Institute of Development Research (IRD)
Adaptations.success_factors: The modeling that has been developed, is an approach to the estimation of how water resource coming from glacier source behaves, for a mid and long-term period over the Cordillera Blanca. The evidence of an actual increase of the average global temperature and the glacial retreat provide more confidence to the presented projections.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: An obstacle to carry out the study was the lack of integrated information on the River basin (e.g. availability of future global climate scenarios, adaptability of the regional numeric model and calculation capacity). In addition, there was moderate to high uncertainty in the construction of climate scenarios, for regions above the 4000m, related to a low density of meteorological stations to validate the results.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Estimations on the availability of water resources related to the deglaciation process as a result of global warming were developed.
Adaptations.comments: This assessment is part of PROCLIM, a project to strengthen national capabilities for an effective performance of the human, institutional, and financial resources in order to face Climate Change and manage Air Quality in prioritized geographic areas and cities.

Adaptations.title: Integrated local assessment and adaptation strategy to CC - PROCLIM
Adaptations.description: Analyzes the current and future vulnerability of the main productive elements of the Piura River Basin. The project seeks to establish an adaptation strategy to climate change for incorporation into the planning and regional development processes.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Calle Alfredo León 211 - Miraflores
Adaptations.source: "Directory of climate change in Peru - Practical Solutions; Hands On: The Climate Change in the Sustainable Development of Peru - PROCLIM. http://www.CONAM.gob.pe:8080/sinia/index.php?idElementoInformacion=8"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment, Autonomous Authority of the Chira-Piura Basin (AACHCP), National Natural Resources Institute (Inrena)
Adaptations.success_factors: The Local Integrated Evaluation was developed under an innovative work-scheme that coordinated the joint effort of several governmental institutions and the population, concatenating political processes, investigation platforms and participatory mechanisms, involving the local and regional organizations as part of this effort.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: An obstacle to carry out the study was the lack of integrated information on the River basin (e.g. availability of future global climate scenarios, adaptability of the regional numeric model and calculation capacity). In addition, there was moderate uncertainty in the construction of climate scenarios. Two methodologies were applied (statistic and dynamic), and two emissions scenarios for a period close to 2035.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Detailed studies were developed at the Piura river basin level and 4 sub-watersheds, as a result of a joint process of six institutions that combined scientific, professional and local actors’ efforts to elaborate the Local Integrated Evaluation and the Climate Change Adaptation Strategy. Piura’s river basin climatic characterization and climate scenarios up to the year 2050, with a 20 × 20 km resolution, were also developed.
Adaptations.comments: This assessment is part of PROCLIM, a project to strengthen national capabilities for an effective performance of the human, institutional, and financial resources in order to face Climate Change and manage Air Quality in prioritized geographic areas and cities.

Adaptations.query: Rio Mantaro, Via de Evitamiento, Huancayo, Peru
Adaptations.title: Vulnerability and Adaptation Local Integrated Assessment - PROCLIM
Adaptations.description: The aim was to assess the vulnerability to climate change of the Mantaro River Basin and formulate policies, strategies and adaptation measures, identifying viable options in major economic sectors to be incorporated into local development plans and regional levels.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Calle Alfredo León 211 - Miraflores
Adaptations.source: Current and future vulnerability to climate change and adaptation measures in the Mantaro River Basin, PROCLIM, 2005.
Adaptations.executing_agent: """Ministry of Environment , National Natural Resources Institute (Inrena),"
Adaptations.success_factors: "The Local Integrated Evaluation focused the study in three prioritized sectors; in addition, the key tool was the participatory workshops and the interdisciplinary and inter-institutional work-scheme which was applied."

Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: A climate atlas of precipitation and air temperature in the Mantaro River Basin was developed, as well as an interdisciplinary study on inter-annual climate variability. Vulnerable areas were identified in the basin, generating climate scenarios for the years 2025 and 2050, with a 20 × 20 km resolution .

Adaptations.title: ENSO index insurance
Adaptations.description:
"From 2004 to 2006 GlobalAgRisk performed a feasibility assessment and preliminary product development work for an insurance product that would reduce constraints to agricultural lending in the microfinance sector.
That early work identified the consequences of El Niño as a major constraint to lending in northern Peru. El Niño is a recurring threat in Peru that can bring catastrophic rainfall and flooding along its northern coast. That assessment led to a focus on the region of Piura and the design of an innovative index insurance product that utilizes measures of Pacific sea surface temperatures obtained from NOAA as the basis of payment. These values are highly predictive and correlated with the extreme El Niño events and their consequences in Piura. The unique aspect of this index is that the sea surface temperatures can signal a severe El Niño months in advance of its impact on land, enabling an insurance payment to be made several months before the onset of catastrophic weather. The advance payment can then be used for risk mitigation and adaptation strategies to reduce losses and disruptions from the impending disaster."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av. Javier Prado Oeste 1440, San Isidro
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment (MINAM), United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Piura Regional Government
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: In 2009, GlobalAgRisk received support from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Full Press Release) to conduct educational outreach and advance product development and pilot testing of El Niño Index Insurance for risk aggregators (financial institutions, business, members of the agricultural value chain) in Piura. The UNDP provided additional support to develop applications of El Niño Index Insurance to rural households, farmers associations, and local and regional government agencies in Piura to facilitate adaptation to climate risks and disaster risk management. El Niño Index Insurance for risk aggregators has been approved by the Peruvian regulator and is being offered by the Peruvian insurance company La Positiva, with reinsurance from PartnerRE. Other applications of El Niño insurance (e.g., for the public sector) will be offered in early 2011.
Adaptations.comments: The original product was designed to transfer the portfolio risks of rural lenders and thereby improve access to credit for smallholder farmers. However, the potential benefits of El Niño Index Insurance extend to many sectors due to the widespread damage and loss that can occur.

Adaptations.query: Ekurhuleni Metropolitan Municipality, Gauteng, South Africa
Adaptations.title: Adapting to and reducing the risk of Future Extreme Rainfall on Urban Flooding
Adaptations.description: The focus is to design a user-friendly climate- change guideline document for municipal decision makers. This guideline is meant to assist decision makers in improved management of the risks that currently arise with climate variability and those that may occur with future climate change. In this project, high resolution regional climate modelling will be applied to improve understanding of the effects that anthropogenic warming may have on thunderstorm formation over the Highveld. These modelled inputs will then be considered in a range of scenarios for planning purposes. These outputs will be workshopped with city managers so that a set of realistic scenarios can be developed. The critical dimension of this work will be the co-adaptive management and design of guidelines.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Wits University, Yale Rd, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa
Adaptations.source: "Tina Fatty, Project manager; ReVAMP home page: http://web.wits.ac.za/Academic/Science/Geography/Research/ReVAMP/ReVAMP.htm"
Adaptations.executing_agent: ReVAMP, The School of Geography, Archaeology and Environmental Studies , Wits University
Adaptations.success_factors: The extent to which we believe the project would be most effective does exceed the budget given by the Water Resource Comission (WRC). Any resistance from the Municipality will delay the project and have great effect on its success.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The effectiveness of the project is directly dependent on the municipality taking it into consideration and implementing the guidelines and recommendations.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No, the focus is on adaptation.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Many municipalities are already having issues with flooding and strained capacity to deal with the effects of thunderstorms. Infrastructure needs to be improved and planning needs to be done in any case. At this point it is relatively inexpensive to include climate change projections into planning now compared to retrofitting in the future.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: We are still in the initial phases of the project but we have had positive feedback from the municipality and they are willing to work with us on the project. The individuals in the team show positivity towards being able to merge the information and modeled data.
Adaptations.comments: a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Intrinsically – we are working directly with climate change models (from the CSIR) and finding how climate change will affect flooding and then adapting to that. We are working mainly with SAWS data for OR Tambo airport and Ekurhuleni Municipality. Downscaled Climate Models from the CSIR are used and these data are used in hydrological model to improve flood prediction and vulnerability. We are working directly with the municipality and we are using their reports and policy documents to attain baseline information.

The objectives are to create: •a broad understanding of climate change and its potential impacts within the affected communities •a programme of action-research through which participants design and implement their own plans and activities to build their communities’ resilience to climate change impacts and a low-carbon economy •a productive (rather than extractive) engagement of scientists and researchers with community questions •a productive engagement with relevant policy formulation processes •a creative documentation of their learning process •the broad dissemination of lesson and methodology through presentations, workshops, conferences, etc. and liaison with politicians and government officials.
