Adaptations.title: Climate change and water – risks, impacts and options for poor urban households
Adaptations.description: The study will look at the current drought in the southern coastal region of the Western Cape Province (southern Cape) to try to understand these dynamics between water scarcity, the responses by local authorities and the impact of those responses on urban poor communities. The overall aim is to contribute to building climate change resilience of poor urban communities by identifying risks, vulnerabilities and knowledge gaps associated with their access to water under climate change conditions. The project includes the following objectives: 1. Investigate and critically assess how each of the Municipalities in the declared southern Cape disaster areas has responded to the drought with respect to domestic water provision and how it is financed. 2. Pilot a consultative process with an affected community in the southern Cape to build an understanding of knowledge gaps and obstacles, share information, strengthen community structures and facilitate engagement with local authorities. 3. Develop resource materials which will assist vulnerable urban communities and municipalities in South Africa adapt to climate change and associated water scarcity. 4. Influence policy, practice and financing relating to water services in a climate-constrained world.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Nuttal Rd, Observatory, Cape Town, South Africa
Adaptations.source: Stephen Law and Jessica Wilson, EGM
Adaptations.executing_agent: Environmental Monitoring Group
Adaptations.success_factors: •Attitude of the municipalities •Interest from affected communities •Ability to influence local decision makers
Adaptations.limiting_factors: •Attitude of the municipalities •Access to information
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: •Yes, empowerment of the urban poor communities through education and awareness raising •Establishing a dialogue with local authorities •Identification of best practices that could be duplicated by other municipalities
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Currently not possible
Adaptations.comments: a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Increasing occurrence and severity of drought in the Western Cape is indicated in current climate change models.

Adaptations.title: Stewardship corridors for climate change adaptation
Adaptations.description: The project aims to create ecological corridors by forging partnerships with private and communal landowners, allowing some level of human use, while protecting biodiversity and allowing ecosystems to function. These will connect core conservation areas in the landscape, while improving the ability of species to adapt to climate change and allowing for long-term mitigation. The KZN Biodiversity Stewardship Programme is focused on building rural community-based initiatives that have tangible climate change adaptation value, through the core focus on improving biodiversity protection through capacity building, training and mentorship. Through the project six stewardship corridors have been estabished: Dalton Private Reserve, Red Desert Nature Reserve, Umgano Community Project, Somkhanda Game Reserve, Usuthu Gorge and the Upper Thukela community site (incorporating Mweni) Major implementation measures include: a)Removal of alien plants i.e. establishment and initiation of an alien plant clearing plan on each of the sites b)Improved grassland management on these sites, through the improved management of fire and livestock grazing training c)Training of field rangers to ensure improved biodiversity monitoring and patrolling in order to assist in understanding the role these areas play in climate change adaptation d) Improved biodiversity management on these sites, by developing and providing financial support for the implementation of a Management Plan for each initiative. e)Provide mentoring of field rangers to these community-based initiatives to ensure viability of these initiatives
Adaptations.contact_person: Kevin McCann, Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife, KZN Biodiversity Stewardship Programme manager
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 13053, Cascades, 3202, South Africa
Adaptations.source: Jessica Thorn, Project Officer, Climate Action Partnership, j.thorn@conservation.org
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife
Adaptations.funding_source: DG Murray Trust, via the Climate Action Partnership
Adaptations.success_factors: • Important role of community offices • Crucial that the needs of the communities are addressed • Importance of ensuring community ownership • By committing to a long-term Biodiversity Stewardship agreement, which will often restrict potential land-use activities to only those compatible with sound conservation management, the landowner / community must realize a benefit from the property, either through financial support or income-generation activities. • mentorship to the field rangers extremely valuable and has added much value to the motivation of the field rangers, and their abilities to perform their duties. • Community initiatives require significant support in building the capacity of middle management structures in order for them to take ownership of these projects, allowing long-term sustainability. • Collective support by several partners, such as in this case Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife, Wildlands Conservation Trust, CAP, DGMT as funders, allows community initiatives to gain momentum
Adaptations.limiting_factors: • Not enough engagement of the broader community i.e. limited understanding and awareness of the community on the reserve and biodiversity agreement area and what implications and benefits the reserve has for them. • The community structures still require significant support in terms of coordinating management meetings, implementing daily management activities • The challenge is to ensure that middle management in these communities are capacitated and take ownership of the projects
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, restoration of healthy ecosystems, soil carbon in grasslands, protection of indigenous forest, catchment and wetland management.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Yes the project has contributed to local job creation, education, training of field rangers and the improved access to water and other ecosystem services that support human well being.
Adaptations.comments: How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Climate change data was provided by SANBI (Guy Midgley), use of stress tests (e.g. 1 degree change, 2 degree change etc.) instead of scenarios Identification of the corridors was done by Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife

Adaptations.title: Scenario planning to assess the implications of climate change on land and water use within the agricultural sector
Adaptations.description: The overarching aim of the project is to identify and promote logical, financially feasible alternatives that will encourage wise, and sustainable use of land and water resources within the agricultural sector of the Garden Route. A significant portion of the agricultural sector within the Garden Route is currently financially unstable and environmentally unsustainable. In these areas inappropriate cultivation and irrigation, overstocking, and illegal activities are causing significant damage to natural resources. The first phase of the project, included an assessment of current agricultural practices in the Garden Route, and an assessment of farmers’ attitudes towards changing rainfall patterns and other climatic variables. The second phase utilizes these findings and make recommendations relating to mitigation and adaptation strategies based on scenario planning exercise among farmers and experts. Recommendations to the farmers, Agricultural Unions, relevant government departments and politicians will be suggested , based on the outcomes projected by the models. The project includes the following components: •In depth study of the perspectives and attitudes of farmers towards climate change •Workshop with farmers for development of existing and potential adaptation and mitigation options •Creating an environment for farmers that allows them to identify of adaptation and mitigation strategies •Scenario workshop with experts and farmers •Revisiting of adaptation and mitigation options and development of adaptation and mitigation strategies by the farmers
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr. Steve du Toit Head of Conservation, Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa, Western Cape Region
Adaptations.contact_adress: 31 Progress Street, George 6529, South Africa
Adaptations.source: "Dr. Steve du Toit; Final Report for Phase 1; Progress Report for Phase 2"
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Eden district municipality, Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa
Adaptations.funding_source: Eden district municipality, Table Mountain Fund
Adaptations.success_factors: •the way in which climate change information is conveyed back to the community •the creation of an interface between science and community in which a genuine dialogue can take place. •Leaders and champions among the farmers
Adaptations.limiting_factors: •the buy in of the farming community •the project is a process and needs continuity •financial resources for future development of the process
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: •Yes, farmers explore adaptation as well as mitigation strategies.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: •Better farming practices and environmental conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Not yet. However, there is a great interests from the farmers to be involved in the project. Not so much they see climate change as a immediate threat but they realize that overall things are changing and that old practices are longer sufficient. They also appreciate the interest in their lives and work.
Adaptations.comments: a)How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Project took a very practical approach and based the design of the project on literature review of IPCC findings (global and regional models). Important was the message that conditions will become hotter and drier.

Adaptations.title: Community Based Adaptation in Africa – The South African component
Adaptations.description: The project is part of a larger transnational project comprising eight African counties (Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda, Kenja, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zambia). It focuses on developing robust methodology on community based climate adaptation processes including monitoring and evaluation systems for adaptation projects. Indigo development & change is implementing the South African component and focuses much of its efforts on supporting small‐scale farmers of the Suid Bokkeveld that decided to explore ways to increase the robustness of their livelihood strategies. Activities include quarterly climate preparedness workshops in which farmers are introduced to climate science and share their own climate knowledge and the identification and actualizing resilient adaption strategies such as the cultivation of wild roiboos and the use of sustainable farming practices. Furthermore Indigo development & change focuses on policy strengthening through the establishment of an adaptation network through which it intends to monitor and influence sectoral and national climate change policies and through the communication of project findings to different levels of decision making.
Adaptations.contact_person: Bettina Koeller, director, Idigo development & change
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 350, Nieuwoudtville 8180, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: Indigo development & change (for the south African component) in collaboration with Associate Adele Arendse.
Adaptations.success_factors: •A participatory action research process: A Participatory Action Research approach ensured that the scientific predictions and findings contributed to the adoption of innovative strategies whilst the by the farmers. At the same time farmers were also able to make valuable contributions to research development and implementation. •Facilitation of active learning •Community ownership of the research and learning process
Adaptations.limiting_factors: •Resource constrains of implementation of technological solutions/ measures •Fact that learning is a ongoing process
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience New economic possibilities e.g. fair trade market, organic market
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Project has a high commitment to the learning process Farmers actively using seasonal forecasts and measure temperatures on a regular basis Farmers benefit directly from the project measures. The project has demonstrated that livelihoods are not only dependent on climate but a host of other factors which determine whether a particular livelihood strategy is successful. The methods used in the project where therefore aimed at unlocking the adaptive capacity of vulnerable groups by fostering problem solving capacity and stimulating a positive and empowered attitude using a participatory action research approach.
Adaptations.comments: a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Core component of the project is climate science and how to create a shared interface between local knowledge and science

Adaptations.title: Climate Change Proofing Water Services
Adaptations.description: The program aims is to contribute to the building of resilience of communities and government in the larger Cape Town area, in order to respond to the impacts of climate change on water, in just and developmental ways. Through a seminar series that brings representatives from civil society, academia and government together, the links between water and climate change, how we respond and the consequences of not responding, are explored. The program`s focus is on the impact of climate change on water services for urban poor communities. In this context the program has several key activities: • Action research on specific topics e.g. on Water Management Devices, which are being rolled out in Cape Town with little thought to the problems they present to many households. •Dialogue with local authorities and lobbying •Network building: work with urban and rural communities affiliated with the Western Cape Water Caucus (which brings together a wide range of NGOs and CBOs working on water issues in the city of Cape Town and surrounds) •Awareness raising and education: e.g. rainwater harvesting and water leaks repair
Adaptations.contact_person: Jessica Wilson, project manager, Environmental Monitoring Group
Adaptations.contact_adress: 10 Nuttal Rd, Observatory, Cape Town, South Africa
Adaptations.source: ": Jessica Wilson EMG project manager; EMG website: http://www.emg.org.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=47&Itemid=22"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Environmental Monitoring Group (EMG)
Adaptations.success_factors: •Attitude of the municipalities •Interest from affected communities •Ability to influence local decision makers •Funding for outreach programs
Adaptations.limiting_factors: •Lack of political will •Structural changes that need to take place in the national and global economy •Distributional effects
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: All activities around water conversation promote the usage of devices that are energy efficient and reduce the carbon foot printing (e.g. lobbying for biogas digesters at wastewater treatment plants)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Most activities focus on empowerment of previously disadvantaged communities at the political and individual level. Civil society is strengthened through democratic and participatory approach.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Impact of the program cannot yet be measured. However, the various activities have led to greater awareness among affected communities and local decision makers. The activities have also helped to connect and mobilize various citizen groups.
Adaptations.comments: a)How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? The program is based on a literature review of existing climate science on future climate change trend in the greater Cape Town area. What information about other adaptation projects should a web portal like ci:grasp contain? •Project that use an integrated approach (i.e. considers the existing local governance system and processes and do not just focus on a single climate stimuli) •Lessons learned •Innovative strategies and solutions

Adaptations.query: Central Karoo District Municipality, Beaufort West, Western Cape, South Africa
Adaptations.title: Riparian Habitat Rehabilitation project
Adaptations.description: The Riparian Habitat Rehabilitation Project was established to develop and implement strategies to rehabilitate key degraded riparian corridors in the Karoo. The project aims to combine sustainable water and biodiversity conservation with job creation and skills development amongst members of the local rural communities, in order to promote resilience of ecosystems and communities to climate change. The project will also act as an adaptation mechanism through the restoration of riparian ecosystems which will help buffer the Karoo communities to the predicted impacts of climate change. The re-vegetating and restoring the soils as well as connecting fragmented pieces of vegetation together will increased capability of the ecosystem to provide its services such as water filtration, reducing sedimentation and flood impacts and build resilience to the impacts of climate change. Specific Measures: 1.Develop and implement a strategy to regenerate degraded riparian zones on farms to create corridors of suitable habitat for Riverine Rabbit dispersal. 2.The ongoing development and propagation of seedlings of indigenous riparian plants in the Karoo Indigenous Plant Nursery in Loxton. 3.Training of nursery staff (i.e Seed collection, seed germination, seedling care, infrastructure management, trail maintenance, simple construction, etc.) 4.The formal mapping and recording of the planting and restoration process into a database, thereby allowing for the restoration process to be formally tracked and quantified over time. This includes monitoring for climate change adaptation. 5.Provide opportunities for members of the rural Loxton community to engage in conservation through skills training and providing employment opportunities, particularly for women and the previously disadvantaged. 6.Develop guidelines for landowners to rehabilitate degraded riparian corridors to promote long term sustainability of natural resources (e.g soil conservation techniques such as digging hollows, mashing)
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr Vicky Ahlmann, The Endangered Wildlife Trust,
Adaptations.contact_adress: EWT Regional Office, Church Circle, Loxton, Box 172, Loxton, 6985, South Africa
Adaptations.source: Jessica Thorn, Project Officer, Climate Action Partnership
Adaptations.executing_agent: The Endangered Wildlife Trust (EWT)
Adaptations.funding_source: CAP, CapeNature, Department of Environmental Affairs, Altron, Altech, Bytes, Powertech, Altech Netstar, MAZDA, National Lottery, SA National Parks, ZGAP, Rand Merchant Bank
Adaptations.success_factors: •Incentive structure i.e. benefits must be clear to the farmers •Restored habitat •Improved vegetation cover •Connectivity across the landscape
Adaptations.limiting_factors: •Buy-in of the municipality has been difficult •Nursing staff lacks independency and still relies on EWT for management support •Some farmers are of the impression that conservation-orientated NGO’s wants to prescribe to them how to manage their farm regarding stocking rates and predator-prey conflict instead of these NGO’s wanting to assist them in improving the lifespan of their veld through proper management.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Yes, improved access to water , habitat restoration, species protection (e.g. rivarian rabbit) and job creation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The evaluation of the project is done regularly by the EWT-RRP management.
Adaptations.comments: How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Considered in the creation of corridors and for monitoring for adaptation benefit.

Adaptations.title: Biodiversity and Red meat initiative
Adaptations.description: This project is part of the larger Namaqualand Wilderness Initiative (NWI) and focuses on the implementation of conservation stewardship. The project works with livestock farmers to find sustainable climate change adaptation solutions, and will encourage and enable farmers to derive tangible income benefits from implementing holistic farming practices. These practices include improved catchment management of wetlands and rivers to increase stream flows ground water recharge and water quantities, the removal of alien vegetation, ensuring appropriate livestock numbers and grazing rotations for herd and veld health, soil management including erosion control, fire management as well as setting aside portions of land for erosion buffers, biodiversity corridors, etc. CI staff provide the support function to the farmers which would normally provided by agricultural extension services, which is not available due to limited resources. The area is under threat from un-sustainable farming activities, such as overgrazing, ploughing up of wetlands and indiscriminate burning. These threats are addressed through the agreements, in which farmers undertake to implement certain conservation actions, like stock reduction, cooperation with wetland restoration and the formation of a fire management plan and alternative predator control methods. In return, CI implements enabling actions that will support farmers in adopting these better land management practices. Currently the BRI has 22 members, 2 of which are private farmers and the rest communal farmers. The area thus under better management at present, on which these 22 members farm, is roughly 9000 ha.
Adaptations.contact_person: Ronald Newman , project mamager, Conservation International
Adaptations.source: Jessica Thorn, Project Officer, Climate Action Partnership, Homepage of Climate Action Partnership: http://www.cap.org.za/default.asp
Adaptations.executing_agent: Conservation International
Adaptations.funding_source: Critical Ecosystem Profile Fund, United Way international, Citi Group
Adaptations.success_factors: •Incentive structures for farmers: people need to feel that they benefit form the stewardship agreements
Adaptations.limiting_factors: • The buy in of commercial farmers: Unlike communal farmers who have better access to water and farming techniques through the project the commercial farmers may nor depend on those incentives as they already have sufficient access to water and farming techniques •History of agonism between conservation sector and the farming community
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Project addresses other stressors such as water scarcity, land degradation through overstocking of animals. The project contribute to better water access, healthier livestock and has created new business opportunities for the farmers i.e. meat supply contract with the supermarket Woolworth. The project engages with landowners to secure areas under conservation and implement sustainable best practices on their farms while at the same time creating opportunities for local people to engage in alternative sustainable livelihood options as a means of adapting to climate change.
Adaptations.comments: a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project? Climate change information for the region was provided by Guy Midgley SANBI and the Climate Systems Analysis Group. The area has been identified as important to protect to ensure resilience against climate change, both in terms of species, which will be able to use the Kamiesberg as refugia because of its higher rainfall and cooler climate and in terms of human livelihoods, especially water security. The reason for the latter is that the Kamiesberg is the catchment for two important non-perennial rivers in the area, the Groen River and the Buffels River and is also home to a network of wetlands, important for catching water in the rainy season and slowly releasing it in the dry summer months.

Adaptations.title: KwaZulu Natal Forest Restoration Project
Adaptations.description: This project is a livelihoods program that helps poor and vulnerable members of our township and rural communities to grow a future for themselves. Wildlands Conservation Trust facilitators teach individuals in these communities how to grow indigenous trees from seed and care for the plants until they reach a certain height. These individuals are referred to as ‘tree-preneurs’. The trees are then traded back to Wildlands for food, clothes, bicycles, agricultural goods and tools, school and university fees. The trees are then either planted back into the communities or planted out in Wildlands’ forest restoration projects. The project supports the ongoing establishment of the Jobe, Ongoye and Buffelsdraai Carbon sinks and the identification and development of new sinks in southern KwaZulu-Natal and the Eastern Cape, using pro-poor development methodologies in pursuit of this overall objective. Wildlands calculates that for every hectare of the 1000 hectares being re-forested on the three sites, 3 to 41/2 tonnes of CO2 will be sequestered per year over a 20-year period. This amounts to 60 000-90 000 tones of CO2 removed from the atmosphere over the project’s lifespan Specific measures: 1.Support the growing, planting and care of 40 000 seedlings per annum, using the Indigenous Trees for Life pro-poor methodology, across the existing (and new) sinks. 2.The management of this process, with emphasis on the training and capacity building of the tree-preneurs and planting and caring SMME’s. 3.The ongoing development of the Wildlands Carbon Sink scientific process, to underwrite the medium – long term sustainability of the sinks. 4.The formal evaluation and development of new sink opportunities in the southern KZN and Eastern Cape regions. 5.Small sclale land owners plant trees on the boundaries of their properties which increases flood protection
Adaptations.contact_adress: P O Box 1138. Hilton 3245, South Africa
Adaptations.source: "Jessica Thorn, Project Officer, Climate Action Partnership; Homepage of Wildlands Conservation Trust http://www.wildlands.co.za/Programmes_TreesForLife_Map.aspx§overview"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Wildlands Conservation Trust
Adaptations.success_factors: Projects is a pro-poor and consultative process engaging the local communities and ensuring that they benefit from the tree planning (e.g. trading for credit scheme where ‘tree-preneurs’ get building materials, school fee credit etc. in exchange for seed collection and planting) Importance of Incentive structure for seed collection and planting Important role of local facilitator Required buy in by local community leaders
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Recent drought has limited the tree survival of plant seeds Low education levels in the communities
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Yes as the trading scheme improves the livelihoods of participating communities.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Internal: •Expansion of the program because of great take up in the communities •Socio-economic study

Adaptations.title: Collaborative governance: Managing the risks associated with flooding and sea-level rise
Adaptations.description: "The project aims to establish a collaborative governance system required for better decision making processes in the face of climate change risks in the City of Cape Town, South Africa. It will achieve this by strengthening institutional partnerships between civil society and government, increasing human and institutional capacity with regards to flooding and sea-level rise; and facilitating access to relevant knowledge at all scales. The focus will be on the governance system around decisions concerning economic planning and legislation, and formal and informal sector decisions involving investment and risk. Specific components of the governance system, that will receive attention, include: • the alignment and contradictions of local policies, • better coordination between government, civil society and private stakeholders, • a two-way flow of knowledge between scales, • balancing competing needs; and • the implications of social and gender inequalities. "
Adaptations.contact_adress: "Dept. of Environmental & Geographical Science; University of Cape Town, Private Bag X3, 7701, South Africa"
Adaptations.initiating_agent: University of Cape Town and Stockholm Environment Institute
Adaptations.executing_agent: University of Cape Town, Stockholm Environment Institute, City of Cape Town, Shack dwellers international
Adaptations.funding_source: Climate change adaptation in Africa (CCAA) programme funded by IDRC and DFID
Adaptations.success_factors: Cooperation between different groups including the City of Cape Town and residents in informal settlements.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: There is a history of political tension around flood risk management in informal settlements in City of Cape Town. This could limit the success of the project.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Collaborative decision-making, contribution to improvement in informal settlements.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Too early

Adaptations.title: DBSA Ledi sustainable communities
Adaptations.description: This project aims to assist the municipality in supporting climate resilient socio-economic development. This includes identifying and supporting those key economic sectors which are compatible with the region’s natural resource base and identifying the impacts of climate change on this resource base. It also includes managing social stresses caused by environmental degradation. The process has included developing socio-economic and environmental scenarios to 2030 and planning so as to manage the risks associated with these scenarios and ensure sustainable development. This Project is part of the DBSA (Development Bank of Southern Africa) Local Economic Development Initiative (LEDI).
Adaptations.contact_adress: Plein st., Caledon, South Africa
Adaptations.source: DBSA – sustainable communities – Ben Schoeman : bens@dbsa.org or Leon Lombaard leonl@dbsa.org website: http://www.twk.org.za/grabouw.htm
Adaptations.executing_agent: Theewaterskloof Muncipality
Adaptations.success_factors: Funding, access to renewable energy contracts
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Part of the project involves investment in renewable energy
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Socio-economic development, risk reduction, environmental conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Not yet.

Adaptations.title: Climate for Water: Using enhanced knowledge of climate variability for the benefit of water resource management
Adaptations.description: Focus on how to improve the uptake of climate information by water resource managers in the Western Cape, South Africa. OBJECTIVES: > Identification of the strengths and weaknesses in current climate prediction tools from the water resource management perspective > Assessment of the potential for improvement, or improved use, of climate prediction tools through incorporation of newly-gained local and international knowledge of climate variability > Identification of crucial knowledge gaps > Demonstration of beneficial use of improved climate prediction tools for water resource management and transfer of knowledge in this regard > Identification of longer-term research, capacity-building and/or educational initiatives which would enable water resource managers to derive maximum benefit from climate modeling and prediction tools
Adaptations.contact_adress: CSAG, Dept Env and Geog Science University of Cape Town
Adaptations.executing_agent: CSAG, Univ of Cape Town
Adaptations.success_factors: Acceptance and use by WR managers
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Resistance to using new sources, due to mistrust, ignorance and changing personnel
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Awareness of climate information sources to encourage access and dialogue for future requirements
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Large increase in awareness of climate variability and the uncertain nature of climate change impacts

Adaptations.title: Legislation
Adaptations.description: Climate change potentially threatens much of what may be broadly interpreted as legislated government service delivery or delegations (provision of water, transport, waste management, living environments) – within this legislated context little clarity exists on the legal framework of national, provincial and local government in terms of clear and actual roles and responsibilities in addressing climate change within this issue of service provision. With the completion of a range of climate change risk assessments and an increase in knowledge of future vulnerabilities, local government must consider its own liability and governance in terms of its delegations in approving plans and developments. One of the key drivers for change in the future will be legal accountability and liability for future impacts on private property and commercial developments. The City is often constrained in taking proactive action through layers of bureaucracy and legislation. Does the urgency of climate change create a new policy environment that will allow faster more directed action that is not slowed through bureaucratic means?
Adaptations.contact_person: Susan Mosdell, Leagal Services, City of Cape Town
Adaptations.contact_adress: Civic Centre, Foreshore, Cape Town, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: City of Cape Town, University of Cape Town, University of the Western Cape, EnAct
Adaptations.success_factors: Successful up take of recommendations
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Link in with carbon tax, etc
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Sustainable development, economic development, environmental conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Too early to say

Adaptations.title: Risk Assessment (Climate Adaptation Plan of Action)
Adaptations.description: In response to the impacts likely to be caused by climate change, the City of Cape Town (CoCT) has prepared a Draft Climate Change Adaptation Plan of Action (CAPA) which outlines the City’s approach to dealing with its vulnerability to Climate Change. The CAPA was prepared by the City’s Strategy and Planning Directorate and is intended to integrate climate change impacts into strategic planning and risk management activities within the City’s line functions and to assist the City to adapt to climate change by identifying climate change adaptation actions for implementation.
Adaptations.contact_person: Gregg Oelofse, Environmental Resource Management, City of Cape Town
Adaptations.contact_adress: 44 Wale Street, Cape Town
Adaptations.executing_agent: City of Cape Town, Golder Associates
Adaptations.success_factors: Successful uptake of recommendations, financial support to implement adaptation strategies identified
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, e.g. temperature increase, densification and green building guidelines to ameliorate heat island effect
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Sustainable development, economic development, environmental conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Too early to say

Adaptations.title: Local Authority Partnerships
Adaptations.description: Facilitate adaptation discussions between the five major coastal metro areas in South Africa with a view to collate, unpack and understand areas of common interest, concern and relevance with relation to adaptation. From the common areas, to refine and identify key themes and issues that would represent a collective position by the metro’s on adaptation areas: a. where assistance by national government is needed, b.  where a shift in national policy would facilitate improved or more effective resilience/adaptation at local level, c.  where a change in national frameworks or funding mechanisms would enhance adaptation/resilience at local level, d. where a change in legislation would promote/facilitate adaptation/resilience at local level. Identify and refine key areas that should form a basis for ongoing engagement and discussion between the local authorities as well as collectively with national government.
Adaptations.contact_person: Gregg Oelofse, Environmental Resource Management, City of Cape Town
Adaptations.contact_adress: 44 Wale Street, Cape Town

Adaptations.success_factors: Successful up take of recommendations
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: "Builds national networks; sharing experiences, knowledge, resources. "
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Too early to say

Adaptations.title: Freshwater / Marine Modelling
Adaptations.description: Current predictions suggest that Cape Town will experience an increase in the intensity and frequency of coastal storms combined with a mean sea level marginal increase over the next two decades. This City has completed a sea level rise risk assessment. However as a coastal City, the marine environment provides a key service to the City as a receiving environment for freshwater run-off and stormwater discharge. Burgeoning development and the attendant increases in the built environment within the City has resulted in an increase in run-off which places increased pressure on the City’s stormwater systems as well as its catchments. The City must begin to investigate and understand the potential combined effects of coastal storm surges, mean sea level rise and increased freshwater and stormwater flow. It is highly likely that these events would coincide given that the storms responsible for extreme rainfall events would often result in coastal wave surges. The combined effect of intense rainfall, high winds and storm surges has the potential to increase flood risk and infrastructure damage.
Adaptations.contact_person: Barry Wood, Catchment Management, City of Cape Town
Adaptations.contact_adress: Civic Centre, Cape Town
Adaptations.executing_agent: City of Cape Town, University of Cape Town (Climate Systems Analysis Group), PDRW
Adaptations.success_factors: Successful up take of recommendations, budget to implement
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Sustainable development, economic development, environmental conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Too early to say
Adaptations.comments: "You can find the ""Coastal Climate Change and Adaptation - A Sea-Level Rise Risk Assessment for Cape Town"" report here: http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/233"

Adaptations.query: Western Cape and KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa
Adaptations.title: An evaluation of the sensitivity of socio-economic activities to climate change in climatically divergent South African catchments
Adaptations.description: To increase the ability to respond to change is crucial in light of projected climate change and enhanced climate variability for South Africa. The country is faced with stressed water resources already and does not have a high level of capacity to cope and adapt. Consequently, a transition into a pro-active, adaptive management approach is imperative. It calls for a highly integrated management concept at catchment level, based on sound understanding of the interdependence of different key factors, such as economic and human needs, environmental requirements and management capacity under CC conditions. One starting point is a detailed analysis of the biophysical baseline and environmental as well as social-economic responses, in order equitably allocate water to all sectors. Knowledge of levels of vulnerability and policy driven opportunities of adaptability within selected catchments will bring comprehensive awareness of alternative strategies, for all of which adequate information management is also critical.
Adaptations.contact_person: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology (SBEEH)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Private Bag X01, Scottsville, 3209, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology
Adaptations.success_factors: Implementation has to be done by governmental bodies and stakeholders in the water sector.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Project designs actions through participatory processes in order to recommend actions that are feasible
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The proposed research outcomes will provide greater security for SOCIETAL and ECONOMIC ACTIVITIES under CC by decreasing vulnerability in each of the selected catchments. Pro-active management will assure any decision-taking momentum to be on a reasonable time and space scale and hence early adaptation to the different stresses initiated by projected CV/CC and associated land use and demographic changes can be introduced, taking into account uncertainties.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Only to be stated after project completion.

Adaptations.title: Developing water related climate change adaptation options to support implementation of policy and strategies for Water for Growth and Development
Adaptations.description: "The aims of the project are: > to develop an adaptive integrated management approach in order to take vulnerabilities into account for policy implementation, specifically focused on the governmental strategy “Water for Growth and Development” > to provide updated knowledge through multiple GCMs on the impacts of climate change in SA; > to provide guidelines for the reduction of uncertainties through improved monitoring and modelling; > to identify a suitable toolkit for vulnerability assessments and adaptation activities, taking ongoing, and future WRC (Water Research Commission) projects into account; and > to develop procedures and methodologies to mainstream climate change into governmental organisations, institutions and rules, specifically for the South African Department of Water and Environmental Affairs."
Adaptations.contact_person: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology (SBEEH)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Private Bag X01, Scottsville, 3209, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology
Adaptations.success_factors: Government needs to implement and mainstream accordingly.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: not known
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Economy: Creating awareness for water as a crucial and limiting resource to the country’s sustainable development - Reduction of vulnerabilities to CC through appropriate adaptation options - Ensure open and transparent dialogue on risks and needs for the economy to develop sustainability - Create stable point of departure for economic activities, hence growth and development Health: Improved management of water resources will lead to better water quality as well as its availability in the long-term. These are the two main issues stressed in the MDGs within the context of water. Environment: - Good understanding of the environment and potential impacts of CC, as well as more certainty in monitoring and modelling - Foster sustainable development by realising that water is a key resource for an environment which services society and the economy equitably with integrity in equal terms. This should lead to appropriate action with environmental issues being incorporated and receiving reasonable credit in the equation of sustainable and adaptive development.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Will only be possible towards the end of the project life time (2012/2013)

Adaptations.title: Global Climate Change and Water Resources in Southern Africa: Potential Impacts of Climate Change and Mitigation Strategies
Adaptations.description: Taking the view that water is South Africa’s key resource, this implies the need to adapt the management of this resource progressively as global climate change progresses, in order to maintain optimal levels of both resource protection and beneficial use of water for society. To better plan for the future, the following objectives are therefore proposed: +> to develop plausible climate change scenarios for Southern Africa +> to investigate the potential impacts of climate change on hydrological responses and associated water resources +> to investigate possible water related socio-economic impacts in a designated Water Management Area +> to recommend appropriate strategies to adapt to, and cope with , water related impacts of potential climate change and +> to determine whether effects of climate change can already be detected and to recommend appropriate monitoring systems for its detection. Furthermore, two case studies identified vulnerabilities and adaptive capacities of, first, a small scale community of irrigation farmers at Mueden and second, large-scale commercial farmers both in the Midlands of KwaZulu-Natal.
Adaptations.contact_person: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology (SBEEH)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Private Bag X01, Scottsville, 3209, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology
Adaptations.success_factors: None
Adaptations.limiting_factors: None
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Final project report is still being re-printed as it was the first and up to now only project that gave a complete (although reduced in complexity) overview of impacts and vulnerabilities in SA as well as more specific in two case study regions.

Adaptations.title: Participatory modelling for assessment of climate change impacts on water resources
Adaptations.description: The project aims to increase understanding and produce more relevant information for planning and adaptation to climate variability and change in relation to water resources through a participatory process. The project will adapt a catchment model after stakeholder requirements, use high-resolution regional climate change scenarios, assess the impact of participatory modelling on stakeholders’ perceptions of climate change related to water resources, explore how to increase stakeholder confidence and twin to a participatory modelling project in Sweden to assess similarities and differences. Results of the project will illuminate how stakeholder participation can be used in order to make climate change studies more relevant and useful to the local needs in developing countries. Co-operation will be in the form of exchange of personnel, joint planning and implementation of stakeholder interviews and workshops, sharing of experiences regarding climatological and hydrological modelling and stakeholder participation in the two HELP basins.
Adaptations.contact_person: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology (SBEEH) or Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute
Adaptations.executing_agent: University of KwaZulu-Natal (School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology) and Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (FoUh Research Department – Hydrology)
Adaptations.success_factors: Participation of stakeholders over the whole time period was partially a problem. Especially the commercial farmers community seemed reluctant to participate.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: None
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The knowledge transfer and discussions within the workshops have trained the participants and made them aware of the choices they have. This awareness can potentially lead to better informed decisions which in the context of the participants could lead to optimized environmental conservation, small farmers further economic development, community development.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: This would need feedback from the workshop participants after the finalization of the project.

Adaptations.title: Towards Defining the WRC Research Portfolio on Climate Change for 2008-2013
Adaptations.description: The growth in awareness of global-change issues as a result of IPCC studies and reports has introduced a new and rapidly evolving focus for climate and atmosphere research in the past decade. This necessitates redefining climate-related, and particularly global climate change-related research thrusts and programmes that the Water Research Commission of South Africa (WRC) supports on behalf of the water sector. Perhaps the largest change is the need for such research to be integrated into a larger body of climate-change research nationally, which embraces a multi-sectoral, multi-level approach in order to deal with multiple stresses and enable the country to successfully face up to challenges that climate change is expected to pose over coming decades. This document sets out the background against which the development of a climate change research portfolio with a water-sector focus was initiated and pursued, with the assistance of a wide complement of stakeholders.
Adaptations.contact_person: Water Research Commission of South Africa
Adaptations.contact_adress: Private Bag X03, Gezina, Pretoria, 0031, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: Consultant G.C. Green
Adaptations.success_factors: Provision of funding by government
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Political Will
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Creating stability and benefit of climate change on all sectors
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The last two annual calls for projects by the WRC seem to reflect significant consideration of this initiative.

Adaptations.title: Municipal Climate Protection Programme (MCPP)
Adaptations.description: "The eThekwini Municipal Climate Protection Programme (MCPP) was initiated in 2004 as concern was increasing with regards to potential climate change impacts. The programme has been developed in a phased manner; Phase 1 focused on the assessment of local climate change impacts; Phase 2 focused on the development of an adaptation workstream with three focal areas of action: municipal level, community–level and urban management intervention. The Headline Climate Change Adaptation Strategy (HCCAS), was the fist of the municipal level interventions. This highlighted key interventions required by the municipality to adapt to climate change. Following the HCCAS of phase 2 it was recognised that sector specific adaptation plans needed to be developed in order to start mainstreaming adaptation planning into the municipality. To test this approach three pilot sectors, health, water and disaster management, where chosen, and sector specific adaptation needs identified. Work is also being pursued investigating the impacts of climate change on the city’s globally significant biodiversity and related open space system. Recognising that the resilience of local communities would also need to be increased, a parallel process of community – based adaptation was initiated, focused on livelihood analyses, food and water security issues and community reforestation projects. A third focal area has also been developed which focuses on a variety of urban management interventions, including: sea level rise modelling, a pilot green roof project and a variety of greening initiatives. The next phase of the project, phase 3, involves the development of a tool which will allow for the simulation, evaluation and comparison of strategic development in the city in the context of climate change, and Phase 4 will work towards mainstreaming climate change concerns into city planning and development."
Adaptations.contact_person: Debra Roberts, Environmental Planning and Climate Protection Department, Development Planning, Environment and Management Unit, Ethekwini Municipality
Adaptations.contact_adress: 166 K.E. Masinga Road, Durban, 4001
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The Environmental Planning and Climate Protection Department of the eThekwini Municipality
Adaptations.executing_agent: eThekwini Municipality
Adaptations.funding_source: eThekwini Municipality and various external donors
Adaptations.success_factors: First of all, the complexity of impacts makes it difficult for the eThekwini Municipality to formulate appropriate adaptation interventions. Secondly, adequate institutional, human and financial resources, as well as political will, are critical for successful implementation of adaptation interventions in the Municipality.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The project has found that in order to deal with potential climate impacts some institutional restructuring of local government activities is required. At the same time, adaptation interventions should be implemented in a manner which embeds the current activities and processes in the day to day operations of the municipality. Various sectors within the municipality have different capacities and thus different abilities to integrate climate change adaptation into their activities. A limiting factor for the project is therefore the provision of adequate institutional, human and financial resources necessary for restructuring and for the mainstreaming of climate change adaptations.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Some of the projects that have been initiated under the MCPP act to reduce emissions, namely the Community reforestation project (carbon sequestration), Green Roof pilot project (natural cooling, thereby reducing the need for electrical cooling and the use of electricity) and 2010 FIFA Soccer World Cup (creating awareness around energy efficiency and influencing new developments, making them more energy efficient).
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Focus on and prioritization of climate change adaptation can make the eThekwini Municipality climate smart, and thus more able to deal with climate impacts and projected climate changes. At the same time, the assessment of municipal sector activities and the work towards finding suitable adaptation interventions can also work to highlight shortcomings in municipal structures and activities, and thus trigger necessary improvements in the Municipality. What is more, the strengthening of institutional, human and financial resources necessary to integrate climate change adaptation into municipal structures and activities also work to strengthen the general capacity of the Municipality. Positive side-effects can also be seen more directly in for example the socio-economic and catchment management benefits of the community reforestation projects.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The first two phases of the project have provided a good insight into local climate impacts, and have brought about an understanding of the necessity of developing sector specific adaptation plans. The last two phases are already well advanced, but at a point where it is still too early to evaluate the full outcome. The initiation of several community projects show that the MCPP goes beyond report writing and top down analysis.
Adaptations.comments: Climate science has been the basis for all the adaptation projects.

Adaptations.title: Stakeholder’s engagement to inform and promote climate change community-based adaptation for the city of Johannesburg
Adaptations.description: "This project aims to provide some insight on how to situate vulnerability, disaster risk and climate change adaptation efforts within the city’s communities. More specifically, it aims to; provide a better understanding of the perceptions and comprehension of climate change amongst civil society; improve resilience to climate change at the community level in order to address the impacts of change; and to strengthen the capacity of the local authorities to integrate climate change concerns in local and city wide planning, as well as their ability to budget for cost-effective policy responses."
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The project is a Climate Change Adaptation Policy Fellowship, awarded by START (Systems for Analysis , Research and Training)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Executed by Linda Phalatse as a City of Johannesburg employee, with supervision from Coleen Vogel from Witwatersrand University
Adaptations.funding_source: START (Systems for Analysis , Research and Training)
Adaptations.success_factors: The success can be measured by the understanding of the concepts on the side of the targeted stakeholders.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The short timeframe can be a limiting factor.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Social welfare, engagement of stakeholders strengthened capacity and understanding.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Adaptation can not be seen as an outcome but as a long term process to build resilience of communities to climate change
Adaptations.comments: Adaptation does not need a new development strategy. At the City of Johannesburg there are existing strategies that can include adaptation to make adjustments in policies, cultures and attitudes that will establish enabling conditions accompanied by infrastructural changes.

Adaptations.title: Sedgefield Desalination Plant
Adaptations.description: Sedgefield, a seaside town on the Garden Route in the southern Cape, situated within the Knysna local municipal area, effectively ran dry in January 2009 when the Karatara River stopped flowing. While potable water was tankered in to Sedgefield, the Knysna Municipality sought an urgent solution, and alternatives were examined to implement rapid, short and medium term options. An innovative, demand-based approach was developed to address the water supply crisis in Sedgefield, and this proved to be cost effective and achievable in the time scales required. The approach included the construction of the Sedgefield desalination plant, a single-pass, reverse osmosis (RO) system that can produce potable water of 1. 5Mℓ/day. Initially the plant will be operated by the supplier for one year – which will probably be extended to three or five years. The team is justifiably proud to have commissioned the plant within three months: the contract award was signed on 1 October 2009 and the plant was functional on 18 December 2009, in time for the anticipated holiday peak in December 2009.
Adaptations.contact_person: Neale Perring, Director Technical Services, Knysna Municipality
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 21 , Knysna , 6570. RSA
Adaptations.source: Neale Perring, Director Technical Services, Knysna Municipality
Adaptations.executing_agent: Knysna Municipality
Adaptations.funding_source: Knysna Municipality funds and grant funds
Adaptations.success_factors: Funding, statutory environmental support and the declaration of a disaster area.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Insufficient funds for implementation and operation. Sea water source within economic distance.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Emission increase rather than decrease due to the plants high electricity usage.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Provides additional water capacity for the growth of the town.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Been very successful and received a high profile of publicity.
Adaptations.comments: This was a reaction project.

Adaptations.title: Waru Waru cultivation and irrigation system
Adaptations.description: Applying indigenous knowledge for agriculture in flood-prone mountainous areas. The Waru Waru System is an irrigation method in dry areas. The project involves the restoration of earthworks about one meter high and 10 to 15 meters wide. These are surrounded by wide, shallow canals which, when filled with water, ensure a microclimate that acts as a buffer against night-time frosts and provides moisture during droughts and drainage during the rainy season. The canals also act as barriers to keep out crawling insect pests.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Av General Santa Cruz 659 Lima 11, Peru
Adaptations.executing_agent: CARE Peru

Adaptations.title: Jal Abhishek Abhiyaan
Adaptations.description: Jal Abhishek Abhiyaan is a convergence program launched by the Government of Madhya Pradesh in 2006 that aimed at promoting community awareness and self initiative towards water conservation and augmentation and converges existing departmental schemes for the same. The program disseminates information about techniques, and facilitates community action for implementing an action plan with funds from different sovernment schemes and public contribution. The stated aims are: (1) To construct water conservation structures through convergence of funds from different line departments. (2) To conserve water through these structures thereby contributing towards ground water recharge. (3) Equitable distribution, usage and saving of the existing water resources.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Panchayat and Rural Development Department,2nd Floor, Vidhyachal Bhavan,Bhopal (M.P.) 462004 INDIA
Adaptations.executing_agent: Rajiv Gandhi Watershed Mission in the Department of Panchayati Raj and Rural Development
Adaptations.funding_source: Convergence of funds from different line departments
Adaptations.success_factors: The success of this program depends on institutional and financial factors such as awareness genaration, community mobilisation and available of funds for construction of water harvesting structures, and sustaining the works over time
Adaptations.limiting_factors: JAA is not a scheme and depends on convergence with multiple government schemes for fund availability, and successful community implementation, and requires leadership and high amounts of administrative effort. This may limit the program in the long run if ways of reducing the coordination effort are not found.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Some impacts possible - e.g. improved soil organic carbon in fields through field bunding, increased ground water levels can potentially reduce energy consumption for irrigation,but are often offset by increased use.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win Win. This program will help in conservation, augmentation and maintenance of water resources in the state with community involvement
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Activities supported include dugwells, farm bunding, farm ponds, percolation tanks, plantation, check dams, ground water recharge pits along with dugwells. The quality of work varies across districts and leadership in districts is key. The program promotes adaptation to climate change by focussing on community and individual water conservation practices and introducing climate reseilient cropping practices
Adaptations.comments: None

Adaptations.title: COMMUNITY GENE FUND
Adaptations.description: The COMMUNITY GENE FUND programme has tried to restore the critical control over seeds in the hands of the rural women in general and dalit women in particular. This programme has laid heavy emphasis on biodiversity in agriculture and recovery of traditional landraces [crop varieties]. Within a span of two years about 500 women who participated in this programme have recovered over 50 traditional landraces and have set up banks of traditional seeds in 30 villages.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 101, Kishan Residency, 1-11-242/1, Street No. 5, Shyamlal Buildings Area ,Begumpet, Hyderabad - 500 016 ,Andhra Pradesh, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO with womens groups
Adaptations.funding_source: Government: Ministry of Rural Development, Government of India.
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional: availability of land and willingness of community to grow traditional seeds and appropriate pricing policy
Adaptations.limiting_factors: improper seed distribution network
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win since the gene fund will be helpful in restoring traditional land races even in a no climate change context
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Crop varieties in cultivation have increased. Over 60 varieties are under active cultivation now as against 25-30 varieties when the programme began in 1996. Diverse cropping which was becoming an exception is now increasing again. • Marginal lands have become productive. Lands which used to produce crops worth Rs.250-300 per acre have started producing crops worth over Rs.4000. • Seeds that can crop about 1000 ha have been stored in villages within a span of two years and three cropping seasons. • Traditional varieties add diversity and nutritive value to the womens household menu. Forgotten foods from the past like Korra, Aargulu, Bailodlu are being consumed again. • A rethinking on the harmful effects of the new agricultural practices has started. People are shifting back, from tractor ploughing to bullocks. { Deep plough through tractor upturns the fine and fertile top soil and brings up the hard subsoil while shallow ploughing through bullocks keeps the fine soil on the upper layers itself } • Many people have started approaching the sangham women for traditional seeds, thus helping promote a local self reliant seed economy.
Adaptations.comments: The community seed banks and other agricultural programs have strengthened the internal input cycle. Mulching, earthworks, use of farmyard manure has reduced erosion and degradation. A cumulative impact of all these efforts can be seen in the fact that no member of DDS sanghams need to suffer hunger since her own access to food has multiplied at least four times. In times of distress members can bank upon the grain support that these programmes can bring together.

Adaptations.title: Vulnerability and Adaptation experiences from Rajasthan and Andhra Pradesh
Adaptations.description:
"The program aims at strengthening the resilience of local communities to conditions of unfavorable weather, like adverse alterations in temperature and precipitation leading to more frequent occurrence of drought and to use the experiences for policy development processes at various level. The 3 specific objectives of the program were:
• To build community level capacities with regard to best practices and technologies in 
the agriculture, water and energy sectors. 
• To optimize the service delivery system and services at selected sites in semi-arid areas 
in India. 
• To promote policy dialogue and advocacy at different levels.
The project in located in the Indian provinces Rajasthan and Andrah Pradesh."
Adaptations.contact_person: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Embassy of Switzerland, Chandragupta Marg, Chanakyapuri, New Delhi 110021, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGOs and technical institutes
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional: Training and skill development on location specific adaptation measures and management of weather abnormalities, mainstreaming gender considerations, and education and social mobilization, Technical support on new irrigation technologies, climate proofing
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Weak community institutions, reluctance to change cropping pattern and type
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret as the project helps in increasing the resilience of communities to the impacts of climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project has highlighted the need for location specific adaptation measures and for participatory research and knowledge management. The V&A interventions have also highlighted the need for mainstreaming gender considerations in all interventions. Women will suffer more from Climate Change, since they have been traditionally in charge of collecting water, fodder and fuel wood, and have been shouldering the responsibility for farm animal care and post-harvest technology. All interventions should therefore be pro-nature, pro-poor and pro-women.
Adaptations.comments: "You can find the following five V&A interventions on ci.grasp too: Community Based Institutions; Pasture Land Development; The System of Rice Instensification; Water Resource Management; A Weather-based Farming Model for Communities "

Adaptations.title: Van Panchayats
Adaptations.description: The Van Panchayats is a Community Forest Management in Uttarakhand emerged from the conflict between the people and the Forest department over the use of the forest resources. VPs were formed after notification of the Van Panchayat Rules, in 1931 and today there a total of 12089 VPs (Uttarakhand Forest Statistics 2008-09) managing a forest area of approximately 5449.642 sq. km. These Van Panchayats help in protecting the forest area close to villages and also in the equitable sharing of the resources among the stakeholders. Projects implemented by various agencies with these VPs help strengthen these institutions and manage forest resources.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Forest Department Uttarakhand, 87, Rajpur road, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, 248001
Adaptations.executing_agent: local government, people and NGOs
Adaptations.success_factors: Community cohesion to form and manage VP. Seem to work better in oak forest areas which provide leaf litter and fodder inputs into the agro-economy.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Areas with community conflicts make it hard to form and manange Van Panchayats. Require some financial inputs for regular forest management, which is rarely available.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: management of local forests by VPs can improve carbon sequestration
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option, helps in sustainable management and conservation of forests by the local user groups
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: the success of this institutional arrangement can be judged by the number of van panchayats that have been formed, mostly on demand by the community, from 1931 till date, and covering 13.63% of the states forest cover. By incentivising local communities to manage their own forest for their own long term benefits, they elicit local investment, mostly in kind, for protection, regulation of harvesting, fire fighting, etc. VPs are also involved in afforestation and reforestation activities in their forest. In recent years the FD has taken steps to re-engage with VPs and also form Joint Forest Management groups and there has been some concern about the erosion of VP autonomy.
Adaptations.comments: "Various programs are being implemeted in different Van Panchayats. One such successful program is running in 15 Van Panchayats in the Almora district of Uttarakhand;Strengthening Rural Community Managed Natural Resource Institutions (Van Panchayats) for enhancing rural livelihood in Uttarakhand which aims at developing income generating activities, conserve the globally significant biodiversity, reduce women drudgery. enhancement in natural resource based rural livelihood."

Adaptations.maintenance_costs: "yes,""The valve and washers to be replaced"
Adaptations.title: Treadle Pump Programme
Adaptations.description: """Treadle Pump"" is a foot operated water lifting device that can irrigate small plots of land of small holders in regions that have higher water table (not deeper than 25 feet). A low cost system, simple in design and easily manageable it appropriately answers the irrigation need for the small farmers. With an internal rate of return of 100% and a benefit cost ratio of 5, ""Treadle Pump"" is an ideal investment for small land holders whose savings are as small as $12 to $15. The project is located in the Indian provinces Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, West Bengal and Orissa. IDEI has established a reliable manufacturing base for producing good quality pumps."
Adaptations.contact_adress: First & Second Floor, C-5/43, Safdarjung Development Area,New Delhi 110 016
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO-IDE
Adaptations.funding_source: multiple sources and user financing of product
Adaptations.success_factors: """Institutional:reliable manufacturing base for producing good quality pumps, effort required to use should be low, wide distribution marketing and repair network, adequate demand for the pump, involvement of multiple players."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: absence of distribution network, dip in water table would make it unusable, lack of technical support
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: low consumption of energy: foot operated water lifting device
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win, low energy efficient water pumping device for areas with high water table
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The cost of a treadle pump and tube well is about Rs 1,200 to 1,300 (£14 to £15), A study has suggested that the annual income of a family has risen by Rs 11,000 (£130) on average as a result of using a treadle pump. This represents a substantial increase since the annual income for many farming families in this region is as low as Rs 7,000. Many farmers have doubled their income, and a few have seen it rise ten-fold. Farmers can easily pay back the Rs 1,200 to 1,300 cost of the pump from their increased earnings.Use of treadle pump allows farmers to cultivate all the year round thus increasing their cropping intensity to 200-300%,and never leave their land fallow.The income impact of the Treadle Pump technology varies across households and regions, but US$100 per year is the conservative estimate of the average increase in the annual net income of each household. Since inception in 1991, around 750,000 treadle pumps have been adopted by small holder farm families.
Adaptations.comments: From year 2000 IDE have embarked on a gradual phase-out programme, based on mutual trust between IDEI and its approved manufacturers to ensure quality assurance of treadle pumps. The phase-out programme involves imparting training to the manufacturers and other IDEI channel partners so that they are able to thoroughly grasp and inculcate a high degree of quality consciousness, especially in the context of strict issuance of warranty cards and instruction manual to the farmers and their empowerment for demanding quick replacement of defective pumps.

Adaptations.title: A Weather-based Farming Model for Communities (WFMC)
Adaptations.description:
"With the objective of building local level capacities of the farming communities to cope with agro-meteorological crop production risks, the M. S. Swaminathan Research Foundation experimented with the establishment of village level mini agro-met observatories in selected project villages namely, Kothur and Srirangapur in Andhra Pradesh and Kundai and Amda in Rajasthan on a pilot scale. 
The underlying hypothesis was that the data collected from the meteorological instruments by the community over a period of time would help the community to develop weather based thumb rules for taking appropriate farm decisions based on simple weather parameters like rainfall, wind speed, temperature and relative humidity.
About 10 farmers, considered to be ‘Agro-met Farmers’ who used the agro-met data extensively for their farm operations and a set of ‘Control Farmers’ played a key role in demonstrating the utility value of the locally generated information besides providing useful insights on the how the enhanced capacity of the local communities, well managed local institutions help broadening the understanding of climate risks and in providing in-situ solutions. A variety of information was gathered from both the ‘Agro-met’ and ‘Control’ farmers practicing cropping system of maize (Kharif)-wheat (Rabi) through a pre-tested questionnaire and personal interviews at various stages of the crop production process."
Adaptations.contact_person: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Embassy of Switzerland, Chandragupta Marg, Chanakyapuri, New Delhi 110021, India
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGOs and technical institutes
Adaptations.funding_source: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Time frames to assess the effectiveness of adaptation strategies at field level should perhaps be longer than the four year span of the V&A project. It will be important to monitor and quantify impacts over a longer period so that the lessons and insights drawn could be extrapolated for wider implications at the national and international levels.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Analysis of data revealed that by adhering to farm decisions based on data generated from the mini observatory, the ‘Agro-met’ farmer group did record a benefit cost ratio of 1.2, from the cropping system of maize-wheat, while it was 0.96 for the ‘Control’ farmers. The partial budgeting analysis also indicated that there is an estimated positive change for the ‘Agro-met’ farmer group. 
The agro-met experiment proved to be an example of a new knowledge based community empowerment that enhances its coping capacity. Thus the knowledge developed is useful to understand the role of both simple technological improvements that the local communities could relate to with appropriate training and the significance of sensitizing people to adverse impacts of climate change will help manage climate risks more prudently at the local level."
Adaptations.comments: "This project is one part oft the ""Vulnerability and Adaptation experiences from Rajasthan and Andhra Pradesh"" by the SDC."
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Test. Gelöschtes Projekt! Kommentar verschickt?

Adaptations.title: Integrated National Adaptation to strengthen the Resilience of Coastal Wetlands
Adaptations.description: "To support the decision making process and public policy for coastal wetlands in Mexico to prevent Climate Change impacts. The project evaluates the environmental services provided by coastal wetlands in the Gulf of Mexico and the cost of hydro-meteorological extreme events; develops scientific research oriented to give solutions for the rehabilitation of coastal wetlands; enhance bridges between the academia and decision makers; generates climate scenarios and develops adaptive capacity. "

It determines the flooding areas in the Urban Zone before a meteorological event. It helps with the contingency plans for the State.
