Adaptations.title: Rehabilitation of Integrated Tank Management Systems in the Kalivelli Watershed
Adaptations.description: The project aimed to increase the water storage capacity of tanks in the Kalivelli watershed. To rehabilitate and manage tanks, community based management institutions were formed and entrusted with the physical work and distribution of water in an equitable manner. The project cost was shared by Palmyra/ICEF and the landholders in a ratio of 7:3. 24 tanks and 4 ponds with a command area of 1687.47ha were worked on along with 2 large channels (‘maduvu’). A total of 2,97,256 m3 of soil excavated, 19,920 m of bund length strengthened, 8885 m of supply channels cleared, encroachments removed in two villages and storage capacities increased by 10.01 million cubic feet.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Aurobrindavan, Auroville - 605 101, Vilupram District, Tamil Nadu
Adaptations.source: "(1) Foundation for Ecological Research, Advocacy and Learning, http://www.feralindia.org/files/manuals/ResHandbk.pdf; (2) India Canada Environment facility, http://envfor.nic.in/divisions/ic/icef-report.pdf, Pg 37 "
Adaptations.executing_agent: Palmyra
Adaptations.success_factors: "Institutional: formation of local water user associations and SHGs and their effective management; financial: contribution of 30% by the user group"
Adaptations.limiting_factors: "without regular maintenance the tank will silt up and stop functioning effectively; functioning of the institutions is essential for maintaining records, user fee deposit and checking inequity in distribution of water (may create conflicts amongst the users)"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: increased irrigation capacity leads to increased agricultural outputs and income in the hands of local communities.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The total number of tanks rehabilitated were 31 as against the proposed 23, there was increased water storage leading to a increase in crop production due to better irrigation. These factors reflect the success of the project in achieving the desired results.
Adaptations.comments: "The project was monitored by FERAL (Foundation for Ecological Research, Advopcacy and Learning). The project site was monitored using GIS based techniques to see the change in cropping pattern, the area of water storage; vegetation cover and drainage pattern were mapped. A five year database for the soil, water quality and meteorological information was created. Indicators were idetified for monitoring with the help of the primary stakeholders; In the final year of the project staff gauges to measure water level and silt traps to measure sedimentation rates were set up. "

Adaptations.query: Ramanathapuram, Tuticorin, Pudhukottai, Tanjore and Nagapattinam in Tamil Nadu
Adaptations.title: Increased Water Harvesting and Diminished Desertification
Adaptations.description:
"The project aims at increasing irrigation water availability through formation of water user associations (WUA) for tank rehabilitation and management in the drought prone coastal areas of Tamil Nadu. WUAs restore tank structures
like tank storage capacity, bunds, sluice outlets, and surplus weirs to their original design standards. Women SHGs (self-help groups) also dig farm level ponds. These steps increase water retention/holding capacity of the tanks and farm ponds, providing water for drinking and domestic purposes and also for irrigation to reduce crop damage. Groundwater levels are also improved. The community based organizations formed would be responsible for future maintenance of the tanks. The project is expected to benefit approximately 12500 families with a total population of 75000."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 18, Pillaiyar Koil Street, S.S.Colony, Madurai - 625 010
Adaptations.executing_agent: DHAN foundation, European Commission and Oxfam Novib, the Netherlands
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional: the formation of new water harvesting structures and their maintenanace depends upon community institutions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: alternate supply of water and no shortage in supply: the need to restore the structures arose only because of shortage of water
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: ground water recharge, reduced salinity ingress, irrigation water for crop production leading to economic benefits
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: 25 community-level tank management associations have been organised since the beginning of the project to rehabilitate village tanks, and 40 women’s self-help groups have been organised in order to excavate 250 new farm ponds. In the Seranthai hamlet in Kothankulam Panchayat of Ramnad district agriculture is the primary source of income and food. Due to degraded tank condition and fluctuating monsoons the total area under irrigation reduced and the community members were forced to migrate. The Seranthai Tank Farmers Association in cooperation with the families restored a tank increasing water holding capacity to 7500m3. Approximately 80 households with an average of 0.3 hectares of paddy fields are assured with single crop yield and the water is also provided for livestock. In Shanmuga Kumarapuram there was a chronic water shortage both for drinking and domestic use, the villagers formed an association and dug up a new pond with a water holding capacity of 7000m3 supplying drinking water for about 11 months a year to 430 inhabitants.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: We are really sorry again. Cause of some database-trouble some Information in this project are lost. Could you please provide the missing information again? The lost information are Project classification, Project costs, Problem-solving capacity and reversibility and Additional information. Thank you very much for your excellent work.

Adaptations.title: Kutch Drought Proofing Project
Adaptations.description: Kutch Drought Proofing Project was initiated to establish self sufficiency in food, fodder and water in the villages of Kutch and thus to increase the capacity of the villagers to withstand calamities. The activities included in the project are earthen farm bunds, stone outlets, grass seeding on bunds, grassland development, Check dams, percolation tanks, bore-well recharging, contour bunding of fields, renovation of existing water harvesting structures and construction of new structures. Use of drip irrigation systems is being promoted for water management. This will result in increasing groundwater levels, reduce salinity ingress and will make communities resilient to drought conditions.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Dr. Rajaram Campus, Nr. St. Xaviers English Primary School, Bhuj (370001) – Kutch
Adaptations.executing_agent: Kutch Nav Nirman Abhiyan, NABARD
Adaptations.funding_source: Prime Ministers National Relief Fund, Ministry of Rural Development
Adaptations.success_factors: effective local institutions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: need basic funds to implement
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: soil carbon benefits would need to be evaluated
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: fulfills water needs, environmental conservation by groundwater recharge and reducing salinity ingress.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "26 villages have been made drought proofed for more than 2 years, 4 villages for more than 1 year; grassland development in 13 villages covering 353 ha; farm bunding in 492 ha, fodder bank in 10 villages with 1112 cattle population; 785 ha of farm land has been treated; 1850 ha of land contributes to soil and loisture conservation. To evaluate the efficiency and success of the project in fulfilling the water needs of the people a rapid assessment of the structures was undertaken. This also helped in understanding the future line of action in the project villages."
Adaptations.comments: The Kutch Drought Proofing project was initially planned for the year 2001 but had to be postponed due to the earthquake in that year.Training and capacity building of the project implementing NGOs was done with the support of Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP). The programme is presently focusing on strengthening the forward linkages of the producers of milk in Kutch through the collaborative approach of Abhiyan and Saurashtra Kutch Dairy Project (a wing of National Dairy Development Board). Under this a fodder bank programme was started in 10 villages to make them self-reliant in terms of fodder availability in drought years. The initiatives of the pprogramme are compiled in a quaterly published magazine (ChatAchat).

Adaptations.title: Construction technique of the Qingzang railway
Adaptations.description: A new way (by controlling the conduction, radiation and convection to cool the roadbed and lower the temperature of permafrost) to keep the frozen soil embankment stable was put forward by the project. Various techniques named the rock embankment structure, the rock and gravel slope protection structure, the ventilated embankment structure, the sun visor structure and the hot rod plus insulation materials were developed. Experiments on the air convection effect of the block-stone embankment, chimney effects of the rock slope protection, heat shield effects of the gravel slope protection, forced convection mechanism of the ventilated embankment structure, enhanced heat transfer mechanism of hot rod were conducted to establish a series of theories, techniques and methodology to evaluate the cooling of roadbed engineering.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 320 Donggang West Road, Lanzhou, Gansu
Adaptations.executing_agent: Cold and Arid Regions Environmental and Engineering Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies:
"No synergy to the mitigation
of climate change"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: It has provided the anticipated effects.
Adaptations.comments: Research results have played an important role in the construction of Qingzang railway.

Adaptations.title: Domestic use of sea water
Adaptations.description: Qingdao is located in the coastal region (west of Yellow Sea) and belongs to one of the urban areas facing severe problems of fresh water shortage in China. The project will construct demonstration samples in Qingdao city to show how the fresh water can be replaced by sea water in domestic usage (especially, water used to flush toilet).The project applies the main techniques developed by the Institute of Seawater Desalination and Multipurpose Utilization to reach the provision of 0.85 million m3 water per year to a community with about 33 thousand residencies. 1, When pumping water from the sea, the beach caisson means (use submarine sands to conduct the depth filtration to sea water) are adopted in the project. In this way, it is sure less suspended materials and pollutants enter into container. 2, Smells of sea water mainly resulted from alga, bacteria and microbe etc. Experiments show that both the sodium hypochlorite and chlorine dioxide can be used as a disinfector to remove the odor. 3, A storage pool for treated sea water is constructed in the community water station. The frequency conversion water supply system, which was designed to regulate water flow according to the real time water consumption and make sure the constant pressure at the pipe end, is used to provide water to the household.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Eastkeyan 1 road, Nankai, Tianjin
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The Institute of Seawater Desalination and Multipurpose Utilization, SOA
Adaptations.executing_agent: The Institute of Seawater Desalination and Multipurpose Utilization, SOA
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Sea water treatment technique is still in its trial stage.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project can provide the anticipated effects.
Adaptations.comments: The project is expected to save fresh water of about 0.276 million Ton per year.The cost of fresh water is 1.618 Yuan/T, while the cost of toilet using sea water is 0.33 Yuan/T

Adaptations.title: Agricultural Water Saving Technology in the Oasis
Adaptations.description: "The project aims to develop water saving technology (for example, low pressure low flow emitter; the root irrigation, storage water irrigation and low-cost micro-irrigation control hardwares, etc.), and to establish demonstration area to train a multidisciplinary, cross-sector, high-level agricultural water saving research team. The general objective of the project is to improve the effective usage of water in arid area."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 403 Nanchang road, Wulumuqi, China
Adaptations.executing_agent: Science and Technology Department of Xinjiang organizes 17 research agencies
Adaptations.success_factors: financial pre-condition
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: After application of new technology developed by the project for the 3,500 acres of cotton and fruit field in Xinjiang, it is expected to increase effectiveness of about 5 billion yuan to 6 billion yuan per year.

Adaptations.title: Harnessing slope farmlands and demonstration of effective ecological agriculture key techniques in the upper Yangtze
Adaptations.description: "Aiming at coping with the constraints on socioeconomic sustainable development in rural area, the project will try to develop efficient regulation techniques of slope croplands and key supporting technologies of ecological agriculture. The project consists of three main technical parts, e.g., micro-topography reconstruction sub-project for soil and water protection; infrastructure supporting technology development sub-project for efficient ecological agriculture ain hilly regions; production technology development sub-project for high crop yields in hilly regions and five other sub -projects mainly for application and demonstration of new technology."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 9 Renminnanlu Siduan, Chengdu
Adaptations.executing_agent: "Chinese Aacademy of Sciences; Ministry of Water Resources"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The mid-term project evaluation meeting, which was held in September 2009, has proven that initial results were already achieved by several sub-projects.

Adaptations.title: China’s National Climate Change Programme
Adaptations.description: Observed climate trends in China are outlined and impacts of climate change on agriculture and livestock industry, forest and other natural ecosystems, water resources and coastal zone are analyzed. For enhancing the capacity of adaptation to climate change, the following countermeasures are put forward: 1, Strengthen farmland infrastructure, adjusting cropping systems, selecting and breeding stress-resistant varieties and developing bio-technologies to increase the improved grassland,restore the grassland suffering from degradation, desertification, and salinity and increase the efficient utilization of agricultural irrigation water. 2, Strengthen the natural forest conservation and nature reserve management, establish key ecological protection area, implement key ecological restoration programs, and enhance natural ecological restoration. 3, By rational exploitation and optimized allocation of water resources, building-up of new mechanism for infrastructure construction (anti-flood engineering systems in the large rivers), popularization of water-saving (high standard for drought relief technique in the farmland), etc, to reduce the vulnerability of water resources to climate change. 4, To reduce the losses from sea level rise through scientific monitoring of sea level change, regulation of the ecosystem of marine and coastal zone areas, rationally exploiting the coastline and coastal wetland, construction of coastal shelterbelt system (such as construction and expansion of mangroves) etc.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 38 Yuetannan jie, Xicheng, Beijing, NDRC
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Government of People’s Republic of China
Adaptations.executing_agent: National Development and Reform Commission and other 17 bureaus etc
Adaptations.success_factors: establish the National leading Group and regional administration system to Address Climate Change
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: the project focuses on emission reductions
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: project outlines the objectives, basic principles and key areas of actions in mitigation of and adaptation to climate change in China

Adaptations.title: Yangtze River Basin climate change vulnerability and adaptation action
Adaptations.description:
"The action aimed at finding a way to mitigate climate change impacts on human being, forest, fresh water, urban area, etc. Detailed information is given on the adaptation methodology of agriculture to climate change: 
1, It was found that with the increment of CO2 concentration and air temperature, the maize and wheat yields are expected to decrease in the Yangtze River Basin, but the rice output remains stable. Therefore, it is recommended to compress the area of maize and generally expand the rice cultivation area.
2, With the increase of heat resources in the river basin, change cropping/harvesting system once per year into twice or even thrice per year to raise the food production.
3, Planting the rice with longer growth period would increase the yield of about 17-23% compared to that of original crop varieties in the river basin."
Adaptations.contact_adress: WWF China Programme Beijing Office Wen Hua Gong,Beijing Working Peoples Culture Palace
Adaptations.executing_agent: "CAS (Institute of Geographic Sciences and Natural Resource Research; Institute of Mountain Hazards and Environment;Institute of Applied Ecology), CMA, Fudan University"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project evaluates the vulnerability of water resources, agriculture, forests, grassland, wetlands and coastal city to climate change, and some general strategies and specific measures are put forward to adapt to climate change.
Adaptations.comments: This is one of the ten actions in HSBC Climate Partnership project

Adaptations.title: Climate Change adaptation strategies in Jiangxi province
Adaptations.description:
"Summarize the observed climatic trends in the last half century and predict the possible trends in the future 50 years in Jiangxi Province. By analyzing the impacts of climate change on economy and society, the following adaptation strategies are put forward:
1, adjust the industrial structure (promote the Machinery, information, electronics, telecommunications, tourism, and other high-tech, high value-added industries) to make sure the increment of energy efficiency.
2, Strengthen the agricultural infrastructure (irrigation and drainage system, water storage system), adjust the cropping systems (increase the greenhouse vegetables, fruits and fish facilities, raise the multiple cropping index) and develop the anti-drought , anti-water logging, anti-pests/diseases, anti-frozen species and high temperature resistant varieties to improve the agricultural adaptability of severe weather.
3, Controlling of soil erosion will be done by
combination of the engineering measures, biological measures and the ecological self-repair, take into account the development of the rural economy, Promote the Lake and the Rivers shelterbelt project, along the highway and rail Green Corridor project, the East River source Shelterbelt project.
4, Consolidate the return fields to lake, convert the land for pasture project results, enhance the natural protected areas, forest home parks and wild animal protection project, the lake wetland restoration project, establish the main ecological effect area to promote the conservation of biological diversity.
5, Complete flood control and drought hazard warning/commanding system, establish a more comprehensive hydro-biological safety system, improve the standards of flood controlling levees to enhance the adaptation to climate change."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 68 Zhongshanxilu, Nanchang
Adaptations.executing_agent: Jiangxi climate change monitoring and assessing centre
Adaptations.success_factors: institutional, environmental, financial pre-conditions
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: adaptation strategies are outlisted
Adaptations.comments: The project outlines climate change adaptation measures which will completed by the year 2015.

Adaptations.title: Adapting to climate change in China (ACCC)
Adaptations.description:
"This project run by UK DIFD aims at improving development of climate change science in China and raise awareness of the need to factor in climate change to broader government policy.
Risk assessments, based upon vulnerability and impacts are produced at national and provincial level and climate risks are integrated into planning and management within the three project provinces. Chinese policymakers and key stakeholders are informed and made aware of the ways to address climate change adaptation within China’s development process.Communication and information sharing is an important component of the project which is implemented mainly through: publications and trainings. China, UK and other countries in Asia and Africa share knowledge to further develop climate change adaptation approaches."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 30th floor South Tower, Kerry Centre, 1 Guang Hua Road, Chao Yang District, Beijing, 100020, China
Adaptations.executing_agent: the Chinese National Development Planning Commission China Meteorological Administration Chinese Academy of Agricultural Science Chinese Academy of Social Science Many other local partners in provinces
Adaptations.funding_source: "Research and Evidence Division of DFID; DFID China; Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC); UK Department of Energy and Climate Change (DECC)"
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions, strong and reliable partnership between the different agents (particularly with NDRC)
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Low levels of awareness on climate change adaptation at national and provincial level
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option because that kind of measure will have to be implemented anyway
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"This project focuses on climate change
adaptation in a broad sense; the main goal
is to help developing climate change adaptation
policies, so that they will be integrated into
China’s development process. Therefore the efficiency of the project is difficult to assess on the short term, and moreover as it has just started, it is probably too early to do any evaluation."
Adaptations.comments: This project has a much bigger magnitude than its predecessor (see project 1) and unlike project 1 it has NDRC (National Development & Reform Commission - Important Chinese Political institution) as a main project partner which gives much more garantees concerning the outreach of the results.

Adaptations.title: Mainstreaming climate change adaptation in irrigated agriculture project
Adaptations.description: The objectives are to enhance adaptation to climate change in agriculture and irrigation water management practices through awareness-raising, institutional and capacity strengthening, and demonstration activities in the Huang-Huai-Hai Basin (3H Basin) in China. This aims to help mainstream climate change adaptation measures, techniques, and activities into the national Comprehensive Agricultural Development (CAD) Program which is China’s largest national investment program in irrigated agriculture. There are three components to the project. The first component is the identification and prioritization of adaptation options. The second component is the demonstration and implementation of adaptation measures. The purpose of this component is to introduce, demonstrate and implement the specific adaptation measures in selected demonstration areas, and adjust and integrate appropriate adaptation measures into the implementation of the Third Irrigated Agriculture Intensification Project (IAIL3), in order to reduce vulnerability to climate change in the 3H Basin. Finally, the third component is the mainstreaming adaptation into national CAD program and institutional strengthening. The component will aim at integrating and mainstreaming climate change adaptation into the national CAD program, including a series of capacity building, technical assistance, knowledge sharing, public awareness activities, and preparation of a national climate change adaptation plan for CAD by State Office of Comprehensive Agricultural Development (SOCAD), with the cooperation of Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), the National Development and Reform Commission(NDRC) and Ministry of Finance (MOF) national climate change adaptation offices.
Adaptations.contact_adress: World Bank Office, Level 16, China World Tower 2 China World Trade Center No.1, Jian Guo Men Wai Avenue Beijing 100004, P.R.China
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Finance, State Office of Comprehensive Agricultural Development (SOCAD)
Adaptations.funding_source: World Bank GEF (Global Environment Facility) - SCCF (Special Climate Change Fund)
Adaptations.success_factors: institutional and perhaps financial pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Adaptation measures for agricultural development, such as the adjustment of crop structure, may be controversial initially
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project seems to have reached good results up to now. Good government support and good cooperation with farmers (many trainings were organized with a significant participation of farmers).
Adaptations.comments: "The project is located in the whole Huang-Huai-Hai Basin in China: 2 counties in each of 6 provinces (Jiangsu, Anhui, Hebei, Shandong, Henan, Ningxia) The sub-project ""Rainfall collection works and water harvesting"" you can found on ci:grasp too: http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/106"

Adaptations.title: Ground water management (Under Shanxi Integrated Agricultural Development Project)
Adaptations.description: This project is one component of a bigger project called Shanxi Integrated Agricultural Development Project. The activities of this component aim at demonstrating viability of more productive and efficent irrigation techniques, and supporting the participating farmers in adapting to climate change impacts. Skills training aim at helping around 5,000 farmers to reduce their dependence on the scarse water resources. Poor households are given subsidies to adopt water-saving irrigation technology. The capacity of water resources bureaus is also strengthened to improve sustainable management of groundwater resources. The experience and findings will be presented in a national workshop in Shanxi and summarized in an Asian Development Bank knowledge product.
Adaptations.contact_person: Akmal Siddig, Lead Professional (Natural Resources Management)/PAU Head, East Asia Department, Agriculture, Environment & Natural Resources Division, ADB
Adaptations.contact_adress: Asian Development Bank, P.O. Box 789 0980 Manila, Philippines
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Government of the Peoples Republic of China
Adaptations.executing_agent: Shanxi Provincial Government
Adaptations.funding_source: Water Financing Partnership Facility (the governments of Australia, Austria, Norway, Spain, and administered by ADB)
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Farmers are not willing to adopt new techniques
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.comments: This project is a component of a much bigger project. It is the only component adressing climate change adaptation. It is a really a new initiative and apparently activities in the field havent started yet.

Adaptations.title: Weather Insurance Project
Adaptations.description: The overall goal of this project is to enable the insurance sector in China to provide commercially viable forms of weather insurance to households and companies for hedging them against negative financial effects due to extreme weather situations. To this end the project embarked on a integrated approach by addressing legal and regulatory issues that might hamper the market launch of index-based insurance as well by supporting re- and insurance companies and other financial services providers to develop demand-oriented forms of weather index-insurance for the respective target groups in the pilot regions.
Adaptations.contact_adress: GTZ GmbH, Tayuan, Diplomatic Office Bldg. 1-15-1, no.14. Liangmahe Nanlu, Chaoyang District, Beijing, 100060, China
Adaptations.executing_agent: GTZ,CMA/NCC,CIRC
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of willingness of the local partners such as CIRC to implement the project
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: It is difficult to evaluate the project at the moment

Adaptations.title: Piloting Climate Change Adaptation to Protect Human Health
Adaptations.description:
"The objective of this global project on public health adaptation to climate change is to “increase adaptive capacity of national health system institutions, including field practitioners, to respond to climate-sensitive health risks”. This will contribute to the broader goal of ensuring that “Health sectors are able to cope with health risks resulting from climate change, including variability”.
The project in China aims at promoting an integrated strategy to improve adaptation to climate change, with a focus on preventing increasing morbidity and mortality during heatwaves.
The main objective is to strengthen the national capacity to respond to the increased health risks due to heatwaves in China. It will focus on reducing the impacts of climate change on cerebro-cardiovascular diseases in the project regions through implementation of heatwave forecasting and early warning systems designed to protect human health."
Adaptations.contact_person: Pradeep Kurukulasuriya, United Nations Development Programme Global Environment Facility Unit (UNDP-GEF) Energy & Environment Group
Adaptations.contact_adress: BDP 304 East 45th Street, 9th Floor New York, NY 10017 USA
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Environmental Health and Related Product Safety, China CDC, and the World Health Organization (WHO)
Adaptations.executing_agent: World Health organization Ministry of Health China Centre for Disease Control and Prevention Local governments, including health, meteorological,education, transportation, and finance departments
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Limited interest of the Chinese government in the potential health impacts. Lack of communication and cooperation across sectors, decision-makers lack the necessary knowledge on the likely health impacts of climate change in China.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Synergy (though quite limited) with climate change mitigation through awareness raising which will make people more aware of the different ways to consume less energy
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: It is difficult to evaluate the project at this stage, as it is just about to commence
Adaptations.comments: Pilot projects are located in Barbados, Bhutan, China, Fiji, Jordan, Kenya and Uzbekistan.

Adaptations.title: Enhanced strategies for climate-proofed and environmentally sound agricultural production (C-PESAP): Agricultural development
Adaptations.description: This project is one component of a much bigger project “The China Climate Change Partnership Framework”. This component aims at designing and developing strategies and actions to adapt to climate change for selected provinces in the Yellow River Basin. This will be done through the development of a multi-sector Information System (IS) and of suitable agricultural practices to address C-PESAP (Climate-Proofed & Environmentally Sound Agricultural Production). An operational plan will be developed which will be fed into the IS to share with stakeholders. Trainings of field technicians and farmer associations in selected agro-ecosystems, and development of pilot suitable agricultural practices with farmers/farmers associations will be organized. The authorities will be involved to develop a roadmap for communities.The strategies generated will serve as examples for replication in other areas.
Adaptations.contact_adress: UN Coordination Policy Advisor RC Office, China
Adaptations.executing_agent: FAO NCCCC (National Coordination Committee on Climate Change) Ministry of Agriculture Ministry of Environment UNESCO ESCAP (United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific) ILO
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of willingness of local stakeholders to adopt new agricultural practices
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy with climate change mitigation
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.comments: "The complete title is: ""China Climate Change Partnership Framework--Component 3.4 Enhanced strategies for climate-proofed and environmentally sound agricultural production (C-PESAP): Agricultural development in selected agro-ecosystems of the Yellow River Basin """

Adaptations.title: Pastoral Risk Management
Adaptations.description:
"The project objective was to reduce the regular animal losses of pastoral herders in Qinghai due to recurrent natural disasters, and to build up their own capacities to prevent damage from natural calamities. The project also contributed to the overall improvement of herders’future livelihoods, reduced environmental degradation and an increased capacity for risk prevention and management at local and provincial levels.
Immediate objectives were:
• To develop a comprehensive pastoral risk management strategy, including annual risk management contingency plans for two counties in Qinghai Province as pilot areas for further replication;
• To develop and field test in selected villages, together with herders, innovative risk management techniques and improved livestock production options to improve rational utilization of the family-based ranches so as to reduce losses when disasters occur. Some specific outputs were to develop annual over-winter risks management plans for the pilot villages and counties and consolidate them into a pastoral risk management agenda for Qinghai Province; to improved winter preparation and risk prevention capacities within pilot villages through institutionalized and implemented: A: Rangeland improvement measures, B: Increased forage production and storage in herders’ households, C: Methods and mechanisms developed for adjustment of herd and flock structures before winter; to develop a risk warning system for herders; to organise a training programme to increase stakeholder capabilities and skills in risk prevention and management."
Adaptations.contact_person: Jeremy Swift, Stephan Baas and Yongong Liu, The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Adaptations.executing_agent: FAO, Rural Institutions and Participation Service Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) Department of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry (DAAH), Qinghai
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of willingness of local stakeholders to adopt new agricultural practices
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy with climate change mitigation
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.comments: The project description doesnt expressly mention climate change adaptation. Nonetheless, it clearly takes into account climate variability (winter temperature for example) or more frequently Natural disasters (such as snow disaster, spring drought).

Adaptations.title: Guangxi Nanning Urban Environmental Upgrading (Guangxi Nanning Urban Infrastructure Development)
Adaptations.contact_person: Satoshi Ishii, Urban Development Specialist East Asia Regional Department, ADB
Adaptations.executing_agent: Nanning Municipal Government
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of institutional support
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy with climate change mitigation
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: A comprehensive assessment has been done in December 2009 during the mid-term review of the Project. The project implementation is generally satisfactory. The project is likely to attain its objective of enhancing the urban environment and public health in Nanning City.
Adaptations.comments: The project description doesnt expressly mention climate change. Nonetheless, as it deals with floods that are meant to increase under changing climate conditions, it is indirectly a climate change adaptation related project.

Adaptations.title: Flood and Watershed Management
Adaptations.description: The development objective of the Project for China is to improve the protection of property and safety of people from flood events and bring about sustainable utilization of land and water resources within Xining Municipality. There are six components to the project. The first component of the project is flood control and management. This component will include both structural and non-structural activities including dikes strengthening, access roads, cross dike structures and water level control structures, an integrated flood warning system, and riverbank landscaping works. This component will also improve the level of flood protection in selected areas of Xining Municipality and in a comprehensive flood warning system. The second component of the project is wastewater collection. This component will support the construction of about 72.5 km of both wastewater and urban storm water collection pipelines to intercept an estimated 33 million tons of wastewater and storm water drainage, which at present flows freely to the river systems in the Municipality, to deliver to existing or proposed wastewater treatment facilities. The third component of the project is participatory watershed management. This component will involve three integrated sets of sub-activities to allow communities to respond to varying soil and water conservation, land use, socio-economic conditions in the 17 individual highest priority sub-watersheds within the municipality. The fourth component of the project is institutional strengthening and capacity building. This component will support construction of a flood warning center, provision of office equipment, consulting services, technical study and research, and training and study tours. The fifth component of the project is resettlement and environmental management. This component will support resettlement and rehabilitation of displaced persons in connection with the implementation of the project, and managing the adverse environmental impacts resulting from the implementation of the project through establishment and operation of environmental management offices, provision of consulting services, and carrying out monitoring and supervision. The six component of the project is project management. This component will support development and operation of a management information system and strengthening the capacity of Xining Municipality to carry out procurement, construction, supervision, quality control, financial management, and monitoring and evaluation with respect to the project.
Adaptations.executing_agent: Xining Development and Reform Commission
Adaptations.funding_source: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
Adaptations.success_factors: Good and efficient cooperation with Xining Municipality
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of institutional support Unwillingness of the population to participate
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy with climate change mitigation
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: It is difficult to evaluate the project at this stage
Adaptations.comments: The project description doesnt expressly mention climate change. Nonetheless, as it deals with floods that are meant to increase under changing climate conditions, it is indirectly a climate change adaptation related project.

Adaptations.title: Integrated Natural Resources and Environmental Management Sector Development (INREM) Program / Strengthening Climate Change Resilience in the INREM Program
Adaptations.description: "The Project aims to improve livelihoods in the upper river basins through effective provision of ecosystem and biodiversity services. Rural livelihood improvements in the upper river basins will be sustained by increased incentives to upland communities and indigenous peoples, improved LGU management capacities and private sector participation to stabilize and/or increase beneficiary access to ecosystem services and through improved land-use and natural resource management efficiencies. Project outputs include: (i) Environmentally sound river basin and watershed management and investment plans developed in four river basins (ii) Supportive policy and regulatory framework established at the national, provincial and municipal levels; (iii) Smallholder, commercial and institutional investments increased in conservation and economic productivity"
Adaptations.contact_adress: ADB Southeast Asia Department, 6 ADB Avenue Mandaluyong City, Philippines
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR)
Adaptations.success_factors: "Planting and maintaining the right species of trees; Community acceptance of the project; and Proper/smooth coordination among project players"
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret option -Biodiversity conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: No output yet
Adaptations.comments: This is basically a natural resource management project for sustainable development and not a consciously conceptualized Climate Change Adaptation project. However, maintaining watersheds as everybody knows is very important in preventing flooding and erosion.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: The project is very wide with different aspects. It would be better to split such big projects up into smaller parts, e.g. one project for each output. Location: Which river basin do you mean in the description? No need for multiple tags or was there an bug in ci:grasp protocol? You mentioned as success factor planting the right species of trees, but in the whole description was nothing said about reforestation or similar. Of course, you can focus on the Natural Resource Management part with reforestation, but then you must describe it more in detail. You could mention that this is only a part of a bigger project in one short sentence in the Description or in the comment field.

Adaptations.title: Programme for Sustainable Management of Natural Resources (Promotion of Agriculture)
Adaptations.description: The region encompassing the provinces of Leyte and Samar is known nationwide for its production of raw materials such as coconut and Manila hemp. However, these raw materials are rarely processed locally, and therefore contribute neither to local value adding nor to creating more employment opportunities. The Government of the Philippines wants to introduce measures to counter this development, promote sustainable use of the nation’s natural resources, establish nature conservation areas, and productively integrate impoverished highland populations in efforts to preserve the remaining forest areas. The project has two components: 1) Promotion of agriculture, and 2) Disaster preparedness in Eastern Visayas
Adaptations.contact_adress: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), Department of Agriculture (DA), Department of Agrarian Reform (DAR), Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), Local Government Units (LGUs)

The two components of the project alone can not give an extern person the understanding of the ongoing steps. Please describe activities and measures in detail. In the “Information source” field you write website. Please give us an address/link or at least the name of the website.

Adaptations.title: Mainstreaming Climate Change Adaptation in Watershed Management and Upland Farming
Adaptations.description:
"Being an archipelagic developing country composed of more than 7000 small islands, the Philippines is highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate related events such as tropical cyclones and El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO). Impacts of these climatic events are further aggravated by the deteriorating condition of the watersheds in the country. The most vulnerable sectors are the upland farmers who have very limited resources and who rely on rain as source of water for farming and domestic use. To reduce vulnerability of upland farmers to climate change and at the same time ensure that the watersheds can continue to deliver the environmental services foremost among which is water, adaptation strategies for the watershed and upland farmers need to be developed. The overall goal of the project is to promote climate change adaptation by upland farmers and watershed managers at the national and local levels in the Philippines. Specifically it intends to: (1) Assess the impacts of climate variability and extremes and climate change to crop yield of farmers in Lantapan, Bukidnon and water yield of Manupali watershed, Bukidnon; (2) Develop adaptation strategies for Landcare farmers and concerned Manupali watershed managers/concerned institutions to minimize risks and maximize opportunities associated with climate change; (3) Promote a multi-stakeholder approach in the formulation of climate risk adaptation through participatory approaches and capacity building of Landcare farmers and watershed managers; (4) Develop risk communication products targeted for the watershed planners and Landcare farmers; and (5) Contribute to the preparation of the Philippines’ Second National Communication by providing case materials.
Results indicate that climate extreme and variability affect the crop yield, farm income, soil quality and health of the upland farmers. Adaptation strategies undertaken by upland farmers to cope with the impacts depend on the nature of climatic event and the extent of their dependency on land based livelihood. Sources of information of the stakeholders as regards, climate variability and extremes and climate change include the different capability building activities of the project such as: (1) IEC during barangay assembly meetings; (2) Focus group discussions; (3) seminars; (4) trainings; (5) distribution of climate change magazine (in English and local dialect); and (6) showing and distribution of video (Heeding the cries of the skies in local dialect and English)."
Adaptations.contact_adress: World Agroforestry Centre Philippines Country Office, Khush Hall, IRRI Los Banos Laguna
Adaptations.executing_agent: University of the Philippines (UP) Los Banos, Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), Landcare Foundation Inc.
Adaptations.funding_source: United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR)
Adaptations.success_factors: Community acceptance and active involvement in the project
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret option – Watershed management/biodiversity conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Concrete Climate Change Adaptation strategies by upland farmers not specified
Adaptations.comments: Documents indicate focus on community awareness raising. Outcome on Climate Change Adaptation strategies rather vague
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Please describe the provided measures and highlight the technical advice aspect in the description. Or is this more an Assessment report? What means IEC? Please explain all abbreviation you use.

Adaptations.title: Iloilo Flood Control Project
Adaptations.description: The Iloilo Flood Control Project (IFCP) is a project of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) in Iloilo City, Philippines. The project aims to reduce flood damage, which has been an almost yearly occurrence. Financed by the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), the project is being implemented in two stages. The first stage is being handled by China International Water & Electric Corp. which consists of the 4.75-kilometer Jaro floodway and the improvement of six bridges and two rivers. The second is implemented by the Hanjin Heavy Industries Co. Ltd. of Korea which includes improvement of the Jaro River mouth, Iloilo River, Upper Ingore Creek and the construction of the Carpenter’s Bridge.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Public Works and Highways
Adaptations.success_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified

Adaptations.comments: Infrastructure almost completed, no report on forestation component

Comments and Evaluation are the same. It seems this entry is only for the evaluation part. If there was a bug in ci:grasp please contact us.

Adaptations.title: Laguna de Bay Community Watershed Rehabilitation Project
Adaptations.description: The project will finance the purchase of emission reduction credits produced from a series of small scale environmental improvement projects implemented by local government and private sector entities in the Laguna de Bay Region, particularly waste management and reforestation projects. The purchase will be done under a framework agreement with the Laguna Lake Development Authority which will act as an intermediary in the process of project identification, qualification and monitoring and will manage the carbon finance revenues.

Incentive structure means measures that promote and enable small-scale and individual adaptation through specific motivations. Or is this Natural Resource Management? Please choose a sector? At least water, right?

Adaptations.title: Disaster Preparedness in the Eastern Visayas
Adaptations.description: The project builds on disaster preparedness activities already in progress. It cooperates closely with the population affected, with local institutions, national authorities, local administrations and other organisations. The following results are being targeted: 1) Local administrations will apply measures to reduce and prevent risks, 2) Six flood early warning systems are to be fully installed and function reliably, 3) Tried and tested methods of disaster preparedness will be employed, such as flood-resistant rice varieties, 4) Knowledge and awareness of local natural hazards and risks will be increased, 5) Disaster risk management will be integrated in the local land-use and development planning process. Examples of relevant activities include the drawing-up of hazard maps, the provision of equipment for and training in flood early warning systems, training for emergency situations, information campaigns, budgeting in the municipal budget and the integration of disaster preparedness in the school curriculum.Systematic cooperation with the other components of the environmental sector programme guarantees optimum utilisation of resources, at the same time strengthening existing partnerships with local and international institutions in order to achieve the common goals. Results achieved so far: 1) regional map that identifies natural hazards has highlighted and impressed the situation upon policy-makers and the population at risk, 2) manual on earthquake-resistant construction techniques is aiding builders and property owners, 3) Villages have been given assistance in drawing up emergency plans and analysing risks, 4) Two of the six flood early warning systems planned have been in operation since April 2009. The remaining four systems will enter service in the coming months, 5) The initial test phase for integration of disaster preparedness into local school curricula has been completed. Location:Leyte, Southern Leyte, Easter Samar, and Northern Samar.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Environment and Natural Resources, National Economic Development Authority, Housing and Land Use Regulatory Board, Office of Civil Defense, National Disaster Coordinating Council, Department of Interior and Local Government
Adaptations.funding_source: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), Bundesministerium für wirtschaftliche Zusammenarbeit und Entwicklung (BMZ), European Union-Disaster Preparedness European Commission humanitarian aid department (EU-Dipecho)
Adaptations.success_factors: Active participation of project partners, Local Government Units, and the communities
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret option – Freedom from fear of flash floods
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Six enhanced low cost flood early warning systems installed in identified flood-prone areas, two more are being prepared, trial of 16 flood resistant rice varieties ongoing in 2 provinces, major watersheds and flood prone areas mapped, trainings on search and rescue operations conducted, capacity building of project partners ongoing.
Adaptations.comments: This project builds capacities of project partners specially the Local Government Units in disaster risk reduction and in Climate Change Adaptation.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: "That is a really huge, but very interesting project with many different parts. So it would be better to split it up and provide more information for each part. I would suggest at least: (1) flood early warning systems (2) flood-resistant rice varieties (as an example methods of disaster preparedness, if there are more, these too) (3) Knowledge Rising, including the integration into school curricula (4) Disaster Risk Management integrated in the local land use and development planning (5) Developing Hazard maps as basis for adaptation decision support “Manual on earthquake-resistant” isn’t related to climate change adaptation. In the “Information source” field you write website. Please give us an address/link or at least the name of the website. In “Synergies to Mitigation” you write High (climate risk reduction). I can’t get the point; a risk reduction could not result directly into mitigation, right? Are there indirect effects? "

Adaptations.title: Strengthening Philippine City Capacities to Address Climate Change Impacts
Adaptations.description: "Project Specific objectives are as follow: 1) Create synergies and links on climate change policies founded on global/ regional best practices; 2) Introduce the urban dimension into national climate change policies/strategies anchored on global/regional best practices; 3) Design and develop appropriate social and physical infrastructure for Sorsogon City to become climate change resilient City through implementation of a climate change responsive city shelter plan; 4) To pilot innovative climate change mitigation and adaptation technologies and mechanisms in the urban/coastal setting; 5) To codify a set of adaptation options for vulnerable human settlements.The main activities include: 1) Identification and mobilization of global/regional partners and documentation of good practices for sharing to national and local government; 2) Development of the national and city climate change profile with highlights on their adaptive capacities and vulnerability to climate change impacts; 3) Capacity building of stakeholders; 4) Demonstration of innovative mechanisms to increase resilience of urban coastal settlements to Climate Change; 5) Documentation of learnings and knowledge sharing at the national level and across cities; 6) Development of policy recommendations / guidelines to increase and support sustainable urban governance vis-a-vis climate change impacts."
Adaptations.contact_person: United Nations Centre for Human Settlements (UN HABITAT) Global Division

Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret option - Planned shelter/settlements

Adaptations.reviewer_comment: "Please describe concrete adaptation measures. You can describe in more detail ""The main activities include: 1), 2), 3), 4), 5)"" you mentioned in the description. Maybe it would be useful to split the project up into these subprojects. Please choose a sector. "

Adaptations.title: Climate Change Adaptation Program
Adaptations.description:
"The project is a pilot the development objective of which is to develop and demonstrate approaches that would enable targeted communities to adapt to the potential impacts of climate variability and change. This would be achieved by strengthening existing institutional frameworks for climate change adaptation, and by the demonstration of cost-effective adaptation strategies in agriculture and natural resources management. The project will increase communities’ adaptive capacity principally by improving: (a) farm management capability under conditions of climate risk; (b) access to information on weather forecasting and climate patterns; and © access to risk management options such as weather index insurance. The primary beneficiaries would include poor farmers whose livelihoods are often impacted by climate-related losses, and other vulnerable groups who depend on natural resources for their livelihoods. The project comprises four components: Component 1 – Strengthening the Enabling Environment for Climate Change Adaptation; Component 2 – Demonstrating Climate Change Adaptation Strategies in the Agriculture and Natural Resources Sectors; Component 3 – Enhanced Provision of Scientific Information for Climate Risk Management; and Component 4 – Project
Coordination."
Adaptations.contact_adress: World Bank
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR)
Adaptations.success_factors: Coordination and seriousness among project players
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-win option – Enhanced extension service
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: No reported project output/outcome
Adaptations.comments: This project has three major components directly dealing with Climate Change Adaptation. The fourth component is on project coordination.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: "The title and the description are very general. Maybe it would be good to focus on “a) farm management capability under conditions of climate risk; (b) access to information on weather forecasting and climate patterns; and access to risk management options such as weather index insurance” or on “Component 2 – Demonstrating Climate Change Adaptation Strategies in the Agriculture and Natural Resources Sectors”. This would be very interesting. "

Adaptations.query: Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Adaptations.title: The Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) Adaptation to Climate Change
Adaptations.description:
"This is a sub-project of Climate Change Impact and Adaptation of Coastal Cities Study. Four Asian coastal cities were selected for the study, including Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC), Bangkok, Manila and Kolkata. HCMC is located on the estuary of the Saigon – Dong Nai River system. A significant part of HCMC is regularly flooded due to a combination of tides, storm surge, rains, floods, and man-made structures. HCMC is recognized as a city at risk of the effects of climate change – it has been identified as one of the ten cities most likely to be severely affected. The study included 4 steps: 1) Baseline Information 2) Modelling of climate change and and its effect on the hydrology 3) Impact assessment 4) Adaptation options identification and proposal.
The project objectives are as follows:
(i) Assessment of the current knowledge base, including historical climate information, coping strategies, and local capacity to deal with natural disasters related to floods, cyclones, and tides 
(ii) Identify potential climate change scenarios 
(iii) Identification of the most vulnerable coastal and urban resources 
(iv) Assessment and quantification of the likely magnitude of effects on social, environmental and economic resources expected due to climate change and variability
(v) Identification and assessment of appropriate alternative intervention scenarios, and prioritization of suitable interventions 
(vi) Analysis of the capacity of relevant government agencies to implement identified interventions and provide appropriate recommendations"
Adaptations.contact_person: Jeremy Carew-Reid, Director of The International Centre for Environment Management
Adaptations.contact_adress: ICEM Vietnam, 32 Xuan Dieu St, Tay Ho, Hanoi, Vietnam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The People’s Committee of Ho Chi Minh City
Adaptations.executing_agent: International Centre for Environmental Management in collaboration with The People’s Committee of Ho Chi Minh City
Adaptations.success_factors:
"Successful uptake of recommendations. 
Government needs to implement and mainstream on adaptation plan accordingly"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Strengthening of capacities of organizations, institutions and policies to deal with climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project assessed the current knowledge and coping strategies for floods, storm surge, cyclones, and tides; identified potential scenarios that could affect coastal watersheds; identified vulnerable infrastructure and communities; quantified the magnitude of climate impacts on social, environmental, and economic resources; prioritized adaptive scenarios within current institutional frameworks; and looked at government capacity to manage natural disasters and climate shocks. 
Policy and practice have been informed by researchers. It improved the knowledge of levels of vulnerability and policy driven opportunities of adaptability in sectors and areas that will require adaptation plans and guidance as a framework for integration."
Adaptations.comments: "The study assessed the impact and vulnerability with linking estimates of threat to potential socio-economic and environmental impacts of climate change on areas, sectors and communities in the Ho Chi Minh City by 2050; identified those which are vulnerable; undertook an economic analysis; identified adaptation options and priorities by defining what needs to be done, by whom and when to reduce the risks of climate change and recommended for integration with development planning by defining next steps for integration of adaptation measures into sector and city development plans, policies, procedures, design standards, budgets, and projects. Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops. "
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Just as a comment for future reference: it is not necessary to differentiate between upper and lower case letters while tagging (Vulnerability / vulnerability). (This project will be accepted as is, there is no need to update it from your side)

Adaptations.title: Friends of the Reef
Adaptations.description: The impact of climate change and El Nino is increasingly causing coral reefs to bleach. Word Wildlife Funds (WWFs) Friends of the Reef project is an effort to protect Asia Pacifics coral reef ecosystems, which are the source of new coral recruits for reefs throughout the region and a source of livelihood for coastal people, especially in the fishery and tourism sectors. Friends of the Reef engages local stakeholders and decision makers in developing, testing, and implementing plans to increase coral reef resilience to major threats in the region, including climate change. This project also aims to increase awareness and advocacy activities by highlighting stories and show-cases from previous, current, and future coral bleaching in major reef countries throughout the Asia-Pacific region then using this information to call for emission reduction in regional countries. Friends of the Reef also provides collaborative management mechanisms, enabling the governments of major reef countries to enhance the management and network of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs). In the Phillipines, the Word Wildlife Fund (WWF) project includes coral monitoring in Tubataha National Park and El Nido National Park.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Word Wildlife Fund (WWF) Philippines
Adaptations.executing_agent: Word Wildlife Fund (WWF)
Adaptations.success_factors: Sustainability of the monitoring program
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: High (results to be used in emission reduction advocacy)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret option - Database on coral reefs
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: No reported project output/outcome
Adaptations.comments: This project is focused on coral reef monitoring and building community awareness on climate change (CC) and its effects particularly on coral reefs.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: “Friends of the Reef engages local stakeholders and decision makers in developing, testing, and implementing plans to increase coral reef resilience to major threats in the region, including climate change.” We are really interested in these plans. Can you provide some more information about this? Or please describe the coral monitoring a bit more. The target sector is coast, right?

Adaptations.title: Hazard mapping and assessment for effective community -based disaster risk management (READY) Project
Adaptations.description: "Three main components: 1) Multi-hazard identification and disaster risk assessment (1:50,000 to 1:10,000 for floods, rain-triggered landslide, storm surge, ground shaking, ground rupture, earthquake-triggered landslide, tsunami), 2) Community-based disaster preparednessInformation, Education and Communication Community based Early Warning Systems, 3) Initiate the mainstreaming of risk reduction into the local development planning process. Detailed maps are produced for every hazard that is likely to hit a province based on its natural features, active fault lines, past events and other factors. The maps also show the extent of the area that may be hit. An accompanying brochure helps the users locate their lands or houses and find out their vulnerability to the hazards. When information is shared through workshops and planning in the communities, residents are assisted in establishing early warning systems. Drills are held to test if evacuation plans are mastered or if these are effective. Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Service Administration (PAGASA) made the maps on floods and storm surges; Phivolcs on earthquakes, ground shaking and ruptures, liquefaction and tsunamis; and MGB on landslides. Namria handles the final production, copying and distribution of the mapsPAGASA has set up a network of community-based rainfall monitoring system in Aurora. It installed rain gauges maintained by volunteers in villages, who send rainfall data by phone, mobile phone or radio to the PAGASA stations in Baler and Casiguran towns and its weather and flood forecasting center in Quezon City.Started in 2006, Ready has been implemented in Surigao del Norte and Surigao del Sur, Leyte, Southern Leyte and Bohol where deadly disasters had occurred.The first 27 provinces identified in 2005 are Benguet, Abra, Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, Cagayan Valley, Isabela, Nueva Vizcaya, Quirino, Pampanga, Zambales, Aurora, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal, Catanduanes, Antique, Iloilo, Bohol, Leyte, Southern Leyte, Eastern Samar, Northern Samar, Zamboanga Del Sur, Zamboanga Sibugay, Agusan Del Sur, Surigao Del Norte, and Surigao Del Sur.The next 16 provinces were identified in 2007 with specific target cities or municipalities. These are Cebu (Metro Cebu), Pangasinan (Dagupan City), Bulacan (Doña Remedios Trinidad, San Miguel), Agusan Del Norte (Butuan City), Western Samar (Catbalogan City), Agusan Del Norte (Butuan City), Camarines Norte (Daet), Quezon (Lopez-Calauag), Oriental Mindoro (Calapan), Aklan (Kalibo), Batanes (Basco), Zamboanga del Norte (Dipolog City), Bukidnon (Malaybay City), Davao Oriental (Mati), Mountain Province (Bontoc), and Lanao Del Sur (Malabang)."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Philippine Institute for Volcanology and Seismology-Department of Science and Technology (PHIVOLCS-DOST) PHIVOLCS Building, C.P. Garcia Avenue, U.P. Campus Diliman, Quezon City 1001 PHILIPPINES
Adaptations.executing_agent: United Nations Development Program, Philippine Institute for Volcanology and Seismology, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Service Administration, Mines and Geosciences Bureau, National Disaster Coordinating Council
Adaptations.funding_source: Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), United Nations Development Program (UNDP)
Adaptations.success_factors: Local Government Unit/community capacity to understand and utilize information/maps
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret option – Information maps made available
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Hazard maps produced and capacity building of Local Government Units (LGUs) ongoing
Adaptations.comments: This project builds capacities of the Local Government Units (LGUs) in disaster risk reduction by providing them the information (hazard maps) and enabling them to assess risk in their area.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Very good description of the community-based rainfall monitoring system. Please give us a Link/Address of the Information Source(Website).

Adaptations.title: National Program Support to Environment and Natural Resources Management
Adaptations.description: "The program’s development objective is improved environment and natural resources management which contributes to sustainable economic growth in the Philippines. To achieve this, the program would strengthen and rationalize Department of Environment and Natural Resources’ (DENR’s) regular core functions under: (a) policy, planning and advocacy; (b) conservation and rehabilitation; © environmental management, enforcement and monitoring; and (d) results based planning and budgeting. Project components have been designed around the Department of Environment and Natural Resources’ (DENR’s) mandate and regular programs, as well as the structure of Major Final Outputs that agencies are adopting in the move toward result based budgeting. The target group for components 1, 3 and 4 will be largely Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) national and regional offices, whilst component 2 will also target Local Government Units (LGUs) and communities. Component 1 Policy, planning monitoring and evaluation: The component would strengthen Department of Environment and Natural Resources’ (DENR’s) capacity in policy, planning and monitoring for programs and activities for which it is responsible. Furthermore, it would facilitate coordination of mandates of various agencies dealing with NRM. Such coordination would increase the efficiency of resource use and increase outcomes for Natural Resources Management (NRM). It would also build capacity at Local Government Units (LGUs) for Natural Resources Management (NRM). Component 2 Integrated Eco-system Management: This component would be implemented in priority watershed areas identified. Project sites: 1) Southern Sierra Madre Watershed Cluster (Angat Watershed Reservation, Ipo Watershed, Dona Remedios Trinidad-Gen. Tinio Watershed Forest Reservem Umiray Watershed Forest Reserve, Kanan Watershed, Coastal Wetlands), 2) Bicol River Basin: Libmanan-Pulantuna Watershed, 3) Liguasan Marsh. The component would support the following: (i) participatory micro-catchment planning, management and awareness raising; (ii) rehabilitation and protection of degraded ecologically sensitive areas including riverine areas; (iii) sustainable forest management; (iv) biodiversity conservation and management within priority PAs and other biologically important areas; (v) sustainable Livelihood Improvements that support IEM; and (vi) assessment, identification and implementation of activities in aqua-silviculture and coastal areas.Component 3 Environmental Management and Enforcement: This component would specifically contribute to: (i) strengthening Department of Environment and Natural Resources’ (DENR’s) role and capacity in the implementation of the environmental impact statement system; (ii) improving enforcement of environmental laws and standards for air, water, solid and toxic and hazardous wastes through the use of command and control and market-based instruments; (iii) improving environmental compliance monitoring of the regulated community; (iv) improving the adjudication process and resolution of environmental violations and pollution cases; (v) helping the Government address the mining legacy of the past by supporting pilot mine rehabilitation and strengthening enforcement of environmental and social policies for current and future mining; and (vi) undertaking geohazard mapping of high risk areas to assist in land use planning and reduce the risk of tragedies such as mudslides that have caused massive loss of life, property and environmental damage.Component 4 Expenditure Planning and Management: In line with national initiatives for improving public sector service delivery, activities under component 4, would specifically be aimed at: (i) strengthening planning and allocation of budgetary resources. More specifically, the component would support the review and revamping of the present budgeting and planning system to ensure the development of more integrated planning/budgeting plans; and (ii) developing the specific inputs related to budgeting and planning that would need to be included in the Management Information System (MIS) developed under component 1, to facilitate a closer link between plans developed and implementation reality; and (iii) overall program coordination, monitoring and evaluation."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Global Environment Facility (GEF)
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Government (Department of Environment and Natural Resources)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR)
Adaptations.success_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret option – Effectively functioning government department
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: No information on project output/outcome
Adaptations.comments: This project is basically intended at improving Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENRs) capability as an agency in performing its functions.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: This project is very big. It seems to be impossible to describe all different aspects in just one description. Please choose the most climate change adaptation related parts and describe it separately, in sub-projects.

Adaptations.title: Linking Climate Change Adaptation to Sustainable Development in Southeast Asia
Adaptations.description:
"Recently, it is being recognized that the way to address climate change is to integrate adaptation policies into the sustainable development programs of the country. By mainstreaming climate change adaptation into the sustainable development and poverty reduction strategies, the most vulnerable sectors (the poor people) will become more resilient to climate change (Sperling, 2003). However, the link between climate change adaptation and sustainable development is not explicitly recognized for a number of reasons. In many cases, the climate change community has little interaction with national development planners. As a result, mainstreaming of climate change adaptation in development efforts is making little headway. This project aimed to help clarify the links between climate change adaptation and sustainable development. By engaging the policy maker community and other relevant stakeholders, the project hoped to contribute to the mainstreaming of climate change adaptation to the sustainable development agenda of SE Asian countries.
Objectives:
The main objectives of the project were: 1. Synthesize research on adaptation strategies for climate change and climate variability in SE Asian countries; 2. Analyze the links of adaptation strategies to the sustainable development goals of the respective countries; 3. Hold a science-policy workshop to disseminate results and solicit recommendations; and 4. Publish the results of the study in a format that is useful to policy makers and other stakeholders."

Adaptations.title: Tropical Forests and Climate Change Adaptation - Philippines
Adaptations.description: "Tropical Forests and Climate Change Adaptations (TroFCCAs) main objective is to contribute to national processes of adaptation to climate change, in particular, and create efforts to mainstream adaptation into development policies.The specific objectives of the project are as follows: 1) Identify regional development issues related to climate change impacts over forest that can increase the vulnerability of the society; 2) Develop specific methodologies to assess vulnerability; 3) Contribute to current national and regional adaptation processes; 4) Develop criteria and indicators for adaptive forest management; 5) Develop policy-oriented adaptation strategies; and 6) Facilitate a science-policy dialogue on adaptation.The project operates in three regions: Central America, Southeast Asia and West Africa. All regions share the same project’s general framework but each will develop their own methods on the basis of their respective regional contexts and prioritized needs. In the Philippines, water resources and landslides are the chosen priority topics.TroFCCA in the Philippines is the continuation of the project entitled: An Integrated Assessment of Climate Change Impacts, Adaptations, and Vulnerability in Watershed Areas and Communities in Southeast Asia (AIACC) that ended in 2006. For TroFCCA’s third year in the Philippines, the main activities consist of the development of methodology for the vulnerability assessment of the water resources, policy and literature studies, development of national policy, and dissemination of information materials. The assessment of vulnerability methods is developed mainly through literature studies and participation in international, regional, and national workshops and seminars.The Philippines is highly dependent on water resources for domestic and industrial use, irrigation, power generation, animal husbandry, fisheries and recreation activities. The country is becoming more prone and susceptible to water related disasters under weather extremes such as floods, droughts, and typhoons.Since susceptibility to water related disasters will likely increase with climate change, TroFCCA in the Philippines focuses on water resources as the priority research area. "
