Adaptations.query: Thua Thien- Hue province, Viet Nam
Adaptations.title: Capacity building for adaptation to Climate Change in Vietnam (CACC project)
Adaptations.description:
"The project aims to reduce vulnerability from the adverse effects of climate change in flood-prone areas of Central Vietnam, by improving capacity at the national and local level to develop adaptation strategies. 
The focused of the project was to ‘strengthen capacity to plan and implement community-based anticipatory adaptation strategies through disaster preparedness and integration of risk reduction and mitigation into local development planning’. 
Major activities of the project include strengthening disaster preparedness, capacity development on best practices for disaster resistant housing and public buildings, technical support, information sharing, and awareness, policy feedback and coordination with provincial priorities, a study on relocation and alternatives for highly vulnerable populations, national workshops on the impact of climate change and community-based adaptation strategies."
Adaptations.contact_person: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation
Adaptations.contact_adress: 3185 Rachel St. East, Montreal, Quebec, Canada H1W 1A3.
Adaptations.source: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation http://unfccc.int/files/adaptation/application/pdf/nwpexpert_shaw_2006.pdf .
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI), Provincial People’s Committee of Thua Thien-Hue.
Adaptations.executing_agent: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI) in collaboration with The Provincial People’s Committee of Thua Thien-Hue.
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
-Incorporation of the community-based issues in the policy level."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: -Resource constrains of implementation of technological solutions/ measures
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"-The project demonstrates a unique way of vulnerability reduction through enhancing capacities of local people and communities.
-The project assisted communities in the two Districts to plan and implement adaptation strategies to reduce vulnerability to the adverse impacts of climate change. 37 sub-projects of Safer Village Plan (SVP), 8 sub-projects of Save Production Plan (SPP) were implemented. It covers 8 villages located in 4 communes.
-276 local officials, 800 local people were trained on Community-Based Disaster Management; 320 people were trained on agriculture, aquaculture, forestry extension service; 52 participants including engineers, technical, local builders were trained on disaster resistant constructions. Such trainings supported the implementation of the SVP and SPP.
-One study on relocation and settlement in Thua Thien Hue published and disseminated which provide better models of safer resettled villages, improve conditions for those villagers and draw more voluntary resettlement in these areas
-2 workshops at national and provincial level to introduce viable options for community-based adaptation strategies which contributed to increased awareness of developing comprehensive adaptation strategies that are integrated with social and economic development planning."
Adaptations.comments: The Province of Thua Thien Hue is in the central region, which is one of the most disaster-prone areas of Vietnam. This project supported communities in the Two Districts of Thua Thien-Hue Province to plan and implement adaptation strategies to reduce vulnerability to the adverse impacts of climate change. Ten villages in five communes, Quang Thai, Quang Phu, Phu Ho and Phu My and Phu Xuan participated in the project.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: The main activity seems to be capacity building. Would you agree to change the project type to ‘Training’? Can you provide some more information about the planning and implementation of adaptation strategies?

Adaptations.title: Sustaining the Mangrove Rehabilitatation Initiative and Livelihood Enhancement
Adaptations.description: The project focuses on mangrove reforestation, livelihood development and training, and community organizing. Seven fisherfolk organizations have been strengthened to help address the dwindling fishery resources contributing to low fish catch in the municipal waters. A total of 180 hectares of newly planted with mangroves accounting to 1,800 propagules planted, and 400 hectares protected. The tenurial instrument and co-management agreement based on the early signs, local fish species, mollusks, as well as shells are abound again. In terms of adopting to and mitigating the impact of climate change, mangrove is the first line of defense in storm surge along the coast. And mangrove species has the highest capacity of carbon sequestration mechanism than any other tree species. Through these two projects, linkage and support from other stakeholders were gained, such as national high-school of Ipil and Universidad de Zamboanga students are doing mangrove planting activities. Also, the Parole and Probation under the Department of Justice are utilizing their prisoners to plant mangroves trees within the project sites using the mangrove nurseries of the project.

Adaptations.query: San Fernando Bay, La Union, Philippines
Adaptations.title: Economic Vulnerability and Possible Adaptation to Coastal Erosion in San Fernando City, Philippines
Adaptations.description: The project investigated erosion in one of the Philippine’s more developed coastal regions. It finds that this coastline is vulnerable to the impact of erosion and that, if nothing is done, the problem will cause hundreds of millions of Php worth of damage. It also finds that a planned protection strategy is the most rational approach to adopt. Such a strategy is socially and politically acceptable, justifiable from an economic perspective and also preserves the area’s beaches along with the social services they provide. The project assessed the coastline of San Fernando Bay in the La Union region of the Philippines. It looks at approximately seven kilometers of the bay’s coastline. San Fernando Bay is a densely populated area and it was chosen because it was identified as a place where coastal erosion is already prevalent. Sea-level rise is a major concern across the Philippines and beyond. Its scale and impact are both expected to become more widespread due to climate change and sea level rise.

Adaptations.title: Albay in Action on Climate Change (A2C2) Program
Adaptations.description: The Albay Provincial legislation unanimously proclaimed the 1st and pioneering prototype for local Climate Change Adaptation, launching in Albay in Action on Climate Change (A2C2), and resolved that environment shall be included in the curricula of all schools, colleges and universities in Albay in August 2007. The scope of the program shall include biodiversity, agricultural resources, wetlands, dry and humid lands, marine and coastal resources. The main strategies of this program are climate adaptation, quality education and direction based on the ‘public and private partnership initiatives’. It addresses the critical needs of the province for its development linked on social interaction, quality education, employment, health care, poverty eradication and for a just, clean and healthy sustainable environment accessible to all. A holistic framework for adaptation was adopted by the Provincial Government of Albay, which includes four strategic components: 1) anthropogenic and environmental adaptation efforts for the benefit of the present and future generations, 2) development of programs aimed to improve social, environmental, economic, and eco-cultural status of the communities, 3) active involvement and genuine participation of the community in the development and implementation of curricula, researches, strategies, technologies, management plans, programs, projects, and approaches that promote climate change adaptation, and 4) reserach and systematic observation, formulation, implementatation, reporting, and institutionalization of appropriate plans, policies, and mechanisms to adapt to climate change, variability and extremes through private and public partnerships

The goal of the project is to enhance human security in Central Viet Nam to cope with the climate change impacts in the form of natural disasters like flood and cyclone.

"

Adaptations.title: Building Mangrove Greenbelts
Adaptations.description: Sea levels on the coast of Bangladesh are expected to rise up to 23cm, directly affecting the lives of 38 million Bangladeshis living in coastal areas. More land is being affected by increasing salinity, also threatening food security, and livelihood options. Char Kukri-Mukri, with a population of around 20,000, is already experiencing a marked increase in both the frequency and intensity of cyclones and accompanying tidal surges, disrupting agriculture and fishing, and also causing massive erosion. Char Kukri-Mukri was one of four sites chosen for this project which is establishing 6,100 hectares of mangrove plantations and 935 hectares of timber species and fruit trees. Women have been trained to grow mangrove saplings, as well as trees used for timber, such as bamboo, and in forest management. Mangrove saplings will soon be planted along the coastline to create mangrove forests containing over 2.5 million trees over the four sites.
Adaptations.contact_adress: UNDP G.P.O Box No. 224 Dhaka 1000 Bangladesh
Adaptations.executing_agent: UNDP, Ministry of Environment and Forest , local communities
Adaptations.success_factors: It’s very important to pick the right varieties, the right species and also to involve the communities in the plantations and the maintenance and the management of the plantations.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, Mangrove forests act as extremely effective carbon sinks, able to absorb 97.57 tons of carbon per hectare, or more than three times the absorptive capacity of non-mangrove forests.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The programme is doing the Natural Resource Managment by training local people to run mangrove nurseries and manage forests and then paying them, a move that will have benefited 5,000 families by the end of 2010.
Adaptations.comments: Mangroves provide physical protection, trapping sediment in their intricate root structure at such a high rate that they can potentially reverse the effects of sea level rise.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: "Fine ;)"

Therefore it focus on the model building for applying scientific-technological advances so as to limit damages.
Furthermore the project promotes the awareness and understanding of the local government authorities and local people on the impacts of climate change on every socio-economic activities and local living environment. And it draws lessons and experiences of the model, analyze and recommend to the local community."

The expected outcomes are

Especially the Evaluation provides only Information about the capacity building aspect of this project (excluding the tanks). If you want to keep Natural Resource Management as project type you must highlight the related aspects a bit more, especially in the description. Please don’t answer direct to this mail. You can contact us by tabea.lissner@pik-potsdam.de and steffen.kriewald@pik-potsdam.de. Thank you very much for your contribution.

Adaptations.title: Micro irrigation technologies
Adaptations.description: "This study looks at micro-irrigation technologies, commonly in use in water scarce areas of developed countries which increase the ability to use water more efficiently in irrigated agriculture. These technologies can improve productivity; raise incomes through increased crop yields and outputs; and enhance food security of households. Low-cost systems include the Pepsee easy drip technology, bucket and drum kits, micro sprinklers, micro tube drip systems and others that have been designed by organizations such as the International Development Enterprises (IDE), along with innovative farmers. The more sophisticated, capital intensive systems are conventional drip and sprinkler systems."
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 2075, Colombo, Sri Lanka
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO: IWMI
Adaptations.success_factors: requires less capital when compared to conventional technologies, low level of skills required, suitable even for small land holdings
Adaptations.limiting_factors: lack of access to groundwater, default on loan repayment, crop specificity of the available micro-irrigation technologies, lack of know-how, poor product quality and absence of adequate credit facilities
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win : reduces input cost while increasing productivity, and promotes sustainable agriculture
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Increase in yields up to 100 , Saving in water by 50 – 60, Uniformity of water application. Precision Placement of Water and Fertilizers, Improvement in quality, Saving in fertilizers by 25 – 30 %, Saving in Electricity, labour and time, Undulating lands can be brought under cultivation, Salinity problems get minimized.
Adaptations.comments: Low-cost micro-irrigation technologies are largely promoted to poor farmers, hence their competitive pricing and compatibility with smallholder farming systems. Farmers can generally recover their initial investment capital between one and three years, although the extent of economic gains from investment depends on the type of crop. Subsidies and options for financing from organizations and government schemes like IDE, the Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP) and the Gujarat state government in India canfurther increase the profitability of investing in microirrigation,which makes a crucial difference in adoption by poorer farmers.

Adaptations.query: Sambalpur, Deogarh and Angul districts in Orissa, India
Adaptations.title: NTFP (Non Timber Forest Products) Enterprises
Adaptations.description: NTFPs constitute an important part of the livelihood of the poor in some of the most backward and tribal regions of Orissa. The work undertaken by Vasundhara involves advocating local primary gatherers’ rights over the products and their markets and they have also set up a Community Enterprise Revolving Fund (CERF). NTFP cooperatives are established to improve the negotiating capacity of collectors, reduce imperfections in the market, so that a larger share of the benefit is accrued by the poor. At present, there are 35 women’s primary cooperatives which have networked to form two unions, which are secondary level cooperatives.
Adaptations.contact_adress: A/70, Sahid Nagar, Bhubaneshwar-751 007, Odisha
Adaptations.executing_agent: Vasundhra
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional and policy support (Odisha Self-help Cooperative Act 2001) for easy formation of cooperatives, access to finance
Adaptations.limiting_factors: community participation, hard to sustain over time
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: economic benefits, social benefits
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "The project intervention has shown 42-54% incremental gains to the members (economic gains); members increased by 80%, number of cooperatives has increased to 38 (2010). There has also been an increase in the influx of the female members in the cooperatives particularly from the Tribals in the region. Success of the cooperatives in the Kuchinda, Bamra and Jamankira blocks of Sambalpur district, Tilaibani and Barkote block of Deogarh district and Pallahara block of Angul districts led to the demand in other areas of Koraput,Sundargarh(Lahunipada)and Phulbani."
Adaptations.comments: "For the project to have greater success it is necessary to integrate the following; (1) Skill Up-gradation, (2) Development and extension of Appropriate Technology for NTFP processing, (3) Compilation and Dissemination of Market Information, (4) Finding alternatives for better and more profitable uses of NTFPs (5) There needs to be shift in focus from timber to NTFP, and this shift needs to be supported by research in the direction of NTFP based forest management systems. "

Adaptations.title: Kisan Credit Card Scheme (KCC)
Adaptations.description: Kisan Credit Card Scheme (KCC) aims at providing adequate and timely support from the banking system to the farmers for their short-term credit needs for cultivation of crops. This mainly helps farmer for purchase of inputs etc., during the cropping season. Repayment can be rescheduled if there is a bad crop season, and extensions are offered for up to 4 years. The card is valid for 3 years and subject to annual renewals. Banks in India that lend for agricultural purposes usually offer the KCC. Withdrawals are made using slips, cards, and a passbook.
Adaptations.contact_person: National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Plot No C-24, G Block, Bandra Kurla Complex, Bandra East, Mumbai 400051
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Reserve Bank of India, GOI and NABARD
Adaptations.executing_agent: Banks
Adaptations.success_factors: Financial: farmer willingness to enter into an agreement with the bank, ability to pay back loans, Institutional: Average land holding size as limit to be fixed on the basis of operational land holding, cropping pattern and scale of finance.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Maintenance of pass and cheque book, inability to repay, crop loss due to repeated drought
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win: The credit card can be used whether or not the crop is affected due to climate change impacts for improved productivity
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Since its launch in August 1998, around 2.38 crore Kisan Credit Cards were issued upto 31 March 2002 by Cooperative Banks, Regional Rural Banks and Commercial Banks put together. Conversion/reschedulement of loans also permissible in case of damage to crops due to natural calamities.
Adaptations.comments: Card valid for 3 years subject to annual review. As incentive for good performance, credit limits could be enhanced to take care of increase in costs, change in cropping pattern, etc. Full years credit requirement of the borrower taken care of.

Adaptations.title: ICICI-BASIX weather indexed insurance
Adaptations.description: The introduction of rainfall insurance by BASIX was the first weather insurance initiative launched in India and the first farmer-level weather insurance offered in the developing world. BASIX, in collaboration with ICICI Lombard and with technical assistance from the Commodity Risk Management Group (CRMG) of the World Bank, piloted the sale of weather insurance to 230 farmers in the Mahahbubnagar district of Andhra Pradesh (A.P.) during the 2003 monsoon season. During the 2005 monsoon season, BASIX sold 7,685 policies to 6,703 customers in 36 locations in 6 states. This product insures the farmers against the possibility of crop loss in moisture stress conditions thereby lowering risk and ensuring sustenance.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Ascent Towers, 3rd Floor, Road No. 10, Opp. Rainbow Children’s Hospital,
Adaptations.executing_agent: BASIX
Adaptations.success_factors: "(1) the presence of customers (2) preferably 200 to 300 acres of groundnut and/or castor bean in the village to ensure a market for the weather insurance; (3) a reasonable number of small- and medium-size farms with 2 to 10 acres of land each; and (4) a village location less than 20 kilometers away from the nearest rainfall reference station, to reduce the basis risk born by the buyer."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: willingness to pay for insurance, building trust
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret: This is especially helpful when there is crop loss as a result of drought, in normal years it will not be very helpful
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Within only three years, the small pilot program graduated into a large weather insurance operation. During the 2005 monsoon season, BASIX sold 7,685 policies to 6,703 customers in 36 locations in 6 states.The best evidence that the product is attractive comes from the fact that most farmers in treatment villages reported that they would like to purchase the insurance for the next kharif season in June 2006.
Adaptations.comments: Once the benefits of the product are fully understood, farmers will be able to alter their production strategies towards maximizing output, rather than diversifying risk, and to shift their demand for credit from consumption loans to investment loans. This shift is likely to result in increased specialization and investment, and to contribute to increased profits and the well-being of the rural population.

Adaptations.title: System of Rice Intensification
Adaptations.description: System of Rice Intensification is an modified set of practices for growing rice. The alterations in the agronomic practices occurs in four distinct components (soil fertility management, planting method (bigger gaps), weed control (mechanical removal) and irrigation (reduced flooding)). The use of this technique has resulted in higher production in normal rainfall years, and also in drought years. By reduced input use, costs are reduced and returns are improved.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 253/I, Vasant Vihar, Dehradun-248006
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Centre for Participatory Watershed Development at PSI
Adaptations.executing_agent: CPWD, WASSAN (technical advice), other partner NGOs in the states
Adaptations.success_factors: Adoption of practice: willingness of the people to adopt this practice
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Return Period: use of this system depends can be limited if the returns are not immediate or take to long to show up
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: reduced green house gas emission, pollution reduction by the lower requirements of fertilizers and pesticides, reduced water usage for production
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: alleviates the impacts of drought or water stress conditions due to climate change, reduces water consumption and increases yield.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: SRI has shown an increase in yield of rice grains and fodder with reduced input use. The systems effectiveness can be judged by its utility even in drought conditions where it shows a higher yield as compared to conventional rice growing method. Water used is also reduce.
Adaptations.comments: The system of SRI has been expanded to include other crops (SCI - System of Crop Intensification). The crops that have been grown using SCI are kidney bean, soyabean, finger millet and maize all showing an increase in grain yileds.

Adaptations.title: Wadi program
Adaptations.description: Wadi is an integrated tribal development and poverty alleviation program initiated by BAIF- DHRUVA. The “Wadi” model of tribal development is holistic in approach addressing production, processing and marketing of the agri horti produce, and thus improving incomes.The critical inputs for the wadi programme include grafted mango saplings, vermi-compost and technical know-how for soil and water conservation and protective irrigation. The other development interventions includes required measures for soil conservation in the wadis, water resource development by digging wells, creating farm ponds, gully plugging and permanent check dams to ensure protective irrigation during the gestation period. The program began with 42 families in 1982 at Vansda, today the tribal development programme covers more than 23,000 families in three blocks of South Gujarat. Huge tracts of wastelands have been converted into orchards.
Adaptations.contact_adress: BAIF Vrindavan Campus-Lachhakadi,
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO:BAIF
Adaptations.success_factors: technical know how, soil and moisture conservation, availability of fruit saplings
Adaptations.limiting_factors: dysfunctional SHGs, absence of market linkages, no value addition
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: yes: vermi compost and organic agriculture methods
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no regret/win win: no regret: Irrespective of climate change the livelihood options generated, protective irrigation measures will help the communities to enhance their income, win win: income from sale and procesing of fruits and irrigation measures will help cope with the impacts of climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The program began with 42 families in 1982 at Vansda, today the tribal development programme covers more than 23,000 families in three blocks of South Gujarat. Huge tracts of wastelands have been converted into orchards. Some acheivements of the program have been: livelihood prmotion and conservation of natural resources, reduction in migration, shift to commercial crops, increase in cropping intensity, processing of cashew and mango, improved health and sanitation, capacity building of women’s SHGs, adoption of Wadi model by families that were not participating earlier.
Adaptations.comments: His Excellency Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam visited the tribal development cluster in Kaprada and Chonda is a significant landmark in the history of Dhruva. The President took keen interest in visiting the Wadis, food processing unit and interacting closely with the participants in our programme during this visit.

Adaptations.title: Community Managed Sustainable Agriculture (CMSA)
Adaptations.description: The CMSA approach replaces the use of chemical pesticides with a combination of physical and biological measures including eco-friendly biopesticides and complements it by adopting biological and agronomic soil fertility improvement measures leading to reduced use of chemical fertilizers. This has significantly reduced the cost of cultivation, the need for large amounts of credit and indebtedness that results. CMSA uses an institutional platform of community organizations and their federations to plan, implement, manage, and monitor the program and provide a single window approach for delivery of livelihood improvement services and enterprises, exclusively for small-farm holders.
Adaptations.contact_person: Mr. D.V.Raidu, State Project Adviser, Society for Elimination of Rural Poverty
Adaptations.contact_adress: Huda Building,Hill Fort Road,
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Resource organisation: Centre for Sustainable Agriculture
Adaptations.executing_agent: Non profit entity: Society for Elimination of Rural Poverty (SERP)
Adaptations.success_factors:
"Institutional: 
leadership and participation of strong community institutions and their federations that own and manage the program
- farmer field schools that deliver extension services
- a menu of technologies options developed with farmer participation and experimentation
- scaling up with practicing farmers as community resource persons [CRPs] who serve as community extensionists
- developing ‘value chain’ investments from inputs to equipment, post harvest and marketing arrangements of produce for development of sustainable agriculture. Convergence with other government programs"
Adaptations.limiting_factors: availability of technical support, labor intensive
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: yes: reduced use of inorganic fertilisers
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Over 300,000 farmers have adopted CMSA in Andhra Pradesh alone, covering 1.36 million acres of farmland—5.1 per cent of the net cropped area in the state—in just over four years. According to estimates by CSA, 2 million acres (10 % of cultivated area) in AP is covered under CMSA. In 2004, CMSA started on 400acres of land in 12 villages and by January 2009 it had grown to cover 1.3million acres (over 552,000 ha). Currently, over 318,000 farmers in 3,171villages (about 12 per cent of the all villages in the state) are practicing CMSA. The program covers 18 of the 23 districts of the state.During 2008-09, the project covered about 13.81 lakh acres with 3.18 lakh farmers across 3171 villages in 18 districts of Andhra Pradesh. Mainstream agricultural research and extension institutions and other programs providing subsidies to farmers for usage of chemical fertilizers and pesticides are still skeptic and more dialogue is needed between the farmers and scientific community practicing sustainable agriculture. The current dialogue on role of agriculture in adaptation to climate change and reduction of carbon footprint through reduction in usage of chemical fertilizershas also started. This augurs for a possible second ‘green’ revolution, particularly for rain fed areas.
Adaptations.comments: The model of NPM approach [Non Pesticidal Management] was developed by the Centre for Sustainable Agriculture and later taken up by SERP for scaling up in other districts with World Bank support.CMSA approach is currently under scrutiny and observation by many agencies. National Mission on Sustainable Agriculture being set up by Government of India is looking at the CMSA approach as one of the key strategies to be replicated at the national level. Many farmer organizations in Andhra Pradesh and other states of India who are facing similar issues and had similar experiences on smaller scale are interested in how to convert CMSA into a people’s movement.

Adaptations.title: Pani Panchayats (Water Council)
Adaptations.description: Pani Panchayats are councils set up for management and distribution of water resources equitable in Maharashtra. They have been set up by Vilasrao Salunkhe and the Gram Gaurav Pratisthan Trust in order to address the issues of water scarcity in drought prone Maharashtra. Pani Panchayats have worked out technological and social innovations that help repair and restore degraded watersheds (thereby increasing water harvests), and by guaranteeing each family within the community an equal share of the water harvested, meets goals of equity as well. Every family member is typically allowed water for cultivation at the rate of half an acre per head subject to a maximum of 2.5 acres per family. In other words 1000 m3 of water per head per year subject to maximum 5000m3 per family per year.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Khalad village, Saswad, Pune District, Maharashtra,
Adaptations.executing_agent: Individual and Gram Gourav Pratisthan Trust
Adaptations.funding_source: State government line departments and other sources
Adaptations.success_factors: guaranteeing water share to each farmer, soil conservation, water harvesting
Adaptations.limiting_factors: social conflicts, subsidy, electricity supply, availability of land
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win: In both drought and non drought years assured irrigation and access to water help farmers to cope
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Barren lands that had produced little or no food were gradually producing one good seasonal crop, which helped farmers survive the year with dignity. In some areas, as water availability increased, farmers could go on for two crops. The 50-odd schemes co-sponsored by the GGP eventually enabled 3,000 acres to be brought under protective irrigation, benefitting a population of some 10,000 people from 1,500 families. The availability of water made possible through conservation schemes and percolation tanks meant that drinking water for the village population was accessible and close at hand and villagers, women especially, did not have to trudge across long distances for water in the hot sun any longer.
Out of the 30 odd water councils set up in Maharshtra, few of them are still functioning and have expanded their work to lift irrigation in some tribal districts in Maharashtra."
Adaptations.comments: Several of the principles behind the organisation of the Pani Panchayat ought to be made part of public policy. First, the principle that people should have equal shares in common resources, if adopted, would revolutionise society in far-reaching ways. Today, a landless person in the village is seen as a person who has no right to resources just because he has no land. Because of this, he often also does not have political power since it is assumed he is poor and therefore his views need not be taken into account when decisions concerning his survival or that of the community are being made.

Adaptations.title: Roof rain water harvesting Akash Ganga
Adaptations.description: Akash Ganga is an innovative roofwater harvesting system that channels rooftop rainwater from every house in a community through gutters and pipes to a network of underground reservoirs with large enough capacity to store a year of drinking water. It depends on community partnership or social enterprise to provide drinking water to the people by renting roofs from home owners or acquiring rights to harvest their rooftop rainwater. One half of the harvested rooftop rainwater is stored in the reservoir attached to the house for the exclusive use of the home owner. The other half flows to the shared community reservoir. People who live under thatched roofs or who cannot afford to have their own reservoirs take water from the shared reservoir.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Teoco, 4th Floor. 12150 Monument Drive, Fairfax, VA 22033
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Dr BP Agrawal, Sustainable Innovations SI (Organisation)
Adaptations.executing_agent: PRI, SI and local community
Adaptations.success_factors: community willingness, technological support, accessing roof right
Adaptations.limiting_factors: financial and technical support, households not willing to give out roof on rent
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win:
"no regret:
the system provides drinking water during dry months especially for poor families"
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Till date the AG system has helped 10,000 villagers gain access to clean water. Mr Agrawal is building a public-private-community partnership to provide potable water to 250,000 people by 2012.Six villages have benefited through the project

Adaptations.title: Experience in promoting micro irrigation technologies
Adaptations.description: Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP) introduced water saving irrigation devices such as drip and sprinkler kits in the groundwater stressed Saurashtra region in Gujarat to help farmers shift to protective irrigation and reduce agriculture input cost. They also promoted crops that use less amount of water and appropriate agronomic practices in addition to the drip and sprinklers.In Junagadh district, where groundwater overuse was very high AKRSP decided to pilot groundwater management with two interrelated objectives of 1) reviving the Meghal river and 2) arresting salinity ingress along the coast in Mangrol Block, where groundwater overuse was leading to increased ingress annually.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 9th and 10th Floors,Corporate house, opposite Dinesh Hall,Ahmedabad -380009
Adaptations.source: Report on AKRSP(I)’s Experiences in Promoting Micro Irrigation Devices in Saurashtra, Gujarat
Adaptations.initiating_agent: NGO- Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP) India
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO- Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP) India
Adaptations.funding_source: INGO-European Commission, Sir Ratan Tata Trust
Adaptations.success_factors: reducing cost, extention and repair service, subsidy and incentive
Adaptations.limiting_factors: lack of training, affordability
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win: promotes sustainable agriculture and is water efficient
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: AKRSP has been able to cover a total of 208 hectares and 262 farmers in 37 villages of 2 blocks at a cost of Rs4100/hectare (comparatively the government in 2002-03 has covered 526 farmers at a total cost of Rs43000/hectare) in the district of Junagadh . AKRSP provided a subsidy for the microtube drip system, which was 50% of the cost in 2002 and 33% in 2003. The total subsidy provided in the 2 years was Rs10.75 lakhs for 208 hectares (Rs5168/hectare)and 262 farmers(Rs 4103/farmer).Farmers pay about Rs10600/hectare and Rs 7500-8000/farmer.

Adaptations.title: Community water project
Adaptations.description: A community water project providing paid access and clean filtered drinking water to poor families in 25 villages in the the coastal area of Andhra Pradesh (AP), via community taps and jerry cans. Naandi foundation (NGO) and Water Health International (disinfection technology provider) implemented an output based aid project to improve rural water services in 3 districts of coastal AP in a public-private partnership. The project aims to create community safe water schemes (CSWS) in 25 villages that lack access to clean drinking water benefitting around 12,500 poor households. Nandi Foundation undertook the mobilisationand collects user fees, and in return gets a performance based subsidy linked to the delivery of pre-agreed outputs including three months of billed water services. This output-based subsidy approach requires that tariffs paid by users for consumption cover the costs of operation and maintenance, user-fee collection, and education and communication activities with key stakeholders and vulnerable groups.Each scheme included a water treatment plant connected to a water distribution point from which users obtain water in jerry cans. This scheme involves the panchayat, Naandi Foundation and WHI with Global Partnership on Output based AID (GPOBA) subsidising the cost of setting up the water treatment plants.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 502, Trendset Towers, Road No 2
Adaptations.executing_agent: Naandi Foundation and Water Health International
Adaptations.funding_source: Global Partnership on Output based AID
Adaptations.success_factors: delivery of the pre agreed outputs, provision of reliable water services, payment of subscription fees
Adaptations.limiting_factors: non payment of user fee, non functioning water treatment plant, high cost of drinking water
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no regret: the financially viable arrangement for provision of clean drinking water to poor communities will work inspite of climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: As of September 2008, four CSWSs have been constructed and verified, three in Krishna and one in West Godavari. The remaining 21 villages have been selected. The aid disbursement is made after meeting clearly defined three outputs, and the last payment is made after the project has worked and water charges are recovered for at least three months. Thus short term evaluation is in-built in the disbursement mechanism of the project.
Adaptations.comments: GPOBA is subsidizing the cost of setting up the water treatment plants in 25 villages through a US$800,000 grant. The subsidy is paid to Naandi in installments after independent verification of three pre-agreed outputs which Naandi pre-finances through commercial borrowing. Notably, a significant part of the subsidy is payable only after each CSWS proves it has provided reliable water services for at least three contiguous months after becoming operational.

Adaptations.title: Adaptive capacities of communities to cope with flood situations
Adaptations.description: Local communities adapt spontaneously to deal with problems of flood, water-logging and climate change.This booklet, collectively brought together by voluntary organizations working with the poor in the flood and water-log affected regions of Eastern Uttar Pradesh documents 45 indigenous adaptation practices. The broad objective of this compilation is to share these various local and traditional flood responsive ways and measures, with people over a larger area in order to build and strengthen their adaptive capabilities and capacities in tackling disasters like floods and thereby mitigating their impacts.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Gorakhpur Environmental Action Group, Post Box § 60, Gorakhpur-273001
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO:Gorakhpur Environmental Action Group (GEAG), Gorakhpur
Adaptations.success_factors: Established networks and trust with local NGOs, CBOs and communities and interaction over time to be able to observe directly as well as to elicit accurate information on adaptation practices.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Limitations to adaptation to flood situations by the community are: state of natural resources, basic physical infrastructure, livelihood systems, gender sensitivity and access to information
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no regret:The documentation of these measures is dependent on the occurrence of floods
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: In terms of the practices followed by the community to adapt to floods, the review shows that it helps them in bearing their losses and that they are able to return to their normal lives as soon as possible with whatever resources they are left with. Remarkably, there is no wide scale migration and people continue to inhabit these regions and learn to live with floods. The documentation of these practices has itself been widely circulated to multiple NGOs, organisations and donors working on climate change adaptation int he country.
Adaptations.comments: The review found that a communitys adaptive capacities are affected mainly by · The state of natural resources in the area. · The livelihood system and opportunities at the local level. · Income generating opportunities outside, in the nearby areas. · Basic physical infrastructures, services and facilities like roads, housing, drinking water, etc. at the local level. · The areas socio-economic and gender sensitivities. · Peoples accessibility to information and know-how. · Social capital in the community

Adaptations.title: Participatory Varietal Selection and Promotion (PVSP)
Adaptations.description: The PVSP programme aims at introduction and validation of Participatory Varietal Selection and Promotion methodology for crop varieties. A pilot project was undertaken in selected districts in Bihar to enhance livelihoods condition through productivity enhancement and to establish farmers’ rights especially, enabling the farmers from resource poor areas in exerting their choice in selection of seeds and technologies that best suits their area. The main crop chosen was moong – grown in the summer months in between wheat and rice. Based on farmer preferences four new varieties of moong were tested through a process of mother and baby plots. The primary focus is testing & validating PVSP through farmers’ participation and dissemination of the same in nearby villages about the technology as well as the varieties tested and ultimately, developing a varietal portfolio of that area. The new varieties led to to 200-300% increase in yield.
Adaptations.contact_person: Mr Asish Mandal, Action for Social Advancement (ASA)
Adaptations.contact_adress: E-5/A, Girish Kunj, Above State Bank of Indore (Shahpura Branch), Bhopal 462 016 Madhya Pradesh
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO:ASA
Adaptations.funding_source: Govt.: Bihar Rural Livelihood Promotion Society (BRLPS
Adaptations.success_factors: traditional growers of moong seed (familiar with crop) , minimum landholding of 400 sq mtrs, access to irrigation (essential at sowing time), member of SHG, small/medium farmers, better results in uplands which have better drainage, and if farmers are able to sow the seed in time which allows harvesting of moong pods 3-5 times before the monsoon
Adaptations.limiting_factors: ability to rent pumps for irrigating and timely sowing, untimely monsoon, training network, availability of improved seed varieties
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret: Increased productivity, taste, texture of crops leading to enhanced income
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: In Bihar the World Bank funded Bihar Rural Livelihood Project (BRLP) is implementing PVS in three districts with technical support by ASA. In the initial phase trials were done with 4 new varieties of moong seed – leading to yields of 10-17 q/ha, as opposed to 2-5 q/ha with the local seeds. It plans to reach more than 48000 farmer households through PVS processes during 2008-2011, of which about 8000 have been covered already. http://www.researchintouse.com/resources/riu09impact5india-crop.pdf
Adaptations.comments: Training camps helped orient farmers. Village resource persons were appointed by ASA during the entire pilot phase to oversee the implementation for the PVSP program

Adaptations.title: Land shaping promotes crop irrigation and prevents water stagnation
Adaptations.description: The low-lying area of the Sundarbans in West Bengal is well-known for frequent floods and cyclones. Water stagnates from June-July and remains muddy upto December making it impossible to grow any crop except the low yielding variety. Ramakrishna Mission Lokasiksha Parishad (RKMLSP) undertook a unique project of Land Shaping wherein a part of a field is raised artificially under its rural livelihoods program. The idea of digging ponds to raise the low land with the help of excavated earth provided sufficient rain water for crop irrigation as well as prevented water stagnation. The available land for crop cultivation for marginal farmers was about 0.2 to 0.6 hectare each. One-fifth (20 per cent) of the land selected for LS is dug up to a depth of 2.4 meters. The excavation could be in the center of the plot or on the side – according to the shape and size of the plot. With the excavated earth, a raised bund of 75 cm, along the boundary of the area is made, to stop water from entering the area. This made it suitable for the cultivation of High Yielding variety (HYV) rice, vegetables etc. On the original low land traditional varieties of rice is grown during monsoon season and chillies, sunflower or water melon is grown during winter season using the pond water. Land Shaping (LS) combined with the Integrated Farming Systems Approach is one of the main factors for enhancing productivity in a sustainable way in the Sundarban.The Ramkrishna Mission Loka-Siksha Parishad (RKMLSP), Narendrapur works in 4 blocks in Sundarban where it has so far completed around 1,600 LS projects in small and marginal farmers’ fields in the Sunderbans area in which the low-lying flood-prone land (plots of 1 to 4 bighas) has been raised by excavating a pond, covering 20-25% area of the plot, at an appropriate position for rain water harvesting and using the excavated soil for making bunds and uplands and lifting the said pond water for irrigating the rabi crops.
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr. Manas Ghosh/ Mr K Patra
Adaptations.contact_adress: Ramakrishna Mission Ashrama, Narendrapur, Kolkata 700 103, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ramakrishna Mission Lokasiksha Parishad (RKMLSP)
Adaptations.success_factors: stagnant water, inability to raise HYV crops, saline water, medium landholding
Adaptations.limiting_factors: willingness to dig a pond in individual farmland
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no regret: In a flood prone area such as Sundarbans this practice will help farmers cope and ensure higher economic returns
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "The Ramkrishna Mission Loka-Siksha Parishad (RKMLSP), Narendrapur in the outskirts of Kolkata has so far completed around 1,600 LS projects in small and marginal farmers’ fields in the Sunderbans area in which the low-lying flood-prone land (plots of 1 to 4 bighas) has been raised by excavating a pond, covering 20-25% area of the plot, at an appropriate position for rain water harvesting and using the excavated soil for making bunds and uplands and lifting the said pond water for irrigating the rabi crops. The pond is used besides irrigation for fish and duck rearing. A small part of the raised land would also accommodate a cattle shed for 3-4 cows and a small poultry-cum-duck near the farmer’s house for about 15-20 poultry birds and 10-15 ducks. The cattle dung and bird excreata are used for compost making along with crop residues and farm wastes; also most farmers produce vermicomposts for raising vegetables and other high value crops. The integration of crop farming with livestock usually cattle, duckery and poultry has resulted in a high level of synergy giving the farmers a 3-4 fold increase in income."
Adaptations.comments: In the last 15 years, RKM in collaboration with other organisations like Ford Foundation, German Agro Action, CAPART, has successfully developed more than 600 individual LS sites and motivated about 1000 families to develop LS for sustainable production and socio-economic development.

Adaptations.title: Sustainable Livelihoods through Organic Farming
Adaptations.description: The main objective of the project is to create livelihoods through organic farming by organizing farmer’s sanghams to cultivate certified seed which are marketed as truth labeled seeds (TFL). A total of 408.57 acres have been selected for input support and crop loan schemes. In addition farmer training sessions and exposure visits are also organised. Demonstration fields have been established in 24 acres in Kancheepuram, Dindigul, Nagapattinam and Ramanathapuram districts where various organic farming technologies like preparation and application of plant growth regulators, using pheromone traps and mechanical traps for pest control, preparation of vermicompost and compost, Azolla cultivation, collection and usage of cow’s urine, using farm ponds for irrigation etc. have been implemented. Infrastructure like a seed grading and processing unit, threshing yard and a training centre have been constructed and efforts are on to set up biopesticide and vermicompost production units in the beneficiary villages.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 30 Gandhi Mandapam Road,
Adaptations.initiating_agent: NGO: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems
Adaptations.success_factors: training programmes, exposure visits, participation in agri exhibitions and fairs, conducting food festivals, capacity building of partner NGOs, recovery of yields for farmers
Adaptations.limiting_factors: low initial returns from agriculture after conversion, initial start up cost
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: yes: use of vermicompost and biopesticide
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no regret: low input agriculture and enhances nutrient value of soil
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Organic seed production is in progress in 175.38 acres in Kancheepuram, Ramanathapuram, Dindigul and Nagapattinam districts. A total of 408.57 acres have been selected for input support and crop loan schemes. Under this component of organic seed production, certified organic seeds and truthfully labeled seeds (TFL) are being produced. Inputs like quality breeder seeds and foundation seeds of paddy varieties, groundnut, blackgram and sesame, organic inputs like green manure seeds, neem cake, biofertilizers, vermicompost and mechanical traps have been distributed to the beneficiaries.
Adaptations.comments: During the period of conversion to organic farmers require support in the form of quality inputs and crop loans for conversion. Under this component, a total of 410.04 acres have been identified from all the four districts for conversion to organic farming by providing input support and crop loan. Inputs like neem cake, biofertilizers, vermicompost and mechanical traps were distributed. Crop loans have been provided for the cultivation in 199.97 acres and for establishing vermicompost production units in Nagapattinam district.

Adaptations.title: Assessment of small and medium scale hydropower plants: synergies and trade offs with rural development
Adaptations.description:
"Lao Cai is a mountainous Vietnamese province with a large potential for development of small and medium scale hydropower plants and a poor population. An innovative possibility would be to explore the scope for small and medium scale hydropower to generate win-win benefits, i.e. both rural development and climate change adaptation advantages in addition to the climate change mitigation ones. There are several potential climate chaneg adaptation and human well-being benefits from small and medium scale hydropower plants. The present project has therefore been launched to analyze the effect of small and medium sized hydropower plants on the adaptation to a changed climate and the possible symbioses and trade offs with the rural development.
The project’s objectives are:
1. To understand the benefits of small and medium scale hydropower plants in climate change adaptation as well as rural development; 
2. To recommend mitigation measures to minimize impacts from small and medium scale hydropower plants on environment and human well-being, especially to poor communities."
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr.Tran Thuc - General Director – Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment
Adaptations.contact_adress: 23/62 Nguyen Chi Thanh, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
Adaptations.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment
Adaptations.success_factors: Local government needs to implement and mainstream accordingly
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of public awareness on climate change in communities
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Besides the benefits to climate change adaptation and mitigation, the project’s results had many recommendations related to the rural development
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Project provided good understand of the benefits of small and medium scale hydropower in climate change adaptation and mitigation include the changes of the hydrological pattern with storage capacities in hydropower reservoirs so that can decrease flash-flood and releasing of water stored in hydropower reservoirs give positive effects on downstream water supply and irrigation.
Furthermore, the project had some recommendations about the rural development that synergy to climate change mitigation and adaptation. With dissemination workshop, these recommendations were communicated to policy makers in local authorities, and they will be use as a scientific basis in development plan of Lao Cai province."
Adaptations.comments: No

Adaptations.title: Vietnam Coastal Zone Vulnerability Assessment and First Steps towards Integrated Coastal Zone Management
Adaptations.description:
"This project assessed the vulnerability of the entire coastal zone of Vietnam to the effects of sea-level rise and identified and prioritised risk reduction options including legal/institutional, economic/financial, technical, biological, physical and infrastructure options and developed an approach for integrated coastal zone management in Vietnam. The focus of this project was to support, guide and strengthen Vietnamese capabilities in facing the complex technical , institutional and organizational matters involved in the effective management of the Vietnamese coastal zone.
Therefore the project used GIS (Geographic information systems) analysis which determined areas of different land-use types inundated by various flood scenarios. And provided loss and risk figures for land use types, population and capital value, reviewed and implications analyzed future development trends as well as institutional, organizational arrangements for coastal zone management.
The findings supported the implementation of a integrated coastal zone management project that time was being planned."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Vietnam’s Administration for Sea and Islands
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Hydrometeorological Service of Vietnam and The General Deparment of International Cooperation of The Netherlands Ministery of Foreign Affairs
Adaptations.executing_agent: The Maria Hydrometeorological Centre of Vietnam and Frederic R Harris and Delft Hydraulics of the Netherlands
Adaptations.success_factors: Mainstreaming the results findings to the coastal zone management planning.
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"- Lack of awareness of climate change issues.
- The constrain of financial resources"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: not specified
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project has created momentum to strengthen the cooperation between authorities on national, provincial, district and local level on coastal management. As such the project has evolved from a climate change-orientated analysis towards a broader scope of development problems in the coastal zone. 
-Recommendations have been made with associated actions to strengthen local capabilities for Coastal Zone Management. It has thereby contributed to the awareness of the need for ICZM. 
- Three pilot studies identified typical concrete issues and problems as bellows:
The coastal sediment deficits (Nam Dinh), sustainable aquaculture development (Thua Thien-Hue), sustainable harbour development (Ba ria Vung tau) and producing dike safety standards and design manuals for coastal defence.
- Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops and the project received extensive media coverage."
Adaptations.comments: Pilot studies were conducted at the three sites: Nam Dinh province (sea dyke erosion), Thua Thien-Hue province (Flooding and Lagoon management) and Ba ria-Vung tau province (Coastal Management and Planning).

Adaptations.title: Polyhouses for Diversification of Agriculture
Adaptations.description: The polyhouses are protective shades constructed with the help of ultraviolet plastic sheets. The structure is prepared with the bamboos or iron pipes. Iron pipe structure is costly but more durable than bamboo. The size of polyhouse may differ depending on the necessity. The direction of polyhouse is always East to West, so that the maximum sunshine is available. The house should not be constructed in shade. The polyhouses are kept cold or hot depending upon the season. Crops growing under the polyhouse are safe from unfavourable environment and hailstorm, heavy rains or scorching sunshine, etc. The humidity of polyhouse is not adversely affected by evaporation resulting in less requirement of water. In limited area of polyhouse, insects and pests control is also easy and less expensive. By adopting the modern technology of polyhouse, the difference in the demand and supply of off-season vegetables and fruits etc. can be minimised. This facilitates in maintaining the quality of the product also.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Krishi Bhawan, Boileauganj, Shimla-171005, Himachal Pradesh, India
Adaptations.source: (1) Department of Agriculture, Government Of Himachal Pradesh, http://www.hpagriculture.com/ (2) IndiaAgronet Agriculture Resource Center http://www.indiaagronet.com/indiaagronet/Hi_Tech/HiTech.htm
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
Adaptations.funding_source: NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development)
Adaptations.success_factors: financial assistance:Installation of these structures is expensive and thus for adoption by farmers they would have to be subsidized, quality material and followup support
Adaptations.limiting_factors: High initial cost
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: economic development, water conservation, social welfare (employment)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project monitoring and evaluation is to be conducted by the – State level committee constituted for the smooth implementation of the project. By the funding agency i.e. NABARD, State level project implementation unit, D.N.O. (District Nodal Officer) and PIA (Project Implementation Agency, subject matter specialists) With the adoption of green house/poly house technology, farmers are growing high value cash crops like capsicum, tomato, cucumber, leafy vegetables etc. The productivity of crops is 4 to 10 times higher and quality of produce is better. The incidence of pests and diseases is very low with better management. The cost of production has reduced considerably and the production is of better quality.
Adaptations.comments: "This project is one part of the ""Pandit Deen Dyal Kisan Bagwan Samridhi Yojna"" that has two main components: Production of cash crops through adoption of precision farming practices through poly house cultivation and Project on Diversification of Agriculture through Micro-Irrigation and other related infrastructure."
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Please provide the title in English. Maybe you can provide more detailed information about the two parts, by splitting up this Project into these two parts. You can highlight this fact in the Title (e.g. Pandit Deen Dyal Kisan Bagwan Samridhi Yojna – Part 1, Pandit Deen Dyal Kisan Bagwan Samridhi Yojna – Part 2) or as a short comment (This is part 1 of the Pandit Deen Dyal Kisan Bagwan Samridhi Yojna) But please provide a translation of the title. I’ve really no idea what it means. Sorry. Thank You.

Adaptations.title: Nagaland Environment Protection and Economic Development
Adaptations.description: Nagaland Environment Protection and Economic Development (NEPED) Project was initiated to find solutions to the practice of shifting cultivation by altering the practice to make it more sustainable rather than try to stop it. To make the practice more sustainable a tree component (agro-forestry) was included with annual crops along with enriched fallow management systems (leaving stumps of Alnus nepalensis, a nitrogen fixing tree, to enhance regeneration and soil fertility) with soil erosion control measures. This helped in soil moisture and nutrient retention, reduction in erosion and diversifying the income base of tribals.
Adaptations.contact_person: Nagaland Environment Protection and Economic Development (NEPED)
Adaptations.contact_adress: NEPED Kohima, Nagaland - 797001, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government: Project Operation Unit (State level), Local NGOs (village level)
Adaptations.funding_source: Government of India and India Canada Environment Facility (ICEF)
Adaptations.success_factors: awareness: Making the communities aware about the negative impacts of conventional shifting cultivation will make adoption of the altered way of shifting cultivation easy
Adaptations.limiting_factors: responsiveness of the communities to adopt to the changed practices, returns: If the returns to the communities are lower than that by the conventional process then the community will not adopt the practice
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: economic returns from agroforestry, environmental benefits by reduced use of Jhum, social welfare
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project was surveyed in the year 1999 when it was found that the replication of the model in the villages is 1:6, i.e there was a six times increase in the area under use of the practice covering a total area of about 33,000 ha from an initial 5500ha. A total of 7.8 million trees were planted. The project success made it possible to go into the second phase for empowerment and economic development. The project success can be attributed to the wide scale acceptance of alternate jhum, continuation of the project from the first phase focusing on environment protection to the second phase focusing on economic empowerment (looks at activities related to additional farming systems over and above the subsistence jhum farming and is more market oriented) and the third one focusing on energy empowerment (to meet the need for energy, upscale power generation to augment energy requirements which is cheap, green and clean .
Adaptations.comments: NEPED has been implemented in two phases and the third one is currently being implemented. In the first two phases the project activities were carried out by the funds made available by ICEF, in the third phase NEPED has been registered as an autonomous institution catering to plantations, micro-credits and several other developmental activities to make it independent of external funding.

Adaptations.title: North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Project for Upland Areas
Adaptations.description: NERCORMP is a livelihood and rural development project initiated to improve the livelihood of the communities by setting up community based Institutions (CBIs) at the grassroots level called – Natural Resources Management Groups (NaRM-Gs) and Self Help Groups (SHG) to provide resilience to local communities by diversifying and increasing income levels, enhancing sustainable use of resources through improving village infrastructure, shifting cultivation practices, biodiversity conservation, grants for enterprise development. It has benefited people by increasing drinking water facility, increasing crop production, increased Non Timber Forest Product (NTFP) collection, etc.
Adaptations.contact_person: North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Project for Upland Areas (NERCORMP)
Adaptations.contact_adress: """Symli Building"", First Floor, Malki-Dhankheti, Shillong-793001, Meghalaya "
Adaptations.executing_agent: North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Society and partner NGOs
Adaptations.funding_source: International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), North Eastern Council, Ministry of DoNER
Adaptations.success_factors: "Institutional:for proper functioning of all the activities; Financial:initial cost for enterprise development"
Adaptations.limiting_factors: community participation, capacity and institution building (without community mobilisation and capacity building the project would not be effective)
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: reduced carbon emissions (abandonment of shifting cultivation practice)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret: economic development (increase in income and agricultural practices), environmental benefits (reduced practice of shifting cultivation)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: An evaluation of the Project was carried out by the Office of Evaluation of the IFAD in 2005 concluding that the Project’s overall impact on poverty deserved a ranking of 5 out of a maximum 6. A wealth ranking exercise conducted by the Project at the completion (PCR) showed that, out of the 86 per cent of the participating households who were below the poverty line at the commencement of the Project, only 18 per cent continued in poverty and the rest 68 per cent had moved up. Jointly, Ministry of Development of North Eastern Region, through the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) of Government of India approached the World Bank to replicate the ‘IFAD model’ in all the 8 NER states. A post project sustainability evaluation has been recommended. An endline evaluation was conducted in May, in 2008 The review after project completion states that the project covered 860 villages against the proposed 1000 villages.The project has formed 1012 NaRM-Gs, 3168 SHGs, 103 Narm-g Cluster Associations and 103 SHG Federations. Socio-economically the number of households having easy access to water increased by 42%, abandonment of jhum by 15% of the households, increase in other cultivation practices such as terrace, orchard and home garden/vegetable cultivation and an increase in NTFP collection (31%), the area under plantation increased by 2716.37 ha. The project resulted in biodiversity and forest conservation of 1835.89 km square area. The increase in overall household income as per base line and endline survey for the six districts was 66%.
Adaptations.comments: In the year 2009 a proposal for expansion of the project to the entire North Eastern region was proposed (NERCORMP-II)

Adaptations.title: Mangrove Forest Restoration in Andhra Pradesh
Adaptations.description: The project was initiated to restore degraded mangroves and prevent further damage and entailed identifying degraded mangrove areas, floristic studies to determine the extent of damage and the species composition to help decide the species to be planted. Restoration works was being carried out by the forest department since 1991 but the technique of canal building to improve easy water flow was started after the intervention by MSSRF. Canals were designed in a fish bone pattern and a trapezoidal shape. The seedlings were planted at the mid level of the canal so that they recieve water at all times but do not submerge. This resulted in restoring 520 ha of mangroves by the Village Level Institution (Eco-development Committee) and Vana Samrakshana Samiti (VSS).
Adaptations.contact_adress: 3rd Cross Street, Institutional Area, Taramani, Chennai – 600 113
Adaptations.executing_agent: MSSRF, Eco-Development Committee (EDC) and Vana Samrakshana Samiti (VSS), Andhra Pradesh Forest Department
Adaptations.success_factors: Local Institutions: Canal digging, planting and desilting, all these activities are carried out by community involvement
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Financial (high initial cost)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: social welfare (providing employment and also increasing fishery resources), environmental protection and conservation (buffer against climate extremes-coastal storms, tidal surges), reduced soil erosion
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project has successfully tested a process for restoring mangroves in multiple sites. 520 ha of area has been restored in 3 districts in the project. Capacity has been built of NGOs and labour. NGOs in the region who were trained in mangrove restoration work have restored an additional area of 215 ha of degraded mangroves. Villagers trained have become skilled in canal digging, planting and desilting can can further the cause of restoring 9442 ha of degraded mangrove forests (Eight village level Institutions).
Adaptations.comments: The species used for plantation were Avicennia marina, Avicennia officinalis and Excoecaria agallocha as these species can tolerate wide range of salinity. The members of the NGOs, namely Sravanthi, Action in Godavari area, Sangamithra Service Society and Coastal Community Development Program in Krishna, were trained in restoration techniques and in participatory approaches in community mobilization and mangrove management (increasing their income) because of the labour force required for such extensive work.

Adaptations.title: Financing Adaptation by carbon credits for air travel
Adaptations.description: "The initiative offers air travelers the option of offsetting the CO2 emission that they would undertake during their upcoming flight, by donating towards the planting of trees. This tree donation option is integrated with the flight booking process on the MakeMyTrip website itself; wherein an air traveler can voluntarily choose to be part of the project by selecting the number of trees he/she wants to plant. A travelers CO2 emission is calculated on the distance that s/he would undertake and the average CO2 emission by an aircraft /mile therein. The project is carried out on filed by the NGO based in Rajasthan SevaMandir. Though this project is primarily a mitigation project it helps the local communities of the Udaipur and Rajsamand Districts of Rajasthan to adapt to the changing climate by increasing their resource base. The activities under the initiative involve tree plantations, boundary wall erection around plantations and water harvesting (digging trenches, gully plugging and construction of check dams). The plantations ensure fodder and shade for cattle, reduce soil erosion and increased agricultural productivity due to improved moisture retention."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Old Fatehpura, Udaipur 313004, Rajasthan, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Seva Mandir, local communities (hamlets of the state)
Adaptations.success_factors: set up institutional network of community organisations to implement the activities and a robust monitoring mechanism
Adaptations.limiting_factors: no
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increases resource base for the local communities in the form of fodder and fuel wood, conserves soil and water
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: ci:grasp specifically aims at providing information on the adaptation to climate change. This project deals with its mitigation and is therefore unfortunately not suitable for the database. Thank you! Your ci:grasp team.

Adaptations.title: Weather based crop Insurance Scheme
Adaptations.description: Weather Based Crop Insurance (WBCI) aims to mitigate the hardship of the insured farmers against the likelihood of financial loss on account of anticipated crop loss resulting from incidence of adverse conditions of weather parameters like rainfall, temperature, frost, humidity etc.The Ministry of Agriculture has sanctioned Rs. 17.34 crores towards weather-based insurance for chilli crop in Guntur district to the losses incurred in the last Rabi season (2009-10). The expenditure, to be incurred by the government, would be entirely borne by the Agriculture Insurance Company of India Limited which is vested with the responsibility of implementing National Agricultural Insurance Scheme.
Adaptations.contact_person: M Parshad, Agriculture Insurance Company of India
Adaptations.contact_adress: 13th Floor, AMBA DEEP, 14, Kasturba Gandhi Marg, Connaught Place, New Delhi - 110 001, INDIA
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Government: Ministry of Agriculture, Government of Andhra Pradesh
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government: Agriculture Insurance Company of India
Adaptations.funding_source: Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India
Adaptations.success_factors: Financial: ability of farmers to pay premium, Technical: correlating weather indices with yield losses, needs upto 25 years historical weather data, accurate recording of weather phenomenon at appropriate spatial and temporal scales, simple claim process and timely payments
Adaptations.limiting_factors: distance of the farm from the weather station, non-coverage of perils other than weather, wider sowing / planting window of the crop, differences in soil types & management practices, shift in climatic and weather patterns, etc. leading to weak correlation between the yield and the weather indices, etc.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win win
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: 17,000 farmers covered, 12000 ha covered and 11.5 crores total premium received. The WBCIS has provided enormous benefits to the Chilly growers in the first season. The number of farmers receiving the benefit was 16,357 and the total amount of claims was Rs 17.34 crore. According to a press release,the number of mandals receiving the benefit was 38. The Agriculture Insurance Company of India CMD said WBCIS has been launched for Red Chilly growers in Guntur district during Kharif 2009 season on a pilot basis. The Company had conducted awareness programmes among the farmers, obtained their consent and provided a customized product as per their requirement.
Adaptations.comments: The Agriculture Insurance Company of India CMD said Weather-Based Crop Insurance Scheme (WBCIS) has been launched for Red Chilly growers in Guntur district during Kharif 2009 season on a pilot basis. The Company had conducted awareness programmes among the farmers, obtained their consent and provided a customized product as per their requirement. WBCIS, which was effectively implemented in Guntur district, has been extended to other districts also for crops like cotton, chilly, oil palm and sweet lime this year.

Adaptations.title: Capacity Building on Climate Change for Civil Society Organizations
Adaptations.description:
"The Project’s objective is to raise awareness and build capacity of civil society, focusing on non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and their partners, to effectively respond to and integrate climate change adaptation and mitigation into relevant existing and future programs to contribute to long term sustainable development of the country and Vietnamese people.
The main components addressing capacity needs are: “Communication and coordination”, “Training on adaptation and mitigation” and “Learning and sharing”.
Therefore the project tries to increased NGOs access to information, communication and coordination on climate change through websites, E-bulletins, newsletters, fact sheets, video clips, movies which will produced by the project.
Furthermore 16 training courses, 3 Training of Trainer ( TOT) courses for NGOs’ local partners will be organized to increase the knowledge and skills on CC adaptation, mitigation and capacity to integrate CC and Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) into existing projects
Last step is to enhanced sharing and learning on practical experience and good models of climate change adaptation through 5 sharing workshops and 2 study tours at existing climate change project side."
Adaptations.contact_person: The Centre for Sustainable Rural Development
Adaptations.contact_adress: No.56, Lane 19/9, Kim Dong street, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The Climate Change Working Group (CCWG) and the Vietnam Non-Governmental Organisations & Climate Change network (VNGO&CC)
Adaptations.executing_agent: The Centre for Sustainable Rural Development (SRD)
Adaptations.success_factors:
"- Sources of information accuracy, completeness and quality of climate change.
- The active participation of NGO’s communities."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of knowledge for CC impacts, vulnerability and adaptation
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Enhancing cooperation between NGOs in Vietnam for Climate change activities
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project is still under implementation.
Adaptations.comments: The Climate Change Working Group (CCWG) and the Vietnam Non-Governmental Organisations & Climate Change Network (VNGO & CC) were formed in 2008 which aim to reduce the vulnerability of poor people in Vietnam to the impacts of climate change through developing and supporting environmentally and economically sustainable and socially just responses to climate change, among which capacity building has been identified as a core objective. This project is very practical for Vietnam in the context of climate change. As the time and financial limited it should have taken the next phase to expand the beneficiaries from the project as well as maintaining the sustainability of the project.

Adaptations.title: Babassu palms - Harvesting the fruits for oil and protein
Adaptations.description: The Guajá of the eastern Amazon, constitute one of the few remaining hunter-gatherer cultures on earth. They occupy a region in the eastern Amazon which is generally characterized as a seasonally dry tropical forest with a dry season from June to December. The palms support regional peasants and indigenous groups with a reliable source of food. Few predators can access these kernels, as the fruits are very hard and it takes 5 tons of pressure to break them. Babassu kernels are good sources of oil and protein, which are often not readily available to the native populations of Amazonia. Other uses of the babassu palm include construction material, woven containers, mats, fuel and ritual applications. The palm is fire-resistant, juveniles (pindovas) can remain in the forest under-story for as long as 50 years, ultimately yielding an accumulation of up to 6,000 plants/ha.
Adaptations.contact_person: Louis C. Forline or Museu Goeldi, Departemento de Ciências Humanas
Adaptations.contact_adress: Avenido Perimetral, 1901, Belém , Pará Brazil CEP 66.077-530
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Local Coping Strategies Databse, Indigenous Knowledge and Development Monitor, http://web.archive.org/web/20041215133728/www.nuffic.nl/ciran/ikdm/8-3/forline.html
Adaptations.success_factors: palm seeds and seedlings, labour
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: While there are a host of other non-timber forest products used and managed by the Guajá, the use of one species, babassu, demonstrates the intimate balance they have forged with natural resources.
