In many cases, the presence of babassu palms is an indication of past habitation and cultivation by indigenous groups and peasants. The Guajá provide a example of the sustainable use and management of natural resources. Indeed, Guajá management practices may serve as a model within rural development. The integration of these practices would, of course, require further studies, partnerships with NGOs, entrepreneurial cooperation, and the formulation of government policy. Essential in facilitating the use of non-timber forest products is respecting indigenous autonomy, in the interest of a successful and ongoing project.
Adaptations.comments: In pre-colonial Brazil, stands of babassu palms served as a dietary supplement. Such stands were an important source of fuel and fibre, and formed a hedge against starvation. Today, the Guajá eat mainly the kernels (nuts) of the babassu fruit.

Adaptations.title: Recycling Scrap Tires into Retaining Walls
Adaptations.description:
"Retaining walls made with scrap tires are helping to raise living standards in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro.
A team of researchers has discovered that the tire walls, built for less than one-third of the cost of conventional anchored concrete retaining walls used elsewhere in the city, may be more effective at stopping landslides during the rainy seasons. First the project team built a test wall in an isolated area and embedded it with measuring instruments to measure its performance. The team used a specially designed saw to slice off one side wall in each tire, tied the tires together in a honeycomb pattern using polypropylene rope, and packed them full of compacted earth. The test walls were layered up to six meters high.
These retaining walls are an economically viable and environmentally sustainable way of building low-cost structures. The walls could be constructed under engineering supervision, by the people themselves."
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr Luciano Medeiros, Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro
Adaptations.contact_adress: Rua Marques de Sao Vicente 225 Gavea, Rio de Janeiro CEP 22453 Brazil
Adaptations.source: UNFCCC Local Coping Strategies Database, IDRC http://www.idrc.ca/en/ev-5145-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html
Adaptations.executing_agent: Pontifícia Universidade Católica (PUC) do Rio de Janeiro, Fundacao Instituto Geotecnica of the Municipality of Rio de Janeiro (GEO-RIO )
Adaptations.success_factors: technical expertise on designing and construction retaining walls, tires
Adaptations.limiting_factors: It is not yet known how high the walls may be built, or how solid they will remain on very swampy or compressible ground over the long term.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, regarding the fact that in Rio alone, more than three million tires are disposed of each year. Many of these tires are illegally burned.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option, reduces injuries and deaths, reduces property losses and save the environment.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Even before the test wall was finished, local authorities were so impressed that they constructed another wall in one of the hillside slum communities. After they constructed the wall, GEO-RIO cleaned up gullies and provided drainage. Shortly after, they had torrential rainfalls. The downpour caused several concrete walls to collapse and several poor housing to be washed away elsewhere in Rio but the tire structures held. Where there had initially been skepticism about the wall, some people felt that as residents of a low-income area they were being given a substandard replacement for concrete, there was now total acceptance.
After seeing the wall’s success on the hillsides, citizens’ groups are already adapting them for their own uses. One small fishing community on a swampy tidal inlet in northern Rio collected tires to build a jetty, and planted it with trees and shrubs to keep tidal water from washing into their homes."
Adaptations.comments: Many landslides begin when loose debris from illegal hillside garbage dumps becomes sodden and topples under its own weight. The heavy material crashes into the mainly plywood shack dwellings below, causing deaths and property damage every rainy season.

Adaptations.title: Sustainable practices for the cultivation of cherimoya
Adaptations.description: The project aims to reduce the vulnerability of the agriculture and fishing productive system of two communities, Oconi and Pie de la Cuesta located within the ecosystem of the xeromorphic forest of Saipina, by contributing environment’s conservation, regulation of water system and the improvement of food security. The beneficiaries of the project will be reached through a training, action, spreading of knowledge and technology development program that will try to identify the factors that affect their productive conditions. To achieve this, it is intended to improve and set up a cherimoya (a native Andes-highland fruit) garden, using agroforestry techniques that will allow for the conservation and proper use of lands, using contour lines and terraces techniques. Furthermore, it will be created several norms to regulate water use in the communities of the medium and higher sites of the basin, as well as norms on sustainable use of natural resources. These norms will be strengthened through bylaws from the two municipalities that share the basin.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Km. 7 1/2 Doble vía a la Guardia, Santa Cruz - Bolivia
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO Fundación Amigos de la Naturaleza (FAN), local Authorities
Adaptations.success_factors: The two communities are dependent on the volume of water of the Oconi River, to water the inhabitants’ smallholdings. Because of this, in years where the precipitation is lower than normal, the River may almost run dry (from August to September), jeopardizing the production of the inhabitants.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The present project will have to face a couple of obstacles, most of them domestic. They are related to working with the beneficiaries on a new subject that has still to be worked on intensively so that they come to fully understand it.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The cherimoya production system has been improved (making it more resistant to climate pressures) in the Oconi and Pie de la Cuesta communities, through the improvement and setting up of gardens with agroforestry systems. Beneficiaries conscious and trained on adaptation to climate change, through sustainable land and water use practices. The communities of the Oconi basin and the Saipina and Comarapa Municipalities have created local norms that promote adaptation to climate change.
Adaptations.comments: "The beneficiaries are nine families of the Pie de la Cuesta community and four families from the Oconi community. During the meetings that were organized to the present, up to 50% of the women participated; however, when it comes to committing to the project, most of them prefer if their husbands appear as beneficiaries, because most of them await for their husband’s or companion’s support before following an initiative."

Adaptations.title: Micro irrigation for Diversification of Agriculture
Adaptations.description:
"The term “micro-irrigation” describes a family of irrigation systems that apply water through small devices. These devices deliver water onto the soil surface very near the plant or below the soil surface directly into the plant root zone. 
Topography of the State is highly variable comprising of lands having negligible slopes to slopes as high as 50 to 60% where crops are raised. For installation of micro-irrigation systems assistance to the extent of 80% of the project cost shall be provided to the beneficiaries as project share. The remaining 20% cost shall be borne by the beneficiaries. Under the project, 17310 micro-irrigation systems are proposed to be installed (17,262 sprinkler and 50 drip) and Command area of 20007 hectares would be covered under economical and efficient irrigation systems. 
Due to variation in altitude and topography, the soil types particularly texture and depth are highly variable. Objective of the project is to induce cultivation of cash crops i.e. vegetables in the proposed project area which at present are under cereals, pulses and oilseeds."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Krishi Bhawan, Boileauganj, Shimla-171005, Himachal Pradesh, India
Adaptations.source: (1) Department of Agriculture, Government Of Himachal Pradesh, http://www.hpagriculture.com/ (2) Introduction to Micro-irrigation http://www.ag.ndsu.edu/pubs/ageng/irrigate/ae1243w.htm
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
Adaptations.funding_source: NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development)
Adaptations.success_factors: financial assistance:Installation of these structures is expensive and thus for adoption by farmers they would have to be subsidized, quality material and followup support
Adaptations.limiting_factors: High initial cost
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: economic development, water conservation, social welfare (employment)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project monitoring and evaluation is to be conducted by the – State level committee constituted for the smooth implementation of the project. By the funding agency i.e. NABARD, State level project implementation unit, D.N.O. (District Nodal Officer) and PIA (Project Implementation Agency, subject matter specialists) With the adoption of green house/poly house technology, farmers are growing high value cash crops like capsicum, tomato, cucumber, leafy vegetables etc. The productivity of crops is 4 to 10 times higher and quality of produce is better. The incidence of pests and diseases is very low with better management. The cost of production has reduced considerably and the production is of better quality.
Adaptations.comments: "This project is one part of the ""Pandit Deen Dyal Kisan Bagwan Samridhi Yojna"" that has two main components: Production of cash crops through adoption of precision farming practices through poly house cultivation and Project on Diversification of Agriculture through Micro-Irrigation and other related infrastructure."

Adaptations.title: Sustainable Development of Coastal Protected Forests
Adaptations.description:
"The Mekong Delta is particularly affected by the impacts of climate change. Rising sea levels and storms of increasing magnitude threaten the poor rural population, Viet Nam’s rice and shrimp production, and Ho Chi Minh City with increasing regularity. 
These hazards can be countered by improving coastal protection. Intact coastal forests attenuate the wind and waves and safeguard the embankments needed to protect the low-lying, extensive Mekong delta against inundation. 
The project advises and supports the provincial Agencies in the development of protective mechanisms for the coastal zone, the management and rehabilitation of the mangrove forests, and the development of implementation mechanisms. In order to improve coastal protection, coastal forests in Bac Lieu Province are being afforested and restored. Conservation zones for mangrove forests administered jointly by the local population and the provincial government are being established. At the same time, the economic situation of coastal populations is being improved. The people thus become less dependent upon the coastal forests and can use these more sustainably. In addition, local government staffs are being trained and relevant institutions are being strengthened."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 6th Floor, Hanoi Towers 49 Hai Ba Trung St. Hanoi Vietnam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), Eschborn / Hanoi, Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bac Lieu Province
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.success_factors: The response of the people involved and the local government.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The lack of cooperation mechanism for integrating sustainable management and the use of natural resources, as well as overlapping competencies among various offices and economic interests (shrimp farms).
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, through carbon sequestration by the mangroves.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win:
"Win-Win option:
- Storm surge-wave and erosion prevention
- Economic development, improve income for people"
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is under running.
- The expected results are:
+ The GTZ organisation will invest 300 million VND to build the first nursery breeding trees for mangrove forests in Bac Lieu province. The trees will be planted in the bird sanctuary and coastal forests, part of the project.
+ 60 hectares of mangroves forest will be planted this year.
So far, the project has demonstrated the positive impact for adapting to climate change of the community."
Adaptations.comments: The project contributes to the conservation of climate-relevant biodiversity. A review is also under way of the extent to which restoring biodiversity in coastal zones may contribute to adapting to climate change impacts. Successful approaches may also be implemented in other provinces of the Mekong delta. The project further contributes to improving the living conditions of the rural population.

Adaptations.title: Building equitable resilience to the impacts of climate change and disasters.
Adaptations.description:
"The project is focused in one of the coastal districts of Ben Tre Province- Binh Dai district where is prone-ness to sea level intrusion, impacting on agriculture, shrimp farming, forestation, water and other livelihoods. The project tried two adaptive livelihood models to support poor communities to apply new techniques and cultivation practices to improve productivity and income. 
Project’s goal is to improve livelihoods through increased access to climate risk management capacity building and crop tolerant diversification.
The project have three components:
i) Livelihood groups have contributed to natural resource management through conducting research, involvement in farmers’ field schools, and employing livelihoods adaptation options such as extension training, saline tolerant crops, adjusted seasonal calendar, land use management, cultivation practices for rice farmers, shrimp farmers, fishermen, salt producers, aquaculture collectives. Through these activities the resilience of livelihoods in Binh Dai district will be significantly increased.
ii) Integration climate risk analysis and adaptation activities into commune action plans through advocacy efforts.
iii) Local authorities and poor communities have improved knowledge in identifying climate risks, hazards and disasters, and have the necessary skills to employ traditional coping strategies, adaptive options and action planning."
Adaptations.contact_person: Bui Kim Huu, Project Coordinator, Oxfam Vietnam
Adaptations.contact_adress: 22 Le Dai Hanh Street, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Oxfam Vietnam and People Committee of Ben Tre Province
Adaptations.executing_agent: Oxfam Vietnam and Department of Agriculture and Rural Development of Ben Tre Province
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities 
-In-line with the National Strategy and Action Plan for Disaster Mitigation and Management."
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"- Short time scale
-Learning processes take a long time and require long term commitment"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is under implementing.
The expected outcomes are
-Integrate climate risks and adaptation measures in 2 commune action plans.
-Farmers benefit directly from the project measures: 3000 farmers gain access to early warning information on disasters in a timely and effective manner; 200 poor households receive appropriate water technologies.
-60 government staff and livelihood group leaders gain the necessary knowledge and skills to apply vulnerability analysis and adaptation action planning.
-200 farmers from 5 Farmers’ Field Schools gain CC knowledge and share innovative adaptation experiences."
Adaptations.comments: The project will be undertaken in two communes of Binh Dai district with a focus on the model building while training and awareness raising activities will be conducted in the whole communes.

Adaptations.title: Drought-Management Considerations for Climate Change Adaptation: Focus on the Mekong Region
Adaptations.description: During recent years, drought has become a common occurrence in most areas in the Mekong River Delta of the Mekong region, including nine provinces in the South of Vietnam. Ninh Thuan province is one of them that are most severely affected by drought. Droughts have been increasing in number, duration, and intensity. Prolonged dry periods have caused significant damage to agriculture and changed the salinity of groundwater thus damaging aquaculture. The project’s main objectives are: 1. To assess the climate vulnerability of rural communities in the most drought-prone areas of Ninh Thuan province. As part of this study, perception surveys were conducted to identify the degree to which the perceptions of communities limited the efficacy of the activities of various intervening agencies. 2. To identify possible adaptation measures to mitigate the impacts on rural communities of ever-increasing climate variability and change, in terms of droughts, with an emphasis on identification of adaptation measures.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 22 Le Dai Hanh Street, Hanoi, Vietnam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The People’s Committee of Ninh Thuan province
Adaptations.executing_agent: Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies of Kyoto University, Japan
Adaptations.funding_source: Oxfam in Viet Nam and The Kyoto University, Japan
Adaptations.success_factors: -Mainstreaming the results findings to the drought management plans. -Participating of stakeholders
Adaptations.limiting_factors: -Lack of mechanism to co-operation on identifying and implementing drought management and mitigation programmes -The constrain of financial resources
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: none
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: -This project provided an in-depth assessment of drought impacts on production and life in the driest areas of Ninh Thuan province (particularly the villages of An Hai, Ninh Phuoc District, and Phuoc Thanh, Bac Ai District) by analyzing the impact of drought on cultivation, stock breeding and aquaculture - Several adaptation measures have been analyzed and proposed such as developing drought-resistant crop seeds, setting up groundwater irrigation systems with high–efficiency, providing new seed species and vaccines at preferential prices, and offering low-interest loans for drought control. - Analyzed and assigned drought control responsibilities and missions at both central and provincial levels (including civil society organizations and NGOs). - Proposed to building upon social institutions like village Self-Help Groups (SHGs), women’s groups, and village water sub-committees, and to promote better forest management for the avoidance of forest fires.
Adaptations.comments: The project used a mix of vulnerability-assessment methodologies, in response to the interdisciplinary nature of the problem. A combination of participatory rural appraisal techniques was used in the study.

Adaptations.title: Netherlands Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM)
Adaptations.description:
"The project focused on the goal of advising the Vietnamese Government in planning and development of the Vietnamese coastal zone, its communities and its resources in a sustainable way, for which ICZM is introduced and accepted as the suitable and effective approach. More particularly, the Project aimed to provide capacity, technical and operational support for the first 3 years of a desired longer term Vietnam ICZM Programme. 
The work was conducted in Hanoi and in three pilot provinces including Nam Dinh (north), Thua Thien – Hue (central) and Ba ria – Vung tau (south) with participation of various national relevant ministries and agencies as well as provincial authorities.
The Project had main objectives: 
• Assist in establishing the required institutional structures and functional linkages between provincial, national and international institutions and stimulate dialogue and exchange of information on Coastal Zone Management across ministerial, institutional and provincial boundaries;
• Produce a practical guide, raise the awareness and enhance the capabilities 
of relevant decision takers and professional staff at national and provincial levels 
to prepare, review, approve and implement Strategy and Action Plans for ICZM
• Initiate short term application of ICZM in three provinces through practical problem solving approaches;
• Identify, provide and co-ordinate techniques, data and tools and train suitable staff and personnel for ICZM in Vietnam."
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr. Hua Chien Thang, Project Coordinator
Adaptations.contact_adress: Vietnam’s Administration for Sea and Islands, No.125 Trung kinh Street, Cau Giay District, Hanoi, Vietnam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Ministry of Natural Resource and Environment (MONRE), the Royal Netherlands Embassy (RNE) in Hanoi
Adaptations.executing_agent: Royal Haskoning, DHV Consultants, WL|Delft Hydraulics and Vietnam Environment Protection Agency of MONRE
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-The active participation of stakeholders.
-Engaging local and scientific knowledge.
-The implementation has to be done by governmental bodies and stakeholders in the coastal zone sectors"
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"Difficult to identify National level Authority to provide the integrated process ICZM to Socio-Economic Development Planning
-Insufficient of Management and Institutional capacities in the Coastal zones."
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: none
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"- Inventoried projects and plans relating ICZM activities.
- Three case studies for three provinces were completed: (i) Thua Thien-Hue province – Lagoon management to prevent flood impacts, overfishing and water quality problems; (ii) Ba Ria Vung Tau province – Management of planning conflicting pressures of tourism and industrial developments plus coastal erosion; (iii) Nam Dinh province – Sea dike erosion threatens coastal villages. 
Three studies contributed on producing a “Integrated Coastal Zone Management Strategy and Action Plan-ICZM SAP” at three provinces. One of the ICZM SAP for Thua Thien Hue has been approved by Province People Committee. Two others has been drafted.
- A training programme has provided that focused on introduction of ICZM principles, tools and techniques. It is conducted at national and provincial level. 
-Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops."
Adaptations.comments: The project design and implementations is based on the findings of the Coastal Zone Vulnerability Assessment Project completed and used ICZM methods and techniques to further introduce and develop ICZM which support the formulation of a national ICZM policy.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: These case studies you mentioned in the evaluation are very interesting. If possible, please enter these case studies as separated projects into ci:grasp. Thank you very much.

Adaptations.title: Developing a model in applying technologies addressing flash floods and droughts
Adaptations.description:
"Cam Tam Commune of Cam Thuy District is a poor and typical commune of the midland mountainous area of Thanh Hoa province in terms of topography, soil conditions, social custom, culture and agricultural practices. This area is regular suffered from effects of droughts and flash flood which threatened directly to property and people life.
The project aims to strengthen the preservation and sustainable use of natural resources to reduce impacts of droughts and flash flood on agricultural production at Cam Tam Commune.
The main objectives are i/ To build models for applying scientific-technological advances so as to limit damages caused by droughts and flash floods through reinforced protection and sustainable use of water resources, land and agricultural biodiversity; ii/ To promote the awareness and understanding of the local government authorities and inhabitants on the impacts of climate change on local sustainable development;"
Adaptations.contact_person: Nguyen Thi Kim Anh, Project Coordinator, UNDP Hanoi
Adaptations.contact_adress: 25-29 Phan Boi Chau Street, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.executing_agent: SGP VIET NAM
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-Participate of communities and local government.
-In-line with the National Strategy and Action Plan for Disaster Mitigation and Management."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is under implementing.
The expected outcomes are
i/ The model of protecting and using sustainably water resources (harvesting and storage of surface water and rainwater) successfully established, with 30 households provided the support to build (or improve) water-harvesting 50 m3 tank to store and supply water. 
ii/ The model of conserving and using land resources and biodiversity sustainably successfully established, with 20 ha of rice-planting land established ( with drought-resistant varieties and an appropriate rotating scheme ), 1-2 endemic mountainous rice varieties restored and developed; 8 hectares of flash flood-limiting model tested; 
iii/ 10-12 training courses and workshops organized with 500 participants therefore the awareness and understanding on the impacts of climate change and adaptation measures enhanced;"
Adaptations.comments: Developing a model in applying technologies to reduce vulnerabilities and to increase adaptive capacity in addressing flash flood and droughts

Adaptations.title: Conserving Biological Diversity
Adaptations.description: With 7100 islands and 36,000 km coastline, the Philippines is affected particularly by climate change impacts, and especially by sea-level rise. The increase in extreme weather events is leading to increased flooding and landslides, and to erosion and land loss along the coasts. This is also jeopardising the unique species diversity of the country. Policy-makers and the wider public have become aware of climate change impacts but a lack of consistent adaptation strategies remains. The project aims to develop strategies for adaptation to climate change and conservation of biodiversity and to implement these in specific cases. Existing structures such as the secretariat of the climate change committee will be strengthened by providing intensive consultancy and training. The development of national adaptation strategies will be supported in processes involving close cooperation with relevant government bodies, local authorities, the private sector and civil society. Moreover, tangible measures to conserve biodiversity will be financed within the context of small-scale projects. The project will also raise awareness among authorities and the population of the issues surrounding climate protection and climate change.
Adaptations.contact_person: Mr. Jochem Lange, GTZ Office Manila
Adaptations.contact_adress: PDCP Bank Centre P.O. Box 2218 MCPO Salcedo Village Makati City, Philippines
Adaptations.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), Eschborn / Manila, Department of Environment and Natural Resources (EnRD)
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Implementation is still running but, the Philippines will be helped to cope better with climate change impacts. Over the long term, the conservation and maintenance of biodiversity contributes to food security and to income generation for the population.
Adaptations.comments: German development cooperation in the Philippines focuses on the Visayas archipelago and the region of Caraga on the island of Mindanao.

Adaptations.title: Coral Triangle Initiative
Adaptations.description: "The Coral Triangle region in the Indo-Pacific Ocean is a global hotspot of marine life abundance and diversity. Destructive fishing practices, overexploitation of coastal and marine fisheries for local and export markets as well as the weakening of the adaptation capacity of the local flora and fauna as a result of climate change are leading to a loss of marine resources affecting the welfare of the population heavily dependent on the sea and its resources for livelihoods, food security and income. Covering the Economic Zones of Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Malaysia, Philippines, Timor Leste and the Solomon Islands, the loss of biodiversity in the region could affect more than 200 million people. In response, the governments of the six countries have launched a ""Coral Triangle Initiative on Coral Reefs, Fisheries and Food Security"". The project aims at establishing two large Marine Protection Areas respectively in the Savu Sea, Indonesia, and in the Kimbe Bay-Bismarck Sea area of Papua New Guinea to increase the regions resilience to climate change. A network of smaller Marine Protected Areas will combine science-based marine protection with community-based measures matching the socio-economic needs of the local population, in order to maintain a robust ecosystem which still allows for sustainable development."
Adaptations.contact_person: Alex Tanody, Savu Sea Marine Protected Area Development Project
Adaptations.contact_adress: Jl. Bung Tomo Blok 1 No 3, Kelurahan Kelapa Lima Kupang Nusa Tenggara Timur 85228 Indonesia
Adaptations.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.executing_agent: "The Nature Conservancy, South Brisbane, Australia, Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (DKP); WWF Indonesia; Provincial and district governments, local universities and community groups; Mama Graun Conservation Trust, Papua New Guinea "
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option, long-term it will improve food security and create additional income(tourism).
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The lessons learned in the process of designing and implementing the resilient network of protected sites within the project are applicable to other areas across the Coral Triangle region. The project is therefore expected to have impacts which will increase the sustainability and impact beyond the core sites. The Savu Sea Marine National Park development activities, got a good appreciation from Anambas Regencies, where in the event at workshop in Jakarta, they also said it would develop a conservation area where the process will learn from Savu Sea Marine National Park.
Adaptations.comments: When compared with countries around Indonesia such as Australia and New Zeland, Fiji and the Cock Island already have fisheries conservation area, the other part is willing to declare such as Papua New Guinea. The absence of marine conservation area for marine mammals, particularly whales in Indonesia, causing the vacuum region as a liaison between the south pacific ocean and the Indian Ocean for the species. Waters of the Savu Sea is an important corridor for both oceans for marine mammals and turtles. It is feared that the lack of marine conservation areas for the purpose of protection of marine mammals and sea turtles would threaten the species from commercial fishing.

Adaptations.title: Advancing the Micronesia Challenge through New Protected Areas
Adaptations.description:
"Island states such as the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Republic of Palau and the Federated States of Micronesia are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. In its Fourth Assessment Report, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has identified with great certainty island states’ vulnerability to sea level rise, deterioration of coastal conditions, diminution of fresh-water resources and increased invasion by non-native species. 
The project will assist the implementation of the Micronesia Challenge in designating areas for conservation, in order to build resilience to the effects of climate change and address the four threats as described by the IPCC. To achieve this, target sites are identified such as the Yela Swamp Forest in the Federated States of Micronesia, threatened by retreating coastline and advancing land development, the Northern Reefs of Palau affected by coral bleaching, and the island home of the Woja community on Majuro Atoll, which faces freshwater scarcity due to poorly planned water extraction and management. Measures undertaken are mostly conservation activities through collaborative agreements with the local stakeholders."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Post Office Box 4040 Koror, Palau 96940
Adaptations.executing_agent: "Micronesia Conservation Trust, Palau Conservation Society; provincial governments of Kayangel and Ngarchelong Federated States of Micronesia; Environment Landowners Association; Chuuk Conservation Society; Marshall Islands: Marine Resources Authority"
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project is expected to secure the community’s tenure and control of their resources, give legal support to local institutions undertaking such measures and favour sustainable socio-economic development in the region.
Adaptations.comments: The project is highly transferable and can be replicated throughout the Micronesian region.

Adaptations.title: Impacts of climate change on water resources and adaptation measures
Adaptations.description: In Vietnam, lack of water due to insufficient supplies together with climate change will result in water scarcity in dry season and more flooding in wet season in 21st century. Therefore, it is necessary to have adequate and appropriate research and quantitative assessment about impacts of climate change on water resources basing on scenarios for climate change in Vietnam. This will be useful to give adaptive measures to change of water resources in the future. The development objectives of the project is to strengthen the capacity of the sectors, organizations and Vietnamese people to adapt and response to climate change impacts on water resources in order to minimize the negative impacts and losses and effectively recovery from their effects, or by taking advantage of positive impacts.
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr. Tran Thuc - General Director – Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment
Adaptations.contact_adress: 23/62 Nguyen Chi Thanh, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
Adaptations.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment
Adaptations.success_factors:
"Mainstreaming adaptation measures in water management policy;
Communicating the project’s results in an easily understanding ways."
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: not specified
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is running and the immediate objectives of it are:
1. To assess impacts of climate change on water resources in some main river basins of Vietnam with the climate change scenario-driven approach;
2. To propose measures adapting to water resources changing due to climate change. Especially, specific solutions for each main river basin in Vietnam will be brought out such as modification the operation rules of reservoir system due to inflow change to ensure amount of water for hydropower, irrigation, domestic supply and environment… for Red river basin; or management of inundation caused by sea level rise; planning infrastructure under circumstance of climate change for Mekong river basin…
The project has had some workshops to disseminate the primary results to all stakeholders."
Adaptations.comments: The project uses PRECIS model (Hadley Centre: http://precis.metoffice.com/) to develop climate change scenarios for each basin, MIKE model systems to assess the flows trend, Penman method to calculate the potential evapotranspiration, and some other models...

Adaptations.title: Sustainable Management of Coastal Forest Ecosystems
Adaptations.description: The Mekong Delta is particularly affected by the impacts of climate change. Rising sea levels and storms of increasing magnitude threaten the poor rural population, Viet Nam’s rice and shrimp production, and Ho Chi Minh City with increasing regularity. Intact coastal forests attenuate the wind and waves and safeguard the embankments needed to protect the low-lying, extensive Mekong delta against inundation. This project is very good and interesting but unfortunately we had this project already in the database. http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/454 I transferred some information from your project into this one, trying to create the best of both. However, the project http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/469 will be rejected.

Adaptations.title: Climate change impacts in Huong river basin and adaptation
Adaptations.description:
"This project is one of the important projects of the Netherlands Climate Assistance Program (NCAP), in 15 developing countries. The Vietnam project is a pilot study of climate change impacts on the natural environment, including water systems and flows, of the most vulnerable people and adaptation policies and measures in Viet Nam.
The project regards the Huong river basin in Thua Thien Hue Province in general and its lagoon population in particular. Future impacts of climate change on the water system and flows of the entire river basin will be projected in an integrated way. The social-economic focus is on the coastal district of Phu Vang in order to involve vulnerable stakeholders in preparing detailed measures to adapt to the projected climate change impacts in their local area."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 23/62 Nguyen Chi Thanh, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
Adaptations.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment
Adaptations.success_factors:
"- The adaptation measures of project are referred to different local and external stakeholders by interviews to make them suitable with the local conditions;
- Furthermore, there was a decision making (or technical) workshop with key-stakeholders in one commune in Phu Vang district using scenarios’ structuring tool and decision making support software."
Adaptations.limiting_factors: - The project was finished before the establishment of Vietnam National Target Program to Respond to Climate change and there are some adaptation measures become not suitable.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: rising awareness of local stakeholders and people on climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project provided adaptation measures for Thua Thien – Hue province in general and Phu Vang district in particular, especially the adaptation solutions for water resources in Phu Vang district:
- Review the planning of irrigation and drainage and gradually consolidate and repair canals to ensure the efficiency of reasonable irrigation and drainage;
- Build new sea dyke Thuan An–Tu Hien according to provincial strategy of adaptation to climate change
- Consolidate the system of boundary dyke to prevent flood and saline flood according to provincial strategy of adaptation to climate change
- Step by step perfect the mechanism of water resources integrated management in
the district area.
Besides, there are some lessons learned in the adaptation in local that was concluded by project: cost-effective use, use both top-down and bottom-up styles in participatory approach, need for translation of the scientific studies results to the language of the end-users, wise use of indigenous knowledge and expert opinion;"
Adaptations.comments: The project assessed the impacts of climate change on water resources by conducting water and climate change modelling for the Huong river basin with the help of MIKE 11 and MIKE basin software.

Adaptations.title: Multiplying Best Practice in Adaptation to Climate Change
Adaptations.description:
"“As a result of climate change impacts, the semiarid north of Brazil is threatened by increasing aridity. The rural, predominantly smallholder population relies mainly on traditional and highly inefficient irrigation technologies and depends greatly upon uncertain rainfall. 
The Federal Environment Agency (UBA) is coordinating a project of adaptation to climate change in Brazil, which is starting with a workshop in Rio de Janeiro for delegates from affected rural regions. 
The purpose of the project is to prepare the rural population to cope with increasing aridity. Tried and proven forms of local initiative for adapting to climate change will be disseminated and replicated by building networks. To this end, pilot projects on irrigation in the northeast of Brazil that are already under way will be expanded. In addition, support is being provided to establish a network of municipalities and organizations seeking to disseminate successful adaptation measures. In addition to training measures, a limited amount of technical equipment (such as pumps and irrigation equipment) is also being provided.
The participatory approach enables the population in the affected regions to cope better with the impacts of climate change. It is envisaged that the results of the pilot projects will be taken up in regional development plans and other strategy papers and will also contribute to the debate on adaptation measures within the context of negotiations concerning the Framework Convention on Climate Change. Moreover, the project contributes to economic stabilization and to food and income security in the region.”"
Adaptations.contact_adress: Postfach 1406 06813 Dessau-Roßlau
Adaptations.executing_agent: German Federal Environment Agency (Dessau), Centro Clima, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ) GmbH, Brasilia Rede de Desenvolvimento Humano, Rio de Janeiro, German Development Service (DED)
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.success_factors: limited amount of technical equipment
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: "Win-Win option; the project contributes to economic stabilization and to food and income security in the region."
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: “The UBA is supporting an agricultural irrigation project that already enjoys international recognition. A solar-powered water supply system is to be installed, and cultivation and sales of regional products are to be promoted. In the course of the project’s two-year duration, adaptation measures for other vulnerable regions in Brazil will be identified and communicated on location.”
Adaptations.comments: Based on experience gained by the project partners, further adaptation projects are to be selected and introduced in other areas, e.g. the Amazon. Local stakeholders and non-governmental organizations will be involved and vouch for the transfer to the local population. Besides setting up a regional and national communications network, the project is intended to support national policymakers in adapting to climate change.

Adaptations.title: Sea water level rise scenarios and possible disaster risk reductions
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr. Tran Thuc, General Director – Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment
Adaptations.contact_adress: 23/62 Nguyen Chi Thanh, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
Adaptations.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment
Adaptations.success_factors: The awareness of Vietnamese Government in marine problems is more and more increased and the project’s results will contribute in policy making processes of the country.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The project focus on some pilot study areas and it can make the adaptation measures may not be detail enough for all Vietnam country regions.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Contribute to coastal management problems
Adaptations.comments: "The project uses Morphologic Vulnerability Index to study the coastal erosion and mapping potential inundation areas; and Coastal Vulnerability Index to assess the risks of sea level rise."

Adaptations.title: Pacific Mangroves Initiative (PMI)
Adaptations.description:
"""Pacific islanders are considered to be among the people most vulnerable to climate change and climate variability. Conserving mangroves and associated habitats is regarded as a key natural adaptation strategy and also serves to mitigate climate change.
The conservation and restoration of these habitats thus has both national and local dimensions. Better legislation and policy, improved knowledge and information about the anticipated impacts of climate change as well as improved capacities of local communities for wetland management have been identified as priority needs by the Pacific Island Countries.
The objective of this project is to increase the resilience of the people of the Pacific Islands to climate change and improve their livelihoods. To this end, data will be collected and analyzed in order to enhance the national baseline information feeding into climate change scenarios. National and local policies and tools for the management and restoration of mangroves and associated ecosystems will be reviewed or developed in each country. Specific mangrove management measures will be applied in selected pilot sites. A comprehensive awareness raising and capacity development programme will complement the activities."""
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr Padma Lal, Chief Technical Adviser, IUCN Office
Adaptations.contact_adress: 5 Maafu Street, Private Mail Bag Suva Fiji
Adaptations.executing_agent: The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), Institute of Applied Science at the University of the South Pacific (USP), Secretariat for the Pacific Regional Environmental Programme (SPREP), Worldfish Solomon Islands
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.success_factors: planting the right species is very important
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, through carbon sequestration by the mangroves.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option, if the project is successful it will furthermore reduce poverty and rural-uban mitigation.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: """The implementation is still ongoing, but the project will enhance the resilience of communities and improve and sustain their livelihoods by conserving and restoring mangroves and associated wetlands. In-country capacity to engage in evidence-based adaptive management will be increased. Broader effects will include a reduction in rural-urban migration, a boost in rural employment and poverty reduction."""
Adaptations.comments: """Mangroves throughout the whole Pacific are being degraded or destroyed due to their use as rubbish dumps, overharvesting, reclamation to make way for tourist resorts, urban development, housing, and even due to the proliferation of squatter or informal settlements in the ‘no-mans’ mangrove areas. So other project locations are Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, Samoa and Tonga."""

Adaptations.title: Climate Insurance Systems
Adaptations.description:
"""The growing frequency and severity of extreme weather events such as typhoons, droughts, floods, and snow storms due to climate change have resulted in an increase in financial losses, and thus threaten the economic basis of households and enterprises – especially those in rural areas and at the lower end of the income spectrum – in many developing countries. 
The project applies an integrated approach by addressing legal and regulatory issues that might hamper the market launch of index-based insurances, and by supporting re- and primary insurance companies and other financial service providers to develop demand-oriented weather insurance products for the respective target groups in the pilot regions. To this end, GTZ cooperates with the insurance regulator (CIRC), the Chinese Meteorological Administration (CMA), Chinese and foreign insurance and re-insurance companies and financial intermediaries.
The project identifies and analyses weather perils in all provinces of China. Through a thorough analysis of past weather events and the economic and social losses resulting from those weather events, the exposure of different households and enterprises to weather perils are analyzed. Through household surveys and client studies the potential demand for weather insurance products is assessed. All this extensive research will then result in the development of suitable weather insurance products, possibly on the basis of parametric triggers, meaning that e.g. farmers will receive insurance payouts once a certain trigger (such as a certain precipitation or water levels for a flood insurance) is reached."""
Adaptations.contact_adress: Sunflower Tower, Room 1100 Maizidian St. 37, Chaoyang District 100026 Beijing VR China
Adaptations.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), China Insurance Regulatory Commission (CIRC)
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of willingness of the local partners such as CIRC to implement the project
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win option
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: """Despite the great interest in weather insurance worldwide, the emerging economies and developing countries still have very little experience with this type of scheme. Each new pilot project thus contributes to a better understanding of this complex issue. The project will also help to boost the professionalism of the Chinese insurance sector and promote underdeveloped rural regions."""

Adaptations.title: Reducing the impact of flooding caused by sea level rise to promote sustainable agriculture production and ensuring food security
Adaptations.description: The project aims to develop community-based sustainable agricultural production models to minimize impacts of flooding and salt water intrusion caused by sea level rise, adapting to climate change and contributing to food security and stable incomes s in a Phuc Hoa commune of Tuy Phuoc District, Binh Dinh Province where rice production is the major source of food and income. The commune is located at the confluence of two branches of Kon river pouring into Thi Nai Coastal Lagoon. It is a low lying and narrow delta with elevations from sea level in the range of 0.5-1.2 m and therefore has been subject to salt water intrusion and frequent flooding during rainy seasons. The project is designed and implemented by testing demonstration models for solutions to adapt to increasingly severely flooding and salt intrusion. These models should use the research results of selecting and creating high yielding flood tolerant rice varieties (such as varieties named 24SS, SH2, BM207, PC6, H43, H30) carried out by IRRI (International Rice Research Institute) in-cooperation with national agriculture institutes. Local farmers’ experiences in coping with flooding and after-flooding conditions will be fully applied in the models. Furthermore the Project aims to strengthen awareness and local capacity to adapt to climate change. Public awareness raising activities will be conducted widely in the whole commune.
Adaptations.contact_person: Nguyen Thi Kim Anh, Project Coordinator, UNDP Hanoi
Adaptations.contact_adress: 25-29 Phan Boi Chau Street, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.executing_agent: SGP VIET NAM
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-Active participation of communities and local government.
-In-line with the National Strategy and Action Plan for Disaster Mitigation and Management."
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is under implementing.
Expected major outputs:
1. Enhanced understanding and knowledge on CC and its impacts, and adaptation measures
2. 2-4 rice varieties which cope better with flooding and salt water intrusion to be selected.
3. A model of 20ha of rice, 2 crops per year, for 2 years, with the participation of 50-60 households to be tested with the application of new rice varieties which cope better with flooding and salt water intrusion.
4. 2-3 groups of households or 10 households trains in rice seed production to meet the demand of the commune and other neighboring communes 
5. A sustainable agricultural production model to be developed and replicated to other areas.
6. 8-10 technical training workshops organize."
Adaptations.comments: Lessons learnt from the models will serve as inputs for the local decision-makers to plan for upscaling them in bigger areas of rice cultivated land and to continue to seek other adaptation measures to address immediate and longer climate change impacts. Information on the models at Phuoc Hoa should be also made available to other neighboring communes with similar conditions for learning and possible replication (such as Phuoc Thang, Phuoc Thuan, Phuoc Son and Phuoc Nghia communes in Tuy Phuoc District) and Cat Chanh, Cat ien, Cat Tai, Cat Thang communes in Phu Cat District).

Adaptations.title: Adaptive water management at a local scale
Adaptations.description:
"The project is part of a larger transnational ADAPTS project named Adaptive Local Water Management which comprising 6 countries (Brazil, Peru, Botswana, Ghana, Ethiopia and Vietnam). The goal of the ADAPTS project is to increase countries’ adaptive capacities by achieving the inclusion of climate change and adaptation considerations in (local-regional) water policies, planning and investment decisions. 
The project main objective is to enable the local counterpart – The Centre for Social Research and Development (CSRD) in Vietnam, to take climate change and adaptation into account when working with local communities, to support selected local adaptation measures and to play a leading role in facilitating a dialogue between communities, researchers and government authorities on climate change and adaptation in the Thua Thien-Hue river basin."
Adaptations.contact_person: Ms. Pham Thi Dieu My, Center for Social Research and Development in Vietnam
Adaptations.contact_adress: No. 2/33 Nguyen Truong To, Hue city, Vietnam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The Provincial People’s Committee of Thua Thien-Hue and The Ministry for Development Cooperation of Netherlands.
Adaptations.executing_agent: CSRD of Hue-Thua Thien,IVM/VU University and Both ENDS
Adaptations.funding_source: The Ministry for Development Cooperation of the Netherlands
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
-Engage local and scientific knowledge"
Adaptations.limiting_factors: -Short time scale
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"-The CSRD developed a good capacity on the issue of climate change and adaptation in their work with local communities, provincial and local authorities through a training course and an extensive survey on adaptation priorities of local communities and existing initiatives. 
-The project assisted the Environmental Protection Branch (DONRE) of Thua Thien-Hue to draft part of the provincial action plan on climate change adaptation. This action plan was officially approved by the Province People Committee on the 28th of August 2010.
-The option of mangroves planting has been identified, analyzed and chosen as a specific adaptation measure to be supported. It serves as a buffer against floods and related erosion and providing other beneficial functions such as habitat for species in the basin.
-The project’s findings and outcomes has been disseminated at the national and international workshops, conferences which has contributed to drawing attention and resources mobilization to those who are interested in climate change issue in the region."
Adaptations.comments: -The project’s main approach: i/ Knowledge development: developing climate change information and studying how local water management can be made “climate-proof”. The Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) methods used for collecting information and identifying local adaptation measures in the study. ii/ Dialogues: establishing policy dialogues between local and national stakeholders on the issues of sustainable water management, climate change and adaptation. iii/ Local action: the identification, support, documentation, analysis and dissemination of innovative, locally-based interventions to assure that local knowledge and visions are included in basin and national policy dialogues.

Adaptations.title: Climate change impact and adaptation in the Mekong Delta
Adaptations.description: "Vietnam is one of the nations most at risk from climate change, and the Mekong Delta -the main producer of rice, is the most vulnerable region in the country. A number of development agencies are providing climate-change linked assistance to Vietnam , but there has been no comprehensive study of the potential effects of climate change has been undertaken on the Mekong region. The project main objective is to develop the capacity of sectors and provincial authorities in the Mekong Delta to increase climate-resilience of programs, plans, policies, and/or projects to guide future development planning. This will result in increased climate change resilience and contribute to poverty reduction. This project have two parts: i/ modeling and assessment work to determine the likely future climate conditions in the region and their impact; ii/ identifying appropriate climate change adaptation measures for targeted areas (Ca Mau, Kien Giang Provinces) and sectors (agriculture, energy, transport) as well as development of pilot projects for scaling up and replication of project outcomes and support to collaborative mechanisms for information sharing and coordinated action on climate change. "
Adaptations.contact_person: Zhai Yongping, Southeast Asia Department (SERD), ADB
Adaptations.contact_adress: 6 ADB Avenue, Mandaluyong City 1550, Metro Manila, Philippines.
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The Government of Vietnam and Asian Development Bank
Adaptations.executing_agent: International Centre for Environmental Management in collaboration with the People’s Committee of Ca Mau, Kien Giang, An Giang, Bac Lieu, Ben Tre, Can Tho, Dong Thap, Long An, Soc Trang, Tien Giang, Tra Vinh and Vinh Long provinces.
Adaptations.funding_source: Asian Development Bank, Australian Grant and The Government of Vietnam
Adaptations.success_factors: Successful upscaling and replication of project outcomes. Government needs to implement and mainstream on adaptation plan accordingly.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of awareness on climate change
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project is under implementing. The expected outputs is 1. Climate change scenarios 2030, 2050 and the effects of future climate conditions on natural, social and economic systems to be documented 2. The appropriate climate change adaptation measures in two targeted provinces and three targeted sectors programs, plans, projects and/or policies to be documented 3. Pilot projects to allow upscaling and replication of project outcomes to be developed 4. The collaborative mechanisms for information sharing and coordinated action on climate change in the Mekong Delta region to be developed. 5. Institutional arrangement to fulfill their development responsibilities in future climate conditions and community awareness of climate change issues and adaptation measures to be increased.
Adaptations.comments: - Climate change scenarios will build on work already carried out by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) and donors. - Use an approach based on GIS to identify the effects of future climate change scenarios on natural, social and economic systems as well as hydro-meteorological characteristics. -Integrated assessment modeling (IAM) will be carried out for target provinces and sectors to provide a more detailed assessment of climate change effects. The results of IAM will provide important inputs to the cost-benefit analysis (CBA) of adaptation options. - Designing climate change adaptation pilot projects to allow eventual upscaling and replication of project outcomes in other provinces or sectors within the Mekong Delta region.

Adaptations.title: Southern Voices Capacity Building
Adaptations.description:
"The project is part of a large transnational programme which supports the strengthening of Southern civil society networks through the country offices and other support structures of the consortium members. 11 national networks, 6 regional and 3 thematic networks will be included in the programme.
The project in Vietnam aimed a better support for climate change advocacy, lobbying and public awareness rising at fair pro-poor positions of governments and other stakeholders to their commitments related to climate issues. A key tool for advocacy will be written Country Assessment Report made by the NGO Climate Change Working Group (CCWG) networks.
Furthermore capacity building and utilization will be prioritized, including organizational and technical strengthening of existing networks and skills at national levels in Organizational development (OD), policy analysis, advocacy, and media engagement.
Focus on strengthening know-how within the Southern networks – brokering knowledge and facilitating linkages on selected themes: adaptation, REDD (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation in Developing Countries), renewable energy/ energy efficiency /low carbon development and gender.
The programme’s objective is to increasing public awareness at national, regional and international levels in order to help implement and develop climate change policies which promote environmental integrity and sustainable development benefitting poor and vulnerable people."
Adaptations.contact_person: Ms. Nguyen Thi Yen, Climate change Coordinator, CARE Vietnam
Adaptations.contact_adress: No. 66 Xuan Dieu, Tay Ho District, Hanoi, Vietnam
Adaptations.executing_agent: CARE Vietnam and Climate Change Working Group
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-Interest from Vietnam NGO’s.
-Facilitation of active learning.
-Ability to engage the different stakeholder groups."
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Awareness of climate change to encourage access and dialogue for future requirements
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"-It is too early to evaluation the project.-The expected main outcomes will be:
i/ The evaluation of network capacity to be documented.
ii/ Country report relating CC mitigation and adaptation policies to be performed.
iii/Capacity building and organizational development for NGO/ Civil Social Organizations to be enhanced."
Adaptations.comments: The Vietnam NGO Climate Change Working Group (CCWG) were formed in 2008. CCWG provides a forum for International and Vietnamese NGOs to actively participate in the climate change debate and also facilitates information sharing, capacity building and coordination among NGO’s in Vietnam and between NGO’s and government in relation to climate change mitigation and adaptation responses. CCWG and its network is designed to implement this project in Vietnam.

Adaptations.title: Conservation and Development of the Kien Giang Biosphere Reserve
Adaptations.description: Kien Giang is a coastal province in the western portion of the Mekong Delta where is extremely vulnerable to the effects of global climate change such as sea level rise, flood, king tides, drought and fire. The project objective is sustainable management of the natural resources of Kien Giang Province and improved management of the protected areas. Through effective management of the protected areas and of the coastal mangrove forests, the natural resources of Kien Giang Province are being used in a sustainable way. The project will focus in three key areas of the Kien Giang Man and the Biosphere (MAB) Reserve that was recognised by UNESCO in 2006. They are U Minh Thuong National Park, Phu Quoc National Park and the Kien Luong Hon Chong Coastal Area. At the same time, the economic situation of coastal populations is being improved. In addition, local government staffs are being trained and relevant institutions are being strengthened.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 6th Floor, Hanoi Towers 49 Hai Ba Trung St. Hanoi Vietnam
Adaptations.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), Eschborn / Hanoi, Department of Science and Technology Kien Giang Province
Adaptations.success_factors: - The active participation of local people and government.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: - The water level falls in the dry season. This practice and the exploitation of the natural resources by local people degrades the biodiversity of the Park. - The current land clearing for agriculture and aquaculture practices also threaten the survival of the forests.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, trough carbon sequestration by the mangroves.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: - Data, information of biodiversity and socio-economic conditions collected by the project, as well as the maps it has produced will be used for the planning of natural resource management by Provincial authorities. - Economic development, improve income for people.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project is under running. The expected results are: -The Assessment of Flora and Fauna biodiversity hot spots -Improved land use management strategies for the Man and the Biosphere Reserve -Improved capacity and technical knowledge of for income generating opportunities including improved marketing -Improved environmental awareness and management of natural resources -Development of management plans for biodiversity conservation in the Biosphere Reserve -Development of technical guidelines for water management in U Minh Thuong National Park -Development of technical guidelines for prevention and fighting of forest fires for U Minh Thuong and Phu Quoc National Parks -Improved capacity for planning, project design and management - A coastal protection model in Hon Dat district which uses new techniques for planting mangroves as well as sea dykes able to withstand the strong currents in the area will be established.
Adaptations.comments: - The project will generate synergies by using lessons learned and joint implementation of some activities in the GTZ Project “Management of the Natural Resources in the Coastal Zone of Soc Trang Province”. - The project takes a participatory approach, and involves interaction between local farmers, the Womens Union, the Youth Union, and government officials.

Adaptations.title: Community Based Mangrove Reforestation and Management
Adaptations.description: Seeing the important role of the mangroves in sustaining local residents livelihoods and contributing to a reduction in natural disasters and the growing threat from climate change, particularly projected sea level rise disaster vulnerability, there is new interest in regenerating mangroves and taking advantage of the safety, livelihood and biodiversity benefits they produce. The project supports Da Loc Commune of Hau Loc coastal District in Thanh Hoa province to planting new mangroves and developing systems for sustainable management of a total of 350ha of mangroves. The project had two overarching aims: i/ Mangroves reforestation and ii/ Community management and protecting of mangroves.
Adaptations.contact_person: Ms. Nguyen Thi Yen, Climate change Coordinator, CARE Vietnam
Adaptations.contact_adress: No. 66 Xuan Dieu, Tay Ho District, Hanoi, Vietnam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: The People Committee of Thanh Hoa Province and CARE Vietnam
Adaptations.executing_agent: CARE Viet Nam
Adaptations.success_factors: Mobilizing all of local peoples participation in planting mangroves and maintaining the trees, particularly with the active participation of the women.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Not specified
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, carbon sequestration by the mangroves
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Livelihood benefits from sustainable use of the mangrove
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: -The replanting of 200ha mangroves was successful, with very high survival rates (70-90%). - A mangrove nursery garden with 15,000 seedlings of the Sonneratia (Cay Ban Chua) has been established and is fully managed by the community. - The project established Farmer Groups with clear institutional structures in place to manage the mangrove. So, the community had an improved awareness on climate change adaptation and capacity to collectively manage the mangrove forest. -The project has had a positive impact on the institutional processes and linkages at the site. The development of the Community Management Boards (CMB) – a successful attempt at collaborative management – demonstrates that full and open participation and empowerment can be successful in driving forward institutional developments.
Adaptations.comments: -Community based approach using traditional knowledge is a good approach in forest plantation and management. -There is a need to expand the scope of the project, with particular attention to awareness rising in other, nearby villages, ensuring that there is no ‘outside’ damage to the mangrove from unsustainable collection of firewood, timber or marine resources. At present the protection teams appear successful in deterring or stopping this impact but the pressure may increase as these resources increase with the development of the mangroves.

Adaptations.query: Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Adaptations.title: Megacity Research Project – Ho Chi Minh City - Integrative Urban and Environmental Planning Framework Adaptation to Climate Change
Adaptations.description:
"The project is one of ten projects in megacities throughout the world developed by the Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus (BTU) under the programme “Sustainable Development of the Megacities of Tomorrow – Energy and Climate Efficient Structures in Urban Growth Centres” (BMBF).
The project focuses on mega-urban region of Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) as one of Vietnamese regions most affected by climate change. The main project’s objective is to develop strategies for adapting urban land, urban structures and urban development concepts to climate changes and to minimize or avoid impacts of climate change in the context of the megacity-HCMC. It aims to increase the resilience and adaptive capacity of the urban system of HCMC.
Two major topics constitute the project structure: Action Field 1 focuses on environmental research; Action Field 2 is concerned with urban development."
Adaptations.contact_person: Prof. Dr. Michael Schmidt - Department of Urban Planning and Spatial Design - Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus
Adaptations.contact_adress: Erich-Weinert-Str. 1 03046 Cottbus, Germany
Adaptations.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research
Adaptations.executing_agent: Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-In line with strategy orientation of the ‘National Target Programme to Respond to Climate Change’ (NTP) which issued by Government in 2008.
-Successful uptake of recommendations.
- The implementation of measures will be an outcome of scientific research and research will be undertaken on grounds of the implementation of measures."
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"-Financial and human resource constrains of implementation of technological solutions/ measures.
-Insufficient of co-ordination mechanism for mainstreaming adaptation measures within local development planning."
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The project outcomes will contribute in environmental conservation of Ho Chi Minh City
Adaptations.comments: "-Two topics constitute the project structure: (i) the Action Field “Urban Environment” encompasses the work packages: Adaptation Planning Framework; Urban Flooding; Urban Climate; Urban Energy; Urban Transport. (ii) the Action Field “Urban Development” includes the four work packages: Precaution and Adaptation Strategies to Climate Change Impacts on the Regional and City Level; Integrative Planning Approach for New Energy and Climate-Efficient Neighborhoods; Livable City - Urban Regeneration and Community-Based Adaptation; Energy-Climate-Efficient Housing Typologies. - A multi-layered typological approach to be utilized to assess the sustainability of urban settlement developments. - With an interdisciplinary approach, the assessment criteria and methodology will be selected with the aim of assessing contents and objectives of the regional land-use planning system for their adequacy and efﬁciency in adaptation to climate change. - One importance component of the project is climate science and how to create a shared interface between local knowledge and science."

Adaptations.title: Strengthening national capacities to respond to climate change in Viet Nam, reducing vulnerability and controlling greenhouse gases emissions
Adaptations.description: "The National Target Program respond to Climate Change (NTP) was issued by Government in 2008 with the main strategic objective of assessing climate change’s impacts on sectors/areas/regions and develop feasible action plan to effective respond to climate change in short-/long-term periods. Within this tight timeframe, the NTP has only proposed one strategic document but the case studies and consultation in order to formulate concrete action plans has not developed yet, while there is limited expertise within the Government Agencies for development of the strategic NTP document and detailed action plans. This project will provide support to the Government in this regard with the main objective: Frameworks, mechanisms and capacities in place to inform, guide and coordinate (i) analysis of climate change related risks and formulation of CC adaptation policy responses and investment plans; and (ii) analysis of Green House Gas emissions, and formulation of investment plans and ways to change consumer behaviour for low-carbon economic development."
Adaptations.contact_person: Mrs. Tran Thanh Thuy – project manager
Adaptations.contact_adress: 23/62 Nguyen Chi Thanh, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources & Environment (MONRE) and United Nation Development Program (UNDP)
Adaptations.executing_agent: MONRE, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) and UNDP Vietnam
Adaptations.funding_source: UNDP, ONE UN in VIETNAM and Government of VIETNAM
Adaptations.success_factors: -Analysis and methodological development of the project ensure that target provinces and selected sectors are able to learn, adapt and (if appropriate) replicate this approach to develop and implement locally-appropriate provincial and sectoral adaptation frameworks. -NTP development has been requested by the Prime Minister and therefore this project have strong government support at both central and local levels.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: - Three province as case studies may not be typical for all regions of Vietnam with different geographical conditions -Consensus not reached and Ministry of Planning and Investment does not include Climate Change criteria in planning guidelines for sectors and provinces. -Fact that learning is a ongoing process
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Raising awareness of Vietnamese people on climate change problems
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "The project is running and its expected outcomes are: – Climate change policy formulated and mainstreamed into the National Target Program to respond to Climate Change, related action plans formulated, and policy and management capacities for roll out strengthened; - Improved knowledge base and national research capacity strengthened to deliver analysis for evidence-based planning and policy development, and implementation of CC-related measures to support sectors and provinces in rolling out the NTP; - Build capacities for regulation, guidance, local policy measures, and project management, and formulate concrete regulations, policy measures and investment plans for CC adaptation and GHG emissions control."
Adaptations.comments: "- Pilot projects in three provinces (Binh Thuan, Binh Dinh, Can Tho) was desigted to experiment with specific approaches to CCA and GHG mitigation in order to develop provincial action plans, climate change integrated in provincial plans, and capacities built of provincial CC Offices; - IMHEN is assigned by MONRE to be the Project Focal Point who will be the lead organisation in the present project, acting for MONRE and working with various departments, offices and institutes in MONRE, MARD and selected provinces; - Direct beneficiaries of the project are: (i) The people, especially those who live in poor rural areas within the project pilot areas; (ii) MONRE, MARD, sectors, provinces and organizations taking part in and related to the project; (iii)Women, who are one of the important target groups of the project"

Adaptations.title: Integration of climate change into existing disaster preparedness programs
Adaptations.description:
"This project is involved in “Disaster Preparedness and Climate Change programmes” which implemented in Nicaragua, Mozambique and Vietnam supported by Red Cross/ Red Crescent Centre based in Netherlands.
Vietnam is one of the most disaster-prone countries in the world. Each year typhoons, floods and droughts cause death, injury, loss of property and infrastructural damages. The projects goal is to contribute to the significant reduction in human suffering and negative effects of natural disasters.
The project objective is to reduce human suffering and negative effects of natural disasters on the most vulnerable people of Vietnam by strengthening Vietnamese capacities to adapt and respond to natural disasters that are enhanced by climate change.
Basic idea was awareness-raising about the impacts of climate change on livelihoods and the need to be prepared to adapt. So NGOs make climate change impacts part of their focus. Furthermore The Red Cross produced two documentaries that were broadcast on national television.
