Also the theme of climate change impacts was integrated into participatory community assessments, which resulted in the identification of community-specific vulnerabilities and solutions (e.g., loud speaker systems for early warning, construction of dams and tree barriers as defense for agricultural land against winds and salt water intrusion).
The project focused on 30 disaster prone coastal communes in 5 provinces ( Nghe An, Ha Tinh, Quang Binh, Ninh Thuan and Binh Thuan) which are most vulnerable areas."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 83 Nguyen Du, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Red Cross, Red Crescent Climate Centre
Adaptations.executing_agent: Vietnam Red Cross Society and Netherlands Red Cross Society
Adaptations.funding_source: The Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"- Lack of CC knowledge of Red Cross key staff.
- Insufficient practical experiences with community based disaster preparedness and the step from Hazard Vulnerability, and Capacity Assessments (HVCA) to project implementation.
- Difficult for Vietnam Red Cross to reach out to policy makers"
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: No direct, but indirect. (e.g. afforestation reduces global CO2)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The project is nothing of both. However, it creates further projects, which could be a No-regret or a Win-Win option.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"This is an appreciated project, recognized by several stakeholders in Vietnam (and abroad) as an example for climate change adaptation, and having created a willingness among the Vietnam Red Cross and the Netherlands Red Cross to continue.
-Various training and dissemination materials were developed and distributed. VNRC staff, national decision makers, local authorities and inhabitants of the 30 project communities were reached by various dissemination activities on the relationship between climate change and disasters and the need to be prepared.
-30 coastal communities were increasing their resilience to storms, floods and drought by implementing small-scale adaptation measures such as building dams, search and rescue centres, planting trees(http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/27) and improving loudspeaker systems for early warning.
Based on this pilot projects, the Red Cross has decided to focus efforts on mangrove restoration and afforestation as a strategy to both ameliorate climate change impact and simultaneously generate funds through the UNFCCC Clean Development Mechanism to finance disaster preparedness.
- The Red Cross is now engaged in a more systematic consultation with the national meteorological office and climate change experts, and using that knowledge for more effective risk management activities."
Adaptations.comments: "The project’s approach is to consider a disaster preparedness related to climate change project is the same as “normal” disaster preparedness project but: - Integrated climate change-component; - More emphasis on advocacy at national level; - More cooperation and exchange with technical institutions and NGO’s. -The project’s approach is based on a triple A principle: (i) Awareness with information and educational activities; (ii) Action with supporting the development of concrete adaptation activities within the existing context of disaster preparedness programmes by implementing 30 community sub-projects; (iii) Advocacy with raising concerns about the impacts of CC on vulnerable people to policy makers and offering practical examples of CC adaptation and disaster preparedness programmes."

Adaptations.title: Management of natural resources in the coastal zone
Adaptations.description:
"The project aims at providing pilot solutions to solve the conflict between economic development and sustainable management of natural resources. In particular, shrimp production has led to rapid economic growth, and large areas are therefore being transformed into shrimp farms in Soc Trang coastal land. The ecological balance of these wetlands is endangered. It lead to the unsustainable exploitation of resources, hampering the protective function that mangrove forests have on coasts and detrimentally affecting the local population’s ability to earn income..
The project objective is to protect and sustainably use the coastal wetlands of Soc Trang Province for the benefit of the local population
One of the priority areas in this project is rehabilitation and manage of mangroves with emphasis on resilience to climate change which is part of the integrated management of the coastal zone."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 134 Tran Hung Dao street, Soc Trang city, Viet Nam
Adaptations.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
Adaptations.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit and People’s Committee of Soc Trang Province
Adaptations.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
Adaptations.success_factors: The participation of all local authorities and people in the project
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"- The awareness of local people about natural resources and the linkage between natural resources management is quite low
- The lack of cooperation mechanism for integrating sustainable management and the use of natural resources, as well as overlapping competencies among various offices and economic interests (shrimp farms)."
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, mangroves are plant communities established in coastal and estuarine areas influenced by the tide in tropical and subtropical zones. They provide important ecosystem services and goods that include sequestration of carbon dioxide
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: economic development
Adaptations.comments: "- The project approach are included (i) Different co-management methods allowing the stakeholders to learn how to reach agreements on the protection and sustainable use of coastal zone. (ii) Rehabilitation and manage of mangroves with emphasis on resilience to climate change as part of the integrated management of the coastal zone. (iii) Intermediaries such as staff from public authorities, womens organisations and communities take part in training courses on the management of the coastal zone. (iv) Development of the sustainable financing of ecosystem services provided by coastal wetlands. (v) Participatory environmental monitoring system.(vi) Establishment of a regional network for the coastal zone in the Mekong Delta. - This is one of three GTZ projects related to adaptation to climate change in coastal areas in Vietnam. The project will generate synergies by using lessons learned and joint implementation of some activities in the Project ""Conservation and Development of the Kien Giang Biosphere Reserve"" that being implemented by GTZ in Vietnam."

Adaptations.query: Madhya Pradesh, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, Uttarakhand, Maharashtra, Kerala, Rajasthan and Tamil Nadu, India
Adaptations.title: Information and Communication Technology (e-choupal)
Adaptations.description: E-choupal comprises of three main elements (1) providing a web enabled computer (with power backup), (2) a trained farmer – the e-choupal shanchalak, and (3) providing access to agricultural oriented information – on weather, scientific farming practices, input supply, financial services, market prices, at the village in the local language. Farmers can take informed decisions, align their farm output with market demand, secure quality and productivity, and reduce uncertainties. Transaction costs are reduced. The e-choupal is a web based initiative of ITC’s International Business Division
Adaptations.contact_adress: Grand Trunk Road, Post Box No. 317, Guntur 522004, Andhra Pradesh
Adaptations.executing_agent: ITC
Adaptations.success_factors: Service providing efficiency, reliability of the information, dissemination of information (information must be provided timely and should be reliable so as to not cause any loss to the farmers, the information should be provided in the local language and should be easily understood)
Adaptations.limiting_factors: internet kiosks management(internet kiosks management)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret (economic development, social welfare)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The initiative has been widely accepted amongst the farmers and the service which was initially started in five states is being given in ten states and will soon cover fifteen states. It is presently operating in ten states, 40,000 villages, 6500 kiosks with four milion people.The e-Choupal has been specially cited in the Government of India’s Economic Survey of 2006-07, for its transformational impact on rural lives.
Adaptations.comments: "The sanchalak bears some operating cost but in return earns a service fee for the e-transactions done through his e-Choupal. Farmers can get real-time information despite their physical distance from the mandis. The system saves procurement costs for ITC Limited. The farmers do not pay for the information and knowledge they get from e-Choupals; the principle is to inform, empower and compete. As per the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), Nokia and ITC will collaborate to offer Nokia Life Tools consumers enriched content available in ITC’s e-Choupal network in the areas of commodity prices as well as updated information on the agriculture sector. "

Adaptations.query: Pulicat Lake, Nellore, Andhra Pradesh, Indien
Adaptations.title: Mangrove Restoration at Lake Pulicat
Adaptations.description: The mangrove restoration project at Lake Pulicat aims to improve the water quality of the lake to improve conditions for growth and multiplication of fish population and the overall goal of the project is to prevent over-fishing. Local communities planting mangroves which act as bio-filters, improving water quality by maintaining nutrient recovery, releasing excess nitrogen, deactivating phosphates, removing toxins such as heavy metals by adsorption and absorption. The restoration of mangroves helps increase fish populations helps maintain the economic activities of the farmers and also gives additional benefits by increasing biodiversity, carbon sequestration and acting as a buffer against coastal storms and cyclones, which will be more frequently through climate change.
Adaptations.contact_person: Centre for Research on New International Economic Order
Adaptations.contact_adress: No. 104, B-Block, Prince Garden, No. 40, Tahmbusamy Road, Kilpauk, Chennai-600010, Tamil Nadu, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Forest Department, CReNIO (Centre for Research on New International Economic Order)
Adaptations.success_factors: community participation for restoration works
Adaptations.limiting_factors: resource exhaustion (fishes), alteration in lake characteristics that deter fish multiplication or growth in the lake
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: besides it economic benefit the project gives environmental protection and also helps in conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: workshops on mangrove restoration have been organised, 20 demonstration programmes for women‘s group leaders are organised and training programmes are held to enable women to work in the tree nurseries. Comprehensive training material in Tamil language to be provided and made available for training and for schools (e.g. Pulicat National Matriculation School)

Adaptations.title: Adjusting to Floods on the Brahmaputra Plains
Adaptations.description: The ICIMOD supported study in Assam documents the ways and means through which the local communities of the study sites have so far coped with and adapted to changing nature of climate and water induced hazards like floods, flash floods, sand casting, river bank erosion, rainstorms etc. Changing nature of the water induced hazards in the study area is a manifestation of the impacts of climate change in the Himalayan region. The perceptions, practices and strategies developed by communities utilising mainly their traditional knowledge systems have been documented and analysed. These include – raised houses, alternate livelihoods, food storage, water resistant paddy, shifting of village site. Factors influencing the community’s adaptive capacity have also been highlighted.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 50, Samanwoy Path, Survey, P.O. Beltola, Guwahati-781028 , Assam, India
Adaptations.initiating_agent: ICIMOD (International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development)
Adaptations.executing_agent: Aaranyak
Adaptations.funding_source: ICIMOD (International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development)
Adaptations.success_factors: established rapport and familiarity with the community, willingness to share traditional coping practices
Adaptations.limiting_factors: dependent on recall
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: best practices and documentation can help in policy development and dissemination to other flood affected regions
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Five case studies were carried out under the ‘Too Much and Too Little Water’ project of ICIMOD, one each in Nepal, China and Pakistan and two in India (Assam and Bihar). The synthesis report contains the abstracts of all the five country case studies. The full reports are published separately for each case study. A short documentary film (11 minutes) titled ‘Living with flood’ has also been made as a supplement to the case study in Assam. 
ICIMOD is complementing the field study with a comprehensive study on the policy aspects of adaptation to climate and water induced hazards in the Greater Himalayan Region. In India the study is being carried out by the National Institute of Disaster Management (NIDM), Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, New Delhi."

Adaptations.title: Climate change and persistent droughts: Impacts, vulnerability and adaptation in rice growing
Adaptations.description: ClimaRice aims to assess the climate variability and its impacts on the water availability and rice production systems in the Cauvery river basin of Tamil Nadu by climate modelling techniques using IPRC (International Pacific Research Centre) Regional Climate Models run at various horizontal resolutions (100, 50 and 25 km). The project would contribute to the regional and national adaption strategies to sustain rice production and ensure food security amidst changing climate, the adaptive mechanisms like SRI / aerobic rice / direct sown rice along with soil microbial technologies in maximizing the water use efficiency under limited water supply situation will be field tested.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Professor & Head, (Project Co-ordinator) Agro Climate Research Centre, Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, Coimbatore - 641 003, TN. India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Tamil Nadu Agricultural University
Adaptations.funding_source: Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Norway/The Royal Norwegian Embassy, New Delhi
Adaptations.success_factors: Accurate and reliable climate modelling technique and farmer friendly results
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Climate data, accuracy of the model for the specific region under study and the inherient uncertainty with data and models that predict the future

Adaptations.title: Deficit Rainfall Insurance (DFRI)
Adaptations.description: The DFRI is an index based insurance where the loss in yield on rain-fed crop is assessed using weighted and capped rainfall data during different stages of the crop period. There are two kinds of products available (1) a single phase product, cheaper and covering one critical crop period, like the flowering and (2) a multi phase product with a higher payout frequency, dividing the growing process in different phases taking into account the minimum and maximum rainfall required for a minimal harvest. The scheme is beneficial for farmers who cultivate rain-fed crops in the 30 Km radius of an IMD station having minimum past data of 20 to 30 years.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 18, Pillaiyar Koil Street, S.S.Colony, Madurai - 625 010
Adaptations.executing_agent: DHAN (Development of Humane Action) Foundation
Adaptations.success_factors: presence of a IMD (Indian Meteorological Department) station, availability of historical data, financial (Without adequate sum of money a farmer cannot get his crops insured)
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Financial, rainfall variation between field and station (Lack of money by the farmer, reciept of payment after initial year of insurance from the bank on the occurrence of a calamity)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No regret
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project can be evaluated based on the increase in the sum insured from the first to the second year from $14,100 to $47,326

Adaptations.title: Rice-wheat Consortium for the Indo-Gangetic Plains
Adaptations.description:
"Zero tillage is the seeding of a crop in unplowed fields, To make the rice-wheat systems of the indo-gangetic plains more productive, tractor drawn zero-tillage drills with six to eleven inverted-T lines are used to seed wheat directly into unplowed fields in a sigle pass of the tractor. The system has reduced production costs (US$ 52/ha), increased crop yields by 5-7% and increased farm income from wheat production by US$ 97/ha. The positive effects have also been realised by the savings in fossil fuel and water, and reducing green house gas emissions.
Especially saving water will be more important with proceeding climate change."
Adaptations.contact_adress: International Maize and Wheat Improvement Centre (CIMMYT), CG Block, NASC Complex, Todapur Road, Pusa, New Delhi 110012, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Rice Wheat Consortium
Adaptations.funding_source: CGIAR (Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research)
Adaptations.success_factors: local manufacturing capacity, involvement of several manufacturers, subsidy to lower investment cost, institutional support for a innovative technology to materialize
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Has spread primarily for wheat crop, rice needs to be addressed, and technology needs to spread to smaller farmers.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: reduces emission of green house gases
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret: the technology will give both economic and environmental returns even in the absence of anthropogenic climate change impacts
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: A comprehensive review of the impacts of zero tillage wheat in the rice wheat systems has been done by Erenstein and Laxmi (2008) giving the following, the practice is adopted on 1.76 million ha area, has reduced production cost by $52/ha, crop yield increase by 5-7%, The farm income has increased by $97/ha from wheat production, increase household incomes has been between $180-340/farm and increase in food production has been 0.7% (343,000 tons). There is an 8% saving of diesel as compared to the conventional system.
Adaptations.comments: Also the primary reason is the monetary gain for the farmer and simplification of field preparation, but despite early expectations of water saving, significant water savings have not yet been achieved.

Adaptations.title: Climate Change Impacts on Coastal Biodiversity
Adaptations.description: The study on Climate Change Impacts on Coastal Biodiversity is formulated to give the sea level rise vulnerability assessment of coastal biodiversity in Tamil Nadu. The study comprises of climate modelling (technique to predict the likely climate in the future) using regional climate models, incorporation of meteorological and geospatial data which is done with the PRECIS software using supercomputing machines. The results of the study will be used in planning or framing adaptation strategies for the coasts.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Centre for Climate Change and Adaptation Research, Anna University Chennai, Chennai-600 025, India.
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Center for climate change and adaptation research
Adaptations.executing_agent: Mr. A. Saleem Khan
Adaptations.funding_source: Department of Environment, Government of Tamil Nadu
Adaptations.success_factors: Technical: data availability, softwares and computing machines
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Data Availability, computing machines, technical knowledge
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win: besides fulfilling the main objective of ascertaining the impacts of climate change of coastal biodiversity the study can also be used for planning adaptation strategies giving economic, social and environmental benefits.
Adaptations.comments: PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impact Studies) regional climate modelling system developed by the Hadley Centre that can be used in any area of the globe to generate a detailed climate change prediction.

Adaptations.title: Sustainable Land , Water and Biodiversity Conservation and Management for Improved Livelihood in Uttarakhand Watershed Sector
Adaptations.description: The project aims at controlling land degradation through the sustainable land and ecosystem management, and improving local livelihoods. The activities include soil conservation, forest regeneration, pasture and silvi-pasture development, soil erosion buns, vegetative barriers, fire management, water augmentation, upscaling of briquette making for meeting energy needs and improving income, enhancing biodiversity conservation by domestication and cultivation of medicinal and aromatic plants. This is a multi-activity project that aims to provide a variety of environmental services and livelihood benefits, and if successful, can have a synergistic effect
Adaptations.contact_adress: Chief Project Director, WMD, Dehradun
Adaptations.source: (1) Gramya: Uttarakhand Decntralized Watershed Development Project, http://www.gramya.in/GEF/index.html
Adaptations.executing_agent: Watershed Management Directorate, Uttarakhand, Govt. of Uttarakhand
Adaptations.success_factors: Effective integration of the Gram Panchayat level watershed plans at the micro-watershed level
Adaptations.limiting_factors: None
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: carbon sequestration, reduced deforestation by providing a substitute to fuel wood
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Besides the economic benefit, the project will also give environmental benefits by modification of micro-climate and soil and water conservation.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project can be evaluated on the basis of the results obtained on comparisons between the set or desired project outcomes with the outputs.

Adaptations.title: Integrated Land Use Management to Combat Land Degradation and Deforestation in Madhya Pradesh
Adaptations.description: Sustainable land and Ecosystem management is the use of land resources (soild, forests, rangelands, water, animals and plants) for the production of goods to meet human needs while assuring the long term productive potential. The project component involves (1) enabling adoption of SLEM (Sustainable Land and Ecosystem Management) in Madhya Pradesh, (2) demonstrating and upscaling of innovative approaches for sustainable land and ecosystem management, (3) developing adaptive capacity. The expected outcomes of the project are to integrate SLEM in the land use planning at the state level, management of natural resources and conservation of biodiversity led by respective community groups, reduced vulnerability of communities and increased resilience of land and ecosystems to climate change and variability.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Regional Technical Advisor, UNDP Regional Centre in Bangkok
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment and Forest, State Government of Madhya Pradesh
Adaptations.success_factors: integration of the different approaches, community involvement, capacity of the state line departments and staff
Adaptations.limiting_factors: integration of the different approaches (Landsacpe, watershed and livelihood development)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: besides its environmental benefits the project will also help in strengthening the economic returns for the people

Adaptations.title: Project Sahyog (A Drought Proofing Initiative in The Thar Desert)
Adaptations.description: The project is a drought proofing initiative in the Thar desert by community participation involving construction of groundwater recharge structures, desiltation of rivers, installation of 31 hand pumps, six open wells constructed, diversifying livelihood opportunities by improved agricultural practices like horticulture, dairy, mushroom farming, etc., drip irrigation, pasture development, enterprise development for women. The project has resulted in increasing the water table level by 20ft, increased wool, milk production and mobilizing women participation.
Adaptations.contact_adress: General Manager, His Highness Maharaja Hanwant Singhji Charitable Trust, Umaid Bhawan Palace, Jodhpur, Rajasthan, India
Adaptations.initiating_agent: His Highness Maharaja Hanwant Singhji Charitable Trust
Adaptations.executing_agent: His Highness Maharaja Hanwant Singhji Charitable Trust, local communities
Adaptations.funding_source: Sir Ratan Tata Trust, His Highness Maharaja Hanwant Singhji Charitable Trust
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional: the interventions will be possible only through community mobilization
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win:
"The activities undertaken in the project are mainly directed towards water conservation and livelihood diversification to help adapt to drought condition
thereby giving economic, social and environmental benefits."
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project impacts were evaluated for the ground water table that showed an average increase of 20 ft, the water level in the open wells remained constant despite monsoon failure, milk and wool production increased by 15% to 25%, increased animal immunity, reduced mortality. Evaluation was also conducted by the State Remote Sensing Application Centre and their study showed a prominent increase in intensity of vegetation cover in the area.
Adaptations.comments: The project has been extended to its second phase being implemented from September 2006. The project will include an additional eight to nine villages which are contiguous to area under phase one of the project.

Adaptations.title: Information and Communication Technology (iKisan)
Adaptations.description: "iKisan was set up with two components, the iKisan.com website, to provide agricultural information online, and technical centres at village level (operated by agricultural graduates who act as the interface between the computer networks and the farmers) providing both on- and off-line information services. Their online services include information on 20 crops and market information about products and services of the companies in the Nagarjuna group, weather forecasting and current events. The offline services include crop diagnostics, disease and pest management, soil testing, sampling and fertility; information about agricultural equipment and other inputs and their availability; market information; crop insurance information; information regarding cropping patterns and systems; poultry- and animal husbandry-related information."
Adaptations.contact_adress: Ikisan Limited, No. 1, Nagarjuna Hills, Hyderabad-500082
Adaptations.executing_agent: Nagarjuna Fertilizer Corporation Ltd. and various extension agencies
Adaptations.success_factors: Service providing efficiency, reliability of the information, dissemination of information (information must be provided timely and should be reliable ensuring no loss to the farmers, the information should be provided in the local language and should be easily understood).
Adaptations.limiting_factors: internet kiosks management (The capability of the kiosk manager to interface wit promptly is essential for the system to function effectively)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret: economic and social benefits
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project can be evaluated on the basis of the number of people using the portal for information (no of hits) and the basis of the different crop information that they provide.

Adaptations.title: Climate Change Vulnerability of Mountain Ecosystems in the Eastern Himalayas
Adaptations.description: This is a preliminary assessment of the impacts and vulnerability of the Eastern Himalayan region to climate change and shows the correlation between biodiversity, ecosystem functioning, drivers of change and human well being.The research activities included country level rapid surveys, thematic workshops, stakeholder interactions, development of technical papers by experts, future climate predictions. The study will help develop future strategies for vulnerability and adaptation of important impact areas.
Adaptations.contact_person: International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development
Adaptations.contact_adress: GPO Box 3226, Kathmandu, Khumaltar, Lalitpur, Nepal
Adaptations.executing_agent: ICIMOD
Adaptations.success_factors: Technical: The success of the study will depend on the scientific method followed for data collection and interpretation and its accuracy
Adaptations.limiting_factors: none
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The study is documenting impacts of climate change and would not be feasible if climate change does not occur. It will give economic and environmental benefits based on the strategies adopted if climate change occurs.

Adaptations.title: Demarcation and erection of stone pillars on the HTL (High Tide Line) on the Tamil Nadu coast
Adaptations.description: High tide line is the highest level of water that is reached during spring tides on the land. The project aims to delineate and mark the HTL along the coasts of Tamil Nadu by erection of stone pillars. The delineation work will be done using remote sensing and the pillars will be fixed along the coast for identification of the HTL on ground for the coastal community. The HTL will also be superimposed on the village cadastral maps to identify setback lines as prescribed by the CRZ notification. This will identify the HTL on the ground and help in implementation of the coastal zone regulation more effectively. The likely impacts would be (1) less pressure on vegetation in the setback areas as they will be clearly identified, thus maintaining storm buffers, and (1) reduce the risk of loss of property by preventing building near the coast, especially if the HTL may shift with sea level rise in the next 50-100 years.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Director of Environment, Government of Tamil Nadu
Adaptations.source: (1) Environment and Forest Department, Government of Tamil Nadu: http://www.tn.gov.in/policynotes/pdf/environment_forest.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: Institute of Remote Sensing, Anna University and Forest Department
Adaptations.success_factors: reliability of information: If the delineation line is not reliable or accurate the coastal zone regulation implementation will not be effective
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Financial: cost of procurement of data for delineation and also for pillars, Technical: knowledge of remote sensing techniques
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Helps in raising awareness and also reducing impacts due to climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: 3 coastal districts have been covered and about 10 are left. The impacts will depend on how this affects the Coast Regulation Zone (CRZ) implementation and will only be known after a separate evaluation.
Adaptations.comments: Maps are given to the District collector, the District town and country planning department and the District Coastal Zone Management Authority (DCZMA) as well as the State CZMA.. The chair is the DC.

Adaptations.title: Enhancing Carbon Credit for Greater Resilience to Vulnerability
Adaptations.description: This is a pilot intervention initiated by World Food Programme and the Government of Uttar Pradesh to control negative impacts of climate change on the food security of households by enhancing carbon stock of the selected villages. The measure adopted is promotion of usage of energy efficient agri and household equipments like solar lightning, bio-gas, energy efficient cooking stove, irrigation pump, etc. The use of crops that are more suited to arid regions like millets, pulsesand other cash crops. Paddy varieties better suited to dry conditions (gives lower yields but improved food security).It also includes promotion of farming practices that lower water use i.e. System of Rice Intensification (SRI), Organic farming to increase soil moisture holding capacity, mulching, bio-gas slurry to increase soil carbon and agro-forestry for carbon credits, drip and sprinkler irrigation and adopting measures for rain water harvesting. It would result in increasing the local food security, reduce the need for food aid, increased carbon stock and reduced green house gas emissions, awareness and capacity building of the village communities.
Adaptations.contact_adress: World Food Programme, 2 Poorvi Marg, Vasant Vihar, New Delhi 110057.
Adaptations.executing_agent: WFP and Government of Uttar Pradesh
Adaptations.success_factors: Community involvement, carbon stock calculation: for comparative analysis it is necessary that the preliminary carbon stock is calculated accurately
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Can be judged only after the assessment of the pilot initiative
Adaptations.comments: In order to help farmers to adopt organic agriculture, zero tillage and agroforestry, trainings and pilots will be developed to demonstrate the sustainability of the practice and the system that may have to be put in place for effective capture of soil carbon and enhance the higher productivity with various alternate strategies such as agro-forestry with horticultural species on agriculture bunds and other village common lands.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Can you please provide an information source? This project has a very big mitigation component, please focus a bit more on the adaptation. Please describe a bit more the relation between carbon stock and food security. Thank you.

Adaptations.title: Joint Forest Management (JFM)
Adaptations.description: Where functional, Joint Forest Management committees undertake protection and management of local forests that meets their needs and provides substantial benefits to the local communities, with support from the Forest departments. JFMCs protection forests from fire, grazing and control fuelwood and timber harvesting, and communities can benefit by sustaining local forests over time for flows of environmental services including water recharge, increased biodiversity and improved micro climate, as well as improved flows of fuelwood, fodder and other NTFP’s (non-timber forest products). However, tenurial insecurity and excessive governmental control, and low community interest can lead to sub-optimal outcomes. Increasing share in timber revenue will help. By increasing the resource availability it diversifies people’s livelihood options, improves water availability by increasing percolation, and sequesters carbon. India has about 100,000 JFMCs.
Adaptations.executing_agent: Forest department of states and the JFM committees
Adaptations.success_factors: institutional, legal recognition
Adaptations.limiting_factors: prior existence of forest management committees
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win win: provides economic, social and environmental benefits
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project success varied with the region where it is implemented. There has been an increase in the number of JFMC’s over the past decades showing a decrease in the extent of degraded forest area but there has not been a considerable increase in the forest area. A firm legal basis for JFM is the biggest issue facing the programe which has created several problems in states where JFM has been implemented . Issues of conflicts among communities, presence of a traditional institution, transparency in management, marketing of products should be sorted out to make JFM a complete success. Options within the Forest Rights Act can help strengthen community tenure and control for existing JFM groups as well.
Adaptations.comments: JFM has also been tried in Sundarbans in West Bengal where the forests act as a buffer against climate extremes of cyclones and storm surges. Forests provide subsistence food and subsistence income in case of failure of crop due to drought, provides more fodder, fuelwood, etc. Improves soil moisture condition especially in hilly areas. The Existence of JFMs also makes harvest (sustainable) easy. In the Udaipur District, JFM committee allows open grazing in the second year of drought.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Please explain the climate change impacts for this project a bit more. Why do you choose Sea-Level-rise? How does the project react on the impacts you choose? Thank you.

Adaptations.query: Uttar Pradesh, Haryana and Punjab, India
Adaptations.title: Tata Kisan Sansar
Adaptations.description: Tata Kisan Kendras are a farmers service centre setup by the Tata Chemical Group. TKKs provide agricultural knowledge and extension and uses remote sensing technology to analyze soil, inform about crop health, pest attacks and predicts final yield based on crop coverage. They also providing agro input supplies, farm equipment leasing, agronomy services, training and other additional services. It was initiated to provide high quality services that are financially viable and also lead to healthier crops, higher yields and enhanced income to the farmers.The use of satellite mapping gives flexilbility in adapting to the changing ownership patterns, climate and soil changes.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Tata Chemicals, Indira Dham, Babrala 202 521, Budaun district, Uttar Pradesh
Adaptations.source: Talwar, V., Mastakar, N. and Bowonder, B., 200?. ICT Platform for Enhancing Agricultural Productivity: The case study of Tata Kisan Kendra. [online] Available at: http://planningcommission.nic.in/reports/sereport/ser/stdy_ict/12_tatakisan.pdf
Adaptations.executing_agent: Tata Chemicals Limited
Adaptations.success_factors: reliability of the data for soil, climate, census data (the GIS will be accurate and effective only if the data used in analysis is accurate)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret: gives economic and social benefits
Adaptations.comments: Tata kisan kendra has gone into its second phase as Tata Kisan Sansar providing not only agri-input data but also other products and innovative services to the farmers.

Adaptations.title: Building Community Resilience to Disasters in Upland Areas
Adaptations.description:
"The project aimed to pilot and to develop a better understanding of the impact of disasters in mountain areas whilst also recognizing the capacities and coping adaptation strategies of the mountainous and ethnic minority communities for reducing their vulnerability to natural disasters. It was one of the first projects in Vietnam to develop strategies for disaster preparedness that are adapted to the unique needs of ethnic minority people. This project supported 6 communes of Lao Cai (Northern Mountain) and Kon Tum (Central Highlands) provinces where are highly prone to flash floods and landslides in Vietnam.
The project also focused on developing systems for risk assessment and planning through the use of hazard mapping. It also set out to pilot a system that would enable early warning and response at commune level.
Based on information gathered through participatory Hazard Vulnerability, and Capacity Assessments (HVCA), the project designed a Community Based Disaster Risk Management training program to raise awareness of the local communities and authorities in these regions to Disaster Risk Reduction issues."
Adaptations.contact_person: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI)
Adaptations.contact_adress: 3185 Rachel St. East, Montreal, Quebec, Canada H1W 1A3
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI), Provincial People’s Committees of Lao Cai and Kon Tum.
Adaptations.executing_agent: CECI, Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development(ACTED) in collaboration with The People’s Committees of Lao Cai and Kon Tum.
Adaptations.funding_source: The European Commissions Directorate General of Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (DIPECHO)
Adaptations.success_factors:
"Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
In line with Governmental Strategy for Natural Disaster Prevention, Response and Mitigation."
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"The high cost and not easy to operate, manage and maintain of rain gauges warning system.
Time and location of landslides and flash floods difficult to forecast.
- Communities did not always understand the digital GIS hazard maps.
-The lack of public awareness on climate change issues"
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"Community-Based Disaster Risk Management Plan developed and implemented in two mountainous provinces.
Typhoon Ketsana struck mountainous Kon Tum Province in September 29 2009; Landslides killed 52 people, destroyed 2000 homes, and completely blocked the transportation system. But families in high risk areas of project’s communes (Tu Mo Rong and Mang Ry Communes of Kon Tum province) were ready to evacuate out of unsafe places, no one died in these communes during Typhoon Ketsana.
-After Training of Trainers course and a series of refresher training programs for 40 local trainers who speak the local ethnic language as well as understand local cultural habits, many training courses has been carried out by trainers in the target communes. This has been raising awareness of the local communities and authorities in disaster risk reduction issues.
-The Information, Education and Communication (IEC) materials on disaster preparedness and risk reduction as well as flipcharts ,VCD, TV/radios, the loudspeaker systems, leaflets , metal signboards, posters, warning signboards, information panels have been disseminated and provided to communities. 
- Three pilot systems consisted of an automatic rain gauge for collecting rainfall information, a SIM card communication system designed to alert commune leaders and a wireless broadcast system for commune leaders to alert other villages were installed in Tu Mo Rong Commune of Kon Tum Province, Ban Ho and Phin Ngan Communes of Lao Cai Province for the disaster warning of flash flood.
- The digital GIS hazard maps (1/10.000) for six project communes were made available to Commune People’s Committee which used by government agencies on disaster risk management activities and helped to establish an early warning system and an evacuation system as well as helped communities recognize and understand potential dangers within the area in which they live.
-.Community Resilience to Disaster’s approaches is shared at the national level by workshops, meetings, and conferences to give examples of how to prepare for disasters in mountain areas that can be applied across the whole country."
Adaptations.comments: "-The project worked in six communes in total. They were Ban Ho, Trung Chai, Phin Ngan and Sang Ma Sao Communes in Lao Cai Province; and Tu Mo Rong and Mang Ry Communes in Kon Tum Province. - The project enlisted a reiterative approach: piloting, testing, monitoring, improving, conducting refresher courses, repeating events, and only expanding those activities that proved to reduce the impact of disasters due to the lack of existing background knowledge on how to best build ethnic minority community resilience to disasters in upland areas. -The digital GIS hazard map was produced with the accurate Global Positioning System (GPS) and HVCA information collected. "

Adaptations.title: Alternate Cropping Pattern for Tamil Nadu
Adaptations.description: The state of Tamil Nadu experienced four continous years of drought from 2000-2004. During this period some experience was gained in promoting alternate crops with lower water requirements. Building on that, this research study has identified alternate cropping patterns for the state of Tamil Nadu based on soil, climatic resources, surface water availability and social requirements. Alternate crop combinations are suggested based on the amount of rainfall and specific crop varieties identified for seven different agro-climatic zones. Crop combinations are developed for three rainfall and drought scenarios - normal rainfall (+-19% of average rainfall), moderate drought (-19-59%) and severe drought (>-59%) situations, and keeping in mind the water availability context - specifically for command areas, tank fed areas, well irrigated and dryland areas. Efforts have been made to propose cropping pattern that are economically viable. Farmers may choose the appropriate cropping pattern, based on the seasonal rainfall forecast given by Department of Agricultural Meteorology, fifteen days before the start of the season.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Directorate of Research, Tamil Nadu Agricultural Research, Coimbatore- 641003, Tamil Nadu, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, district joint directors of agriculture
Adaptations.success_factors: technical feasibility and advancement (the study should be accurate so that it can be implemented on the field)
Adaptations.limiting_factors: "biological, farm and community compatibility; agronomic adoptability; economic viability and socio-cultural acceptability. The communication of the seasonal forecasts, and cropping patterns needs to happen in a small window of a fortnight when farmers decide on the cropping pattern at the start of the season. Also seeds need to be available in adequate quantity for the proposed cropping combinations. "
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win: the system is being developed to reduce the impacts of climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Evaluation information was not available.
Adaptations.comments: """For example for Tank-irrigated areas in Kancheepuram district in the North Eastern Zone, the normal combination is of rice-rice. The shifts proposed are rice-maize (normal year), maize/millets/vegetables - pulses (Moderate drought) and wheat/fodder maize Wheat / fodder maize/fodder cowpea/vegetables (lab lab / cluster bean / bhendi) (Nov.-Feb.) for servere drought years."" "

Adaptations.query: Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya and Nagaland, India
Adaptations.title: Package of Organic Practices for Arecanut, Ginger, Large Cardamom, Passion fruit and Pineapple
Adaptations.description: Horticultural crops like pineapple, passion fruit, large cardamom, arecanut and ginger have been promoted in North Eastern states of India to stabilize cultivation in shifting cultivation areas. These are traditionally organic practices and the study documents the organic practices – crop growing methods, input supplies and harvesting procedure, and can help with certification, thus helping maintain them as organic. The crops have been selected based on the knowledge of cultivation and farming, the economic returns, nutritional value and also because these crops are being promoted for the rehabilitation and resettlement of shifting cultivators as they can address the livelihood and food security needs of the people. Organic agriculture systems enhance biological diversity, increase soil biological activity, maintain long term soil fertility and recycle wastes of animal and plant origin thus minimizing the use of non-renewable resources. They also improve soil moisture retention. All these characteristics of organic practices in horticultural crops will give sustained production with minimum inputs thus reducing the need for shifting cultivation for livelihood. Because the organic agricultural systems are more diverse they have greater flexibility to cope with adverse effects of climate change leading to higher economic and ecological stability and also because they have low input costs, the risk of partial or total crop failure will be lowered.
Adaptations.contact_person: North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Project
Adaptations.contact_adress: """Symli Building"", First Floor, Malki-Dhankheti, Shillong-793001, Meghalaya "
Adaptations.initiating_agent: NERCORMP (North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Project)
Adaptations.executing_agent: NERCORMP
Adaptations.funding_source: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations), New Delhi
Adaptations.success_factors: availability of bio-fertilizers, market demand, traditional practices
Adaptations.limiting_factors: None
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: it improves social, economic and environmental benefits
Adaptations.comments: The report researched four regions: Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya and Nagaland

Adaptations.title: Development of Regional Flood Formula Using L-Moments for North Brahmaputra River System
Adaptations.description: This is a study to develop a regional flood frequency estimates for gauged catchments relationship using L-moment (statistics used to summarize the shape of a probability distribution) based robust frequency distribution for the North Brahmaputra river system to provide rational flood frequency estimates for gauged catchments. It may also serve as a useful alternative for estimation of floods of desired return periods for the ungauged catchments of the study area. Estimation of flood magnitudes and frequency is required for planning and designing of various types of water resources projects. 10 data sites for this study was selected after testing data from 12 data sites as the 10 data sites comprised of homogeneous data sets.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Jal Vigyan Bhawan, Roorkee-247667, Uttarakhand, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: National Institute of Hydrology
Adaptations.success_factors: technical: the method followed to collect data, data analysis and interpretation
Adaptations.limiting_factors: lack of data, need based
Adaptations.comments: Flood frequency estimates are made using historical data but the climate change impacts are felt in recent pasts. This study takes into consideration data from multiple catchment (gauged and un-gauged) considering impacts of recent pasts thus providing estimates of flood frequency that are more in-tuned to recent changes. For future changes a small factor (above or below the estimate) must be considered.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Does this assessment really consider Climate Change? If yes, please describe it a bit more. Thank you

Adaptations.title: National Mission for Green India
Adaptations.description: The National Mission for a Green India is one of the eight Missions under the National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC), recognizes that climate change phenomena will affect and alter the distribution, type and quality of natural resources of the country and the associated livelihoods of the people. To reduce the negative impacts of climate change the forestry sector will be promoted and enhanced because of its environmental amelioration through climate mitigation, food security, water security, biodiversity conservation and livelihood security of forest dependant communities. The activties such as afforestation, reforestation on open, degraded urban and peri-urban forest lands, restoration of mangroves and wetlands, adoption of agroforestry in fallow and degraded agricultural lands, enhancing biomass/NTFP (Non timber forest products) based livelihood will be taken up.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Nehru Foundation for Development, Thaltej Tekra, Ahmedabad-380054
Adaptations.initiating_agent: MoEF (Ministry of Environment and Forestry), Government of India
Adaptations.executing_agent: National: MoEF (Ministry of Environment and Forestry), State: Forest and agriculture department
Adaptations.success_factors: political will and involvement of communities, baseline assessment of natural resources: because of the large spatial scale of the project, baseline data is needed to compare the results before and after the project to see how effective the project was and to ascertain the project success
Adaptations.limiting_factors: lack of coordination and planning at central level: if there is no coordination at the central level the projects effectiveness will reduce
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Besides the environmental benefits of the project, it will also improve the economic and social conditions
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: not yet implemented

Adaptations.title: The Chouka System - A soil and moisture conservation technique
Adaptations.description: The chouka or square system is a soil and moisture conservation technique applied primarily in degraded pasture lands of moderate slope in Rajasthan. The technique involves digging a checkerboard network of shallow recessed squares a few metres in length and under 1ft deep with an overall bund on the three lower sides in a U-shape along moderate sloped plains. A 2 km by 1.5 km area of pastureland would have choukas dug around the edge of the area with two foot high bunds creating a barrier surrounding the field. Each Choukha fills with water and excess flows to the next interconnected chaukha and so on. This system retains soil moisture beyond the monsoon to rejuvenate dry pasture lands and capture and divert rain water for ground water recharge and future use into low lying water tanks and ponds. The system is suitable for arid and semi-arid areas. The choukas have enabled the conversion of dry wastelands to fodder rich areas and has also helped increase the diversity of medicinal herbs and avian fauna.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Gram Vikas Navyuvak Mandal Laporiya, Dudu, Jaipur, Rajasthan-303008
Adaptations.source: (1) Chouka Pranali, jal avem mrida sanrakshan ke kshetra main navachar. First edition, 15 November, 2007. GMVNL and UNICEF Rajasthan, (2) Gocchar ka Prasad Bandta Laporiya, 2004. GMVNL, Laporiya
Adaptations.executing_agent: GMVNL (Gram Vikas Navyuvak Mandal Laporiya), Community members
Adaptations.funding_source: Community members, Self and multiple funding sources
Adaptations.success_factors: Environmental: Topography of the region is very important, the system works well only when the land has some degree of slope
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Extensive soil work, requires considerable labour to undertake and better suited to moderate areas with minimum slope to 4% slope. Not applicable in undulating, sand dunes and hilly areas.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-win: the system has been made keeping in mind the variability in rainfall and drought pattern of the region. It has not only provided the resources the method was sought for (fodder and water) but has also improved the economic status of the farmers, social welfare and has also helped in conservation of soil.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project has been implemented in parts of Gujarat and Afghanistan based on its effectiveness to conserve water and provide fodder resources

Adaptations.title: Rajasthan Water Sector Restructuring Project (RWSRP)
Adaptations.description: The Rajasthan Water Restructuring Project involved formation of local farm level committes (Water Users Associations) to transfer some of the operations and management of minor systems to these groups. The project  rehabilitated 91 irrigation systems, improving surface and ground water resources, increasing productivity of agriculture by improving irrigation systems performance and agricultural practices. The activities included dam safety works, intensification of agricultural extension services, institutional and capacity buliding, ground water management and dissemination of information regarding state water policy. As of March 2010 546 Water User Associatios have been formed.
Adaptations.contact_adress: State Ground water Department, Jhalana Doongri, Jaipur-302004, Rajasthan
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ground water Board, CECOEDECON, Sareeta
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional: Water Users Association responsible for management and maintenance
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win: gives economic, social and environmental conservation benefits
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: An impact study for the ground water works was carried out in the year 2010. According to a report by World Bank the implementation progress of RWSRP is good.
Adaptations.comments: For the ground water management a pilot was done in three districts namely Jodhpur, Sikar and Rajasmand.

Adaptations.title: Impact of Climate Change and food insecurity on poverty
Adaptations.description: By affecting the length of the growing season and variation in precipitation, climate change is likely to affect the agricultural productivity and food security of small farmers.Farmers along the coastline may loose their lands with rise in sea level. The scoping study assesses stakeholder perceptions, especially of small and marginal farmers about the impacts of climate change and the measures needed for mitigating the adverse impact of climate change on food security. The study is being done in four countries-– Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan. The study would help assess current perceptions of stakeholders who are likely to be amongst the worst hit by climate change, on impacts and adaptation steps, such as change in cultivation practices and appropriate measures to facilitate food banks.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Centre for International Trade, Economics and Environment, D-217, Bhaskar Marg, Bani Park, Jaipur-302016, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: CUTS, CECOEDECON
Adaptations.success_factors: data collection technique, target community and interpretation: results of the study will entirely depend on the mentioned factors
Adaptations.limiting_factors: community shows no interest or participation in the study
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Thank you very much for your contribution. Just one short question: Why do you choose Sea-Level rise as an impact? If this is correct, please explain it in the description. You mentioned only precipitation.

Adaptations.query: Sangamner and Akole blocks of Ahmednagar district of Maharashtra, India
Adaptations.title: Promotion of Climate Change Adaptation in Semi-Arid and Rainfed Regions
Adaptations.description: The project aims to build resilience and capacities of poor rural communities to adapt to climate change. The village communities will be organised into Village Development Communities (VDC) and the women members into Self Help Groups (SHGs). The project will focus on the following four measures: (1) Promotion of Climate Change Adaptive Behaviour and Disaster Risk Mitigation, (2) Promotion of Renewable Energy as a well-being and mitigation measure, (3) Capacity building, knowledge generation, dissemination and policy dialogue, & (4) Empowering, equipping and enabling WOTR (Watershed Organisation Trust) to serve as a national referal centre for climate change adaptation. The project is experimental in nature and will help to draw lessons and devise best practices that can be later widely replicated and scaled up to adapt to climate change.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Paryavaran,Behind Market Yard, Ahmednagar - 414001
Adaptations.executing_agent: WOTR (Water Organisation Trust), Sampada Trust and the Sanjeevani Institute for Empowerment and Development (SIED)
Adaptations.funding_source: Swiss Agency for Development Cooperation (SDC) and National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD)
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional and capacity building
Adaptations.limiting_factors: technical: There is “little experience and validated field level successes existing in terms of building resilience and capacities of poor rural communities to adapt to climate change”
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: emission reduction: because of use of alternate and renewable energy for household cooking and lighting
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-win: adaptation, mitigation
Adaptations.comments: component 1 i.e., Promotion of Climate Change Adaptive Behaviour and Disaster Risk Mitigation includes (i) Participatory, comprehensive, and integrated watershed and ecosystems management along watershed lines. (ii) Integration of biodiversity conservation in adaptation and mitigation measures. (iii) Building up of food security through promoting sustainable agriculture. (iv) Development and establishment of integrated crop micro irrigation systems and practices. (v) Promotion of sustainable livelihoods. (vi) Gender and women’s empowerment. and that VDCs are now a sub-committee of the gram panchayat (The Government of Maharashtra passed enabling legislation to this effect and amended the Bombay and Village Panchayat Act, 1958).

Adaptations.query: Madhya Pradesh, Himachal Pradesh, Rajasthan, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttarakhand, India
Adaptations.title: Affordable Drip Irrigation Technology Intervention Program (ADITI)
Adaptations.description: Low cost, modular, protective drip irrigation can help save and diversify crops for small rainfed farmers. IDEI’s micro irrigation program for water scarce states in India includes the Affordable Drip Irrigation Technology Intervention (ADITI) program which promotes the use of low cost drip irrigation kits. These kits are applicable in a wide range of plot sizes varying from 20 square meters to 1000 square meters, with prices ranging from Rs.250 to Rs.4000. These kits are manufactured and supplied by private agencies supported by IDEI. The ADITI kits reduce the limitations of rain fed farming, enabling a farmer to grow a wider variety of crops, cultivate all the year round, reduce the water use by 30-60%, and increase crop yields by 20-40%.
Adaptations.contact_adress: C 5/43, (1st & 2nd Floor), Safdarjang Development Area, New Delhi - 110016
Adaptations.executing_agent: IDEI, local NGOs, private manufacturers and distributors
Adaptations.funding_source: multiple sources and user financing for the product
Adaptations.success_factors: Research and development, technical aspects: Research and development (The program has effectively addressed the issue of affordability by reducing costs through R & D and offering modular systems), technical aspects (There is backup service support available for addressing technical problems that ensures a user).
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Labor: some low cost drip systems require more labor than conventional systems which may not be easily available
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Reduce energy consumption: Drip systems operated with gravity pressure or with low-pressure low horsepower pump reduce energy consumption
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-win: water conservation
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Large number of drip irrigation kits have been sold so far (2,95,000). . Studies have been conducted to evaluate the use of these kits and also their impact on the farmers income and their consumption pattern that show a positive impact of the drip irrigation kits. The kits are seen to reduce water use by over 50%, increase yields by 20% -40%, and can double the amount of irrigated area in situations of low water availability
Adaptations.comments: The low cost drip irrigation system is designed to be incremental, ranging from US$ 5.6 to $ 88.9 for plot sizes of 20 square meters to 1000 square meters and can be expanded with profits derived from crop. The kits have been designed so that they can address the irrigation issues of different farmers with varying plot sizes.

Adaptations.title: Community Seed Bank Project
Adaptations.description: The community seed bank project helps in conserving traditional seed varieties by encouraging farmers to form sangams and grow indigenous varieties organically and by setting up farmer community seed banks for seed exchange, distribution and utilization. The marketing of the seeds is done by CIKS’s (Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems) own outlet – Arogyam to sustain the practice of conserving and growing. About 130 paddy and 50 vegetable varieties have been conserved in four districts, 125 villages with 37 farmer sangams benefitting 3000 farmers. The varieties conserved have specific characteristics including drought, water logging, salinity, disease and pest and flood tolerance.
Adaptations.contact_adress: CIKS, 30, Gandhi Mandapam Road, Kotturpuram, Chennai-600 085, Tamil Nadu, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: CIKS
Adaptations.success_factors: institution for management of sangams and for creating revolving funds, marketing
Adaptations.limiting_factors: awareness, forming local institutions: lack of awareness about conserving traditional seed varieties
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: environmental conservation and social welfare
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: About 130 paddy and 50 vegetable varieties have been conserved in four districts, 125 villages with 37 farmer sangams benefitting 3000 farmers as most of the species have drought, water logging, salinity, disease and pest and flood tolerance.
Adaptations.comments: Farmers who cultivate traditional varieties are given technical assistance of manuring their field organically, treating pests by natural control methods etc. At the end of the season the farmer then returns twice the quantity of seeds that he had taken from the seed bank, these seeds are then distributed further which has a multiplying effect, creating a revolving fund. Some sangams also run biopesticide units as an additional source of income.

Adaptations.title: Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme for Kharif crops (2010)
Adaptations.description: The weather based crop insurance scheme provides a financial safety net to weather induced risk of crop loss and is thus has an important climate change adaptation potential. It operates on the principle of area approach – the geographical area around a reference weather station is pre-notified by the State Level Coordination Committee on Crop Insurance (SLCCCI). The scheme is valid for crops that have been notified by SLCCCI. The sum insured is almost the same as the cost of cultivation and predeclared by AIC (Agriculture Insurance Company of India Limited) and even the crops to be insured are notified two months before a season. It currently insures crops in the Rabi (winter) and Kharif (monsoon) seasons and only those crops that have been notified by the State Government are considered for insurance. Coverage is available for deficit rainfall (both volume and distribution ) and excess rainfall, with triggers defined for each.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Directorate of Agriculture, Pant Krishi Bhawan, Jaipur-302005, Rajasthan
Adaptations.executing_agent: Agriculture Department, Government of Rajasthan
Adaptations.funding_source: Agriculture Insurance Company of India limited, ICICI Lombard, IFFCO Tokio General Insurance
Adaptations.success_factors: Financial: Without capital to invest the scheme will not be implemented
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Lack of finances: Without capital to invest the scheme will not be implemented
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret: gives financial safety to farmers against weather based crop losses
Adaptations.comments: For a crop in the Kharif season there are two types of insurance covers (i) Deficit rainfall cover- (a) Rainfall cover Volume: This is divided into three phases, periods of which depend upon the crops being grown. In each phase there are two triggers based on amount of rainfall and for both these triggers there is a different rate (Rs./mm). The maximum payout for these phases is different for each crop but the total maximum payout under the cover is Rs. 3000 for each crop. (b) Rainfall Distribution Cover (Consecutive dry days): for this there is one trigger based on the number of dry days and the payout (maximum and for number of trigger days) varies accordingly with each crop and number of consecutive dry days. (ii) Excess Rainfall Cover (multiple crops): In this case there can be one or two phases with time periods, amount of rainfall and payout varying for different crops and for those that have different phases. The premium for each is 10% of the total sum insured. The scheme for weather based insurance is also applicable for the Rabi crops and has been initiated since the year 2007-08. For detailed information please check this weblink: http://www.rajasthankrishi.gov.in/WeatherInsuranceindex.asp.

Adaptations.title: Earthen dams - A Community Based Watershed Development Approach
Adaptations.description: Improving water availability in semi-arid areas is a key adaptation action. The community based approach of watershed development involved facilitating the formation of village development committees (VDCs). CECOEDECON and the VDCs constructed an 800 m long earthen dam with anicut in the pasture land to harvest monsoon flows and raise ground water recharge rates and levels. The intervention has resulted in increased availability of water, reduced soil erosion, improved water quality, increased livestock population and agricultural yields. It has directly beneffited 344 families and a cattle population of 5000. There has been land quality improvement of 2900 ha. The VDCs are responsible for management, operation and co-ordination of the dam, the VDCs have taken initiative in community mobilization and repair of dam (retro-fitting of top, stone pitching of slope to control erosion).
Adaptations.contact_adress: Co-Director, Cecoedecon, F 159-160, Industrial Area, Sitapura, Jaipur, Rajasthan
Adaptations.source: Bapugaon, Community Based Watershed Development Approach (Published 2005)
Adaptations.executing_agent: CECOEDECON, Gram Panchayat, Village Development Committee, Panchayat Samiti
Adaptations.funding_source: CECOEDECON, Village Development Committee, Panchayat Samiti
Adaptations.success_factors: Technical: Without technical support from the NGO the intervention would not have been possible
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win: soil and water conservation, social welfare and economic development
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: An impact assessment of the work was done in the year 2000 which showed the positive results of the intervention on crop yields in the village Bapugaon (wheat increased from 4.5 -9 Q/ha to 48-60 Q/ha, and for the three crops of mustard (4.5-7.5Q/ha), Bajra (12-15Q/ha) and Groundnut (7.5-9Q/ha) the yield increased to 24-30 Q/ha. It has also resulted in improving the water and land quality of the local region.
Adaptations.comments: "The contribution for the earthen dam and anicut at Bapugaon was Rs. 2,39,000 out of which CECOEDECON contributed Rs 76400, Panchayat Samiti contributed Rs 125,000 and the contribution of the Village Development Committee was Rs 37,600. Since 2000 onwards, (1) most of the farmers started taking three crops a year (Rabi, Kharif and Jayad) and growing vegetables like Tomato, Chilly, Arbi and watermelon in the Zayad season; (2) water became available throughout the year in all the wells. The most profound effect of the storage has been seen in the quality of water (showed increased hardness and salinity content due to decreasing water quantity) that has reached potable standards. The other beneficial are seen in the improved social status of villagers and reduced migration. "

Adaptations.title: Vulnerability Assessment of Kolkata metropolitan area to increased precipitation in a Changing Climate
Adaptations.description: This study aims to strengthen the understanding of the vulnerability of Kolkata from increased precipitation caused by climate change effects by developing hydrological, hydraulic, and storm drainage models to identify vulnerable areas and assessing monetary, social, and environmental impacts resulting from such climate change events. It then suggests adaptation proposals and mitigation options as well as local capacity building such that the planning process can take into account climate change threats in Calcutta
Adaptations.contact_person: Mr Debal Ray, Chief Environment Officer
Adaptations.contact_adress: """Department of Environment, Government of West Bengal, Writers Building, Biplabi Trailakya Sarani, B B D Bagh, Kolkata, West Bengal, India "" "
Adaptations.source: """VULNERABILITY OF KOLKATA METROPOLITAN AREA TO INCREASED PRECIPITATION IN A CHANGING CLIMATE Sector Note, June 11, 2010,FINAL DRAFT, Environment, Climate Change and Water Resources Department South Asia Region"" "
Adaptations.executing_agent: World Bank, Govt. of West Bengal, IIT Delhi
Adaptations.success_factors: availability of input data for modeling, technical expertise , hard and soft resilience measures identified for adaptation to flood
Adaptations.limiting_factors: appropriate data, multidisciplinary team
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret: climate change projections are essential to develop adaptation plans for a vulnerable city
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The study has come out with: modeling results such as vulnerable wards to climate change, loss likely to occur, soft and hard adaptation measures such as investing in hard urban services including roads, traffic, water supply, storm water and sewage channels, electricity and telecommunications and that recognized the importance of open space, and green areas as an integral part of city development and investing in soft infrastructure such as- strengthening of disaster management and preparedness for both pre and post disaster situations.
Adaptations.comments: Among the suggested adaptation measures, a number of projects are either currently under way or are planned for future implementation in KMA under the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM) and the Kolkata Environmental Improvement Project (KEIP)scheme funded by ADB. The selection and prioritization of projects for adaptation have to be made based on cost benefit analysis using the net present value (NPV) approach.

Adaptations.title: Bio Gas (Best practices)
Adaptations.description: Functional Biogas units at the household level can reduce fuelwood required for cooking, lessen time spent to collect fuelwood, improve air quality, and still provide slurry for application in fields. But convenient and efficient design, construction quality and back-technical support are key in ensuring that units are used over time. The MPRLP was declared an implementing agency for biogas plants in September 2008 by the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy, Government of India. Project villages in 9 districts had the potential but with no trained manpower for the activity. MPRLP biogas program started by conducting training for staff to orient them, followed by mason and user trainings. Energy promoters training with a specially designed tool kit, which helps for repair of plants. About 5000 units have been built in two years and the design and institutional structure has been improved. Around 70% of these units are functional. The key benefits of the bio gas units as perceived by the community is the time saved in travelling long distances by the women to collect fuel wood and avoiding seasonal issues – of lantananot being available after February, and wet fuelwood in the monsoons. Also most houses own some cattle with low milk yields – their dung can be put to use for the bio gas units.
Adaptations.contact_person: Neeraja Upadhayay, Madhya Pradesh Rural Livelihoods Project (MPRLP)
Adaptations.contact_adress: MPRLP 3rd floor Beej Bhawan Bhopal MP, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: MPRLP
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional, reliable technology base for construction of good quality biogas, supplier & repair network
Adaptations.limiting_factors: water scarcity would make it unusable, technical support.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: yes: low energy consumption, solid waste management, decrease pressure on forest.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: From September 2008 till august 2010,MPRLP has constructed 4833 family size biogas plants in nearly 800 villages, nearly 300 masons have been trained ,along with147 livelihood promoters are trained for operation & maintenance purpose. nearly 5000 women are being trained for its usage during user training. As per the last survey 70% of the bio gas units are functional.
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: This is a very interesting project, but can you explain a bit more the relation to drought, which you choose as impact. Thank you

Adaptations.title: Community Grain Fund (CGF)
Adaptations.description:
"Groups of women in rural AP have formed sanghams (voluntary associations) and, with the help of local NGOs and DDS, regenerate fallow land within the village, and grow, store and distribute
traditional varieties of grain through their own Community Grain Fund which functions as a local public distribution system. With the assistance of DDS, the women lobbied with the government to change their policy and loans were made available, allowing them to prepare village fallows and sow the first crops. Loans were repaid at market rates over five years in the form of grain to village committees who store it and manage the Community Grain Funds (CGF). The establishment of these funds required a one-time expenditure on the part of the government after which the CGF have operated independently. Grain from the CGF is sold at subsidized prices to the poorest and most vulnerable in the village. The amount that people can purchase was established according to need as determined by the villagers themselves in a participatory process. """
Adaptations.contact_adress: "101, Kishan Residency, 1-11-242/1, Street No. 5, Shyamlal Buildings Area Begumpet, Hyderabad - 500 016 Andhra Pradesh"""
Adaptations.initiating_agent: womens collectives (sangams) and DDS (Deccan Development Society)
Adaptations.executing_agent: sangams (womens collectives)
Adaptations.success_factors: strong institution, low default, storage facilities, availability and access to land
Adaptations.limiting_factors: breakdown of the sangham linkages, higher default rates and willingness of farmers to participate
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: yes: The seeds grown using organic farming techniques which are less enrgy intensive
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret: reviving back traditional seeds and establishing a grain bank are useful irrespective of climate change
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Through this alternative PDS the women brought over 1000 hectares of fallows under the plough. They produced an extra 800,000 kilograms of sorghum in their villages in the very first year of the project. This meant that they were able to produce nearly three million extra meals in 30 villages. Or 1000 extra meals per family. The fodder provided by the newly cultivated fields sustained over 6000 heads of cattle in 30 villages. Finally and more importantly in each village 2500 extra wage days were created. 500 towards ploughing, sowing and manuring and 2000 wages in weeding. In all 75000 extra wage days were earned in 30 villages.
Adaptations.comments: The amount of grain that villagers could purchase was established according to need as determined by the villagers themselves, in public participatory processes. The money earned from the sales was deposited in an interest-bearing bank account in the name of the Community Grain Fund, and used to fund loans to bring additional fallow land under cultivation. The initial bank deposit was for a five year term and the interest subsidized the reduced price the villagers paid when they bought the grain in lean times.
