Therefore, after the initial investment by DDS in providing small loans to bring land under cultivation, the Community Grain Fund did not require outside assistance, and continues to fund new cultivation, increasing the amount of food produced and consumed locally, as well as local employment possibilities.

Adaptations.title: East Kolkata Wetlands
Adaptations.description: The EKW are a complex of natural wetlands and extensive man-made fishponds that absorb the stormwater runoff during monsoon events and reduce flooding risks for Calcutta. In normal times they effectively use nutrient rich sewage flows for profitable pisciculture and vegetable cultivation, thus providing a natural sewage treatment service as well. Much EKW area has been lost to real estate pressures, and the East Kolkota Wetland Management Act of 2006 implemented by the EKW Management Authority controls further landuse change and support conservation of the wetlands in about 12500 ha.
Adaptations.contact_person: Dr Nitai Kundu, Chief Technical Officer
Adaptations.contact_adress: EKW Management Authority, Department of Environment, Govt. of West Bengal, Writers Building, Kolkata 700001
Adaptations.executing_agent: EKWMA (East Kolkata Wetlands Management Authority)
Adaptations.success_factors: enabling legislation, non interference of political interests,repair of sewage channels and treatment
Adaptations.limiting_factors: increasing land value and real estate pressures
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win: The wetlands will contine to provide services and livelihoods even during non flood season
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project has three major benefits – regular sewage treatement through a natural process, livelihood through fishery and vegetables for locals, and the storm water runoff function. The value of the sewage function can be guaged from the fact that the recurring cost for a small treatment facility of 500 mgd capacity is about Rs 1 billion, and the EKW absorb about 3000 mgd thus saving about Rs 6 billion of operation costs annually. The flooding damage avoided is extra.

Adaptations.title: Coastal vulnerability assessment and strategies for better preparedness towards impact of climate change and SLR along the West Bengal coast
Adaptations.description: The study seeks to describe the current and projected vulnerabilities to climate change in the study area. The Sundarbans have been chosen as the proposed area to study the dependence of the communities on coastal ecosystems and the impacts on livelihoods that might arise due to future climate change. The key vulnerabilities that the study focused on were: coastal vulnerability to climatic hazards, SLR (Sea Level Rise) and saltwater intrusion and deriving a vulnerability range determining climatic hazard risk zones along the coast. The vulnerabilities will be assessed using a mix of secondary literature to understand the nature of occurrence of climatic hazards, hazard mapping, genarating an analytical model to indicate area under inundation under different levels of SLR and bio physical and socio economic impact assessment. Based on the vulenrability and impact assessments, the study would bring out policy recommendations. These will feed into identifying areas for interventions for the development of suitable adaptation strategies and developing the state Disaster Management Plans.
Adaptations.contact_person: Ms. Sreeja Nair, Research Associate, Centre for Global Environment Research
Adaptations.contact_adress: The Energy Resources Institute (TERI), Darbari Seth Block, IHC Complex, Lodhi Road, New Delhi - 110 003, INDIA
Adaptations.source: TERI proposal on Coastal vulnerability assessment and strategies for better preparedness towards impact of climate change and SLR along the West Bengal coast
Adaptations.executing_agent: TERI (The Energy Resources Institute)
Adaptations.success_factors: availability of input data for modeling, technical expertise
Adaptations.limiting_factors: appropriate data at required temporal and spatial scale
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret: climate change projections are essential to develop adaptation plans for a vulnerable city
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: it is an ongoing study

Adaptations.title: System of Rice Intensification in selected Madhya Pradesh Rural Livelihoods project (MPRLP) districts
Adaptations.description:
"SRI (System of Rice Intensification) is a package of practices for cultivating rice which use less seed, water, and chemical fertilizers and more bio-fertilizers. There is more spacing between the seeds and saplings are transplanted, and flood irrigation is not practiced. This can enhancing rice productivity even under climate change.
The basic concepts of SRI: 
• Use young seedlings to preserve mature plants growth potential.
• Avoid trauma to the roots
• Give plants optimally wider spacing.
• Keep paddy soil sufficiently moist but not continuously flooded mostly aerobic and not saturated.
• Actively aerate the soil.
• Enhance soil organic matter.
The total cost of production with conventional techniques comes to Rs 2695 per hectare, as compared to Rs 3065 under SRI technology.In the eastern district of Dindori under MPRLP, under SRI intervention, there has been a sharp increase in the percentage of farmers with surplus rice from 51% to 81% after introduction of SRI. There are 907 BPL households who reported to have had surplus rice to provide 3 square meals a day."
Adaptations.contact_person: Mr Sandeep Khanwalkar, State Coordinator Agriculture
Adaptations.contact_adress: Madhya Pradesh Rural Livelihood Project, Beez Bhawan Arera Hill Bhopal MP
Adaptations.executing_agent: MPRLP
Adaptations.success_factors: transplanting labor, bio fertiliser, technical advice
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Erratic and heavy rains, labour availability, quality seeds, irrigation facility.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes: use of bio pesticides and less water demands less energy
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win:Even in non drought years this techniques is low input
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The SRI technique was introduced in the MPRLP in the year 2006-07 in 4 of their rice producing districts when the project felt the need for enhancing productivity in the resource poor areas. SRI was promoted on large scale through demonstrations, organizing training, field visits with active involvement of farmer’s, project facilitators and people’s representatives. Seeing the initial success farmers started adopting this technique with the help of project team. In 25 blocks in 4 districts the land cultivated under conventional method is around 1,633,329.67 acre. More than 189,594 households of 1505 villages grow paddy through conventional technique. In these 25 blocks, the SRI is practiced by 10181 households spread over 641 villages and 8924 acrea of area. An input output analysis of the conventional method of rice cultivation and SRI, the yield increase from an average of 15 to 36 quintals per ha or 140%. The gross return (@ Rs 800/quintal of paddy) is Rs 12000 under conventional practise and Rs 28800 after SRI and the cost of cultivation is Rs 2695 under conventionel method and Rs 3065 under SRI method, so the net returns are Rs 9305 and Rs 25735 respectively – an increase of over 170%
Adaptations.comments: SRI can play an important role in enhancing rice productivity, maintaining soil fertility with well ecosystem preservation . It is water saving (by 25-50%) and seed saving (by 50-80%) besides increased yield (at least 25-50% but usually over 100%). The location specific changes should be made and permitted while promotion and popularization of SRI. Theses changes would facilitate the farmers for quick adoption on larger area.

Adaptations.title: Social Forestry Plantation
Adaptations.description: Community forests and plantations on common lands provide multiple biomass benefits to local communities, can improve the soil moisture and groundwater situation. In addition to fuelwood, they provide an additional source of fodder for livestock and act as a safety asset in times of crop failure. This becomes more important under Climate Change to reduce the impact on the forest. With a view to increase peoples participation in forest protection and management the Rajasthan Forest Department collaborated with the Barodiya Panchayat in Jaipur district, to plant a total of 73 acres in the years 1985, 1992 and 1993 with species like Acacia tortilis, Eucalyptus spp. and Dalbargia sissoo. The plantation provided the communities with fuel wood, fodder and timber benefits. A management plan was prepared to harvest the plantation after completion of its rotation period. Based on the harvest plan, an auction was held which led to high bids and the revenue was divided equally between the community and the forest department, as per the state government order S. F. (17) 11 Raj./8/82-A/ on June 5, 1982 regulations.
Adaptations.contact_adress: DFO, Room no 304, II floor, Mini Secretariat, Jaipur, Rajasthan
Adaptations.source: "Management Plan, Barodiya Plantation ""85"", Range- Chaksu Van mandal, Jaipur "
Adaptations.executing_agent: Forest Department, Gram panchayat
Adaptations.success_factors: institutional, distribution of monetary benefits: to protect and manage the forests (forest department and the Gram Sabha), for continued forest plantation, protection and management by the community
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret: the plantation activity gives economic returns in the form of fuelwood and the final felling and also gives other benefits like increased availability of fodder and environmental benefits like soil binding and checking erosion, etc. These benefits will be obtained despite anthropogenic climate change impacts
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The harvesting of the plantation resulted in a net income of Rs 8,000,000 which was equally divided amongst the community and forest department. The plantation also provided fodder and fuelwood to the local communities.
Adaptations.comments: Increased availability of fodder to the villagers led to an increase in livestock population by the community. The monetary income received from the final harvest was equally distributed amongst the forest department and the community. The community used their share of the money for improving rural infrastructure - building a village road and funded additional plantation work from NREGA - the social security employment guarantee funds

Adaptations.title: Soil and Water Conservation Programmes
Adaptations.description: Himachal Pradesh has hilly terrain and high rainfall in the rainy season increasing erosion, while water scarcity is experienced in other seasons. The state department of Agriculture is implementing rain water harvesting including Individual, Community based tank and Head weirs etc, and soil conservation and soil erosion control schemes to increase agricultural production. Improved water availabillity improves productivity and reduces risk of crop failure while soil conservation helps preserve fertility in the longer run.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Directorate of Agriculture, Krishi Bhawan, Boileauganj, Shimla-171005, Himachal Pradesh
Adaptations.executing_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh
Adaptations.success_factors: institutional mechanisms, water users groups, financial resources, technical support
Adaptations.limiting_factors: inadequate repair and maintenance, lack of funds
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret: SMC (Soil and Moisture Conservation) and watershed treatment undertaken by the Department is essential for water availability and groundwater recharge especially during dry spells
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The major interventions here are the structures built and the financial outlays for undertaking minor and major irrigation works. During the year 2007-08, The Department has executed 98 Minor irrigation Schemes / Water Harvesting Structures with an expenditure of Rs. 324.54 lakh . 29 projects of Minor Irrigation were executed with an expenditure of Rs. 350.61 lakh during the year 2008-09 and a provision of Rs. 327.24 is required to complete these 29 schemes during 2009-10.
Integrated Watershed Management: The Department of Agriculture is constructing Community Based Water Harvesting Structures, Silt retention structure in R.C.C. , Concrete, masonry and Check dams in wire crate mesh etc on 100% assistance to provide protective / life saving and assured irrigation.During the financial year, 2008-09, Rs 100 lakh have been provided under this scheme. The schemes are executed through participatory approach and cover engineering and vegetative measures. This is a State Plan Scheme."

Adaptations.title: Community Grain Bank
Adaptations.description: Agragamee (an NGO working in rural Orissa) helped in setting up grain banks by mobilising rural tribal communities to address the issue of food security and to reverse the situation of debt trap and bondage. Tribals were encouraged to make collective savings of grain soon after the harvests and Agragamee helped by matching the amount of grain collected for the first 2-3 years. They can borrow grains at a nominal rate of interest set by the community institution, which they can repay the following year after the crop is harvested. The village communities used the established traditional method of storing in grain bins and polished bamboo baskets once the grains were dried on bamboo mats, plastered with cow dung. On an average 1 basket holds 4-5 quintals of grain which can be kept for one year.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Bhubaneswar Office, ND-8, V.I.P Area, Nayapalli, Bhubaneswar - 751015
Adaptations.executing_agent: NGO:Agragamee
Adaptations.success_factors: record keeping, training for the management committee, transparency and continuity, high rates of return of grain, active participation of village committee members, low interest rates
Adaptations.limiting_factors: non participation, high rate of default, lack of proper storage
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: No-regret: it provides a safety net even if climate change does not occur
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The extensive coverage of this programme over the two blocks in Rayagada and Koraput districts, helped establish grain banks in 700 villages, with wholehearted support from the community. Out of this, grain banks in 500 villages are functioning successfully, and have made substantial contributions in helping the tribal community climb out of the debt trap. Agragamee’s model of grain bank has gained wide recognization and is being taken up for replication by Government as well as other development agencies.
Adaptations.comments: A good practice case is that of Hailiasahi a hamlet of Mandibisi village. Each family here was bonded to the local zamindar (landlord), or the brahmins (priests) of the village. The terms of bondage were inhuman and compelling. The 16 tribal families in this hamlet could not even claim ownership over their homestead land. Agragamee intervened, in 1982, in this village to help the members access the government programme of rehabilitation of bonded labourers, along with providing them employment for a short period.The village continued saving in the grain bank. Now, the hamlet of Haliasahi is able to dictate terms to the villagers of Mandibist with a substantial savings of more that 100 quintals of grain in their bank. They now have a surplus, which they also lend to other tribal villages.

Adaptations.title: Economics of Adaptation to Climate Change
Adaptations.description:
"The project is part of a larger transnational project named Economics of Adaptation to Climate Change (EACC) which comprising 6 countries (Bangladesh, Bolivia, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mozambique and Vietnam). The goal of the EACC project is to develop cost estimates for adaptation responses based on climate simulations of future impacts combined with sectorial analysis of agriculture, water, fisheries, and forests, among others, which aim at identifying social vulnerability and adaptive capacity in particularly climate-impacted geographic regions and among particularly vulnerable.
The project’s main objectives: 
- To identify key socioeconomic and biophysical zones and develop a typology and livelihood profile of areas and communities that are climate vulnerable in Vietnam.
- To assess the policy and institutional framework for adaptation – at the national, regional and local levels – through interactions with policy makers and other stakeholders in Vietnam.
- To classify different types of local social vulnerability to climate change through targeted fieldwork in selected vulnerable areas of the country from which livelihood typologies are developed. 
- To work with local affected communities, policy makers, scientists, and other interested stakeholders to develop participatory scenarios of adaptation pathways that might be chosen in the future.
- To produce data, analysis, and advice for the overall EACC study on where the social assessment can help clarify questions of vulnerability, adaptation, and economic costs."
Adaptations.contact_adress: 1818 H Street, NW Washington, DC 20433, U.S.A
Adaptations.executing_agent: The World Bank Team in cooperation with The Center for Natural Resources and Environmental Studies, Challenge to Change and Dragon Institute
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"- Community awareness of climate change is low. Therefore, to implement the recommendations that make sure the report is limited.
- The information and data used to analysis is limited."
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "- Identified impacts of climate change and vulnerability and adaptation options - Identified key socioeconomic and biophysical zones of vulnerability to climate change, and typologies of livelihood profiles of areas and communities that are climate vulnerable - Assessed the policy and and institutional framework for adaptation at the national, regional, and local levels Vietnam, through analyzing the “National Target Program respond to Climate Change ” issued by Government in 2008. - Assessed local existing and potential adaptation options and measures - Organized Participatory Scenario Development (PSD) workshops to identify and categorize adaptation pathways suitable for different livelihood groups. - Provided recommendations on: i/ Respond to direct and indirect impacts of climate change (disaster needed to transition to long-term adaptation, developing the warming system and weather forecast as well as incorporation in economic and social planning), ii/ Social risk management asset development and social protection (livelihood resilience, safety net programs, strategies for adaptation plans); iii/ Policy design and implementation (Role of government, overlapping mandates, climate change adaptation mainstreamed into plans, investment needed) "
Adaptations.comments: The project has four components: - Climate projections and assessment of exposure, climate sensitivity, and potential impact through use of forecasted climate models - Assessment of adaptive capacity, adaptation deficit, and mal adaptation through study of past climate adaptation - Estimation of the costs of future adaptations that will be necessary - National assessment of adaptation to climate change The methodologies used were: - Community Risk Mapping - Focus groups to gather information regarding climate hazards, impacts, and adaptation practices and to address the role of community formation and group identity on adaptation choices, the teams conducted targeted focus groups. - Key stakeholder interviews.

Adaptations.title: Asian Cities Climate Change Resilience Network (ACCCRN) in Viet Nam
Adaptations.description:
"The project is part of a larger transnational project named Asian Cities Climate Change Resilience Network (ACCCRN) which comprising 4 countries (India, Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam). Three cities has been selected in Vietnam are Da Nang, Can Tho and Quy Nhon. The goal of project is to develop collaborative action plans for adaptation to climate change to benefit poor and vulnerable residents, which is build capacity for city governments, city-level organizations to enable them to reduce climate vulnerability, and to prepare funding proposals for donor support to adaptation plans. In each city, the project will working with city technical Agencies to help the integration of climate change issues into their planning and to raise awareness of future climate impacts and to build up capacity and responses of local organizations.
It is composed four phase:
1/. City scoping and selection
2/. City – level engagement and capacity development
3/. Implementation of effective urban resilience building projects
4/. Replication"
Adaptations.contact_adress: No 38, Ngo Quyen St, Ha Noi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.executing_agent: Institute for Social and Environmental Transition (U.S.A), National Institute for Science and Technology Policy and Strategy Studies, Challenge to Change
Adaptations.success_factors:
"- The response of the people involved and the local government
- The project must be in line with the strategic directions of “National Target Program to Respond to Climate Change” and “National Strategy for Natural Disaster Prevention, Response and Mitigation to 2020” which issued by Government."
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"- The awareness of staff in the local organizations on the impacts of climate change is low.
- Lack of information sharing and management across sectors"
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is under running.
-The expected results are:
+ The report of “Responding to urban Climate change” to be edited and published 
+ Organize training courses on building design climate change adaptation plan for the cities ACCCRN member.
+ Support planting mangrove forest in Thi Nai Lagoon, Quy Nhon.
+ Organized National Workshop is to training and introduction to the principles, methods, tools and planning processes to adapt to climate change for focal point staff in each city."
Adaptations.comments: "- The most vulnerable populations in the ACCCRN cities are: Recent migrants who lack residential registration; At-risk communities in coastal or floodplain sites that are resettle to new locations; Women, children, parents, and poor. - A combination of methods and tools centered on Shared Learning Dialogues and climate vulnerability analyses that they have adapted to their specific city contexts to use in the project. - A climate change scenario carried out by Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) will be used to this project. "

Adaptations.title: Mangrove plantation, Joint Forest Management and Revenue Sharing in Sundarban Reserve Forest
Adaptations.description: The Forest Department undertakes Mangrove plantation in the reserve forest of the Sundarban Biosphere Reserve (SBR). The Mangroves are extremely important to the coastal ecosytstem as they act as soil binders and diffuse impacts of storms. They are a natural habitat for fish, prawns etc and support the fish and shrimp economy and are also habitat for the Royal Bengal Tiger and important for the biodiversity of the region. The WB Forest Department has issued Govt. Orders for formation of Forest Protection Committees (FPC) around the Reserved/ Protected Forests, and Eco-Development Committees (EDC) around the National Park and Sanctuaries of Sundarban region also. Till now, 52 FPCs and 14 EDCs have been registered. They get a 25% share of the entry fee receipts (Rs 10/day per person) from visitors to the SBR. After formation of FPCs/EDCs instances of felling, poaching, have reduced and tiger survival after village visits has increased. The user groups are involved in some of these plantations as well.
Adaptations.contact_person: P. Vyas, Director, Sundarban Biosphere Reserve, West Bengal
Adaptations.contact_adress: Directorate of Forests
Adaptations.executing_agent: community, Forest Department
Adaptations.success_factors: survival rate, suitable species, community support and involvement
Adaptations.limiting_factors: inundation
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The FD does 1000 ha of plantations each year. Since 1989, 15000 ha of mangroves have been planted.
Adaptations.comments: The FD has promoted rainwater harvesting in the FPC villlages. Channels have been redug. There is need for long-term modelling of the bio-physical processes in the sundarbans that includes subsidence due to tectonic plate subsiding, accretion, dredging and deposited silt and hydrological processes in the delta.

Adaptations.query: South West region of West Bengal, India
Adaptations.title: Five Percent Technique - On farm pond using five percent of the field area to store run off water
Adaptations.description: Five percent technology is a risk reducing technique implemented on farm where a pit covering 5% of the total area of a field is dug at the most upstream spot of the plot, to store water for protective irrigation of crops during the dry season. These pits collect runoff water and store it for use during dry spells. These pits are usually about 1.5 meters deep and water is manually lifted and applied to fields. Five percent is the minimum area for supplying the required irrigation to upland paddy during its critical growth periods immediately after monsoon. Farmers can make bigger or deeper pits depending on land availability and soil type. This technique is promoted by an NGO Professional Assistance for Development Action (PRADAN) and its local partners especially in the dry South West Bengal region.
Adaptations.contact_adress: PRADAN, Lal Mohan Trivedi Lane, Nilkuthi Danga, Purulia – 723 101,West Bengal
Adaptations.executing_agent: PRADAN
Adaptations.success_factors: availability of 5% area, willingness of the farmer
Adaptations.limiting_factors: scattered landholding
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win: it is an effective and low cost strategy for assured irrigation especially during dry season
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The cost of treatment for making a farm pond is around Rs 25,000 per ha and can be financed through the NREG scheme. It can save rain fed crops during low rainfall periods and improve productivity of barren uplands.

Adaptations.title: Community Resilience with Natural Disaster in Mekong Delta
Adaptations.description:
"Project goal is to empower flood-prone communities in the Mekong to reduce the impact of natural disasters and secure and enhance their livelihoods. 
Main project’s objective is to build sustainable community and household resilience to floods in highly flood-prone, inland areas of the Mekong Delta by reducing the vulnerability to flooding of household and communes in Long An, Dong Thap and An Giang provinces.
In the past two decades flooding in the Mekong that impacts by climate change has become unpredictable, increasing in frequency, duration and intensity. The three targeted provinces suffer the most frequent and persistent flooding in the Mekong. In 2002, large-scale flooding lead to the death of 163 people, destruction of houses and the spread of water-related diseases.
Project has three main components:
1. Community-based disaster management: Facilitating changes in the way communities prepare for, adaptation, respond to and recover from disasters implemented at both village and commune level.
2. Institutional capacity building: Building the capacity of CARE’s implementing partner Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) by raising the understanding of and skills to apply participatory approaches and methodologies as well as adaptation and preparedness measures amongst DARD members.
3. Livelihood diversification and alternative income generation: Assisting poor and marginalized individuals and families in diversifying their income sources during non-disaster periods as well as securing alternative income generation opportunities in times of disaster."
Adaptations.contact_person: Ms. Phan Tran Hong Tham, Project Coordinator, CARE Vietnam
Adaptations.contact_adress: 18A, Nguyen Du Street, My Binh , Long Xuyen City, An Giang province
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Australian Agency for International Development (AusAid) and Provincial People’s Committees of An Giang, Long An, Dong Thap
Adaptations.executing_agent: CARE in collaboration with The Departments of Agriculture and Rural Development of An Giang, Long An, Dong Thap Provinces.
Adaptations.success_factors:
"-Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
- In line with Governmental Strategy for Natural Disaster Prevention, Response and Mitigation."
Adaptations.limiting_factors:
"- The lack of financial resources in the practices of disaster preparedness.
-The lack of public awareness on climate change issues."
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win:
"- Yes, empowerment of the communities through training and awareness raising on DRR and income generation.
- Socio-economic development, environment conservation."
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is under implementing, the main expected outcomes are:
-19,000 households (HHS) benefit from improved village or commune-wide preparedness, adaptation or response infrastructure or services. 
-3,800 HHS benefit from improved household physical assets (home, boats etc.) through sub-grants or relief assistance.
-3,250 HHS benefit from employment in newly-established or expanded businesses within project-targeted sub-sectors.
-3,900 HHS benefit from training in more efficient agriculture or other technical areas for self-employment.
-6,500 HHS benefit from using newly-introduced financial products provided by People’s Credit Funds that assist to smooth income and expenditure flows.
-Integration of Disaster Risk Reduction into the social-economic development plan at province, district, village, commune level.
-HHS have a high sense on disaster preparedness and mitigation:
(i) 88 –92% HHSs of 3 provinces having high awareness of living in disaster areas. (ii) Number of drowning’s & house damage strongly reduced. (iii) Better income for poor households in the flood seasons.
The initial results of the project is that there was no reported damages houses as well as no death recorded in the last couple of years."
Adaptations.comments: "-The project carry out in twelve communes in six districts of Long An, Dong Thap and An Giang provinces. - In each village, a Village Development Group (VDG) is established VDGs take a leading role in designing, implementing the Village Development Plan (VDP), monitoring and evaluation. The activities of VDP focus on three following sectors: (i) disaster risk reduction (DRR); (ii) capacity building for households in DRR; (iii) Income generation/ livelihood activities for households. -Community Participatory Planning Approach is adopted and highly appreciated by villagers and local authorities due to its relevance, effectiveness and positive impacts on the community. "

Adaptations.title: Conservation and development of local grape-fruit varieties in the flooding area of Day River
Adaptations.description:
"At Red River Delta of Vietnam, Day River originates from Red River and flows to Tonkin Gulf. Day River has been for flood diversion as part of flood control in Red River Delta. Frequent floods diverted to Day River have greatly affected the way the local residents live and produce agricultural products including the effect to grapefruit production – one of the main incomes of Day River (Hoai Duc district) community.
The project aims to contribute to conserving and improving agricultural biodiversity as a coping strategy to climate change scenario at Red River Delta through developing models for conserving and developing grapefruit varieties which have advantages of fast fruits maturity, good commercial quality, and being high resistant to the flood-prone conditions in Day river, Hoai Duc district. 
The main objective is (i) To identify negative impacts of climate change on grapefruit genetic biodiversity at the flood-diverted area of Day River. (ii) To assess and select the best grapefruit variety with desirable characteristics including high rate of fruit maturation, high commercial quality, resistance to flood, drought and diseases for commercial production. (iii) To develop demonstration models for selected grapefruit variety with suitable cultivation techniques.(iv) To enhance the local residents’ awareness about the impact of climate change and adaptation on agricultural production of Red River Delta.
The major activities are:
- Surveys and collection of weather data from Ha Noi Meteological station during the last 10 years
- Organize participatory discussion and workshops on impacts of climate change
- Survey (interviewing local people) to decide the suitable grapefruit varieties for selection for use
- Selecting the best varieties with participation of various stakeholders (experts, producers, consumers, local officers and households)
- Tag the lead grapefruit tree and map the grapefruit gene pool as basis for future conservation and multiplication
- Provide technical and financial funding to households participating in conserving the selected varieties
- Develop 2 nursing sites (100 m2 each) to multiply grapefruits
- Rapid multiplication of Que Duong grapefruit variety using VietGap-oriented techniques
- Develop models on Que Duong grapefruit plantations using 2 varieties for commecial production purpose
- Training on market access for participating households.
- Document traditional knowledge to produce a publication on techniques on nursing and cultivation of Que Duong grapefruit varieties "
Adaptations.contact_person: Nguyen Thi Kim Anh, Project Coordinator, UNDP Hanoi
Adaptations.contact_adress: 25-29 Phan Boi Chau Street, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Adaptations.executing_agent: SGP VIET NAM and Farmers Union of Hoai Duc District
Adaptations.success_factors: -Active participation of communities and local government.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: not specified
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"The project is under implementing.
Expected major outputs:
-A report on the extreme weathers (temperature, rainfall, flooding, and drought) on degree and distribution of grapefruit genetic biodiversity at the project target site to be produced.
- Grapefruit varieties with desirable qualifications to be selected and multiplied
- A model for community conservation of grapefruit genetic biodiversity at Cat Que Commune of Hoai Duc District at 5-7 genes and 100 individuals/gene to be developed 
- A model for conservation of selected grapefruit variety with suitable cultivation techniques to be developed for commercial production purpose: 50 households will participate with land area involved 300-360 m2/household
-Advocacy activities on threats of climate change on biodiversity to be successfully organized. 
-Develop 2 nursing sites (100 m2 each) to multiply grapefruits
- Participatory discussions and workshops on impacts of climate change and adaptation measures and training on market access for participating households to be organized."
Adaptations.comments: -The project is designed and implemented by testing demonstration model of community conservation of grapefruit genetic biodiversity and suitable cultivation techniques for commercial production purpose. -Local farmers’ experiences in coping with flooding to be fully applied in the models. -Public awareness raising activities will be conducted widely in the whole commune.

Adaptations.query: São Sebastião do Paraíso, Minas Gerais, Brazil
Adaptations.title: Integrated farming of coffee plants for adaptation and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions
Adaptations.description: "The coffee tree is one of the most important and traditional activites in the Brazilian agriculture. And might be appreciably affected by the climate changes, mainly with the temperature increase.There are already some researches that show promising techniques to minimize the climatic extreme effect, such as coffee crop grown shaded. Besides the adaptation of coffee crop in warmer environments using management techniques, some agroforestal systems are being adopted for carbon mitigation. The aim of the present study is (i) evaluate the potencial of shade coffee crop using different fruit trees and forestry in order to decrease the temperature in the full sun coffee crop, promoting the coffee adaptation in climate change effects; (ii) quantify the carbon balance in the system soil-plant-atmospher to assess the potencial for carbon sequestration in different shading system; (iii) evaluate the biomass production through of the more advanced remote sensing methods."
Adaptations.contact_adress: "Cidade Universitária ""Zeferino Vaz"", Campinas, Brazil"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Cepagri/Unicamp and Embrapa
Adaptations.funding_source: Brazilian Coffee Research and Development Consortium/Embrapa Coffee
Adaptations.success_factors: A critical factor for the success of this project is a temperature. If the temperature during the experiment does not reach at least 32 degrees Celsius is not possible to observe a difference between the experiment.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The limiting factors of the project are the samples used to quantify the carbon stock, since that is necessary destroy a great number of coffee tree.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: This project besides promotes the coffee adaptation in climate change effects, it also mitigates the greenhouse gases emissions by carbon sequestration
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: This project is another positive side effect that is related to social development, since there is no migration of the crop due to climate change and adaptation practices can add value to coffee.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: So far, it is possible to observe an increase of biomass in shaded coffee
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Dear Hilton, thank you very much for your contribution to our platform! The projects fits the database perfectly, it will be moved to the open database. We only have some minor suggestions to improve the content for the database. Since the focus of the platform is on adaptation, we would suggest renaming the project to something like ‘Adaptation of coffee crops to climate change through increased shading’. It would also be great to have some more information in the ‘Evaluative Information’ part. Anything that gives more insight into challenges you have encountered or a general evaluation of whether the projects seems to be a success would be great. You can go back to your project at any time to add or edit information, also after it has been moved to the database. Thanks again and also Jürgen Kropp sends his regards!

Adaptations.title: Climate Adaptation Centre
Adaptations.description: WWF India in collaboration with other WWF Netherlands, Hewlett Packard and GTZ recently inaugurated a Climate Adaptation Centre on the Sundarban island, which aims to help Mousuni villagers better handle climate change by providing integral services such as an electronic early warning system, disaster preparedness kits, knowledge, resources and skills for adapting to climate impacts and educational materials for students. Disaster Management Teams and 6 task forces within each team have been made and trained within the 4 Mouzas in Mousuni. The task forces comprise of the early warning team, evacuation and rescue team, primary health team, water and sanitation team, disaster relief management team and advisory team. The leaders for each of the team are selected unanimously by the other members and in the event of any disaster the leaders of the early warning team hear the warning on the radio or receive an sms and inform the rest. The Climate Adaptation Centre provides rice seeds to the farmers and also holds information about the various varieties of rice, their market values and benefits of government schemes and programmes.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 172 B, Lodhi Estate,New Delhi- 110003
Adaptations.executing_agent: WWF India, Netherlands, HP and GTZ
Adaptations.success_factors: reliability of early warning information, dissemination of climate information, forming disaster mangement groups
Adaptations.limiting_factors: reduced coping capacity, delayed weather information, warning in vernacular language, low uptake for climate proofing activities
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win (Apparatus for early warning and agro met services is essential for vulnerable regions such as the Sundarbans)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The centre has only been set up last year so impacts are not visible yet. However, other adaptation strategies introduced by WWF have included the re-introduction of indigenous salt-tolerant rice plants to farmers on the island. Information on adaptation seems to be reaching the people as is evident from the fact that now almost 40 farmers use salt-tolerant paddy in Mousuni Island since last year when the centre had started. As the market value of this variety (tal mugur) is not far behind other high-yielding varieties, farmers on the island have been successful in maintaining their livelihoods without having to worry about losing crops to salt water incursion. Also, the number of volunteers in disaster response teams has significantly gone up. At present a community elected institution runs the centre with support from WWF.
Adaptations.comments: The early warning system has been linked to Jadavpur University in Kolkata and will receive messages whenever there is an oncoming disaster. The Centre also houses relief material such as stretchers, torches and medical aid.
