Adaptations.title: Hydrological Mangrove Rehabilitation
Adaptations.description:
"The work in this region began in 2002, creating a mangrove atlas with partners which first proposed community based mangrove management areas in the Jangkang and Kembung rivers. Natural hydrology was restored in the area as four tidal creeks reconnected to their inland freshwater sources and raised mounds of Acrostichum aureum. Ten of the 36.5 hectares were planted while the remaining two thirds of the area were left unplanted in order to compare growth rates between reforested seedlings and natural re vegetation. Future monitoring of the restoration is being carried out by MAP-Indonesia, Yayasan Laksana Samudera, University of Riau and the local community.
An illustrated manual delineating the process of hydrological mangrove rehabilitation was produced as part of the project."
Adaptations.contact_adress: P.O. Box 1854, Port Angeles, WA 98362
Adaptations.executing_agent: MAP-Indonesia, Yayasan Laksana Samudera, University of Riau and the local community
Adaptations.success_factors: It’s very important to pick the right varieties, the right species and also to involve the communities in the plantations and the maintenance and the management of the plantations.
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Yes, Mangrove forests act as extremely effective carbon sinks, able to absorb 97.57 tons of carbon per hectare, or more than three times the absorptive capacity of non-mangrove forests.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Win-Win option.
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: In 2006 MAP completed mangrove rehabilitation projects with three community groups, totaling an area of around 80 hectares.
Adaptations.comments: MAP is unique in that it acts as a sort of megaphone, amplifying the voice of the coastal fishers in matters of relevance and importance to their lives. MAP also acts as a vital foot bridge or link between the global North and South on issues of over-consumption, deforestation, marine conservation, and human rights, as well as addressing such present day crises as climate change and sea level rise.

Adaptations.title: Adaptation measures as part of the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA) and Scheme
Adaptations.description:
"“The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA) is an Indian job guarantee scheme, that came into effect on February 2, 2006 in 200 of India’s most backward districts. However, from April 1, 2008 the Act covers all of rural India. It provides a legal guarantee of 100 days of wage employment in a financial year to every rural household whose adult members volunteer to do unskilled manual work at the minimum wage rate notified for agricultural labour prescribed in the state or else an unemployment allowance. The main objective of the Act is to supplement wage employment opportunities in rural areas. 
Some of the key features of the Act are : 
-100 days of employment to a local rural household if it demands it and is willing to do unskilled manual work 
-A Job Card is necessary for demanding employment under NREGA. 
-A written application by a Job Card holding family to the Gram Panchayat or Programme Officer is necessary for demanding employment 
-All adult members whose names are on the Job Card can apply for employment. The entitlement of 100 days of employment in a financial year is for a household as an aggregate. 
Creation of durable assets and strengthening the livelihood resource base of the rural poor is one of the main objectives of the Scheme. The permissible works under this Scheme are: 
-Water Conservation 
-Drought proofing (including plantation and afforestation)
-Flood control and protection works including drainage in water logged areas
-Land development
-Minor irrigation, horticulture and land development on the land of SC / ST / BPL / Indira Awas Yojana and land reform beneficiaries. 
-Rural connectivity to provide all-weather access 
The most important aspect of this Scheme is ensuring that there are a sufficient number of works that are available to respond to the demand for employment within 15 days of demand. The role of Gram Sabha and Gram Panchayat in the planning process is that the Gram Sabha should identify and recommend works and the Gram Panchayat should consolidate and send the recommendations of Gram Sabha to the Programme Officer. The Central government outlay for scheme is 401 billion or Rs. 40,100 crores in FY 2010-11. """
Adaptations.contact_person: Ms. Amita Sharma, Joint Secretary ,Ministry of Rural Development, Govt. of India
Adaptations.contact_adress: Krishi Bhavan, Dr Rajendra Prasad Road, New Delhi 110001
Adaptations.initiating_agent: National and State Govt.: Rural development
Adaptations.executing_agent: Panchayats
Adaptations.success_factors: transparency of gram panchayats, regular disbursement of wages, social audit
Adaptations.limiting_factors: corruption in releasing funds, elite capture and exclusion of weaker communities,only employment focus, activities not implemented according to a plan, spatially or time-wise, disconnected and scattered implementation of activities which may require broad scale planning
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win (ensures employment despite climate change impacts)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"National:NREGA commenced on February 2, 2006 in 200 districts, was expanded to cover another 130 districts in 2007-2008 and eventually covered all 593 districts in India by April 1, 2008. The outlay was Rs. 110 billion in 2006-2007, and rose steeply to Rs. 391 billion (140% increase in amount with respect to previous 2008-2009 budget) in 2009-2010. As of 30th June,2010 a total of 179,43,189 families in the country have been provided employment under MGNREGS. A specific study carried out in selected villages in Chitradurga district, Karnataka to examine the impact of the NREGA activities from the perspective of providing environmental services and reducing the vulnerability show :
• increased ground water recharge,
• increased water percolation,
• enhanced water storage in tanks,
• increase in soil fertility,
• reclamation of degraded lands and
• carbon sequestration.
2. These NREGA activities and the resulting environmental services contributed to increased crop and livestock production.
3. There was no example of any significant scale negative impacts from any of the NREGA activities implemented.
4. NREGA activities also reduced the vulnerability of crop production, water availability and livelihoods to uncertain and low rainfall, low water availability and poor soil fertility.
5. The field studies in Chitradurga have clearly demonstrated the potential of NREGA activities to provide environmental services as well as to reduce vulnerability, despite the short period of only 1 to 3 years to deliver the services. Longer period of 5-10 years is needed to realize the full environmental services or vulnerability reduction potential, due to the gestation period involved (e.g., ground water recharge, soil fertility improvement and forest growth).
6. NREGA activities were not implemented in the villages according to any micro-plan or watershed plan or in any sequential manner. Despite this limitation, many NREGA activities have the potential to provide guaranteed benefits. Examples of such activities for Chitradurga district are:
• Desilting of water bodies accompanied by silt removal and application to crop fields
• Land development leading to land leveling and cropping
• Afforestation (as a drought proofing activity) with appropriate species choice
• Construction of percolation tanks."
Adaptations.comments: "Several impact assessment studies have been carried out on NREGA. (1) Independent surveys by economists such as Jean Dreze, found that NREGA workers had to put up with numerous infringements of their rights without being able to do much about it: lack of work, delays in wage payment, non-payment of minimum wages, absence of worksite facilities, were common. Most of these irregularities remain unaddressed, often even unnoticed. The persistence of corruption is another aspect of this lack of accountability. Three related problems that have contributed to this state of affairs are: confusion about the operational requirements of the Act; absence of any grievance redress system; and lack of independent monitoring. (2) Winrock India carried out a study of district level convergence between MG-NREGS & ongoing schemes of different Departments/ Ministries to ensure effective convergence for durable asset creation and promote strengthening of the livelihood resource base of the rural poor in the districts of Betul and Sehore in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh in India. It was found that at the district level, convergence is primarily limited to the planning stage itself, with elaborate discussions at the district level meetings amongst the concerned departments. Meanwhile, with inputs from the project team of Winrock, a few plans were developed in the two pilot districts for convergence between MG-NREGS and some line departments’ schemes such as those of Water Resource Department, Forest Department, Agriculture/Horticulture Department through involvement of KVKs for training & extension activities, Sports Department and Fisheries Department. (3) Another impact assessment was carried out by the Professional Institutional Networking (PIN) of Ministry of Rural Development, sanctioned by United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in the three districts namely Sirsa in Haryana, Sirmaur in Himachal Pradesh and Hoshiarpur in Punjab. Some of the main findings main findings of Panchayat perception, worksite verification, workers and non workers assessment of NREGS are: Role of Gram Panchayats is becoming extremely crucial in planning and implementation of the rural development scheme. Elected Panchayats in districts of Sirsa and Sirmaur reported that they received training, whereas only one fifth of the Panchayats in Hoshiarpur district received training on NREGA. Regarding the Panchayati Awareness about Measurement Book (MB), it was seen that Panchayats awareness with regard to measurement Book among Panchayat members is very good in Sirsa as compared to Hoshiarpur and Sirmaur District GPs. On the impact of NREGA on employment genaration, all the Panchayats reported that economic condition of the wage earners has improved and moreover the workers need not to go outside the village to seek work. The common problem areas quoted were: lack of Proper trained staff, delay in receiving funds and lack of awareness on different aspect of NREGA guidelines and convergence with other department etc."

Adaptations.title: Documentation of traditional knowledge about early warning indicators for weather change
Adaptations.description: This is a documentation of the traditional knowledge and practices in the state of Rajasthan. The proverbs and sayings have been recorded as told by the vilage communities. These traditional practices rely heavily on repeated observation of nature and natural processes and surroundings and help predict future trends and events, some of which could be threats. These warnings range from changes about the weather conditions, cloud movement, wind direction and speed, activities of animals and birds and any specific changes occurring in the development of plants. These practices can be used by the communities to rely on their own indigenous warning system about the changing weather and thus reduce the heavy losses that are incurred due to unexpected weather changes.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Co-Director, CECOEDECON, F 159-160, Industrial Area, Sitapura, Jaipur, Rajasthan
Adaptations.source: CECOEDECON, Kahanwanta main chupiyo Mausam ro gyan (The knowledge and information about weather in hidded in proverbial sayings)
Adaptations.executing_agent: CECOEDECON
Adaptations.success_factors: strong belief in traditional practices amongst communities, experiences of the elderly members of the community, realisation of threats posed by weather and climate change
Adaptations.limiting_factors: negative experiences of the older generation, disregard and lack of belief for traditional knowledge and practices. Actual change in weather patterns due to climate change may actually make some of the saying redundant ?
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win (social welfare, revival of traditional knowledge systems, warnings can be used to reduce damages or avert them completely)
Adaptations.comments: The book contains several sayings a few of them are (a) Rains seldom come if the friuts on the neem tree (Azadirachta indica) do not ripen and fall to the ground, (b) there is no produce if the ripened fruits of the neem (Indian lilac) tree remain attached to the tree branches, (c) chances of rain reduce if the clouds have a yellowish tinge in the evening, (d) good rains can be expected in the year when a higher number of black spiders are observed, (e) clouds that have the shape of francolins (teetar) feathers give rains, (f) It is believed that if rains in December occur only for half the time then the crop production is also reduced to half, (g) Transplanting time for barley and wheat is right when the germinated plant is yellow in colour and not green and (h) Storms or hot summer winds starting from the Northern direction is considered a good sign and give a good crop, etc.

Adaptations.title: The Livelihoods Improvement Program for Himalayas-Meghalaya
Adaptations.description: The main project objectives are to assess the impacts of climate change and socioeconomic changes on the poor in mountain areas of HKH region and to identify adaptation/coping mechanisms. In Meghalaya – the project measures includes trainings, worshops, group formation, farm activities including agriculture (integrated jhum development, SRI), horticulture (oranges, pineapple, banana, turmeric) soil and water resources (afforestation,) livestock and aquaculture and forestry development (NRM, NTFP). Non-farm activities include value addition, processing, marketing, transportation, marketing and energy sector. The project also focusses on rural finance, entrepreneurship development, policy studies and advocacy, etc. This helps in empowerment and capacity building of communities, livelihood diversification, soil and water conservation. The project is implemented in five districts, 570 villages and 29,300 villages in the state of Meghalaya.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Meghalaya Rural Developement Society, [Livelihoods Improvement Project for the Himalayas], Project Management Unit, Lower Cleve Colony, Near Directorate of Agriculture Office, Shillong, 73003
Adaptations.source: (1) ICIMOD http://www.icimod.org/?page=1038, (2) Meghalaya Development Society: http://mrds.nic.in/
Adaptations.executing_agent: Meghalaya Development Society (MRDS)
Adaptations.funding_source: IFAD, Institutional finance, beneficiary component, state government contribution
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional support
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win (addresses climate change challenges directly, provides social benefits, economic benefits)
Adaptations.comments: "These projects come under the second phase of ""Programme for Securing Livelihood in Uplands and Mountains of the Hindu-Kush Himalayas"" Compare with http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/559 "

Adaptations.title: Ajeevika - Livelihoods Improvement Project for the Himalayas
Adaptations.description: The overall project objectives are to assess the impacts of climate change and socioeconomic changes on the poor in mountain areas of Hindu Kush Himalaya region, identify adaptation/coping mechanisms and enhance livelihood opportunities. The project is targeted at mountain communities (poor households and women) living in the western and eastern Himalayas. In the state of Uttaranchal the project aims to enhance livelihood opportunities, access required financial resources, manage new technology and institutions, establish non-farm enterprises, increase income through more sustainable cultivation systems.The project works by supporting local entrepreneurship and SHGs and demonstrations covering diverse activities related to agriculture, horticulture, livestock, forestry, soil and water conservation and ecotourism. The project is expected to have the following results: promote approximately 2846 community institutions, capacity building of target population with special emphasis on women and landless labourers, effective savings and credit operation with SHGs, business plan development for establishing enterprise and identification of policy issues affecting livelihoods of poor. The project has set up a company to support small entrepreneurs and help access and interface with financial and credit systems.
Adaptations.contact_adress: 272 C, Vasant Vihar, Phase II, Dehradun, Uttarakhand
Adaptations.executing_agent: Uttarakhand Gramya Vikas Samiti
Adaptations.funding_source: IFAD, Institutional finance, beneficiary component, state government contribution
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional support
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win (addresses climate change challenges directly, provides social benefits, economic benefits)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Visit by IFAD Supervision Mission in May 2007 suggested various action points for streamlining the Project Logframe and M&E manual. The reporting framework of the PMU has been simplified participatorily and the types of reports to be generated have been identified.
Adaptations.comments: For the Ajeevika, Uttaranchal Livelihoods Improvement Project for the Himalayas (ULIPH) the Project staff have been trained on Monitoring & Evaluation. Focus on increased self-monitoring by SHG in project interventions has been initiated.

Adaptations.title: Land and Water Management leading towards Biodiversity Conservation
Adaptations.description: The purpose of the project was to encourage biodiversity conservation and enhancement practices by the community, through land and water management including the restoration of deteriorated ponds by deepening and widening and strengthening embankments, revitalisation of degraded lands by plantations and protection to reduce erosion and sedimentation in the ponds and protection of endangered species of trees including in local community conserved sacred groves (devra) and community groves (banni). It involved formation of an Environment Action Committee (EAC) for effective implementation of the project activities with pro-active participation of women members. This resulted in an increase in water availability by increasing ground water recharge, better availability of fuel and fodder, community awareness, traditional knowledge transfer, increased involvement of government personnel in community based projects.
Adaptations.contact_adress: CUTS-CHD (Consumer Unity and Trust Society-Centre for Human Development), Bani Park, Jaipur
Adaptations.executing_agent: CUTS-CHD
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional, technical (liasioning between various departments for technical assistance, for effective implementation of project (management), to carry out project activities (structural))
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Institutional (intensive support for local institutions)
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Carbon sequestration (plantations to check soil erosion)
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win (Besides the major objective of conserving biodiversity the project has resulted in an increased availability of watre for the community, economic benefits have been accrued by employment generation. It has increased awareness in the community about sustainable use and conservation of natural resources)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Baseline survey was done prior to project initiation and an impact assessment study was carried out after the end of the project activities. Renovation of two deteriorated ponds for rainwater harvesting has resulted in increasing water holding capacity.
Adaptations.comments: To control soil erosion plantations were carried out,technical assistance for this project came from different departments that is irrigation, civil, ground water, soil conservation, watershed and agricultur engineers and geology, forestry, agriculture, horticulture and animal husbandry.

Adaptations.query: Districts of Panchkula, Yamunanagra, Ambala, Kurukshetra, Sirsa, Fatehabad, Hisar, Bhiwani, Mahendragargd and Rewari, Haryana
Adaptations.title: Haryana Community Forestry Project
Adaptations.description: The Haryana Community Forestry Project aimed to build the capacity of rural communities to improve the natural environment and maintain land fertility through sustainable management of natural resources. It supported formation of village organisations (Village Resource Management Committees-VRMCs, Hill Resource Management Societies-HRMS, Farm Forestry Associations-FFA), rehabilitation of sand dune and wind erosion affected areas, wastelands and community lands. In addition, the project facilitated poplar plantations, multi-species agroforestry introduction, improved kitchen gardens, alternative energy efficient cooking stoves and generation of income by micro-enterprise development. The project also focuses on soil and water conservation measures and nineteen water harvesting structures have been built, in drier regions johads (traditional water bodies) have been renovated to capture runoff. The project was implemented in 338 villages in Haryana.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Forest Department Haryana, C-18, Van Bhawan, Sector 6, Panchkula,
Adaptations.executing_agent: Haryana Forest Department
Adaptations.success_factors: formation of and functional autonomy and support to village organisations, effective implementation of schemes by the forest department
Adaptations.limiting_factors: financial and technical input, long term protection is the key issue which requires sustained involvement of local institutions
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: carbon sequestration, reduction if fuel consumption lowering emissions
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win (increases economic benefits by livelihood diversification, social welfare, environmental benefits of soil and water conservation, sand dune fixation, reduced emissions, etc.)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: "The effectiveness of the project can be judged by the following factors; increased tree cover from 9% to 32% on common lands, 8338 ha of common lands under plantation, increase of trees on private lands has been 5.5 times, improved availability of fuelwood, 4.7 million paid workdays, stabilisation of shifting sand dunes, 108 self help groups formed in 101 villages, crop production has increased three times."
Adaptations.comments: Under the Kyoto Protocol Clean Development Mechanism (CDM), a project activity has been formulated, covering an area of 370 hectares in Sirsa district of the state, for submission to UNFCCC.

Adaptations.title: NREGA (Soil and Water Conservation)
Adaptations.description: The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MG-NREGA) provides a employment based safety net on demand in all rural districts of the country. The scheme operates by giving the families of the rural communties a job card that makes them eligible to work. Each rural family is eligible for a maximum of hundred days of wage employment, annually in their own panchayat. Under the scheme soil and water conservation works are carried out by the community including ditch-cum-bund fencing, staggered trenches, forest plantation and V-ditch construction. This work benefits the community by increasing water retention capacity, fodder availability and conserving soil. With frequent and extensive droughts – Rajasthan is a major utiliser of this program.
Adaptations.contact_person: Shri Ram Niwas Mehta, (Project Director, NREGA)
Adaptations.contact_adress: Rural Development Department, Secretariat, Jaipur, Rajasthan
Adaptations.source: "The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005; Conference proceedings (25th October, 2010) of MNREGA in the Rural Development and Panchayati Raj Department, Government of Rajasthan"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Rural Development and Panchayati Raj Department
Adaptations.funding_source: Government of India, some share from state government
Adaptations.success_factors: Institutional (For effective implementation of the scheme it is essential to have pre-established rules and guidelines (MNREGA, 2005))
Adaptations.limiting_factors: financial status of the rural community (If the village community is not poor and have a secure and sufficient flow of income they would not take up the work. )
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no-regret (It is a source of income for the people along with other benefits and would be helpful even in the absence of anthropogenic climate change impacts)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: A study conducted by Institute of Development Studies has evaluated NREGA in Rajasthan giving the following results and conclusion. There has been an increase in employment especially to women members of the society, reduced migration, reduced incidence of debt, improved environmental conditions, reduced erosion, increased agricultural production. In Jhalawar the water level increased upto 10-15%. The problems of administration at different levels, delayed payment of wages, lack of technical assistance for field work improvisation still exist. There is a need for regular monitoring of projects. People’s capacity for implementation of project has to be build up, greater responsibility to the panchayats with regard to fiscal disbursement of wages at the village level.
Adaptations.comments: According to the study conducted by Institute of Development Studies in the districts of Dungarpur, Jhalawar, Banswara, Jalore and Karauli majority of the schemes under NREGA were for drought proofing and water harvesting and thus only the soil and water conservation scheme has been focussed on in this description.

Adaptations.title: Sukhomajri - A case of forest and watershed protection in India
Adaptations.description: Sukhomajri is a village in the erosion prone Shivalik hills near Chandigarh in north Indian state of Haryana where there was a severe problem of erosion in the upstream catchment area leading to silting up of the downstream Sukhna Lake. In 1977 under the guidance of PR Mishra four tanks were built to conserve rainwater. This increased water storage and provided protective irrigation to the rainfed crops, increasing yields. This became an incentive to the villagers to stop grazing and initiate afforestation and watershed protection in the catchment, to reduce erosion and prevent sedimentation of their tanks. As many of the graziers did not own land and thus would not benefit directly from the water and increased yields, an innovative step was taken – of spliting water ownership from land ownership. The water stored was made the property of all villagers – equally shared by both land holders and landless, thus the landed bought water beyond their share from the landless folks. The project gave increased yields in agriculture, protected forest cover, and reduced erosion. The dam and catchment management was undertaken by Hill Resource Management Societies (HRMS) and HRMS were set up in scores of villages in the region.
Adaptations.source: (i) Kerr, J., 2002. Watershed Development, Environmental Services, and Poverty Alleviation in India. World Development. Vol 30, Issue 8, pp. 1387-1400. (ii) http://environmentportal.in/files/community.pdf (iii) http://www.watershedmarkets.org/
Adaptations.executing_agent: Local community members of the HRMS
Adaptations.success_factors: community involvement, public, private and community participation and interaction, technical support, benefits received by the community saving the resource, equitable sharing of resources (community involvement: The measure failed initially because of the lack of concern amongst the villagers about the water woes of the Chandigarh city, public, private and community participation and interaction: the integration amongst the three parties must be transparent and no individual or personal motives should exist that may hamper the sucess of the intervention, technical support: the intervention succeeded when technical expertise was provided by Mr. P.R. Mishra (environmentalist) to build tanks for increasing water storage, benefits received by the community saving the resource: the community recieved benefits in the form of increased water storage and increased yields which acted as an incentive for them to conserve the watershed.)
Adaptations.limiting_factors: The measure failed initially because of the lack of concern amongst the villagers about the water woes of the Chandigarh city.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win (environmental protection and conservation, resource availability, increased income, livelihood and food security, sustainable flow of environmental services)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: the following benefits were observed (i) savings of upto US$ 0.2 million each year in dredging and other costs to the government, (ii) increased water for irrigation leading to an increase in wheat (0.68 tonnes/ha to 1.43 tonnes/ha) and maize (0.61 tonnes/ha to 1.22 tonnes/ha) production from the year 1977 to 1986, (iii) the annual household incomes went up from Rs 2000 to Rs 3000 between 1979 to 1984, (iv) the village now earns Rs 3,50,000 and 10,000 from the sale of collective milk and bhabar grass respectively, (v) tree density increased from 13 to 1292 trees/ha between 1977 to 1986, (vi) the forest has over 0.3 million Khair trees (Acacia catechu), each tree valued at Rs 3000 (US$ 70)

Adaptations.title: Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM)
Adaptations.description:
"The ICZM’s development objective is to assist the Government of India in building national capacity for implementation of comprehensive coastal management approach in the country, and piloting the integrated coastal zone management approach in states of Gujarat, Orissa and West Bengal.The Project will help build the appropriate institutional arrangements, capacity and advanced knowledge systems needed to implement the national program. 
In West Bengal, the project will support capacity building of the state level agencies and institutions, preparation of an ICZM plan for the coastal sediment cell for the coastal region, and piloting of ICZM approaches include mangrove plantation. The pilot investments in West Bengal will complement the ICZM plan and the capacity building sub-components to address the major coastal zone management issues in the two targeted coastal stretches of (i) Digha-Shankarpur, and (ii) Sagar Island in the
Sundarban, covering about 13 percent of West Bengal’s coasts. The investments will include (a) conservation and protection of coastal resources including mangrove and coastal shelterbelt plantation; pilot works in shoreline protection for Digha beach and the southern end of Sagar Island; and rehabilitation of the marine aquarium at Digha; (b) environment and pollution management by completing the sewerage system for Digha to prevent flow of sewage onto the sandy beach; cleaning and environmental improvement of the Digha beach, and solid waste management in Digha; improvement of the fish auction centre at Digha; and distribution of grid electricity on Sagar Island to replace diesel generation and prevent soil and water pollution; and (c) livelihood security of coastal communities in Sagar Island including support to CBO coordinated livelihood improvement activities; afforestation-based livelihood improvement; promotion of local small-scale tourism and ecotourism activities; and provision of cyclone shelters in the coastal villages."
Adaptations.contact_person: Mr Tapas Paul, World Bank Senior Environment Specialist and Project team leader
Adaptations.contact_adress: The World Bank, 69-70, Lodi Estate, New Delhi-110003
Adaptations.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment and Forest, GOI, national and state project management units (PMUs)
Adaptations.success_factors: political will, research and studies to establish the hazard parameters, allocation of resources
Adaptations.limiting_factors: weak institutional structure to implement ICZM, lack of end users of knowledge and capacity building services
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: yes (Carbon finance opportunities will be explored to enhance financial attractiveness of interventions such as improved sewerage systems and the mangrove plantations. )
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win win (Irrespective of climate change it is important to have an ICZM structure in place because of India’s long coastline)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: It is a fairly recent project, and according to pre-calculations, the state level pilot investments are likely to directly benefit 1.1 million people, while the state and national capacity building activities will benefit 7.65 million people directly, and 35 million people indirectly in the medium term, and eventually all 63 million people living in the low elevation coastal areas in India.
Adaptations.comments: "The description for the project has been given specifically for the state of West Bengal.""The initial set of three states have been selected on various grounds including pressure on coast, presence of critical ecosystems, risks of natural hazards, etc. The Asian Development Bank is supporting a less comprehensive shoreline management project in Karnataka, Maharashtra and Goa. It is envisaged that the second phase of the ICZM would take up the other coastal states with project preparation in all remaining coastal states commencing immediately."" "

Adaptations.title: Vulnerability Assessment and Adaptation to Climate Change-Agriculture Sector
Adaptations.description: "The focus of the project is primarily on agriculture sector, accounting for a large part of the income generated in the state. A vulnerability assessment will be carried out for the community in terms of important agricultural crops produced in the state. The findings will be used to develop adaptation strategies in consultation with the different stakeholders and a cost-benefit analysis of a climate change adaptation plan will be prepared for the state. The project outcomes will be the identification of agro-climatic zone specific impacts for two main crops, wheat and soyabean; the impact of climate change on production of the two crops, profile of categories of people based on their adaptive capacity; various factors that are likely to impact these categories and to what degree; draft policy goal for adaptation in agriculture sector, assessment of adaptation options and prioritising the options along with their time lines."
Adaptations.contact_adress: B-32, TARA Crescent, Qutub Institutional Area, New Delhi-110015, India
Adaptations.executing_agent: Environment Protection and Coordination Organisation (EPCO), Bhopal, Stockholm Environment Institute (Oxford Centre), Development Alternatives
Adaptations.funding_source: Ministry of Environment and Forests, Department of Energy and Climate Change (United Kingdom)
Adaptations.success_factors: accurate and reliable vulnerability assessment, detailed assessment so that the adaptation strategies can be formulated for specific regions with a greater chance of success, effective implementation of the adaptation strategies
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: win-win (the project helps address the impacts of climate change on agriculture sector which then impacts the livelihood of the community (social welfare- food, income, employment security))
Adaptations.comments: The approach being followed for this project is (i) State level research, (ii) Extensive stakeholder engagement, (iii) Action Research Framework, and (iv) Focus on Solutions: their identification, scalability and replication

Adaptations.query: Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, India
Adaptations.title: Artificial Recharge to Ground Water through dugwells
Adaptations.description: The Central Ground Water Board (CGWB), under the Ministry of Water Resources, had implemented a study on Ground Water in the IX plan in which recharge structures were constructed in areas where water scarcity existed. The performance evaluation studies indicated increased availability of ground water especially in lean months. In the X plan a rain water harvesting and artifial recharge to ground water was taken up in over-exploied blocks of four states. In the XI plan, the scheme of Artificial Recharge to Groundwater through dugwells has been taken up under the mandate of the Overall Master Plan for Artificial Recharge to Groundwater, prepared in 2002 by the Central Ground Water Board. This scheme promotes ground water recharge by promoting and financing the construction of dug well recharge structures for the 4.455 million existinging irrigation wells. This includes a filter pit for simple filteration of rainwater that is then diverted into existing wells for groundwater recharge.This scheme is implemented in 1180 blocks of seven states namely, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Gujarat & Madhya Pradesh at an estimated cost of Rs. 1798.71 crores given by the Ministry of Finance through NABARD. The scheme provides 100% subsidy to marginal and small farmers and 50% subsidy to other farmers. An increase in ground water recharge will improve agricultural production (irrigation) and drinking water supply, enhance drought mitigation and benefit economic development. It will also mitigate ground water quality problems such as that of floride.
Adaptations.contact_adress: CENTRAL GROUND WATER BOARD, NH-IV, Bhujal Bhawan, Faridabad - 121001
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Central Ground Water Board(CGWB), NABARD, Ministry of Water Resources
Adaptations.executing_agent: NABARD. State Government, Panchayati Raj Institutions, CGWB, NGOs
Adaptations.success_factors: financial (A huge cost is incurred in installing these structures and is a pre-requisite for the scheme to be successful), Quality of construction and maintenance, and monitoring
Adaptations.limiting_factors: Limited monitoring
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: "win-win (environmental benefits: improved water quality, recharge of ground water; socio-economic benefits: improved water availability for domestic and agricultural purposes.)"
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Earlier performance evaluation studies in the IX plan show increased availability of ground water especially in lean months.

Adaptations.query: Dhar and Jhabhua, Madhya Pradesh, India
Adaptations.title: Strengthening Participatory Irrigation Management
Adaptations.description: Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) is useful in improving irrigation management along with sustainability of the system. Such a project sets up institutions such as Water User Associations (WUA) at the village level to effectively manage distribution of irrigation water, collect water user fee at the micro level and thus helps in increasing the area under effective irrigation and makes the system sustainable and equitable. A pilot project has been undertaken in two drought prone areas, Maan in district Dhar and Jobat in district Jhabua in western Madhya Pradesh through convergence of funds from different agencies to provide micro channel irrigation, awareness, capacity building and training of WUAs and exposure visits have been conducted.The PIM projects in these two areas seeks to converge financial resources from agencies such as Narmada Valley Development Authority, Madhya Pradesh Rural Livelihood Project and National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme to support micro channel irrigation in individual farms to increase efficiency and utilisation of water by strengthening WUAs through exposure visits, capacity building and training.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Madhya Pradesh Rural Livelihood Project, Beez Bhawan Arera Hill Bhopal MP
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Govt. of MP: Narmada Valley Development Authority(NVDA)
Adaptations.executing_agent: NVDA, MPRLP
Adaptations.success_factors: capacity building of the community, repair and maintenance, technical support
Adaptations.limiting_factors: lack of insitutional support, non availability of funds for technical support
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: no regret (capacity building for accessing water for irrigation and repair and maintenance especially during dry years)
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation:
"There are a total of 16 WUA’s in Man & Jobat ( 10 in Man & 6 in Jobat). Rules for water sharing & distribution are common across different regions for participatory irrigation management, for the first three years it is free of cost & then the user group members have to pay a user fee. In this area, an NGO Development Suppor Center is already working for strengthening the repayment system as a reult of which they are able to recover the water charges. At present the WUA charges Rs.200 to 250 per bigha per year for irrigation which is deposited in the WUA accounts. The Chief Minister of Madhya Pradesh has awarded this project for excellent irrigation work. The tail end users are also a part of the decision making committee are benefitted. The total area in Man & Jobat is 25000 ha, 15000 ha in Man &10000 ha in Jobat. Nearly 5000 ha of area was already irrigated from before this project. From 2008 onwards through continuous efforts under this projec, now nearly 18000 ha of area has been irrigated out of which 7500 ha is in Man (before project it was only 2000 ha area)&10500 ha in Jobat(before project it was only 3000 ha). Funds are converged through the NREGA scheme. Some of the instituion building, training and awareness genaration work undertaken in the project are:
1. Motivation and awareness activities in Maan and Jobat Projects: Project/ Village levels meetings 111, PRA 25
2. Exposure visit in Maan and Jobat project: 
WUA President & TC members in MP (Satak) No of programs: 2
3. WUA Membership Fee collection in Maan and Jobat project:No. of WUAs 13
Membership fee collected in Rs. 63770
4. Progress of NREGS assisted physical works:
No of Estimates 206, Funds released to the WUAs Rs 137.78 lakhs, Employment wages Rs 44.49 lakhs
5. Capacity building and strengthening of WUAs
Training 149, Project level Co-ordination 136 workshops."
Adaptations.comments: Strengthening Participatory Irrigation Management in western districts of Dhar and Jhabhua in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh under the Narmada Valley Development Authority (Best practices)

Adaptations.title: INCA - Adaptation and Mitigation Strategies of Andean People
Adaptations.description: Countries like Peru and Bolivia are bearing the consequences of climate change, such as extreme weather events, which are directly affecting crops, livestock, biodiversity, and, last but not least, increasing levels of poverty. Livelihood strategies of the Andean region are based on principles of risk management, contributing to the resilience of family livelihood development. Vulnerable mountain farmers are nowadays applying these ancient strategies in a combination of homegrown experimentation and scientific know-how to adapt to climate change. Understanding these adaptations has become one of the most important focuses of research into climate change impacts and vulnerability.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Pienner Str. 7, 01737 Tharandt, Germany
Adaptations.executing_agent: TU Dresden (Germany), UNALM (Peru), Instituto de Ecologia (Bolivia)
Adaptations.mitigation_synergies: Scientific exchange of adaptation and mitigation strategies on climate change among local users, scientific community, state authorities, NGOs, as well as other relevant stakeholders in the tropical Andean region by communicative networking, elaboration of extension packages for farmers, scientific qualification on B.Sc., M.Sc., doctoral and postdoctoral level
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: "The development of the INCA follows a long term strategy. Sustainable network management after the end of funding by DAAD will be assured by the following integrated activities: (1) Establishment of a cross-border education cooperation at master or doctoral level with the partner universities; (2) Use of the extensive alumni network as a basis for further external funding; (3) Creation of synergies with existing EU master and doctoral programs (SUTROFOR, FONASO); (4) Integration into other networks like UNEP/UNESCO course of the TU Dresden, Humboldt Foundation; (5) Initiation of R&D cooperation between GIZ and consultancies."
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The endogenously determined strategies, which are based on the experience of the farmers, are to be complemented by knowledge and experiences coming from outside farm-household systems and communities. In a collaborative way, this exogenous knowledge is to placed at the disposal of the local actors. Through this a participative network on climate change contributes to bridge the gap between the global discourse on climate change and local action. The necessary network approach leads to a far reaching involvement of the local actors.
Adaptations.comments: "International Network on Climate Change ""INCA"" - Understanding Adaptation and Mitigation Strategies of Tropical Andean People. "
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: Thank you very much for your interesting and informative contribution. I guess INCA is the abbreviation for International Network on Climate Change. But maybe you can write some words about that under “Additional Information”. If you have questions you can contact us directly by steffen.kriewald@pik-potsdam.de or tabea.lissner@pik-potsdam.de Anyway, this project will be accepted right now :) Thank you.

Adaptations.title: CLIMATE, WATER AND AGRICULTURE: IMPACTS AND ADAPTATION OF AGRO-ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS IN AFRICA
Adaptations.description: In many parts of Africa, agro-ecological systems are characterized by recurring drought events, soil degradation and water supply shortages. Presently, public infrastructure such as roads, long-term weather forecasts, and agricultural research and extension are inadequate to secure adequate adaptation. This project will assess quantitatively how climate affects current agricultural systems and will predict how these systems may be affected in the future by climate change under various global warming scenarios, and suggest what role adaptation could play. Therefore the project will implement a series of annual workshops over a three year period to provide country teams with tools necessary to conduct. Furthermore the project will culminate with an international conference aimed at high-level economists, scientists and policy makers from the region, to disseminate regional knowledge on the vulnerability of the agricultural sector to climate variability and climate.
Adaptations.contact_adress: The Centre for Environmental Economics and Policy in Africa (CEEPA) Rooms 3-34, 3rd Floor, Education & Law Building University of Pretoria, Pretoria 0002 , South Africa
Adaptations.source: "• www.ceepa.co.za • CEEPA Discussion Paper No. 8 Special Series on Climate Change and Agriculture in Africa ISBN 1-920160-01-09 ; Discussion Paper ISBN 1-920160-08-6, July 2006; http://www.ceepa.co.za/climate_change/index.html"
Adaptations.executing_agent: Centre for Environmental Economics and policy in Africa(CEEPA) – Univ of Pretoria
Adaptations.success_factors: • Adaptation options need to be suggested to the partners in water management, agriculture and municipal planning • Role players need to be informed about the project’s outcomes
Adaptations.limiting_factors: • The capacity of managers and farmers to respond is unknown. • The difficulty in communication technical climate information in a balanced and skilful way. • A further problem is that in the developing country context farms may face financial or informational constraints which serve to delay efficient adaptation.
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Yes, there is a significant capacity building component. Many public meetings and talks have been held and presented to raise awareness of climate change and the riskd facing the sectors in the study area
Adaptations.comments: The project aims to improve national and regional assessments of the economic impact of climate change on the agricultural sector of eleven African countries, and to determine the economic value of various adaptation options. The eleven Countries are: Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Egypt, Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Niger, Senegal, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Adaptations.title: MANAGING CLIMATE RISK FOR AGRICULTURE AND WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT IN SOUTH AFRICA
Adaptations.description: This project will address two significant problems related to adaptation to climate change in the water resources sector of African countries • The first is that relevant and important information from climate change forecasts is not being disseminated to water resource managers, nor is it being integrated into water resources policy, planning and management in a systematic way for agricultural and human use in Africa • The second, related problem is that there is currently a shortage of integrated approaches for evaluating and making adaptation decisions related to water resources in Africa. The project will make use of climate change hydrological model output to input into a socio-economic model to determine the value of water within each demand sector and suggest adaptation and management options for the future
Adaptations.contact_adress: Dept Env and Geog Science University of Cape Town
Adaptations.executing_agent: Consortium: Universities of Free State, Cape Town and Kwazulu-Natal, IRI (USA), UNEP-Risoe (Denmark)
Adaptations.success_factors: • Buy-in from water resource managers and agricultural and industrial sectors
Adaptations.limiting_factors: • Uncertainties in modeling outputs
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: Better awareness and mathematical modeling component of water use and value Collection of pertinent data regarding agricultural water usage
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: The project has already created awareness among stakeholders and is proceeding adequately
Adaptations.comments: no
Adaptations.reviewer_comment: The link seems to be incorrect. Please check www.bergriver.co.za The project is good. Thank you.

Adaptations.title: Advancing Capacity to support Climate Change Adaptation (ACCCA): five pilot projects
Adaptations.description: "This project seeks to reduce the vulnerability of poor populations in sub-Saharan Africa to climate change by mobilizing scientists and all the other actors concerned to inform political decision-making. It will do so by means of five pilot projects in rural and urban populations. The project will emphasize the generation, organization and communication of information on the risks resulting from climate change, climate variability and extreme climatic events, as well as preparation for their effects on food security (Cameroon, Ethiopia, Kenya) and water supply (South Africa, Burkina Faso). The lessons drawn from the five experiments can then be applied in larger scale projects. The ACCCA project is currently supporting 19 adaptation pilot actions in 17 countries across Africa and Asia. The pilot projects selected for funding under ACCCA each aim to achieve the following objectives: • Identify and prioritize climate risks to stakeholders and the climate influenced decisions that they face; • Assess available knowledge about risks and adaptation opportunities, as well as synthesize the knowledge in terms that are directly relevant to stakeholder concerns and decision-making needs; • Develop, test and disseminate risk communication materials that are designed to assist adaptation decisions; • Use the risk communication materials in stakeholder forums to develop recommendations for climate change adaptation and promote their adoption; and • Identify critical knowledge gaps that impede effective adaptation decisions and design assessment activities that would generate new knowledge to fill them. "
Adaptations.contact_adress: Manager, Climate Change Programme (CCP) United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR)
Adaptations.executing_agent: * UNITAR * ENDA-TM * SEI Oxford Office * CSAG-UCT* START * START SE ASIA * START Temperate East Asia
Adaptations.success_factors: • Understanding the local decision making context for climate risk management and the baseline status of climate-related knowledge is essential for determining information needs and tailoring communication strategies • Social learning between project implementers and stakeholders, based on early and active stakeholder engagement, such as through participatory development and testing of risk communication material, is key to producing information that is relevant to stakeholders and that can empower them to act.
Adaptations.limiting_factors: • Difficulties were encountered in relaying technical and scientific information in an easy-to-understand manner because of the complexities of the subject and the tendency for the nature of the scientific information to become transformed during translation. • Developing clear and relevant climate risk communication messages requires collating large and often complex sets of information and knowledge from diverse sources
Adaptations.no_regret_win_win: The need for appropriate communication of climate risks is particularly great in the developing world where vulnerability to climate change and variability is extensive and adaptation planning is lagging, stemming from poor understanding and awareness of the long-term impacts and implications of climate change on livelihoods and development, low institutional capacities to relay information, and lack of access to resources to support adaptation planning
Adaptations.outcome_evaluation: Through this process, teams within the pilot projects improved their capacity to integrate climate information and communicate risk to local communities and policy makers, while the climate change c=science and risk communication support teams gained familiarity of and appreciation for the complexities and challenges involved in promoting improved understanding of climate change science and the development of climate risk communication tools and methods to support robust decision making for adaptation
Adaptations.comments: no

Adaptations.title: Sub-Saharan African Cities: A Five-City Network to Pioneer Climate Adaptation through Participatory Research and Local Action
Adaptations.description: "This project aims to address the knowledge, resource, capacity and networking gaps of five Southern African cities by strengthening their ability to plan for, and adapt to, the impacts associated with climate change. General objective The overarching objectives of this project are: - To develop 5 tailor-made adaptation frameworks for managing the increased risk to African local government and their communities due to climate change impact. - To establish a standardised approach for the collection and analyses of climatic base-line data which will assist future localised projections to assist in planning and decision making procedures. Location: The five urban centres chosen for this project are Cape Town, South Africa, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania; Maputo, Mozambique; Walvis Bay, Namibia; and Port St. Louis, Mauritius. "
Adaptations.contact_adress: ICLEI Africa Secretariat - HEAD OFFICE 8th Floor, 44 Wale Street, Cape Town, 8001, South Africa
Adaptations.executing_agent: "executing agent: ICLEI. For three of the project cities namely; Walvis Bay, Namibia; Maputo, Mozambique and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania ICLEI will be working closely with UNHabitat"

Adaptations.title: BaltCICA: Impacts, Costs and Adaptation in the Baltic Sea Region, Kaloundborg
Adaptations.description: The BaltCICA Project is designed to focus on the most imminent problems that climate change is likely to cause in the Baltic Sea Region. The concentration of large parts of the population and many larger cities in coastal areas make the region especially sensitive to climate change. Changes in precipitation and flood patterns as well as rising sea level can affect not only the built environment but also water availability and quality.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Pappelallee 20, 14469 Potsdam
Adaptations.executing_agent: Geological Survey of Finland (GTK)

Adaptations.description: The BaltCICA Project is designed to focus on the most imminent problems that climate change is likely to cause in the Baltic Sea Region. The concentration of large parts of the population and many larger cities in coastal areas make the region especially sensitive to climate change. Changes in precipitation and flood patterns as well as rising sea level can affect not only the built environment but also water availability and quality.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Pappelallee 20, 14469 Potsdam
Adaptations.executing_agent: Geological Survey of Finland (GTK)

Adaptations.title: Climate and Energy in a complex Transition Process towards Sustainable Hyderabad
Adaptations.description: Hyderabad is an emerging megacity in Southern India. Rapid increase of population and fast economic growth cause expanding energy and resource consumption and constantly increasing greenhouse gas emissions. Climate change will lead to extreme weather events, disastrous floods, strong heat waves, extreme droughts and increasing water scarcity. One third of the population is living below poverty line and suffers from severe food and health problems. In this particular environment, responding to the anticipated climate change impact requires exploring greenhouse gas mitigation and adaptation strategies and ways towards increased energy efficiency and renewable energy. The core hypothesis of the Project is that “getting the institutions right” is one main key to solve the problems of sustainable resource use and to achieve a sustainable development of the Hyderabad region.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Pappelallee 20, 14469 Potsdam
Adaptations.executing_agent: Humboldt University Berlin

Adaptations.title: At Waters Edge: Coastal Resilience in Grenada and St. Vincent and the Grenadines
Adaptations.description: The At Waters Edge (AWE) project aims to demonstrate that small island states governments and communities can enhance their resilience to climate change by protecting, restoring and effectively managing their marine and coastal ecosystems and by strengthening local capacity for adaptation. In this context, adaptation is the process of adjusting to actual and expected climatic changes, like sea level rise and storm surge, while curbing impacts on human wellbeing.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Kingston, Jamaica
Adaptations.executing_agent: The Nature Conservancy

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Desaraju Palli: Water treatment and pond renovation
Adaptations.description: Drinking water improvement is the first preferred intervention for Dasaraju Palli, as pointed out during community meetings in 2011. AdaptCap will contribute to a low carbon climate resilient development by installing a water filtration plant near the village overhead tank to the existing pond. The water from both these sources is treated by gravity filters. The filtered water will be pumped by a solar pump into the two existing ground-level distribution tanks.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Academy of Gandhian Studies (AGS)
Adaptations.annotations: "{""custom_impact"":""Increased salinity of agricultural lands"",""custom_stimulus"":""Extreme weather events (e.g. cyclones)""}"

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Ramudupalli Palem and Sri Ramapurami: Cyclone Resistant Causeway and Fishing Equipment Shed
Adaptations.description: Ramudupalli Palem and Sri Ramapuram are suffering the same impacts of cyclones and flooding, and so have jointly prioritized and agreed to share two interventions as neighbours. First, the communities prioritize a causeway bridge as access to the coast from the village without walking through the Buckingham Canal. Second, a concrete reinforced shed along the road from the village to the beach will provide a climate-proof storage of motors, nets and other fishing equipment.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Academy of Gandhian Studies (AGS)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Perumalpettai: Coastal Bund Construction
Adaptations.description: Because the original Perumalpettai as well as the re-built village are used by the local population and both are prone to storm surges and flooding, a bund for both locations will be created just behind the dunes in a length of 700m until it connects with the existing bund. It will have a height of 4 meters and deposit on the sides to a width of 6 meters – planted with undergrowth on the slopes to prevent erosion. For realization, soil will be transported from a site 400 meters away.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Vengamukka Palem: Solar Power Backup for Reverse Osmosis Plant
Adaptations.description: To address the problem of drinking water supply in Vengamukka Palem the AdaptCap project will provide solar power to the existing reverse osmosis plant to secure water desalination ― not only during times of power cuts. The reverse osmosis system needs 3KW power which can be supplied by the 4kWp solar system. The system will have a 20kWh backup system which is sufficient to run the reverse osmosis plant for 6 to 7 hours per day. The backup can be fully charged by solar on sunny days. Trainings will be provided for the community as well as for local NGO representatives to maintain the solar system.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Academy of Gandhian Studies (AGS)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Kadapakkam: Pond Renovation, Bund and Shutter Construction
Adaptations.description: In Kadapakkam, strong storm surges and salt water infiltration have contaminated the main pond on the southwest side of the village. Village leaders have proposed to deepen the pond which currently has a depth of 3m by 1.5m. AdaptCap is funding the pond project. The pond will reach a sand bed and absorb more water during the rainy season, improving well water quality. The villagers also decided that they would construct a bund around the pond and two shutters to protect from backwater floods and control the inlet of fresh water from the catchment area. Moreover, plants will be lined around the bund to prevent erosion. The NGO will work with the rural water department leadership to build and maintain the bund.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Kaduvetti: Road Side Channel Bund Construction
Adaptations.description: Most of the homes in Kaduvetti as well as the main road are located alongside a canal. In the rainy season, the canal overflows, flooding homes and crops with brackish water, harming health and livelihoods. Village leaders call for a bund approximately 1km long on the backwater shore to protect their fields from floods and salt water intrusion. The height of the existing bund will be increased to 1.3 meters and the width to 3 meters. Moreover, planting works will be carried out to prevent erosion of the bund. The road gradient will also be re-established.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Govupeta: Individual Latrines and Smokeless Chulas
Adaptations.description: Health risks associated with deficient sanitation and soil erosion are two problems aggravated by climate change. Installing dual pit individual latrines and cleaner burning cooking stoves in the community of Govupetta can contribute to climate resilient development of the village. AdaptCap will install dual pit individual latrines. The pilot project will be able to provide 80 toilets with 45% community cost share. Approximately 12 people are likely to share a latrine on average (2 families). The sanitation intervention will be done in tandem with a clean chulas project: The smokeless chulas (cooking stoves) will be distributed to around 80 families who are currently using the inefficient traditional concrete or mud stoves. Both, the latrine and chulas program will encompass education materials, posters, demonstrations.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Academy of Gandhian Studies (AGS)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Chepala Dibbada Palem and Chukkavani Palem: Water filtration and distribution Repair
Adaptations.description: Due to changing climate the stress on fresh water quality and availability for residents of Chepala Dibbada Palem and Chukkavani Palem is increasing. During summer seasons, the temple wells now dry up or go saline and villagers face drinking water shortages. AdaptCap is addressing this with pollution control and pretreatment through improved filter media along with bacteria eradicating chlorination. The distribution piping scheme is checked and replaced where necessary.Moreover, three 2000 litre Syntex water tanks and 6 single tap public fountains will be installed.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Academy of Gandhian Studies (AGS)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Motumula: Tank Renovation and Rainwater Catchment
Adaptations.description: During the last years the output from agriculture was reduced in Motumula due to drought, shorter, unseasonable, and more intense rainfall causing for example flash floods. To stop wasting rainwater that runs through a drainage canal in Motumula’s agriculture fields during the monsoon period, farming leaders would like to dig a pond in the irrigation canal, which is 150-200 meters away from the large irrigation tank built by the state government for 14 villages in the area. From the pond, the water can be pumped to the 600 acre agricultural tank. The pond will fill during heavy rain, at which time pumps will lift the water into the agricultural bund area. The tank digging and check dam in the canal will create a water storage of many thousands of cubic meters of water.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Academy of Gandhian Studies (AGS)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Poovula Doruvu: Horticulture and Floriculture Sprinkler Systems
Adaptations.description: With changing rainfall patterns and temperature increase, climate change further increases the necessity for efficient irrigation of small horticulture and floriculture gardens in Poovula Doruvu. The Poovula Doruvu community agreed that a community sprinkler irrigation scheme was their first priority in the face of current and potential future water shortages. Such a scheme in Poovula Doruvu is estimated to help 130 families save water and energy in the 60 acres of village lands. The AdaptCap pilot project will ensure that groups of four families can share a sprinkler kit consisting of an electric pump, sprinkler sets, and enough hose for about an acre of land.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Academy of Gandhian Studies (AGS)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Pillai Colony: Drinking Water System Repair
Adaptations.description: Pillai Colony villagers discussed the pressing need to solve their freshwater water problems because it is the main challenge they are facing at the moment. Therefore, the AdaptCap project will renovate Pillai Colony’s piped water infrastructure. The project will assist the Panchayat with checking and repairing the existing water pipes, renovating the taps, tank base, and drainage system around the taps. However, training will be required for proper use of the renovated water system and proper maintenance to keep it from deteriorating again. Therefore, AdaptCap will facilitate workshops in order to build capacity on water management and maintenance.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Kumarakudi: Bund Strengthening and Shutter Construction
Adaptations.description: Storms, flooding and salination threaten the agricultural lands of Kumarakudi. Local NGOs worked closely with village leaders to identify that the preferred pilot project to be built would be a 1-2 kilometer long bund around the agricultural fields. The height of the bund will be increased to 3 meters and the width to 8 meters, leveled, planting undergrowth on the slopes to prevent erosion. A shutter will also be required where irrigation canals connect to the Manjal River in order to allow for field drainage during the monsoon season.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Nadupalayam: Backwater River Bund
Adaptations.description: Climate change brings about sea water infiltration and stronger storms, challenging the existing irrigation channels in Nadupalayam. Agriculture is the main source of income, therefore community leaders preferred a backwater bund as the most beneficial project for adaptation in the face of current challenges and climate projections. The bund height will be increased to 1.5 meters and the width to 3 meters, planting on the slopes to prevent erosion.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Thirumalai Nagar: Climate-Smart Lighting
Adaptations.description: Through clean and decentralized solar energy, unaffected by the frequent power outages in the village, Thirumalai Nagar’s schools, community temples, latrines, fishing equipment storage areas and other public places will receive solar lighting via the AdaptCap project. The project will address safety issues, especially for women using the latrine and to protect against vulnerability from grid power outages at night. The solar lighting in boat docking areas will help fishermen to work more safely even in times of power outages and thus adapt to more difficult circumstances for their livelihood brought on by climate change, in particular extreme weather events like storms. Self-sufficiently supplied by clean energy, the solar lighting will contribute to climate change mitigation as well as adaptation.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: AdaptCap - Chinnakaramedu: Rain Water Storage Facilities
Adaptations.description: The salinization of ground water and agricultural fields threatens Chinnakaramedus population. Due to higher temperatures and floods, agriculture is more and more at risk. Therefore, leaders of the farming community have asked for a pond to link with a fresh water drainage canal requiring renovation to join up with the flowing canal a few hundred meters north of the village. Farmers need the pond to collect rainwater from the existing ditches dug around the field and to be available to pump out for irrigation to cultivate paddy in clay soil and ground nut in sandy soil. The project will also encompass the construction of a bund around the pond to protect it from any saline floods and a fence to protect from other contamination.
Adaptations.contact_adress: Caspar-Theyß-Straße 14a, 14193 Berlin, GERMANY
Adaptations.initiating_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
Adaptations.executing_agent: Avvai Village Welfare Society (AVVAI)

Adaptations.title: "GIZ Regional Project ""Silva Mediterranea-CPMF"" : Adapting Forest Policy Framework Conditions to Climate Change in the MENA region"
Adaptations.description: "The GIZ regional project operates in the framework of the Collaborative Partnership on Mediterranean Forests (CPMF) and in support to the Silva Mediterranea committee on Mediterranean forestry issues. The overall objective of this project is to improve the framework conditions for the sustainable management of forest ecosystems in order to preserve the supply of goods and services in the face of climate change. The project concerns selected countries in the MENA region whose forest resources are significant : Algeria, Lebanon, Morocco, Syria, Tunisia and Turkey. The project is designed around four components: 1) Capacity building of the forest administrations in terms of climate change and enhancement of the value of goods and services provided by forests; 2) Inter-institutional relations with partner sectors to increase the appreciation and acknowledgement by these sectors for the goods and services provided by forests; 3) Communication, information and awareness raising of the general public, particularly as to the expected impacts of climate change and the socio-economic importance of the goods and services provided by forests; 4) Mobilization of external support and partnerships. "
Adaptations.annotations: "{""custom_impact"":""Forest pests and diseases increase"",""custom_sector"":""Partner sectors of the forest administrations""}"
